quoteText:
NOW, what I want is, Facts.  Teach these boys and girls nothing but
Facts.  Facts alone are wanted in life.  Plant nothing else, and root out
everything else.  You can only form the minds of reasoning animals upon
Facts: nothing else will ever be of any service to them.  This is the
principle on which I bring up my own children, and this is the principle
on which I bring up these children.  Stick to Facts, sir!
subQuotationList:
['NOW, what I want is, Facts.  Teach these boys and girls nothing but
Facts.  Facts alone are wanted in life.  Plant nothing else, and root out
everything else.  You can only form the minds of reasoning animals upon
Facts: nothing else will ever be of any service to them.  This is the
principle on which I bring up my own children, and this is the principle
on which I bring up these children.  Stick to Facts, sir!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: In this life, we want nothing but Facts, sir; nothing but Facts!
subQuotationList: ['In this life, we want nothing but Facts, sir; nothing but Facts!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: boys and girls,
subQuotationList: ['boys and girls,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: sir,
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Girl number twenty, I don't know that girl.  Who is that girl?
subQuotationList: ['Girl number twenty,', "I don't know that girl.  Who is that girl?"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Sissy Jupe, sir,
subQuotationList: ['Sissy Jupe, sir,']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Sissy is not a name, Don't call yourself Sissy.
Call yourself Cecilia.
subQuotationList: ['Sissy is not a name,', "Don't call yourself Sissy.\nCall yourself Cecilia."]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: It's father as calls me Sissy, sir,
subQuotationList: ["It's father as calls me Sissy, sir,"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Then he has no business to do it, Tell him he
mustn't.  Cecilia Jupe.  Let me see.  What is your father?
subQuotationList: ['Then he has no business to do it,', "Tell him he\nmustn't.  Cecilia Jupe.  Let me see.  What is your father?"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: He belongs to the horse-riding, if you please, sir.
subQuotationList: ['He belongs to the horse-riding, if you please, sir.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
We don't want to know anything about that, here.  You mustn't tell us
about that, here.  Your father breaks horses, don't he?
subQuotationList: ["We don't want to know anything about that, here.  You mustn't tell us\nabout that, here.  Your father breaks horses, don't he?"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
If you please, sir, when they can get any to break, they do break horses
in the ring, sir.
subQuotationList: ['If you please, sir, when they can get any to break, they do break horses\nin the ring, sir.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
You mustn't tell us about the ring, here.  Very well, then.  Describe
your father as a horsebreaker.  He doctors sick horses, I dare say?
subQuotationList: ["You mustn't tell us about the ring, here.  Very well, then.  Describe\nyour father as a horsebreaker.  He doctors sick horses, I dare say?"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Oh yes, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, sir.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Very well, then.  He is a veterinary surgeon, a farrier, and
horsebreaker.  Give me your definition of a horse.
subQuotationList: ['Very well, then.  He is a veterinary surgeon, a farrier, and\nhorsebreaker.  Give me your definition of a horse.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Girl number twenty unable to define a horse! Girl number twenty
possessed of no facts, in reference to one of the commonest of animals!
Some boy's definition of a horse.  Bitzer, yours.
subQuotationList: ['Girl number twenty unable to define a horse!', "Girl number twenty\npossessed of no facts, in reference to one of the commonest of animals!\nSome boy's definition of a horse.  Bitzer, yours."]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Bitzer, Your definition of a horse.
subQuotationList: ['Bitzer,', 'Your definition of a horse.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Quadruped.  Graminivorous.  Forty teeth, namely twenty-four grinders,
four eye-teeth, and twelve incisive.  Sheds coat in the spring; in marshy
countries, sheds hoofs, too.  Hoofs hard, but requiring to be shod with
iron.  Age known by marks in mouth.
subQuotationList:
['Quadruped.  Graminivorous.  Forty teeth, namely twenty-four grinders,
four eye-teeth, and twelve incisive.  Sheds coat in the spring; in marshy
countries, sheds hoofs, too.  Hoofs hard, but requiring to be shod with
iron.  Age known by marks in mouth.']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Now girl number twenty, You know what a horse
is.
subQuotationList: ['Now girl number twenty,', 'You know what a horse\nis.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Very well, That's a horse.  Now, let me ask you girls and boys, Would you paper a
room with representations of horses?
subQuotationList: ['Very well,', "That's a horse.  Now, let me ask you girls and boys, Would you paper a\nroom with representations of horses?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Yes, sir!
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir!']
speaker: _group
referringExpression: one half of the children cried in chorus

quoteText: No, sir!
subQuotationList: ['No, sir!']
speaker: _group
referringExpression: the other half seeing in the gentlemans face that Yes was wrong cried out in chorus

quoteText: Of course, No.  Why wouldn't you?
subQuotationList: ["Of course, No.  Why wouldn't you?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: You _must_ paper it,
subQuotationList: ['You _must_ paper it,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
You must paper it, whether you like it or not.
Don't tell _us_ you wouldn't paper it.  What do you mean, boy?
subQuotationList: ['You must paper it,', "whether you like it or not.\nDon't tell _us_ you wouldn't paper it.  What do you mean, boy?"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I'll explain to you, then, why you wouldn't paper a room with representations of
horses.  Do you ever see horses walking up and down the sides of rooms in
reality   in fact?  Do you? Of course no, Why, then, you are not to see anywhere, what you don't see in
fact; you are not to have anywhere, what you don't have in fact.  What is
called Taste, is only another name for Fact. This is a new principle, a discovery, a great discovery, Now, I'll try you again.  Suppose you were going to carpet a
room.  Would you use a carpet having a representation of flowers upon
it? Girl number twenty, So you would carpet your room   or your husband's room, if you were a
grown woman, and had a husband   with representations of flowers, would
you? Why would you?

quoteText: Yes, sir!
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir!']
speaker: _group

quoteText: No, sir!
subQuotationList: ['No, sir!']
speaker: _group

quoteText: If you please, sir, I am very fond of flowers,
subQuotationList: ['If you please, sir, I am very fond of flowers,']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
And is that why you would put tables and chairs upon them, and have
people walking over them with heavy boots?
subQuotationList: ['And is that why you would put tables and chairs upon them, and have\npeople walking over them with heavy boots?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
It wouldn't hurt them, sir.  They wouldn't crush and wither, if you
please, sir.  They would be the pictures of what was very pretty and
pleasant, and I would fancy
subQuotationList: ["It wouldn't hurt them, sir.  They wouldn't crush and wither, if you\nplease, sir.  They would be the pictures of what was very pretty and\npleasant, and I would fancy"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Ay, ay, ay!  But you mustn't fancy, That's it!  You are never to fancy.
subQuotationList: ["Ay, ay, ay!  But you mustn't fancy,", "That's it!  You are never to fancy."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
You are not, Cecilia Jupe, to do
anything of that kind.
subQuotationList: ['You are not, Cecilia Jupe,', 'to do\nanything of that kind.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Fact, fact, fact!
subQuotationList: ['Fact, fact, fact!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Fact, fact, fact!
subQuotationList: ['Fact, fact, fact!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
You are to be in all things regulated and governed, by fact.  We hope to have, before long, a board of fact, composed of
commissioners of fact, who will force the people to be a people of fact,
and of nothing but fact.  You must discard the word Fancy altogether.
You have nothing to do with it.  You are not to have, in any object of
use or ornament, what would be a contradiction in fact.  You don't walk
upon flowers in fact; you cannot be allowed to walk upon flowers in
carpets.  You don't find that foreign birds and butterflies come and
perch upon your crockery; you cannot be permitted to paint foreign birds
and butterflies upon your crockery.  You never meet with quadrupeds going
up and down walls; you must not have quadrupeds represented upon walls.
You must use, for all these purposes, combinations
and modifications (in primary colours) of mathematical figures which are
susceptible of proof and demonstration.  This is the new discovery.  This
is fact.  This is taste. Now, if Mr. M'Choakumchild, will proceed to give
his first lesson here, Mr. Gradgrind, I shall be happy, at your request,
to observe his mode of procedure.
subQuotationList:
['You are to be in all things regulated and governed,', "by fact.  We hope to have, before long, a board of fact, composed of
commissioners of fact, who will force the people to be a people of fact,
and of nothing but fact.  You must discard the word Fancy altogether.
You have nothing to do with it.  You are not to have, in any object of
use or ornament, what would be a contradiction in fact.  You don't walk
upon flowers in fact; you cannot be allowed to walk upon flowers in
carpets.  You don't find that foreign birds and butterflies come and
perch upon your crockery; you cannot be permitted to paint foreign birds
and butterflies upon your crockery.  You never meet with quadrupeds going
up and down walls; you must not have quadrupeds represented upon walls.
You must use,", 'for all these purposes, combinations
and modifications (in primary colours) of mathematical figures which are
susceptible of proof and demonstration.  This is the new discovery.  This
is fact.  This is taste.', "Now, if Mr. M'Choakumchild,", 'will proceed to give
his first lesson here, Mr. Gradgrind, I shall be happy, at your request,
to observe his mode of procedure.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

Mr. M'Choakumchild, we only wait for

subQuotationList: ['an eminently practical']

elucidate the diverting accomplishments of his highly trained performing

his astounding feat of throwing

enliven the varied performances at frequent

the highly novel and laughable

quoteText: Now, to think of these vagabonds, attracting the young rabble from a model school.
subQuotationList: ['Now, to think of these vagabonds,', 'attracting the young rabble from a model school.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Louisa!!  Thomas!!
subQuotationList: ['Louisa!!  Thomas!!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
referringExpression: Mr Gradgrind crossed to the spot where his family was thus disgraced laid his hand upon each erring child and said

quoteText: In the name of wonder, idleness, and folly! what do you do here?
subQuotationList: ['In the name of wonder, idleness, and folly!', 'what do you do here?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Wanted to see what it was like,
subQuotationList: ['Wanted to see what it was like,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: What it was like?
subQuotationList: ['What it was like?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Yes, father.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, father.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Thomas, though I have the fact before me, I find it difficult to believe
that you, with your education and resources, should have brought your
sister to a scene like this.
subQuotationList: ['Thomas, though I have the fact before me, I find it difficult to believe\nthat you, with your education and resources, should have brought your\nsister to a scene like this.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I brought _him_, father, I asked him to come.
subQuotationList: ['I brought _him_, father,', 'I asked him to come.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I am sorry to hear it.  I am very sorry indeed to hear it.  It makes
Thomas no better, and it makes you worse, Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['I am sorry to hear it.  I am very sorry indeed to hear it.  It makes\nThomas no better, and it makes you worse, Louisa.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
You!  Thomas and you, to whom the circle of the sciences is open; Thomas
and you, who may be said to be replete with facts; Thomas and you, who
have been trained to mathematical exactness; Thomas and you, here! In this degraded position!  I am amazed.
subQuotationList: ['You!  Thomas and you, to whom the circle of the sciences is open; Thomas\nand you, who may be said to be replete with facts; Thomas and you, who\nhave been trained to mathematical exactness; Thomas and you, here!', 'In this degraded position!  I am amazed.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby']], []]

quoteText: I was tired, father.  I have been tired a long time,
subQuotationList: ['I was tired, father.  I have been tired a long time,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Tired?  Of what?
subQuotationList: ['Tired?  Of what?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I don't know of what   of everything, I think.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know of what   of everything, I think."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Say not another word, You are childish.  I
will hear no more.
subQuotationList: ['Say not another word,', 'You are childish.  I\nwill hear no more.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
What would your
best friends say, Louisa?  Do you attach no value to their good opinion?
What would Mr. Bounderby say?
subQuotationList: ['What would your\nbest friends say, Louisa?  Do you attach no value to their good opinion?\nWhat would Mr. Bounderby say?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: What, would Mr. Bounderby say?
subQuotationList: ['What,', 'would Mr. Bounderby say?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: What would Mr. Bounderby say?
subQuotationList: ['What would Mr. Bounderby say?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I hadn't a shoe to my foot.  As to a stocking, I didn't know such a
thing by name.  I passed the day in a ditch, and the night in a pigsty.
That's the way I spent my tenth birthday.  Not that a ditch was new to
me, for I was born in a ditch.
subQuotationList:
["I hadn't a shoe to my foot.  As to a stocking, I didn't know such a
thing by name.  I passed the day in a ditch, and the night in a pigsty.
That's the way I spent my tenth birthday.  Not that a ditch was new to
me, for I was born in a ditch."]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText: No!  As wet as a sop.  A foot of water in it,
subQuotationList: ['No!  As wet as a sop.  A foot of water in it,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Enough to give a baby cold,
subQuotationList: ['Enough to give a baby cold,']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText:
Cold?  I was born with inflammation of the lungs, and of everything
else, I believe, that was capable of inflammation, For years, ma'am, I was one of the most miserable little
wretches ever seen.  I was so sickly, that I was always moaning and
groaning.  I was so ragged and dirty, that you wouldn't have touched me
with a pair of tongs.
subQuotationList:
['Cold?  I was born with inflammation of the lungs, and of everything
else, I believe, that was capable of inflammation,', "For years, ma'am, I was one of the most miserable little
wretches ever seen.  I was so sickly, that I was always moaning and
groaning.  I was so ragged and dirty, that you wouldn't have touched me
with a pair of tongs."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
How I fought through it, _I_ don't know, I was
determined, I suppose.  I have been a determined character in later life,
and I suppose I was then.  Here I am, Mrs. Gradgrind, anyhow, and nobody
to thank for my being here, but myself. _My_ mother?  Bolted, ma'am! My mother left me to my grandmother, and, according to
the best of my remembrance, my grandmother was the wickedest and the
worst old woman that ever lived.  If I got a little pair of shoes by any
chance, she would take 'em off and sell 'em for drink.  Why, I have known
that grandmother of mine lie in her bed and drink her four-teen glasses
of liquor before breakfast!
subQuotationList:
["How I fought through it, _I_ don't know,", 'I was
determined, I suppose.  I have been a determined character in later life,
and I suppose I was then.  Here I am, Mrs. Gradgrind, anyhow, and nobody
to thank for my being here, but myself.', "_My_ mother?  Bolted, ma'am!", 'My mother left me to my grandmother,', "and, according to
the best of my remembrance, my grandmother was the wickedest and the
worst old woman that ever lived.  If I got a little pair of shoes by any
chance, she would take 'em off and sell 'em for drink.  Why, I have known
that grandmother of mine lie in her bed and drink her four-teen glasses
of liquor before breakfast!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
She kept a chandler's shop, and kept me in an
egg-box.  That was the cot of _my_ infancy; an old egg-box.  As soon as I
was big enough to run away, of course I ran away.  Then I became a young
vagabond; and instead of one old woman knocking me about and starving me,
everybody of all ages knocked me about and starved me.  They were right;
they had no business to do anything else.  I was a nuisance, an
incumbrance, and a pest.  I know that very well.
subQuotationList:
["She kept a chandler's shop,", 'and kept me in an
egg-box.  That was the cot of _my_ infancy; an old egg-box.  As soon as I
was big enough to run away, of course I ran away.  Then I became a young
vagabond; and instead of one old woman knocking me about and starving me,
everybody of all ages knocked me about and starved me.  They were right;
they had no business to do anything else.  I was a nuisance, an
incumbrance, and a pest.  I know that very well.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I was to pull through it, I suppose, Mrs. Gradgrind.  Whether I was to
do it or not, ma'am, I did it.  I pulled through it, though nobody threw
me out a rope.  Vagabond, errand-boy, vagabond, labourer, porter, clerk,
chief manager, small partner, Josiah Bounderby of Coketown.  Those are
the antecedents, and the culmination.  Josiah Bounderby of Coketown
learnt his letters from the outsides of the shops, Mrs. Gradgrind, and
was first able to tell the time upon a dial-plate, from studying the
steeple clock of St. Giles's Church, London, under the direction of a
drunken cripple, who was a convicted thief, and an incorrigible vagrant.
Tell Josiah Bounderby of Coketown, of your district schools and your
model schools, and your training schools, and your whole kettle-of-fish
of schools; and Josiah Bounderby of Coketown, tells you plainly, all
right, all correct   he hadn't such advantages   but let us have hard-headed,
solid-fisted people   the education that made him won't do for everybody,
he knows well   such and such his education was, however, and you may force
him to swallow boiling fat, but you shall never force him to suppress the
facts of his life.
subQuotationList:
["I was to pull through it, I suppose, Mrs. Gradgrind.  Whether I was to
do it or not, ma'am, I did it.  I pulled through it, though nobody threw
me out a rope.  Vagabond, errand-boy, vagabond, labourer, porter, clerk,
chief manager, small partner, Josiah Bounderby of Coketown.  Those are
the antecedents, and the culmination.  Josiah Bounderby of Coketown
learnt his letters from the outsides of the shops, Mrs. Gradgrind, and
was first able to tell the time upon a dial-plate, from studying the
steeple clock of St. Giles's Church, London, under the direction of a
drunken cripple, who was a convicted thief, and an incorrigible vagrant.
Tell Josiah Bounderby of Coketown, of your district schools and your
model schools, and your training schools, and your whole kettle-of-fish
of schools; and Josiah Bounderby of Coketown, tells you plainly, all
right, all correct   he hadn't such advantages   but let us have hard-headed,
solid-fisted people   the education that made him won't do for everybody,
he knows well   such and such his education was, however, and you may force
him to swallow boiling fat, but you shall never force him to suppress the
facts of his life."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Well! what's the matter?  What is young
Thomas in the dumps about?
subQuotationList: ['Well!', "what's the matter?  What is young\nThomas in the dumps about?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: We were peeping at the circus, and father caught us.
subQuotationList: ['We were peeping at the circus,', 'and father caught us.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
And, Mrs. Gradgrind, I should as
soon have expected to find my children reading poetry.
subQuotationList: ['And, Mrs. Gradgrind,', 'I should as\nsoon have expected to find my children reading poetry.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Dear me, How can you, Louisa and Thomas!  I
wonder at you.  I declare you're enough to make one regret ever having
had a family at all.  I have a great mind to say I wish I hadn't.  _Then_
what would you have done, I should like to know?
subQuotationList:
['Dear me,', "How can you, Louisa and Thomas!  I
wonder at you.  I declare you're enough to make one regret ever having
had a family at all.  I have a great mind to say I wish I hadn't.  _Then_
what would you have done, I should like to know?"]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
As if, with my head in its present throbbing state, you couldn't go and
look at the shells and minerals and things provided for you, instead of
circuses! You know, as well as I do, no young
people have circus masters, or keep circuses in cabinets, or attend
lectures about circuses.  What can you possibly want to know of circuses
then?  I am sure you have enough to do, if that's what you want.  With my
head in its present state, I couldn't remember the mere names of half the
facts you have got to attend to.
subQuotationList:
["As if, with my head in its present throbbing state, you couldn't go and
look at the shells and minerals and things provided for you, instead of
circuses!", "You know, as well as I do, no young
people have circus masters, or keep circuses in cabinets, or attend
lectures about circuses.  What can you possibly want to know of circuses
then?  I am sure you have enough to do, if that's what you want.  With my
head in its present state, I couldn't remember the mere names of half the
facts you have got to attend to."]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby']], [['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: That's the reason!
subQuotationList: ["That's the reason!"]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Don't tell me that's the reason, because it can't be nothing of the
sort, Go and be somethingological directly.
subQuotationList: ["Don't tell me that's the reason, because it can't be nothing of the\nsort,", 'Go and be somethingological directly.']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText:
Bounderby, you
are always so interested in my young people   particularly in Louisa   that I
make no apology for saying to you, I am very much vexed by this
discovery.  I have systematically devoted myself (as you know) to the
education of the reason of my family.  The reason is (as you know) the
only faculty to which education should be addressed. And yet,
Bounderby, it would appear from this unexpected circumstance of to-day,
though in itself a trifling one, as if something had crept into Thomas's
and Louisa's minds which is   or rather, which is not   I don't know that I
can express myself better than by saying   which has never been intended to
be developed, and in which their reason has no part.
subQuotationList:
['Bounderby,', 'you
are always so interested in my young people   particularly in Louisa   that I
make no apology for saying to you, I am very much vexed by this
discovery.  I have systematically devoted myself (as you know) to the
education of the reason of my family.  The reason is (as you know) the
only faculty to which education should be addressed.', "And yet,

can express myself better than by saying   which has never been intended to

speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']], []]

quoteText:
There certainly is no reason in looking with interest at a parcel of
vagabonds, When I was a vagabond myself, nobody
looked with any interest at _me_; I know that.
subQuotationList: ['There certainly is no reason in looking with interest at a parcel of\nvagabonds,', 'When I was a vagabond myself, nobody\nlooked with any interest at _me_; I know that.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Then comes the question; with his
eyes on the fire, "in what has this vulgar curiosity its rise?
subQuotationList: ['Then comes the question;', 'with his\neyes on the fire, "in what has this vulgar curiosity its rise?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I'll tell you in what.  In idle imagination.
subQuotationList: ["I'll tell you in what.  In idle imagination."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I hope not, I confess, however, that the
misgiving _has_ crossed me on my way home.
subQuotationList: ['I hope not,', 'I confess, however, that the\nmisgiving _has_ crossed me on my way home.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
In idle imagination, Gradgrind, A very bad thing
for anybody, but a cursed bad thing for a girl like Louisa.  I should ask
Mrs. Gradgrind's pardon for strong expressions, but that she knows very
well I am not a refined character.  Whoever expects refinement in _me_
will be disappointed.  I hadn't a refined bringing up.
subQuotationList:
['In idle imagination, Gradgrind,', "A very bad thing
for anybody, but a cursed bad thing for a girl like Louisa.  I should ask
Mrs. Gradgrind's pardon for strong expressions, but that she knows very
well I am not a refined character.  Whoever expects refinement in _me_
will be disappointed.  I hadn't a refined bringing up."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Whether, whether any instructor or servant can
have suggested anything?  Whether Louisa or Thomas can have been reading
anything?  Whether, in spite of all precautions, any idle story-book can
have got into the house?  Because, in minds that have been practically
formed by rule and line, from the cradle upwards, this is so curious, so
incomprehensible.
subQuotationList:
['Whether,', 'whether any instructor or servant can
have suggested anything?  Whether Louisa or Thomas can have been reading
anything?  Whether, in spite of all precautions, any idle story-book can
have got into the house?  Because, in minds that have been practically
formed by rule and line, from the cradle upwards, this is so curious, so
incomprehensible.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Stop a bit! You have one of those strollers' children in the
school.
subQuotationList: ['Stop a bit!', "You have one of those strollers' children in the\nschool."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Cecilia Jupe, by name,
subQuotationList: ['Cecilia Jupe, by name,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Now, stop a bit! How did she come there?
subQuotationList: ['Now, stop a bit!', 'How did she come there?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Why, the fact is, I saw the girl myself, for the first time, only just
now.  She specially applied here at the house to be admitted, as not
regularly belonging to our town, and   yes, you are right, Bounderby, you
are right.
subQuotationList:
['Why, the fact is, I saw the girl myself, for the first time, only just
now.  She specially applied here at the house to be admitted, as not
regularly belonging to our town, and   yes, you are right, Bounderby, you
are right.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Now, stop a bit! Louisa saw her when she
came?
subQuotationList: ['Now, stop a bit!', 'Louisa saw her when she\ncame?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Louisa certainly did see her, for she mentioned the application to me.
But Louisa saw her, I have no doubt, in Mrs. Gradgrind's presence.
subQuotationList: ["Louisa certainly did see her, for she mentioned the application to me.\nBut Louisa saw her, I have no doubt, in Mrs. Gradgrind's presence."]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Pray, Mrs. Gradgrind, what passed?
subQuotationList: ['Pray, Mrs. Gradgrind,', 'what passed?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh, my poor health! The girl wanted to come
to the school, and Mr. Gradgrind wanted girls to come to the school, and
Louisa and Thomas both said that the girl wanted to come, and that Mr.
Gradgrind wanted girls to come, and how was it possible to contradict
them when such was the fact!
subQuotationList:
['Oh, my poor health!', 'The girl wanted to come
to the school, and Mr. Gradgrind wanted girls to come to the school, and
Louisa and Thomas both said that the girl wanted to come, and that Mr.
Gradgrind wanted girls to come, and how was it possible to contradict
them when such was the fact!']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText:
Now I tell you what, Gradgrind! Turn this girl to
the right about, and there's an end of it.
subQuotationList: ['Now I tell you what, Gradgrind!', "Turn this girl to\nthe right about, and there's an end of it."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: I am much of your opinion.
subQuotationList: ['I am much of your opinion.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Do it at once, has always been my motto from a child.
When I thought I would run away from my egg-box and my grandmother, I did
it at once.  Do you the same.  Do this at once!
subQuotationList: ['Do it at once,', 'has always been my motto from a child.\nWhen I thought I would run away from my egg-box and my grandmother, I did\nit at once.  Do you the same.  Do this at once!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Are you walking? I have the father's address.
Perhaps you would not mind walking to town with me?
subQuotationList: ['Are you walking?', "I have the father's address.\nPerhaps you would not mind walking to town with me?"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Not the least in the world, as long as you do it
at once!
subQuotationList: ['Not the least in the world,', 'as long as you do it\nat once!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I never wear gloves, I didn't climb up the ladder in _them_.   Shouldn't be so high up,
if I had.
subQuotationList: ['I never wear gloves,', "I didn't climb up the ladder in _them_.   Shouldn't be so high up,\nif I had."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
referringExpression: it was his custom to say

quoteText:
It's all right now, Louisa: it's all right, young Thomas, you won't do so any more.  I'll answer for it's being all
over with father.  Well, Louisa, that's worth a kiss, isn't it?
subQuotationList: ["It's all right now, Louisa: it's all right, young Thomas,", "you won't do so any more.  I'll answer for it's being all\nover with father.  Well, Louisa, that's worth a kiss, isn't it?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: You can take one, Mr. Bounderby,
subQuotationList: ['You can take one, Mr. Bounderby,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Always my pet; ain't you, Louisa? Good-bye,
Louisa!
subQuotationList: ["Always my pet; ain't you, Louisa?", 'Good-bye,\nLouisa!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
What are you about, Loo? You'll rub
a hole in your face.
subQuotationList: ['What are you about, Loo?', "You'll rub\na hole in your face."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
You may cut the piece out with your penknife if you like, Tom.  I
wouldn't cry!
subQuotationList: ["You may cut the piece out with your penknife if you like, Tom.  I\nwouldn't cry!"]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: This man lives at Pod's End, and I don't quite know Pod's End, Which is it, Bounderby?
subQuotationList: ["This man lives at Pod's End, and I don't quite know Pod's End,", 'Which is it, Bounderby?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Halloa! Stop!  Where are you going! Stop!
subQuotationList: ['Halloa!', 'Stop!  Where are you going! Stop!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Why are you tearing about the streets, in this
improper manner?
subQuotationList: ['Why are you tearing about the streets,', 'in this\nimproper manner?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I was   I was run after, sir, and I wanted to get
away.
subQuotationList: ['I was   I was run after, sir,', 'and I wanted to get\naway.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Run after? Who would run after _you_?
subQuotationList: ['Run after?', 'Who would run after _you_?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
What do you mean, boy? What are you doing?  How
dare you dash against   everybody   in this manner?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean, boy?', 'What are you doing?  How\ndare you dash against   everybody   in this manner?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Was this boy running after you, Jupe?
subQuotationList: ['Was this boy running after you, Jupe?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Yes, sir,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir,']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
No, I wasn't, sir! Not till she run away from me.  But
the horse-riders never mind what they say, sir; they're famous for it.
You know the horse-riders are famous for never minding what they say, It's as well known in the town as   please, sir, as the
multiplication table isn't known to the horse-riders.
subQuotationList:
["No, I wasn't, sir!", "Not till she run away from me.  But
the horse-riders never mind what they say, sir; they're famous for it.
You know the horse-riders are famous for never minding what they say,", "It's as well known in the town as   please, sir, as the
multiplication table isn't known to the horse-riders."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: He frightened me so, with his cruel faces!
subQuotationList: ['He frightened me so,', 'with his cruel faces!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Oh! Oh!  An't you one of the rest!  An't you a
horse-rider!  I never looked at her, sir.  I asked her if she would know
how to define a horse to-morrow, and offered to tell her again, and she
ran away, and I ran after her, sir, that she might know how to answer
when she was asked.  You wouldn't have thought of saying such mischief if
you hadn't been a horse-rider?
subQuotationList:
['Oh!', "Oh!  An't you one of the rest!  An't you a
horse-rider!  I never looked at her, sir.  I asked her if she would know
how to define a horse to-morrow, and offered to tell her again, and she
ran away, and I ran after her, sir, that she might know how to answer
when she was asked.  You wouldn't have thought of saying such mischief if
you hadn't been a horse-rider?"]
speaker: Bitzer
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
Her calling seems to be pretty well known among 'em, You'd have had the whole school peeping in a row, in a
week.
subQuotationList: ["Her calling seems to be pretty well known among 'em,", "You'd have had the whole school peeping in a row, in a\nweek."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Truly, I think so, Bitzer, turn you about and
take yourself home. Jupe, stay here a moment.  Let me hear of your
running in this manner any more, boy, and you will hear of me through the
master of the school.  You understand what I mean.  Go along.
subQuotationList:
['Truly, I think so,', 'Bitzer, turn you about and
take yourself home. Jupe, stay here a moment.  Let me hear of your
running in this manner any more, boy, and you will hear of me through the
master of the school.  You understand what I mean.  Go along.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Now, girl, take this gentleman and me to your
father's; we are going there.  What have you got in that bottle you are
carrying?
subQuotationList: ['Now, girl,', "take this gentleman and me to your\nfather's; we are going there.  What have you got in that bottle you are\ncarrying?"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe']], [['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText: Gin,
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Dear, no, sir!  It's the nine oils.
subQuotationList: ["Dear, no, sir!  It's the nine oils."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: The what?
subQuotationList: ['The what?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: The nine oils, sir, to rub father with.
subQuotationList: ['The nine oils, sir, to rub father with.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Then, what the devil do
you rub your father with nine oils for?
subQuotationList: ['Then,', 'what the devil do\nyou rub your father with nine oils for?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
It's what our people aways use, sir, when they get any hurts in the
ring, They bruise themselves very bad sometimes.
subQuotationList: ["It's what our people aways use, sir, when they get any hurts in the\nring,", 'They bruise themselves very bad sometimes.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Serve 'em right, for being idle. By George! when I was four or five years younger
than you, I had worse bruises upon me than ten oils, twenty oils, forty
oils, would have rubbed off.  I didn't get 'em by posture-making, but by
being banged about.  There was no rope-dancing for me; I danced on the
bare ground and was larruped with the rope.
subQuotationList:
["Serve 'em right,", 'for being idle.', 'By George!', "when I was four or five years younger
than you, I had worse bruises upon me than ten oils, twenty oils, forty
oils, would have rubbed off.  I didn't get 'em by posture-making, but by
being banged about.  There was no rope-dancing for me; I danced on the
bare ground and was larruped with the rope."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
And this is
Pod's End; is it, Jupe?
subQuotationList: ["And this is\nPod's End; is it, Jupe?"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: This is it, sir, and   if you wouldn't mind, sir   this is the house.
subQuotationList: ["This is it, sir, and   if you wouldn't mind, sir   this is the house."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
It's only crossing the bar, sir, and up the stairs, if you wouldn't
mind, and waiting there for a moment till I get a candle.  If you should
hear a dog, sir, it's only Merrylegs, and he only barks.
subQuotationList: ["It's only crossing the bar, sir, and up the stairs, if you wouldn't\nmind, and waiting there for a moment till I get a candle.  If you should\nhear a dog, sir, it's only Merrylegs, and he only barks."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Merrylegs and nine oils, eh! Pretty well this, for a self-made man!
subQuotationList: ['Merrylegs and nine oils, eh!', 'Pretty well this, for a self-made man!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Father is not in our room, sir, If you wouldn't mind walking in, I'll find him directly.
subQuotationList: ['Father is not in our room, sir,', "If you wouldn't mind walking in, I'll find him directly."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Father must have gone down to the Booth, sir.  I don't know why he
should go there, but he must be there; I'll bring him in a minute!
subQuotationList: ["Father must have gone down to the Booth, sir.  I don't know why he\nshould go there, but he must be there; I'll bring him in a minute!"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
What does she mean! Back in a minute?  It's more
than a mile off.
subQuotationList: ['What does she mean!', "Back in a minute?  It's more\nthan a mile off."]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: By your leaves, gentlemen!
subQuotationList: ['By your leaves, gentlemen!']
speaker: Master Kidderminster
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby']
referringExpression: a young man appeared at the door and introducing himself with the words

quoteText: By your leaves, gentlemen, It was you, I believe, that were wishing to see Jupe!
subQuotationList: ['By your leaves, gentlemen,', 'It was you, I believe, that were wishing to see Jupe!']
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
referringExpression: said Mr E W B Childers
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby']], [['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
It was, His daughter has gone to fetch him, but I
can't wait; therefore, if you please, I will leave a message for him with
you.
subQuotationList: ['It was,', "His daughter has gone to fetch him, but I\ncan't wait; therefore, if you please, I will leave a message for him with\nyou."]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers']]]

quoteText:
You see, my friend, we are the kind of people
who know the value of time, and you are the kind of people who don't know
the value of time.
subQuotationList: ['You see, my friend,', "we are the kind of people\nwho know the value of time, and you are the kind of people who don't know\nthe value of time."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Master Kidderminster']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers']], [['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers']]]

quoteText:
I have not, the honour of knowing _you_,   but if you mean that you can make
more money of your time than I can of mine, I should judge from your
appearance, that you are about right.
subQuotationList: ['I have not,', 'the honour of knowing _you_,   but if you mean that you can make\nmore money of your time than I can of mine, I should judge from your\nappearance, that you are about right.']
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: And when you have made it, you can keep it too, I should think,
subQuotationList: ['And when you have made it, you can keep it too, I should think,']
speaker: Master Kidderminster
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby']

quoteText: Kidderminster, stow that!
subQuotationList: ['Kidderminster, stow that!']
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers

quoteText:
What does he come here cheeking us for, then? If you want to
cheek us, pay your ochre at the doors and take it out.
subQuotationList: ['What does he come here cheeking us for, then?', 'If you want to\ncheek us, pay your ochre at the doors and take it out.']
speaker: Master Kidderminster
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Master Kidderminster', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers']], [['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Master Kidderminster', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Kidderminster, stow that!   Sir, I was addressing myself to you.  You may or you may
not be aware (for perhaps you have not been much in the audience), that
Jupe has missed his tip very often, lately.
subQuotationList: ['Kidderminster,', 'stow that!   Sir,', 'I was addressing myself to you.  You may or you may\nnot be aware (for perhaps you have not been much in the audience), that\nJupe has missed his tip very often, lately.']
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Master Kidderminster']], [['Thomas Gradgrind']], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText: Has   what has he missed?
subQuotationList: ['Has   what has he missed?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText: Missed his tip.
subQuotationList: ['Missed his tip.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Offered at the Garters four times last night, and never done 'em once, Missed his tip at the banners, too, and was
loose in his ponging.
subQuotationList: ["Offered at the Garters four times last night, and never done 'em once,", 'Missed his tip at the banners, too, and was\nloose in his ponging.']
speaker: Master Kidderminster
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby']

quoteText:
Didn't do what he ought to do.  Was short in his leaps and bad in his
tumbling,
subQuotationList: ["Didn't do what he ought to do.  Was short in his leaps and bad in his\ntumbling,"]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers

quoteText: Oh! that is tip, is it?
subQuotationList: ['Oh!', 'that is tip, is it?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText: In a general way that's missing his tip,
subQuotationList: ["In a general way that's missing his tip,"]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
referringExpression: Mr E W B Childers answered

quoteText:
Nine oils, Merrylegs, missing tips, garters, banners, and Ponging, eh! Queer sort of company,
too, for a man who has raised himself!
subQuotationList: ['Nine oils, Merrylegs, missing tips, garters, banners, and Ponging, eh!', 'Queer sort of company,\ntoo, for a man who has raised himself!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Lower yourself, then, Oh Lord! if you've raised
yourself so high as all that comes to, let yourself down a bit.
subQuotationList: ['Lower yourself, then,', "Oh Lord! if you've raised\nyourself so high as all that comes to, let yourself down a bit."]
speaker: Master Kidderminster
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby']

quoteText: This is a very obtrusive lad!
subQuotationList: ['This is a very obtrusive lad!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
We'd have had a young gentleman to meet you, if we had known you were
coming, It's a pity
you don't have a bespeak, being so particular.  You're on the Tight-Jeff,
ain't you?
subQuotationList:
["We'd have had a young gentleman to meet you, if we had known you were
coming,", "It's a pity
you don't have a bespeak, being so particular.  You're on the Tight-Jeff,
ain't you?"]
speaker: Master Kidderminster
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Master Kidderminster', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Master Kidderminster', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: What does this unmannerly boy mean, by Tight-Jeff?
subQuotationList: ['What does this unmannerly boy mean,', 'by Tight-Jeff?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
There!  Get out, get out! Tight-Jeff or Slack-Jeff,
it don't much signify: it's only tight-rope and slack-rope.  You were
going to give me a message for Jupe?
subQuotationList: ['There!  Get out, get out!', "Tight-Jeff or Slack-Jeff,\nit don't much signify: it's only tight-rope and slack-rope.  You were\ngoing to give me a message for Jupe?"]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers

quoteText: Yes, I was.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I was.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Then, my opinion is, he will never
receive it.  Do you know much of him?
subQuotationList: ['Then,', 'my opinion is, he will never\nreceive it.  Do you know much of him?']
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers

quoteText: I never saw the man in my life.
subQuotationList: ['I never saw the man in my life.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
I doubt if you ever _will_ see him now.  It's pretty plain to me, he's
off.
subQuotationList: ["I doubt if you ever _will_ see him now.  It's pretty plain to me, he's\noff."]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers

quoteText: Do you mean that he has deserted his daughter?
subQuotationList: ['Do you mean that he has deserted his daughter?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText:
Ay!  I mean, that he has cut.  He was
goosed last night, he was goosed the night before last, he was goosed
to-day.  He has lately got in the way of being always goosed, and he
can't stand it.
subQuotationList:
['Ay!  I mean,', "that he has cut.  He was
goosed last night, he was goosed the night before last, he was goosed
to-day.  He has lately got in the way of being always goosed, and he
can't stand it."]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText: Why has he been   so very much   Goosed?
subQuotationList: ['Why has he been   so very much   Goosed?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
His joints are turning stiff, and he is getting used up, He has his points as a Cackler still, but he can't get a living out of
_them_.
subQuotationList: ['His joints are turning stiff, and he is getting used up,', "He has his points as a Cackler still, but he can't get a living out of\n_them_."]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers

quoteText: A Cackler! Here we go again!
subQuotationList: ['A Cackler!', 'Here we go again!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
A speaker, if the gentleman likes it better, Now, it's a remarkable fact, sir, that it cut that man deeper, to
know that his daughter knew of his being goosed, than to go through with
it.
subQuotationList: ['A speaker, if the gentleman likes it better,', "Now, it's a remarkable fact, sir, that it cut that man deeper, to\nknow that his daughter knew of his being goosed, than to go through with\nit."]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
referringExpression: said Mr E W B Childers

quoteText:
Good! This is good, Gradgrind!  A man so
fond of his daughter, that he runs away from her!  This is devilish good!
Ha! ha!  Now, I'll tell you what, young man.  I haven't always occupied
my present station of life.  I know what these things are.  You may be
astonished to hear it, but my mother   ran away from _me_.
subQuotationList:
['Good!', "This is good, Gradgrind!  A man so
fond of his daughter, that he runs away from her!  This is devilish good!
Ha! ha!  Now, I'll tell you what, young man.  I haven't always occupied
my present station of life.  I know what these things are.  You may be
astonished to hear it, but my mother   ran away from _me_."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Very well, I was born in a ditch, and my mother ran
away from me.  Do I excuse her for it?  No.  Have I ever excused her for
it?  Not I.  What do I call her for it?  I call her probably the very
worst woman that ever lived in the world, except my drunken grandmother.
There's no family pride about me, there's no imaginative sentimental
humbug about me.  I call a spade a spade; and I call the mother of Josiah
Bounderby of Coketown, without any fear or any favour, what I should call
her if she had been the mother of Dick Jones of Wapping.  So, with this
man.  He is a runaway rogue and a vagabond, that's what he is, in
English.
subQuotationList:
['Very well,', "I was born in a ditch, and my mother ran
away from me.  Do I excuse her for it?  No.  Have I ever excused her for
it?  Not I.  What do I call her for it?  I call her probably the very
worst woman that ever lived in the world, except my drunken grandmother.
There's no family pride about me, there's no imaginative sentimental
humbug about me.  I call a spade a spade; and I call the mother of Josiah
Bounderby of Coketown, without any fear or any favour, what I should call
her if she had been the mother of Dick Jones of Wapping.  So, with this
man.  He is a runaway rogue and a vagabond, that's what he is, in
English."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
It's all the same to me what he is or what he is not, whether in English
or whether in French, I
am telling your friend what's the fact; if you don't like to hear it, you
can avail yourself of the open air.  You give it mouth enough, you do;
but give it mouth in your own building at least, Don't give it mouth in this building, till you're
called upon.  You have got some building of your own I dare say, now?
subQuotationList:
["It's all the same to me what he is or what he is not, whether in English
or whether in French,", "I
am telling your friend what's the fact; if you don't like to hear it, you
can avail yourself of the open air.  You give it mouth enough, you do;
but give it mouth in your own building at least,", "Don't give it mouth in this building, till you're
called upon.  You have got some building of your own I dare say, now?"]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
referringExpression: retorted Mr E W B Childers
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Perhaps so,
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps so,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Then give it mouth in your own building, will you, if you please? Because this isn't a strong building, and too much of you
might bring it down!
subQuotationList: ['Then give it mouth in your own building, will you, if you please?', "Because this isn't a strong building, and too much of you\nmight bring it down!"]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers

quoteText:
Jupe sent his daughter out on an errand not an hour ago, and then was
seen to slip out himself, with his hat over his eyes, and a bundle tied
up in a handkerchief under his arm.  She will never believe it of him,
but he has cut away and left her.
subQuotationList:
['Jupe sent his daughter out on an errand not an hour ago, and then was
seen to slip out himself, with his hat over his eyes, and a bundle tied
up in a handkerchief under his arm.  She will never believe it of him,
but he has cut away and left her.']
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText: Pray, why will she never believe it of him?
subQuotationList: ['Pray,', 'why will she never believe it of him?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Because those two were one.  Because they were never asunder.  Because,
up to this time, he seemed to dote upon her, Poor Sissy!  He had better have apprenticed her, Now, he
leaves her without anything to take to.
subQuotationList: ['Because those two were one.  Because they were never asunder.  Because,\nup to this time, he seemed to dote upon her,', 'Poor Sissy!  He had better have apprenticed her,', 'Now, he\nleaves her without anything to take to.']
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe', 'Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']], [['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']], [['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText:
It is creditable to you, who have never been apprenticed, to express
that opinion,
subQuotationList: ['It is creditable to you, who have never been apprenticed, to express\nthat opinion,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText: _I_ never apprenticed?  I was apprenticed when I was seven year old.
subQuotationList: ['_I_ never apprenticed?  I was apprenticed when I was seven year old.']
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers

quoteText:
Oh!  Indeed? I was not aware of its being the custom
to apprentice young persons to
subQuotationList: ['Oh!  Indeed?', 'I was not aware of its being the custom\nto apprentice young persons to']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Idleness, No, by the Lord
Harry!  Nor I!
subQuotationList: ['Idleness,', 'No, by the Lord\nHarry!  Nor I!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Her father always had it in his head, that she was to be taught
the deuce-and-all of education.  How it got into his head, I can't say; I
can only say that it never got out.  He has been picking up a bit of
reading for her, here   and a bit of writing for her, there   and a bit of
ciphering for her, somewhere else   these seven years.
subQuotationList:
['Her father always had it in his head,', "that she was to be taught
the deuce-and-all of education.  How it got into his head, I can't say; I
can only say that it never got out.  He has been picking up a bit of
reading for her, here   and a bit of writing for her, there   and a bit of
ciphering for her, somewhere else   these seven years."]
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe']], [['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText:
When Sissy got into the school here, her father was as
pleased as Punch.  I couldn't altogether make out why, myself, as we were
not stationary here, being but comers and goers anywhere.  I suppose,
however, he had this move in his mind   he was always half-cracked   and then
considered her provided for.  If you should happen to have looked in
to-night, for the purpose of telling him that you were going to do her
any little service, it would be very fortunate and well-timed; very
fortunate and well-timed.
subQuotationList:
['When Sissy got into the school here,', "her father was as
pleased as Punch.  I couldn't altogether make out why, myself, as we were
not stationary here, being but comers and goers anywhere.  I suppose,
however, he had this move in his mind   he was always half-cracked   and then
considered her provided for.  If you should happen to have looked in
to-night, for the purpose of telling him that you were going to do her
any little service,", 'it would be very fortunate and well-timed; very
fortunate and well-timed.']
speaker: Mr. E. W. B. Childers
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe']], [['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Master Kidderminster', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Cecilia Jupe']], []]

quoteText:
On the contrary, I came to tell him that her
connections made her not an object for the school, and that she must not
attend any more.  Still, if her father really has left her, without any
connivance on her part   Bounderby, let me have a word with you.
subQuotationList:
['On the contrary,', 'I came to tell him that her
connections made her not an object for the school, and that she must not
attend any more.  Still, if her father really has left her, without any
connivance on her part   Bounderby, let me have a word with you.']

addressees: ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
No.  _I_ say no.  I advise you not.  I say by
no means.
subQuotationList: ['No.  _I_ say no.  I advise you not.  I say by\nno means.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
But even as an example to Louisa, of what this pursuit which
has been the subject of a vulgar curiosity, leads to and ends in.  Think
of it, Bounderby, in that point of view.
subQuotationList: ['But even as an example to Louisa, of what this pursuit which\nhas been the subject of a vulgar curiosity, leads to and ends in.  Think\nof it, Bounderby, in that point of view.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Thquire! Your thervant!
Thith ith a bad piethe of bithnith, thith ith.  You've heard of my Clown
and hith dog being thuppothed to have morrithed?
subQuotationList: ['Thquire!', "Your thervant!\nThith ith a bad piethe of bithnith, thith ith.  You've heard of my Clown\nand hith dog being thuppothed to have morrithed?"]
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Well, Thquire, Ith
it your intenthion to do anything for the poor girl, Thquire?
subQuotationList: ['Well, Thquire,', 'Ith\nit your intenthion to do anything for the poor girl, Thquire?']
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText: I shall have something to propose to her when she comes back,
subQuotationList: ['I shall have something to propose to her when she comes back,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Glad to hear it, Thquire.  Not that I want to get rid of the child, any
more than I want to thtand in her way.  I'm willing to take her prentith,
though at her age ith late.  My voithe ith a little huthky, Thquire, and
not eathy heard by them ath don't know me; but if you'd been chilled and
heated, heated and chilled, chilled and heated in the ring when you wath
young, ath often ath I have been, _your_ voithe wouldn't have lathted
out, Thquire, no more than mine.
subQuotationList:
["Glad to hear it, Thquire.  Not that I want to get rid of the child, any
more than I want to thtand in her way.  I'm willing to take her prentith,
though at her age ith late.  My voithe ith a little huthky, Thquire, and
not eathy heard by them ath don't know me; but if you'd been chilled and
heated, heated and chilled, chilled and heated in the ring when you wath
young, ath often ath I have been, _your_ voithe wouldn't have lathted

speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: I dare say not,
subQuotationList: ['I dare say not,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
What thall it be, Thquire, while you wait?  Thall it be Therry?  Give it
a name, Thquire!
subQuotationList: ['What thall it be, Thquire, while you wait?  Thall it be Therry?  Give it\na name, Thquire!']
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText: Nothing for me, I thank you,
subQuotationList: ['Nothing for me, I thank you,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Don't thay nothing, Thquire.  What doth your friend thay?  If you
haven't took your feed yet, have a glath of bitterth.
subQuotationList: ["Don't thay nothing, Thquire.  What doth your friend thay?  If you\nhaven't took your feed yet, have a glath of bitterth."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Father, hush!
she has come back!
subQuotationList: ['Father, hush!\nshe has come back!']
speaker: Josephine Sleary
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']
referringExpression: Josephine a pretty fairhaired girl of eighteen who had been tied on a horse at two years old and had made a will at twelve which she always carried about with her expressive of her dying desire to be drawn to the grave by the two piebald ponies cried

quoteText: Ith an internal thame, upon my thoul it ith,
subQuotationList: ['Ith an internal thame, upon my thoul it ith,']
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
O my dear father, my good kind father, where are you gone?  You are gone
to try to do me some good, I know!  You are gone away for my sake, I am
sure!  And how miserable and helpless you will be without me, poor, poor
father, until you come back!
subQuotationList:
['O my dear father, my good kind father, where are you gone?  You are gone
to try to do me some good, I know!  You are gone away for my sake, I am
sure!  And how miserable and helpless you will be without me, poor, poor
father, until you come back!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
Now, good people all, this is wanton waste of time.  Let the
girl understand the fact.  Let her take it from me, if you like, who have
been run away from, myself.  Here, what's your name!  Your father has
absconded   deserted you   and you mustn't expect to see him again as long as
you live.
subQuotationList:
['Now, good people all,', "this is wanton waste of time.  Let the
girl understand the fact.  Let her take it from me, if you like, who have
been run away from, myself.  Here, what's your name!  Your father has
absconded   deserted you   and you mustn't expect to see him again as long as
you live."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText:
I tell you what, Thquire.  To thpeak plain to you, my opinion ith that
you had better cut it thort, and drop it.  They're a very good natur'd
people, my people, but they're accuthtomed to be quick in their
movementh; and if you don't act upon my advithe, I'm damned if I don't
believe they'll pith you out o' winder.
subQuotationList:
["I tell you what, Thquire.  To thpeak plain to you, my opinion ith that
you had better cut it thort, and drop it.  They're a very good natur'd
people, my people, but they're accuthtomed to be quick in their
movementh; and if you don't act upon my advithe, I'm damned if I don't
believe they'll pith you out o' winder."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']
referringExpression: Sleary in some haste communicated the following hint apart to Mr Bounderby

quoteText:
It is of no moment, whether this person is to be expected
back at any time, or the contrary.  He is gone away, and there is no
present expectation of his return.  That, I believe, is agreed on all
hands.
subQuotationList:
['It is of no moment,', 'whether this person is to be expected
back at any time, or the contrary.  He is gone away, and there is no
present expectation of his return.  That, I believe, is agreed on all
hands.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText: Thath agreed, Thquire.  Thick to that!
subQuotationList: ['Thath agreed, Thquire.  Thick to that!']
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
Well then.  I, who came here to inform the father of the poor girl,
Jupe, that she could not be received at the school any more, in
consequence of there being practical objections, into which I need not
enter, to the reception there of the children of persons so employed, am
prepared in these altered circumstances to make a proposal.  I am willing
to take charge of you, Jupe, and to educate you, and provide for you.
The only condition (over and above your good behaviour) I make is, that
you decide now, at once, whether to accompany me or remain here.  Also,
that if you accompany me now, it is understood that you communicate no
more with any of your friends who are here present.  These observations
comprise the whole of the case.
subQuotationList:
['Well then.  I, who came here to inform the father of the poor girl,
Jupe, that she could not be received at the school any more, in
consequence of there being practical objections, into which I need not
enter, to the reception there of the children of persons so employed, am
prepared in these altered circumstances to make a proposal.  I am willing
to take charge of you, Jupe, and to educate you, and provide for you.
The only condition (over and above your good behaviour) I make is, that
you decide now, at once, whether to accompany me or remain here.  Also,
that if you accompany me now, it is understood that you communicate no
more with any of your friends who are here present.  These observations
comprise the whole of the case.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText:
At the thame time, I mutht put in my word, Thquire, tho
that both thides of the banner may be equally theen.  If you like,
Thethilia, to be prentitht, you know the natur of the work and you know
your companionth.  Emma Gordon, in whothe lap you're a lying at prethent,
would be a mother to you, and Joth'phine would be a thithter to you.  I
don't pretend to be of the angel breed myself, and I don't thay but what,
when you mith'd your tip, you'd find me cut up rough, and thwear an oath
or two at you.  But what I thay, Thquire, ith, that good tempered or bad
tempered, I never did a horthe a injury yet, no more than thwearing at
him went, and that I don't expect I thall begin otherwithe at my time of
life, with a rider.  I never wath much of a Cackler, Thquire, and I have
thed my thay.
subQuotationList:
['At the thame time,', "I mutht put in my word, Thquire, tho
that both thides of the banner may be equally theen.  If you like,
Thethilia, to be prentitht, you know the natur of the work and you know
your companionth.  Emma Gordon, in whothe lap you're a lying at prethent,
would be a mother to you, and Joth'phine would be a thithter to you.  I
don't pretend to be of the angel breed myself, and I don't thay but what,
when you mith'd your tip, you'd find me cut up rough, and thwear an oath
or two at you.  But what I thay, Thquire, ith, that good tempered or bad
tempered, I never did a horthe a injury yet, no more than thwearing at
him went, and that I don't expect I thall begin otherwithe at my time of
life, with a rider.  I never wath much of a Cackler, Thquire, and I have
thed my thay."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
The only observation I will make to you, Jupe, in the way of influencing
your decision, is, that it is highly desirable to have a sound practical
education, and that even your father himself (from what I understand)
appears, on your behalf, to have known and felt that much.
subQuotationList:

quoteText:
Be sure you know your own mind, Jupe, I
say no more.  Be sure you know your own mind!
subQuotationList: ['Be sure you know your own mind, Jupe,', 'I\nsay no more.  Be sure you know your own mind!']

addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText: When father comes back, how will he ever find me if I go away!
subQuotationList: ['When father comes back,', 'how will he ever find me if I go away!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster']

quoteText:
You may be quite at ease, you may be quite at ease, Jupe, on that score.
In such a case, your father, I apprehend, must find out Mr.
subQuotationList: ['You may be quite at ease,', 'you may be quite at ease, Jupe, on that score.\nIn such a case, your father, I apprehend, must find out Mr.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Mr. Sleary', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
Thleary.  Thath my name, Thquire.  Not athamed of it.  Known all over
England, and alwayth paythe ith way.
subQuotationList: ['Thleary.  Thath my name, Thquire.  Not athamed of it.  Known all over\nEngland, and alwayth paythe ith way.']
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Master Kidderminster', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
Must find out Mr. Sleary, who would then let him know where you went.  I
should have no power of keeping you against his wish, and he would have
no difficulty, at any time, in finding Mr. Thomas Gradgrind of Coketown.
I am well known.
subQuotationList:

quoteText:
Well known, You're one of
the thort, Thquire, that keepth a prethiouth thight of money out of the
houthe.  But never mind that at prethent.

Oh, give me my clothes, give me my clothes, and let me
go away before I break my heart!

quoteText:
Good-bye, my dear! You'll make your fortun, I hope, and
none of our poor folkth will ever trouble you, I'll pound it.  I with
your father hadn't taken hith dog with him; ith a ill-conwenienth to have
the dog out of the billth.  But on thecond thoughth, he wouldn't have
performed without hith mathter, tho ith ath broad ath ith long!

quoteText:
Leave the bottle, my dear; ith large
to carry; it will be of no uthe to you now.  Give it to me!

quoteText:
No, no! Oh, no!  Pray let me
keep it for father till he comes back!  He will want it when he comes
back.  He had never thought of going away, when he sent me for it.  I
must keep it for him, if you please!

quoteText:
Tho be it, my dear.  (You thee how it ith, Thquire!)  Farewell,
Thethilia!  My latht wordth to you ith thith, Thtick to the termth of
your engagement, be obedient to the Thquire, and forget uth.  But if,
when you're grown up and married and well off, you come upon any
horthe-riding ever, don't be hard upon it, don't be croth with it, give
it a Bethpeak if you can, and think you might do wurth.  People mutht be
amuthed, Thquire, thomehow, they can't be alwayth a working, nor yet they
can't be alwayth a learning.  Make the betht of uth; not the wurtht.
I've got my living out of the horthe-riding all my life, I know; but I
conthider that I lay down the philothophy of the thubject when I thay to
you, Thquire, make the betht of uth: not the wurtht!
