quoteText:
And yet, sir, how does it turn out
after all?  Why here she is at a hundred a year (I give her a hundred,
which she is pleased to term handsome), keeping the house of Josiah
Bounderby of Coketown!
subQuotationList:
['And yet, sir,', 'how does it turn out
after all?  Why here she is at a hundred a year (I give her a hundred,
which she is pleased to term handsome), keeping the house of Josiah
Bounderby of Coketown!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Princes and lords may flourish or may fade,
    A breath can make them, as a breath has made,
subQuotationList: ['Princes and lords may flourish or may fade,\n    A breath can make them, as a breath has made,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
referringExpression: an orator of this kind brought into his peroration

quoteText:
Mr. Bounderby, you are unusually slow, sir, with
your breakfast this morning.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bounderby,', 'you are unusually slow, sir, with\nyour breakfast this morning.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Why, ma'am, I am thinking about Tom Gradgrind's whim;
subQuotationList: ["Why, ma'am,", "I am thinking about Tom Gradgrind's whim;"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Tom Gradgrind's whim, ma'am, of bringing up the
tumbling-girl.
subQuotationList: ["Tom Gradgrind's whim, ma'am, of bringing up the\ntumbling-girl."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
The girl is now waiting to know, whether she is to
go straight to the school, or up to the Lodge.
subQuotationList: ['The girl is now waiting to know,', 'whether she is to\ngo straight to the school, or up to the Lodge.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
She must wait, ma'am, till I know myself.  We
shall have Tom Gradgrind down here presently, I suppose.  If he should
wish her to remain here a day or two longer, of course she can, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["She must wait, ma'am,", "till I know myself.  We\nshall have Tom Gradgrind down here presently, I suppose.  If he should\nwish her to remain here a day or two longer, of course she can, ma'am."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Of course she can if you wish it, Mr. Bounderby.
subQuotationList: ['Of course she can if you wish it, Mr. Bounderby.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I told him I would give her a shake-down here, last night, in order that
he might sleep on it before he decided to let her have any association
with Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['I told him I would give her a shake-down here, last night, in order that\nhe might sleep on it before he decided to let her have any association\nwith Louisa.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Indeed, Mr. Bounderby?  Very thoughtful of you!
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, Mr. Bounderby?  Very thoughtful of you!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
It's tolerably clear to _me_, that the little puss can
get small good out of such companionship.
subQuotationList: ["It's tolerably clear to _me_,", 'that the little puss can\nget small good out of such companionship.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Are you speaking of young Miss Gradgrind, Mr. Bounderby?
subQuotationList: ['Are you speaking of young Miss Gradgrind, Mr. Bounderby?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Yes, ma'am, I'm speaking of Louisa.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, ma'am, I'm speaking of Louisa."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
and there being two little girls in question, I did not know which might
be indicated by that expression. Your observation being limited to "little puss,"
subQuotationList: ['and there being two little girls in question, I did not know which might\nbe indicated by that expression.', 'Your observation being limited to "little puss,"']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Louisa, Louisa, Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['Louisa,', 'Louisa, Louisa.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: You are quite another father to Louisa, sir.
subQuotationList: ['You are quite another father to Louisa, sir.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
If you had said I was another father to Tom   young Tom, I mean, not my
friend Tom Gradgrind   you might have been nearer the mark.  I am going to
take young Tom into my office.  Going to have him under my wing, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["If you had said I was another father to Tom   young Tom, I mean, not my\nfriend Tom Gradgrind   you might have been nearer the mark.  I am going to\ntake young Tom into my office.  Going to have him under my wing, ma'am."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText: Indeed?  Rather young for that, is he not, sir?
subQuotationList: ['Indeed?  Rather young for that, is he not, sir?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I'm not going to take him at once; he is to finish his educational
cramming before then, By the Lord Harry, he'll have
enough of it, first and last!  He'd open his eyes, that boy would, if he
knew how empty of learning _my_ young maw was, at his time of life. But it's extraordinary the difficulty I have on scores of such
subjects, in speaking to any one on equal terms.  Here, for example, I
have been speaking to you this morning about tumblers.  Why, what do
_you_ know about tumblers?  At the time when, to have been a tumbler in
the mud of the streets, would have been a godsend to me, a prize in the
lottery to me, you were at the Italian Opera.  You were coming out of the
Italian Opera, ma'am, in white satin and jewels, a blaze of splendour,
when I hadn't a penny to buy a link to light you.
subQuotationList:
["I'm not going to take him at once; he is to finish his educational
cramming before then,", "By the Lord Harry, he'll have
enough of it, first and last!  He'd open his eyes, that boy would, if he
knew how empty of learning _my_ young maw was, at his time of life.", "But it's extraordinary the difficulty I have on scores of such
subjects, in speaking to any one on equal terms.  Here, for example, I

when I hadn't a penny to buy a link to light you."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']], []]

quoteText: I certainly, sir, was familiar with the Italian Opera at a very early age.
subQuotationList: ['I certainly, sir,', 'was familiar with the Italian Opera at a very early age.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Egad, ma'am, so was I, with the wrong side of it.  A
hard bed the pavement of its Arcade used to make, I assure you.  People
like you, ma'am, accustomed from infancy to lie on Down feathers, have no
idea _how_ hard a paving-stone is, without trying it.  No, no, it's of no
use my talking to _you_ about tumblers.  I should speak of foreign
dancers, and the West End of London, and May Fair, and lords and ladies
and honourables.
subQuotationList:
["Egad, ma'am, so was I,", "with the wrong side of it.  A
hard bed the pavement of its Arcade used to make, I assure you.  People
like you, ma'am, accustomed from infancy to lie on Down feathers, have no
idea _how_ hard a paving-stone is, without trying it.  No, no, it's of no
use my talking to _you_ about tumblers.  I should speak of foreign
dancers, and the West End of London, and May Fair, and lords and ladies
and honourables."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I trust, sir, it is
not necessary that you should do anything of that kind.  I hope I have
learnt how to accommodate myself to the changes of life.  If I have
acquired an interest in hearing of your instructive experiences, and can
scarcely hear enough of them, I claim no merit for that, since I believe
it is a general sentiment.
subQuotationList:
['I trust, sir,', 'it is
not necessary that you should do anything of that kind.  I hope I have
learnt how to accommodate myself to the changes of life.  If I have
acquired an interest in hearing of your instructive experiences, and can
scarcely hear enough of them, I claim no merit for that, since I believe
it is a general sentiment.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Well, ma'am, perhaps some people may be pleased to
say that they do like to hear, in his own unpolished way, what Josiah
Bounderby, of Coketown, has gone through.  But you must confess that you
were born in the lap of luxury, yourself.  Come, ma'am, you know you were
born in the lap of luxury.
subQuotationList:
["Well, ma'am,", "perhaps some people may be pleased to
say that they do like to hear, in his own unpolished way, what Josiah
Bounderby, of Coketown, has gone through.  But you must confess that you
were born in the lap of luxury, yourself.  Come, ma'am, you know you were
born in the lap of luxury."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
I do not, sir, deny
it.
subQuotationList: ['I do not, sir,', 'deny\nit.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: And you were in crack society.  Devilish high society,
subQuotationList: ['And you were in crack society.  Devilish high society,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: It is true, sir,
subQuotationList: ['It is true, sir,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: You were in the tiptop fashion, and all the rest of it,
subQuotationList: ['You were in the tiptop fashion, and all the rest of it,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Yes, sir, It is unquestionably true.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir,', 'It is unquestionably true.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Can Jupe be sent here, Bounderby?
subQuotationList: ['Can Jupe be sent here, Bounderby?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Now, I tell you what, my girl.  The name of that lady by the teapot, is
Mrs. Sparsit.  That lady acts as mistress of this house, and she is a
highly connected lady.  Consequently, if ever you come again into any
room in this house, you will make a short stay in it if you don't behave
towards that lady in your most respectful manner.  Now, I don't care a
button what you do to _me_, because I don't affect to be anybody.  So far
from having high connections I have no connections at all, and I come of
the scum of the earth.  But towards that lady, I do care what you do; and
you shall do what is deferential and respectful, or you shall not come
here.
subQuotationList:
["Now, I tell you what, my girl.  The name of that lady by the teapot, is

quoteText:
I hope, Bounderby, that
this was merely an oversight.
subQuotationList: ['I hope, Bounderby,', 'that\nthis was merely an oversight.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
My friend Tom Gradgrind suggests, Mrs. Sparsit, that
this was merely an oversight.  Very likely.  However, as you are aware,
ma'am, I don't allow of even oversights towards you.
subQuotationList: ['My friend Tom Gradgrind suggests, Mrs. Sparsit,', "that\nthis was merely an oversight.  Very likely.  However, as you are aware,\nma'am, I don't allow of even oversights towards you."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: You are very good indeed, sir, It is not worth speaking of.
subQuotationList: ['You are very good indeed, sir,', 'It is not worth speaking of.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Jupe, I have made up my mind to take you into my house; and, when you
are not in attendance at the school, to employ you about Mrs. Gradgrind,
who is rather an invalid.  I have explained to Miss Louisa   this is Miss
Louisa   the miserable but natural end of your late career; and you are to
expressly understand that the whole of that subject is past, and is not
to be referred to any more.  From this time you begin your history.  You
are, at present, ignorant, I know.
subQuotationList:
['Jupe, I have made up my mind to take you into my house; and, when you
are not in attendance at the school, to employ you about Mrs. Gradgrind,
who is rather an invalid.  I have explained to Miss Louisa   this is Miss
Louisa   the miserable but natural end of your late career; and you are to
expressly understand that the whole of that subject is past, and is not
to be referred to any more.  From this time you begin your history.  You
are, at present, ignorant, I know.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Mrs. Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText: Yes, sir, very,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir, very,']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
I shall have the satisfaction of causing you to be strictly educated;
and you will be a living proof to all who come into communication with
you, of the advantages of the training you will receive.  You will be
reclaimed and formed.  You have been in the habit now of reading to your
father, and those people I found you among, I dare say?
subQuotationList:
['I shall have the satisfaction of causing you to be strictly educated;
and you will be a living proof to all who come into communication with
you, of the advantages of the training you will receive.  You will be
reclaimed and formed.  You have been in the habit now of reading to your
father, and those people I found you among, I dare say?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText:
Only to father and Merrylegs, sir.  At least I mean to father, when
Merrylegs was always there.
subQuotationList: ['Only to father and Merrylegs, sir.  At least I mean to father, when\nMerrylegs was always there.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Never mind Merrylegs, Jupe, I don't ask about him.  I understand you to have been in the habit of
reading to your father?
subQuotationList: ['Never mind Merrylegs, Jupe,', "I don't ask about him.  I understand you to have been in the habit of\nreading to your father?"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
O, yes, sir, thousands of times.  They were the happiest   O, of all the
happy times we had together, sir!
subQuotationList: ['O, yes, sir, thousands of times.  They were the happiest   O, of all the\nhappy times we had together, sir!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
And what, did you read to
your father, Jupe?
subQuotationList: ['And what,', 'did you read to\nyour father, Jupe?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
About the Fairies, sir, and the Dwarf, and the Hunchback, and the
Genies, and about
subQuotationList: ['About the Fairies, sir, and the Dwarf, and the Hunchback, and the\nGenies,', 'and about']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Hush! that is enough.  Never breathe a word of
such destructive nonsense any more.  Bounderby, this is a case for rigid
training, and I shall observe it with interest.
subQuotationList: ['Hush!', 'that is enough.  Never breathe a word of\nsuch destructive nonsense any more.  Bounderby, this is a case for rigid\ntraining, and I shall observe it with interest.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Well, I have given you my opinion already, and
I shouldn't do as you do.  But, very well, very well.  Since you are bent
upon it, _very_ well!
subQuotationList: ['Well,', "I have given you my opinion already, and\nI shouldn't do as you do.  But, very well, very well.  Since you are bent\nupon it, _very_ well!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Tom, I
wonder
subQuotationList: ['Tom, I\nwonder']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
referringExpression: Louisa had been overheard to begin a conversation with her brother one day by saying

quoteText: Louisa, never wonder!
subQuotationList: ['Louisa, never wonder!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
referringExpression: upon which Mr Gradgrind who was the person overhearing stepped forth into the light and said

quoteText:
I am sick of my life, Loo.  I, hate it altogether, and I hate everybody
except you,
subQuotationList: ['I am sick of my life, Loo.  I, hate it altogether, and I hate everybody\nexcept you,']
speaker: Young Thomas
referringExpression: said the unnatural young Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: You don't hate Sissy, Tom?
subQuotationList: ["You don't hate Sissy, Tom?"]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: I hate to be obliged to call her Jupe.  And she hates me,
subQuotationList: ['I hate to be obliged to call her Jupe.  And she hates me,']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: No, she does not, Tom, I am sure!
subQuotationList: ['No, she does not, Tom, I am sure!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
She must, She must just hate and detest the whole set-out
of us.  They'll bother her head off, I think, before they have done with
her.  Already she's getting as pale as wax, and as heavy as   I am. As to me, I am a Donkey, that's what _I_ am.  I am as obstinate as one, I
am more stupid than one, I get as much pleasure as one, and I should like
to kick like one.
subQuotationList:
['She must,', "She must just hate and detest the whole set-out
of us.  They'll bother her head off, I think, before they have done with
