quoteText: Not me, I hope, Tom?
subQuotationList: ['Not me, I hope, Tom?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
No, Loo; I wouldn't hurt _you_.  I made an exception of you at first.  I
don't know what this   jolly old   Jaundiced Jail, would be without you.
subQuotationList: ["No, Loo; I wouldn't hurt _you_.  I made an exception of you at first.  I\ndon't know what this   jolly old   Jaundiced Jail,", 'would be without you.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Indeed, Tom?  Do you really and truly say so?
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, Tom?  Do you really and truly say so?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Why, of course I do.  What's the use of talking about it!
subQuotationList: ["Why, of course I do.  What's the use of talking about it!"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Because, Tom, as I get older, and nearer growing up, I often sit wondering
here, and think how unfortunate it is for me that I can't reconcile you
to home better than I am able to do.  I don't know what other girls know.
I can't play to you, or sing to you.  I can't talk to you so as to
lighten your mind, for I never see any amusing sights or read any amusing
books that it would be a pleasure or a relief to you to talk about, when
you are tired.
subQuotationList:
['Because, Tom,', "as I get older, and nearer growing up, I often sit wondering
here, and think how unfortunate it is for me that I can't reconcile you
to home better than I am able to do.  I don't know what other girls know.
I can't play to you, or sing to you.  I can't talk to you so as to
lighten your mind, for I never see any amusing sights or read any amusing
books that it would be a pleasure or a relief to you to talk about, when
you are tired."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas']], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText:
Well, no more do I.  I am as bad as you in that respect; and I am a Mule
too, which you're not.  If father was determined to make me either a Prig
or a Mule, and I am not a Prig, why, it stands to reason, I must be a
Mule.  And so I am,
subQuotationList:
["Well, no more do I.  I am as bad as you in that respect; and I am a Mule
too, which you're not.  If father was determined to make me either a Prig
or a Mule, and I am not a Prig, why, it stands to reason, I must be a
Mule.  And so I am,"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
It's a great pity, it's a great pity, Tom.  It's very
unfortunate for both of us.
subQuotationList: ["It's a great pity,", "it's a great pity, Tom.  It's very\nunfortunate for both of us."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh!  You, you are a girl, Loo, and a girl comes out of it
better than a boy does.  I don't miss anything in you.  You are the only
pleasure I have   you can brighten even this place   and you can always lead
me as you like.
subQuotationList:
['Oh!  You,', "you are a girl, Loo, and a girl comes out of it
better than a boy does.  I don't miss anything in you.  You are the only
pleasure I have   you can brighten even this place   and you can always lead
me as you like."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
You are a dear brother, Tom; and while you think I can do such things, I
don't so much mind knowing better.  Though I do know better, Tom, and am
very sorry for it.
subQuotationList: ["You are a dear brother, Tom; and while you think I can do such things, I\ndon't so much mind knowing better.  Though I do know better, Tom, and am\nvery sorry for it."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I wish I could collect all the Facts we hear so much about, and all the Figures, and all the people
who found them out: and I wish I could put a thousand barrels of
gunpowder under them, and blow them all up together!  However, when I go
to live with old Bounderby, I'll have my revenge.
subQuotationList:
['I wish I could collect all the Facts we hear so much about,', "and all the Figures, and all the people
who found them out: and I wish I could put a thousand barrels of
gunpowder under them, and blow them all up together!  However, when I go
to live with old Bounderby, I'll have my revenge."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Your revenge, Tom?
subQuotationList: ['Your revenge, Tom?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I mean, I'll enjoy myself a little, and go about and see something, and
hear something.  I'll recompense myself for the way in which I have been
brought up.
subQuotationList: ["I mean, I'll enjoy myself a little, and go about and see something, and\nhear something.  I'll recompense myself for the way in which I have been\nbrought up."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
But don't disappoint yourself beforehand, Tom.  Mr. Bounderby thinks as
father thinks, and is a great deal rougher, and not half so kind.
subQuotationList: ["But don't disappoint yourself beforehand, Tom.  Mr. Bounderby thinks as\nfather thinks, and is a great deal rougher, and not half so kind."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh! I don't mind that.  I shall very well know how
to manage and smooth old Bounderby!
subQuotationList: ['Oh!', "I don't mind that.  I shall very well know how\nto manage and smooth old Bounderby!"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
What is your great mode of smoothing and managing, Tom?  Is it a
secret?
subQuotationList: ['What is your great mode of smoothing and managing, Tom?  Is it a\nsecret?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh! if it is a secret, it's not far off.  It's you.  You are
his little pet, you are his favourite; he'll do anything for you.  When
he says to me what I don't like, I shall say to him, That'll bring him
about, or nothing will.
subQuotationList:
['Oh!', "if it is a secret, it's not far off.  It's you.  You are
his little pet, you are his favourite; he'll do anything for you.  When
he says to me what I don't like, I shall say to him,", "That'll bring him
about, or nothing will."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Have you gone to sleep, Loo?
subQuotationList: ['Have you gone to sleep, Loo?']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: No, Tom.  I am looking at the fire.
subQuotationList: ['No, Tom.  I am looking at the fire.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: You seem to find more to look at in it than ever I could find, Another of the advantages, I suppose, of being a girl.
subQuotationList: ['You seem to find more to look at in it than ever I could find,', 'Another of the advantages, I suppose, of being a girl.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Tom, do you look forward with any satisfaction to this change to Mr.
Bounderby's?
subQuotationList: ['Tom,', "do you look forward with any satisfaction to this change to Mr.\nBounderby's?"]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Why, there's one thing to be said of it, it will be getting away from home.
subQuotationList: ["Why, there's one thing to be said of it,", 'it will be getting away from home.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: There is one thing to be said of it, it will be getting away from home.  Yes.
subQuotationList: ['There is one thing to be said of it,', 'it will be getting away from home.  Yes.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Not but what I shall be very unwilling, both to leave you, Loo, and to
leave you here.  But I must go, you know, whether I like it or not; and I
had better go where I can take with me some advantage of your influence,
than where I should lose it altogether.  Don't you see?
subQuotationList:
["Not but what I shall be very unwilling, both to leave you, Loo, and to
leave you here.  But I must go, you know, whether I like it or not; and I
had better go where I can take with me some advantage of your influence,
than where I should lose it altogether.  Don't you see?"]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Yes, Tom.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Tom.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Except that it is a fire, it looks to me as stupid and blank
as everything else looks.  What do you see in it?  Not a circus?
subQuotationList: ['Except that it is a fire,', 'it looks to me as stupid and blank\nas everything else looks.  What do you see in it?  Not a circus?']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
I don't see anything in it, Tom, particularly.  But since I have been
looking at it, I have been wondering about you and me, grown up.
subQuotationList: ["I don't see anything in it, Tom, particularly.  But since I have been\nlooking at it, I have been wondering about you and me, grown up."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Wondering again!
subQuotationList: ['Wondering again!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
I have such unmanageable thoughts, that they
_will_ wonder.
subQuotationList: ['I have such unmanageable thoughts,', 'that they\n_will_ wonder.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Then I beg of you, Louisa, to do nothing of that description, for goodness'
sake, you inconsiderate girl, or I shall never hear the last of it from
your father.  And, Thomas, it is really shameful, with my poor head
continually wearing me out, that a boy brought up as you have been, and
whose education has cost what yours has, should be found encouraging his
sister to wonder, when he knows his father has expressly said that she is
not to do it.
subQuotationList:
['Then I beg of you, Louisa,', "to do nothing of that description, for goodness'
sake, you inconsiderate girl, or I shall never hear the last of it from
your father.  And, Thomas, it is really shameful, with my poor head
continually wearing me out, that a boy brought up as you have been, and
whose education has cost what yours has, should be found encouraging his
sister to wonder, when he knows his father has expressly said that she is
not to do it."]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Louisa, don't tell me, in my state of
health; for unless you had been encouraged, it is morally and physically
impossible that you could have done it.
subQuotationList: ["Louisa, don't tell me, in my state of\nhealth; for unless you had been encouraged, it is morally and physically\nimpossible that you could have done it."]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
referringExpression: her mother stopped her with the conclusive answer

quoteText:
I was encouraged by nothing, mother, but by looking at the red sparks
dropping out of the fire, and whitening and dying.  It made me think,
after all, how short my life would be, and how little I could hope to do
in it.
subQuotationList:
['I was encouraged by nothing, mother, but by looking at the red sparks
dropping out of the fire, and whitening and dying.  It made me think,
after all, how short my life would be, and how little I could hope to do
in it.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Nonsense! Nonsense!
Don't stand there and tell me such stuff, Louisa, to my face, when you
know very well that if it was ever to reach your father's ears I should
never hear the last of it.  After all the trouble that has been taken
with you!  After the lectures you have attended, and the experiments you
have seen!  After I have heard you myself, when the whole of my right
side has been benumbed, going on with your master about combustion, and
calcination, and calorification, and I may say every kind of ation that
could drive a poor invalid distracted, to hear you talking in this absurd
way about sparks and ashes!  I wish, yes, I really _do_ wish that I had never had a
family, and then you would have known what it was to do without me!
subQuotationList:
['Nonsense!', "Nonsense!
Don't stand there and tell me such stuff, Louisa, to my face, when you
know very well that if it was ever to reach your father's ears I should
never hear the last of it.  After all the trouble that has been taken
with you!  After the lectures you have attended, and the experiments you
have seen!  After I have heard you myself, when the whole of my right
side has been benumbed, going on with your master about combustion, and
calcination, and calorification, and I may say every kind of ation that
could drive a poor invalid distracted, to hear you talking in this absurd
way about sparks and ashes!  I wish,", 'yes, I really _do_ wish that I had never had a
family, and then you would have known what it was to do without me!']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
What is the first
principle of this science?
subQuotationList: ['What is the first\nprinciple of this science?']
speaker: Mr. M'choakumchild

quoteText:
To do unto others as I
would that they should do unto me.
subQuotationList: ['To do unto others as I\nwould that they should do unto me.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
referringExpression: she had only yesterday been set right by a prattler three feet high for returning

quoteText: must be kept to it.
subQuotationList: ['must be kept to it.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: It would be a fine thing to be you, Miss Louisa!
subQuotationList: ['It would be a fine thing to be you, Miss Louisa!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Do you think so?
subQuotationList: ['Do you think so?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I should know so much, Miss Louisa.  All that is difficult to me now,
would be so easy then.
subQuotationList: ['I should know so much, Miss Louisa.  All that is difficult to me now,\nwould be so easy then.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: You might not be the better for it, Sissy.
subQuotationList: ['You might not be the better for it, Sissy.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I should not be the worse,
Miss Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['I should not be the worse,\nMiss Louisa.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: I don't know that.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know that."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
You are more useful to my mother, and more pleasant with her than I can
ever be, You are pleasanter to yourself, than _I_ am
to _my_self.
subQuotationList: ['You are more useful to my mother, and more pleasant with her than I can\never be,', 'You are pleasanter to yourself, than _I_ am\nto _my_self.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: But, if you please, Miss Louisa, I am   O so stupid!
subQuotationList: ['But, if you please, Miss Louisa,', 'I am   O so stupid!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
You don't know, what a stupid girl I am.  All
through school hours I make mistakes.  Mr. and Mrs. M'Choakumchild call
me up, over and over again, regularly to make mistakes.  I can't help
them.  They seem to come natural to me.
subQuotationList:
["You don't know,", "what a stupid girl I am.  All
through school hours I make mistakes.  Mr. and Mrs. M'Choakumchild call
me up, over and over again, regularly to make mistakes.  I can't help
them.  They seem to come natural to me."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Mr. and Mrs. M'Choakumchild never make any mistakes themselves, I
suppose, Sissy?
subQuotationList: ["Mr. and Mrs. M'Choakumchild never make any mistakes themselves, I\nsuppose, Sissy?"]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: O no! They know everything.
subQuotationList: ['O no!', 'They know everything.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Tell me some of your mistakes.
subQuotationList: ['Tell me some of your mistakes.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I am almost ashamed, But to-day, for
instance, Mr. M'Choakumchild was explaining to us about Natural
Prosperity.
subQuotationList: ['I am almost ashamed,', "But to-day, for\ninstance, Mr. M'Choakumchild was explaining to us about Natural\nProsperity."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: National, I think it must have been,
subQuotationList: ['National, I think it must have been,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Yes, it was.   But isn't it the same?
subQuotationList: ["Yes, it was.   But isn't it the same?"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: You had better say, National, as he said so,
subQuotationList: ['You had better say, National, as he said so,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
National Prosperity.  And he said, Now, this schoolroom is a Nation.
And in this nation, there are fifty millions of money.  Isn't this a
prosperous nation?  Girl number twenty, isn't this a prosperous nation,
and a'n't you in a thriving state?
subQuotationList:
["National Prosperity.  And he said, Now, this schoolroom is a Nation.
And in this nation, there are fifty millions of money.  Isn't this a
prosperous nation?  Girl number twenty, isn't this a prosperous nation,
and a'n't you in a thriving state?"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: What did you say?
subQuotationList: ['What did you say?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Miss Louisa, I said I didn't know.  I thought I couldn't know whether it
was a prosperous nation or not, and whether I was in a thriving state or
not, unless I knew who had got the money, and whether any of it was mine.
But that had nothing to do with it.  It was not in the figures at all,
subQuotationList:
["Miss Louisa, I said I didn't know.  I thought I couldn't know whether it
was a prosperous nation or not, and whether I was in a thriving state or
not, unless I knew who had got the money, and whether any of it was mine.
But that had nothing to do with it.  It was not in the figures at all,"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: That was a great mistake of yours,
subQuotationList: ['That was a great mistake of yours,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Yes, Miss Louisa, I know it was, now.  Then Mr. M'Choakumchild said he
would try me again.  And he said, This schoolroom is an immense town, and
in it there are a million of inhabitants, and only five-and-twenty are
starved to death in the streets, in the course of a year.  What is your
remark on that proportion?  And my remark was   for I couldn't think of a
better one   that I thought it must be just as hard upon those who were
starved, whether the others were a million, or a million million.  And
that was wrong, too.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, Miss Louisa, I know it was, now.  Then Mr. M'Choakumchild said he
would try me again.  And he said, This schoolroom is an immense town, and
in it there are a million of inhabitants, and only five-and-twenty are
starved to death in the streets, in the course of a year.  What is your
remark on that proportion?  And my remark was   for I couldn't think of a
better one   that I thought it must be just as hard upon those who were
starved, whether the others were a million, or a million million.  And
that was wrong, too."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Of course it was.
subQuotationList: ['Of course it was.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Then Mr. M'Choakumchild said he would try me once more.  And he said,
Here are the stutterings
subQuotationList: ["Then Mr. M'Choakumchild said he would try me once more.  And he said,\nHere are the stutterings"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Statistics,
subQuotationList: ['Statistics,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Yes, Miss Louisa   they always remind me of stutterings, and that's
another of my mistakes   of accidents upon the sea.  And I find (Mr.
M'Choakumchild said) that in a given time a hundred thousand persons went
to sea on long voyages, and only five hundred of them were drowned or
burnt to death.  What is the percentage?  And I said, Miss; I said it was nothing.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, Miss Louisa   they always remind me of stutterings, and that's
another of my mistakes   of accidents upon the sea.  And I find (Mr.
M'Choakumchild said) that in a given time a hundred thousand persons went
to sea on long voyages, and only five hundred of them were drowned or
burnt to death.  What is the percentage?  And I said, Miss;", 'I said it was nothing.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Nothing, Sissy?
subQuotationList: ['Nothing, Sissy?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Nothing, Miss   to the relations and friends of the people who were
killed.  I shall never learn, And the worst of all is,
that although my poor father wished me so much to learn, and although I
am so anxious to learn, because he wished me to, I am afraid I don't like
it.
subQuotationList:
['Nothing, Miss   to the relations and friends of the people who were
killed.  I shall never learn,', "And the worst of all is,
that although my poor father wished me so much to learn, and although I
am so anxious to learn, because he wished me to, I am afraid I don't like
it."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Did your father know so much himself, that he wished you to be well
taught too, Sissy?
subQuotationList: ['Did your father know so much himself, that he wished you to be well\ntaught too, Sissy?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
No one hears
us; and if any one did, I am sure no harm could be found in such an
innocent question.
subQuotationList: ['No one hears\nus; and if any one did, I am sure no harm could be found in such an\ninnocent question.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
No, Miss Louisa, father knows very little indeed.  It's as much as he can do to
write; and it's more than people in general can do to read his writing.
Though it's plain to _me_.
subQuotationList: ['No, Miss Louisa,', "father knows very little indeed.  It's as much as he can do to\nwrite; and it's more than people in general can do to read his writing.\nThough it's plain to _me_."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Your mother?
subQuotationList: ['Your mother?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Father says she was quite a scholar.  She died when I was born.  She
was; she was a
dancer.
subQuotationList: ['Father says she was quite a scholar.  She died when I was born.  She\nwas;', 'she was a\ndancer.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Did your father love her?
subQuotationList: ['Did your father love her?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
O yes!  As dearly as he loves me.  Father loved me, first, for her sake.
He carried me about with him when I was quite a baby.  We have never been
asunder from that time.
subQuotationList: ['O yes!  As dearly as he loves me.  Father loved me, first, for her sake.\nHe carried me about with him when I was quite a baby.  We have never been\nasunder from that time.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe', 'Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText: Yet he leaves you now, Sissy?
subQuotationList: ['Yet he leaves you now, Sissy?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Only for my good.  Nobody understands him as I do; nobody knows him as I
do.  When he left me for my good   he never would have left me for his
own   I know he was almost broken-hearted with the trial.  He will not be
happy for a single minute, till he comes back.
subQuotationList:
['Only for my good.  Nobody understands him as I do; nobody knows him as I
do.  When he left me for my good   he never would have left me for his
own   I know he was almost broken-hearted with the trial.  He will not be
happy for a single minute, till he comes back.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText:
Tell me more about him, I will never ask you again.
Where did you live?
subQuotationList: ['Tell me more about him,', 'I will never ask you again.\nWhere did you live?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
We travelled about the country, and had no fixed place to live in.
Father's a; a clown.
subQuotationList: ["We travelled about the country, and had no fixed place to live in.\nFather's a;", 'a clown.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: To make the people laugh?
subQuotationList: ['To make the people laugh?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Yes.  But they wouldn't laugh sometimes, and then father cried.  Lately,
they very often wouldn't laugh, and he used to come home despairing.
Father's not like most.  Those who didn't know him as well as I do, and
didn't love him as dearly as I do, might believe he was not quite right.
Sometimes they played tricks upon him; but they never knew how he felt
them, and shrunk up, when he was alone with me.  He was far, far timider
than they thought!
subQuotationList:
["Yes.  But they wouldn't laugh sometimes, and then father cried.  Lately,
they very often wouldn't laugh, and he used to come home despairing.
Father's not like most.  Those who didn't know him as well as I do, and
didn't love him as dearly as I do, might believe he was not quite right.
Sometimes they played tricks upon him; but they never knew how he felt
them, and shrunk up, when he was alone with me.  He was far, far timider
than they thought!"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText: And you were his comfort through everything?
subQuotationList: ['And you were his comfort through everything?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I hope so, and father
said I was.  It was because he grew so scared and trembling, and because
he felt himself to be a poor, weak, ignorant, helpless man (those used to
be his words), that he wanted me so much to know a great deal, and be
different from him.  I used to read to him to cheer his courage, and he
was very fond of that.  They were wrong books   I am never to speak of them
here   but we didn't know there was any harm in them.
subQuotationList:
["I hope so, and father
said I was.  It was because he grew so scared and trembling, and because
he felt himself to be a poor, weak, ignorant, helpless man (those used to
be his words), that he wanted me so much to know a great deal, and be
different from him.  I used to read to him to cheer his courage, and he
was very fond of that.  They were wrong books   I am never to speak of them
here   but we didn't know there was any harm in them."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText: And he liked them?
subQuotationList: ['And he liked them?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
O very much!  They kept him, many times, from what did him real harm.
And often and often of a night, he used to forget all his troubles in
wondering whether the Sultan would let the lady go on with the story, or
would have her head cut off before it was finished.
subQuotationList:
['O very much!  They kept him, many times, from what did him real harm.
And often and often of a night, he used to forget all his troubles in
wondering whether the Sultan would let the lady go on with the story, or
would have her head cut off before it was finished.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: And your father was always kind?  To the last?
subQuotationList: ['And your father was always kind?  To the last?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Always, always!
subQuotationList: ['Always, always!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Kinder and kinder
than I can tell.  He was angry only one night, and that was not to me,
but Merrylegs.  Merrylegs; is his
performing dog.
subQuotationList:
['Kinder and kinder
than I can tell.  He was angry only one night, and that was not to me,
but Merrylegs.  Merrylegs;', 'is his
performing dog.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Why was he angry with the dog?
subQuotationList: ['Why was he angry with the dog?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Father, soon after they came home from performing, told Merrylegs to
jump up on the backs of the two chairs and stand across them   which is one
of his tricks.  He looked at father, and didn't do it at once.
Everything of father's had gone wrong that night, and he hadn't pleased
the public at all.  He cried out that the very dog knew he was failing,
and had no compassion on him.  Then he beat the dog, and I was
frightened, and said,
subQuotationList:
["Father, soon after they came home from performing, told Merrylegs to
jump up on the backs of the two chairs and stand across them   which is one
of his tricks.  He looked at father, and didn't do it at once.
Everything of father's had gone wrong that night, and he hadn't pleased
the public at all.  He cried out that the very dog knew he was failing,
and had no compassion on him.  Then he beat the dog, and I was
frightened, and said,"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText:
And he stopped,
and the dog was bloody, and father lay down crying on the floor with the
dog in his arms, and the dog licked his face.
subQuotationList: ['And he stopped,\nand the dog was bloody, and father lay down crying on the floor with the\ndog in his arms, and the dog licked his face.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Finish by telling me how your father left you, Sissy.  Now that I have
asked you so much, tell me the end.  The blame, if there is any blame, is
mine, not yours.
subQuotationList: ['Finish by telling me how your father left you, Sissy.  Now that I have\nasked you so much, tell me the end.  The blame, if there is any blame, is\nmine, not yours.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Dear Miss Louisa, I
came home from the school that afternoon, and found poor father just come
home too, from the booth.  And he sat rocking himself over the fire, as
if he was in pain.  And I said, (as he
did sometimes, like they all did), and he said, And when I came to stoop down and look up at his face, I saw that he was
crying.  The more I spoke to him, the more he hid his face; and at first
he shook all over, and said nothing but and
subQuotationList:
['Dear Miss Louisa,', 'I
came home from the school that afternoon, and found poor father just come
home too, from the booth.  And he sat rocking himself over the fire, as
if he was in pain.  And I said,', '(as he
did sometimes, like they all did), and he said,', 'And when I came to stoop down and look up at his face, I saw that he was
crying.  The more I spoke to him, the more he hid his face; and at first
he shook all over, and said nothing but', 'and']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']], [['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']], [['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']], []]

quoteText:
I am asking Sissy a few questions, Tom, You have
no occasion to go away; but don't interrupt us for a moment, Tom dear.
subQuotationList: ['I am asking Sissy a few questions, Tom,', "You have\nno occasion to go away; but don't interrupt us for a moment, Tom dear."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh! very well! Only father has brought old Bounderby
home, and I want you to come into the drawing-room.  Because if you come,
there's a good chance of old Bounderby's asking me to dinner; and if you
don't, there's none.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! very well!', "Only father has brought old Bounderby
home, and I want you to come into the drawing-room.  Because if you come,
there's a good chance of old Bounderby's asking me to dinner; and if you
don't, there's none."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: I'll come directly.
subQuotationList: ["I'll come directly."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: I'll wait for you, to make sure.
subQuotationList: ["I'll wait for you,", 'to make sure.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
At last poor father said that he had
given no satisfaction again, and never did give any satisfaction now, and
that he was a shame and disgrace, and I should have done better without
him all along.  I said all the affectionate things to him that came into
my heart, and presently he was quiet and I sat down by him, and told him
all about the school and everything that had been said and done there.
When I had no more left to tell, he put his arms round my neck, and
kissed me a great many times.  Then he asked me to fetch some of the
stuff he used, for the little hurt he had had, and to get it at the best
place, which was at the other end of town from there; and then, after
kissing me again, he let me go.  When I had gone down-stairs, I turned
back that I might be a little bit more company to him yet, and looked in
at the door, and said, Father
shook his head and said, and I left him sitting by the fire.  Then the thought
must have come upon him, poor, poor father! of going away to try
something for my sake; for when I came back, he was gone.
subQuotationList:
['At last poor father said that he had
given no satisfaction again, and never did give any satisfaction now, and
that he was a shame and disgrace, and I should have done better without
him all along.  I said all the affectionate things to him that came into
my heart, and presently he was quiet and I sat down by him, and told him
all about the school and everything that had been said and done there.
When I had no more left to tell, he put his arms round my neck, and
kissed me a great many times.  Then he asked me to fetch some of the
stuff he used, for the little hurt he had had, and to get it at the best
place, which was at the other end of town from there; and then, after
kissing me again, he let me go.  When I had gone down-stairs, I turned
back that I might be a little bit more company to him yet, and looked in
at the door, and said,', 'Father
shook his head and said,', 'and I left him sitting by the fire.  Then the thought
must have come upon him, poor, poor father! of going away to try
something for my sake; for when I came back, he was gone.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']], [['Signor Jupe']], [['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText: I say!  Look sharp for old Bounderby, Loo!
subQuotationList: ['I say!  Look sharp for old Bounderby, Loo!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
There's no more to tell, Miss Louisa.  I keep the nine oils ready for
him, and I know he will come back.  Every letter that I see in Mr.
Gradgrind's hand takes my breath away and blinds my eyes, for I think it
comes from father, or from Mr. Sleary about father.  Mr. Sleary promised
to write as soon as ever father should be heard of, and I trust to him to
keep his word.
subQuotationList:
["There's no more to tell, Miss Louisa.  I keep the nine oils ready for
him, and I know he will come back.  Every letter that I see in Mr.
Gradgrind's hand takes my breath away and blinds my eyes, for I think it
comes from father, or from Mr. Sleary about father.  Mr. Sleary promised
to write as soon as ever father should be heard of, and I trust to him to
keep his word."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Mr. Sleary'], ['Mr. Sleary'], ['Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText: Do look sharp for old Bounderby, Loo! He'll be off if you don't look sharp!
subQuotationList: ['Do look sharp for old Bounderby, Loo!', "He'll be off if you don't look sharp!"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
I beg your pardon,
sir, for being troublesome   but   have you had any letter yet about me?
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon,\nsir, for being troublesome   but   have you had any letter yet about me?']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
referringExpression: Sissy dropped a curtsey to Mr Gradgrind in the presence of his family and said

quoteText: No, Jupe, nothing of the sort,
subQuotationList: ['No, Jupe, nothing of the sort,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Good gracious bless me, how my poor head is vexed and worried by that
girl Jupe's so perseveringly asking, over and over again, about her
tiresome letters!  Upon my word and honour I seem to be fated, and
destined, and ordained, to live in the midst of things that I am never to
hear the last of.  It really is a most extraordinary circumstance that it
appears as if I never was to hear the last of anything!
subQuotationList:
["Good gracious bless me, how my poor head is vexed and worried by that
girl Jupe's so perseveringly asking, over and over again, about her
tiresome letters!  Upon my word and honour I seem to be fated, and
destined, and ordained, to live in the midst of things that I am never to
hear the last of.  It really is a most extraordinary circumstance that it
appears as if I never was to hear the last of anything!"]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
referringExpression: she would come a little way out of her wrappers like a feminine dormouse and say

quoteText: Yet I don't see Rachael, still!
subQuotationList: ["Yet I don't see Rachael, still!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Why, then, ha' missed her!
subQuotationList: ["Why, then, ha' missed her!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Rachael!
subQuotationList: ['Rachael!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool
referringExpression: he was very near this figure then fell into his former walk and called

quoteText: Ah, lad!  'Tis thou?
subQuotationList: ["Ah, lad!  'Tis thou?"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: I thought thou wast ahind me, Rachael?
subQuotationList: ['I thought thou wast ahind me, Rachael?']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: No.
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Early t'night, lass?
subQuotationList: ["Early t'night, lass?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
'Times I'm a little early, Stephen! 'times a little late.  I'm never to
be counted on, going home.
subQuotationList: ["'Times I'm a little early, Stephen! 'times a little late.  I'm never to\nbe counted on, going home."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Nor going t'other way, neither, 't seems to me, Rachael?
subQuotationList: ["Nor going t'other way, neither, 't seems to me, Rachael?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: No, Stephen.
subQuotationList: ['No, Stephen.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
We are such true friends, lad, and such old friends, and getting to be
such old folk, now.
subQuotationList: ['We are such true friends, lad, and such old friends, and getting to be\nsuch old folk, now.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: No, Rachael, thou'rt as young as ever thou wast.
subQuotationList: ["No, Rachael, thou'rt as young as ever thou wast."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
One of us would be puzzled how to get old, Stephen, without 't other
getting so too, both being alive, but, anyways,
we're such old friends, and t' hide a word of honest truth fro' one
another would be a sin and a pity.  'Tis better not to walk too much
together.  'Times, yes!  'Twould be hard, indeed, if 'twas not to be at
all,
subQuotationList:
["One of us would be puzzled how to get old, Stephen, without 't other
getting so too, both being alive,", "but, anyways,
we're such old friends, and t' hide a word of honest truth fro' one
another would be a sin and a pity.  'Tis better not to walk too much
together.  'Times, yes!  'Twould be hard, indeed, if 'twas not to be at
all,"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: 'Tis hard, anyways, Rachael.
subQuotationList: ["'Tis hard, anyways, Rachael."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Try to think not; and 'twill seem better.
subQuotationList: ["Try to think not; and 'twill seem better."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I've tried a long time, and 'ta'nt got better.  But thou'rt right; 't
might mak fok talk, even of thee.  Thou hast been that to me, Rachael,
through so many year: thou hast done me so much good, and heartened of me
in that cheering way, that thy word is a law to me.  Ah, lass, and a
bright good law!  Better than some real ones.
subQuotationList:
["I've tried a long time, and 'ta'nt got better.  But thou'rt right; 't
might mak fok talk, even of thee.  Thou hast been that to me, Rachael,
through so many year: thou hast done me so much good, and heartened of me
in that cheering way, that thy word is a law to me.  Ah, lass, and a
bright good law!  Better than some real ones."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Never fret about them, Stephen, Let the laws be.
subQuotationList: ['Never fret about them, Stephen,', 'Let the laws be.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Yes, Let 'em be.  Let everything be.
Let all sorts alone.  'Tis a muddle, and that's aw.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', "Let 'em be.  Let everything be.\nLet all sorts alone.  'Tis a muddle, and that's aw."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Always a muddle?
subQuotationList: ['Always a muddle?']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Ay, Rachael, lass,
awlus a muddle.  That's where I stick.  I come to the muddle many times
and agen, and I never get beyond it.
subQuotationList: ["Ay, Rachael, lass,\nawlus a muddle.  That's where I stick.  I come to the muddle many times\nand agen, and I never get beyond it."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool
referringExpression: He let them fall turned a smiling face upon her and said

quoteText: Good night, dear lass; good night!
subQuotationList: ['Good night, dear lass; good night!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Heaven's mercy, woman! Hast thou come back again!
subQuotationList: ["Heaven's mercy, woman!", 'Hast thou come back again!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Eigh, lad?  What, yo'r there?
subQuotationList: ["Eigh, lad?  What, yo'r there?"]
speaker: Mrs. Blackpool

quoteText:
Back agen? Yes!  And back agen.  Back agen ever and ever so often.  Back?
Yes, back.  Why not?
subQuotationList: ['Back agen?', 'Yes!  And back agen.  Back agen ever and ever so often.  Back?\nYes, back.  Why not?']
speaker: Mrs. Blackpool

quoteText:
I'll sell thee off again, and I'll sell thee off again, and I'll sell
thee off a score of times! Come awa' from th' bed!
subQuotationList: ["I'll sell thee off again, and I'll sell thee off again, and I'll sell\nthee off a score of times!", "Come awa' from th' bed!"]
speaker: Mrs. Blackpool

quoteText:
Come
awa! from 't.  'Tis mine, and I've a right to t'!
subQuotationList: ["Come\nawa! from 't.  'Tis mine, and I've a right to t'!"]
speaker: Mrs. Blackpool

quoteText:
Now, Stephen, what's the matter with _you_? Now, you know, we have never
had any difficulty with you, and you have never been one of the
unreasonable ones.  You don't expect to be set up in a coach and six, and
to be fed on turtle soup and venison, with a gold spoon, as a good many
of 'em do! and therefore I know already that you have not come here to make a
complaint.  Now, you know, I am certain of that, beforehand.
subQuotationList:
['Now, Stephen,', "what's the matter with _you_?", 'Now, you know,', "we have never
had any difficulty with you, and you have never been one of the
unreasonable ones.  You don't expect to be set up in a coach and six, and
to be fed on turtle soup and venison, with a gold spoon, as a good many
of 'em do!", 'and therefore I know already that you have not come here to make a
complaint.  Now, you know, I am certain of that, beforehand.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: No, sir, sure I ha' not coom for nowt o' th' kind.
subQuotationList: ["No, sir, sure I ha' not coom for nowt o' th' kind."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Very well, You're a steady Hand, and
I was not mistaken.  Now, let me hear what it's all about.  As it's not
that, let me hear what it is.  What have you got to say?  Out with it,
lad!
subQuotationList:
['Very well,', "You're a steady Hand, and
I was not mistaken.  Now, let me hear what it's all about.  As it's not
that, let me hear what it is.  What have you got to say?  Out with it,
lad!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I can go, Mr.
Bounderby, if you wish it,
subQuotationList: ['I can go, Mr.\nBounderby, if you wish it,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Now you know, this good lady is a born lady, a high lady.  You are not
to suppose because she keeps my house for me, that she hasn't been very
high up the tree   ah, up at the top of the tree!  Now, if you have got
anything to say that can't be said before a born lady, this lady will
leave the room.  If what you have got to say _can_ be said before a born
lady, this lady will stay where she is.
subQuotationList:
["Now you know, this good lady is a born lady, a high lady.  You are not
to suppose because she keeps my house for me, that she hasn't been very
high up the tree   ah, up at the top of the tree!  Now, if you have got
anything to say that can't be said before a born lady, this lady will
leave the room.  If what you have got to say _can_ be said before a born
lady, this lady will stay where she is."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
Sir, I hope I never had nowt to say, not fitten for a born lady to year,
sin' I were born mysen',
subQuotationList: ["Sir, I hope I never had nowt to say, not fitten for a born lady to year,\nsin' I were born mysen',"]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Very well, Fire away!
subQuotationList: ['Very well,', 'Fire away!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I ha' coom, to ask yo yor advice.  I need 't overmuch.  I
were married on Eas'r Monday nineteen year sin, long and dree.  She were
a young lass   pretty enow   wi' good accounts of herseln.  Well!  She went
bad   soon.  Not along of me.  Gonnows I were not a unkind husband to her.
subQuotationList:
["I ha' coom,", "to ask yo yor advice.  I need 't overmuch.  I
were married on Eas'r Monday nineteen year sin, long and dree.  She were
a young lass   pretty enow   wi' good accounts of herseln.  Well!  She went
bad   soon.  Not along of me.  Gonnows I were not a unkind husband to her."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I have heard all this before, She took to
drinking, left off working, sold the furniture, pawned the clothes, and
played old Gooseberry.
subQuotationList: ['I have heard all this before,', 'She took to\ndrinking, left off working, sold the furniture, pawned the clothes, and\nplayed old Gooseberry.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: I were patient wi' her.
subQuotationList: ["I were patient wi' her."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: The more fool you, I think,
subQuotationList: ['The more fool you, I think,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I were very patient wi' her.  I tried to wean her fra 't ower and ower
agen.  I tried this, I tried that, I tried t'other.  I ha' gone home,
many's the time, and found all vanished as I had in the world, and her
without a sense left to bless herseln lying on bare ground.  I ha' dun 't
not once, not twice   twenty time!
subQuotationList:
["I were very patient wi' her.  I tried to wean her fra 't ower and ower
agen.  I tried this, I tried that, I tried t'other.  I ha' gone home,
many's the time, and found all vanished as I had in the world, and her
without a sense left to bless herseln lying on bare ground.  I ha' dun 't
not once, not twice   twenty time!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
From bad to worse, from worse to worsen.  She left me.  She disgraced
herseln everyways, bitter and bad.  She coom back, she coom back, she
coom back.  What could I do t' hinder her?  I ha' walked the streets
nights long, ere ever I'd go home.  I ha' gone t' th' brigg, minded to
fling myseln ower, and ha' no more on't.  I ha' bore that much, that I
were owd when I were young.
subQuotationList:
["From bad to worse, from worse to worsen.  She left me.  She disgraced
herseln everyways, bitter and bad.  She coom back, she coom back, she
coom back.  What could I do t' hinder her?  I ha' walked the streets
nights long, ere ever I'd go home.  I ha' gone t' th' brigg, minded to
fling myseln ower, and ha' no more on't.  I ha' bore that much, that I
were owd when I were young."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
I ha' paid her to keep awa' fra' me.  These five year I ha' paid her.  I
ha' gotten decent fewtrils about me agen.  I ha' lived hard and sad, but
not ashamed and fearfo' a' the minnits o' my life.  Last night, I went
home.  There she lay upon my har-stone!  There she is!
subQuotationList:
["I ha' paid her to keep awa' fra' me.  These five year I ha' paid her.  I
ha' gotten decent fewtrils about me agen.  I ha' lived hard and sad, but
not ashamed and fearfo' a' the minnits o' my life.  Last night, I went
home.  There she lay upon my har-stone!  There she is!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I was acquainted with all this, you know, except
the last clause, long ago.  It's a bad job; that's what it is.  You had
better have been satisfied as you were, and not have got married.
However, it's too late to say that.
subQuotationList:
['I was acquainted with all this, you know,', "except
the last clause, long ago.  It's a bad job; that's what it is.  You had
better have been satisfied as you were, and not have got married.
However, it's too late to say that."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Was it an unequal marriage, sir, in point of years?
subQuotationList: ['Was it an unequal marriage, sir, in point of years?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
You hear what this lady asks.  Was it an unequal marriage in point of
years, this unlucky job of yours?
subQuotationList: ['You hear what this lady asks.  Was it an unequal marriage in point of\nyears, this unlucky job of yours?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Not e'en so.  I were one-and-twenty myseln; she were twenty nighbut.
subQuotationList: ["Not e'en so.  I were one-and-twenty myseln; she were twenty nighbut."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Indeed, sir? I
inferred, from its being so miserable a marriage, that it was probably an
unequal one in point of years.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, sir?', 'I\ninferred, from its being so miserable a marriage, that it was probably an\nunequal one in point of years.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
referringExpression: said Mrs Sparsit to her Chief

quoteText: Well?  Why don't you go on?
subQuotationList: ["Well?  Why don't you go on?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: I ha' coom to ask yo, sir, how I am to be ridded o' this woman.
subQuotationList: ["I ha' coom to ask yo, sir, how I am to be ridded o' this woman."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
What do you mean? What are you talking about?  You took her for better
for worse.
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?', 'What are you talking about?  You took her for better\nfor worse.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I mun' be ridden o' her.  I cannot bear 't nommore.  I ha' lived under
't so long, for that I ha' had'n the pity and comforting words o' th'
best lass living or dead.  Haply, but for her, I should ha' gone
battering mad.
subQuotationList:
["I mun' be ridden o' her.  I cannot bear 't nommore.  I ha' lived under
't so long, for that I ha' had'n the pity and comforting words o' th'
best lass living or dead.  Haply, but for her, I should ha' gone
battering mad."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
He wishes to be free, to marry the female of whom he speaks, I fear,
sir,
subQuotationList: ['He wishes to be free, to marry the female of whom he speaks, I fear,\nsir,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I do.  The lady says what's right.  I do.  I were a coming to 't.  I ha'
read i' th' papers that great folk (fair faw 'em a'!  I wishes 'em no
hurt!) are not bonded together for better for worst so fast, but that
they can be set free fro' _their_ misfortnet marriages, an' marry ower
agen.  When they dunnot agree, for that their tempers is ill-sorted, they
has rooms o' one kind an' another in their houses, above a bit, and they
can live asunders.  We fok ha' only one room, and we can't.  When that
won't do, they ha' gowd an' other cash, an' they can say
subQuotationList:
["I do.  The lady says what's right.  I do.  I were a coming to 't.  I ha'
read i' th' papers that great folk (fair faw 'em a'!  I wishes 'em no
hurt!) are not bonded together for better for worst so fast, but that
they can be set free fro' _their_ misfortnet marriages, an' marry ower
agen.  When they dunnot agree, for that their tempers is ill-sorted, they
has rooms o' one kind an' another in their houses, above a bit, and they
can live asunders.  We fok ha' only one room, and we can't.  When that
won't do, they ha' gowd an' other cash, an' they can say"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
an' they can go their separate ways.  We can't.  Spite
o' all that, they can be set free for smaller wrongs than mine.  So, I
mun be ridden o' this woman, and I want t' know how?
subQuotationList: ["an' they can go their separate ways.  We can't.  Spite\no' all that, they can be set free for smaller wrongs than mine.  So, I\nmun be ridden o' this woman, and I want t' know how?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: No how,
subQuotationList: ['No how,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: If I do her any hurt, sir, there's a law to punish me?
subQuotationList: ["If I do her any hurt, sir, there's a law to punish me?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Of course there is.
subQuotationList: ['Of course there is.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: If I flee from her, there's a law to punish me?
subQuotationList: ["If I flee from her, there's a law to punish me?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Of course there is.
subQuotationList: ['Of course there is.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: If I marry t'oother dear lass, there's a law to punish me?
subQuotationList: ["If I marry t'oother dear lass, there's a law to punish me?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Of course there is.
subQuotationList: ['Of course there is.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
If I was to live wi' her an' not marry her   saying such a thing could be,
which it never could or would, an' her so good   there's a law to punish
me, in every innocent child belonging to me?
subQuotationList: ["If I was to live wi' her an' not marry her   saying such a thing could be,\nwhich it never could or would, an' her so good   there's a law to punish\nme, in every innocent child belonging to me?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Of course there is.
subQuotationList: ['Of course there is.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Now, a' God's name, show me the law to help
me!
subQuotationList: ["Now, a' God's name,", 'show me the law to help\nme!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Hem!  There's a sanctity in this relation of life, and   and   it must be kept up.
subQuotationList: ["Hem!  There's a sanctity in this relation of life,", 'and   and   it must be kept up.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
No no, dunnot say that, sir.  'Tan't kep' up that way.  Not that way.
'Tis kep' down that way.  I'm a weaver, I were in a fact'ry when a chilt,
but I ha' gotten een to see wi' and eern to year wi'.  I read in th'
papers every 'Sizes, every Sessions   and you read too   I know it!   with
dismay   how th' supposed unpossibility o' ever getting unchained from one
another, at any price, on any terms, brings blood upon this land, and
brings many common married fok to battle, murder, and sudden death.  Let
us ha' this, right understood.  Mine's a grievous case, an' I want   if yo
will be so good   t' know the law that helps me.
subQuotationList:
["No no, dunnot say that, sir.  'Tan't kep' up that way.  Not that way.
'Tis kep' down that way.  I'm a weaver, I were in a fact'ry when a chilt,
but I ha' gotten een to see wi' and eern to year wi'.  I read in th'
papers every 'Sizes, every Sessions   and you read too   I know it!   with
dismay   how th' supposed unpossibility o' ever getting unchained from one
another, at any price, on any terms, brings blood upon this land, and
brings many common married fok to battle, murder, and sudden death.  Let
us ha' this, right understood.  Mine's a grievous case, an' I want   if yo
will be so good   t' know the law that helps me."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Stephen Blackpool', 'Mrs. Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Now, I tell you what! There _is_ such a law.
subQuotationList: ['Now, I tell you what!', 'There _is_ such a law.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
But it's not for you at all.  It costs money.  It costs a mint of
money.
subQuotationList: ["But it's not for you at all.  It costs money.  It costs a mint of\nmoney."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: How much might that be?
subQuotationList: ['How much might that be?']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Why, you'd have to go to Doctors' Commons with a suit, and you'd have to
go to a court of Common Law with a suit, and you'd have to go to the
House of Lords with a suit, and you'd have to get an Act of Parliament to
enable you to marry again, and it would cost you (if it was a case of
very plain sailing), I suppose from a thousand to fifteen hundred pound, Perhaps twice the money.
subQuotationList:
["Why, you'd have to go to Doctors' Commons with a suit, and you'd have to
go to a court of Common Law with a suit, and you'd have to go to the
House of Lords with a suit, and you'd have to get an Act of Parliament to
enable you to marry again, and it would cost you (if it was a case of
very plain sailing), I suppose from a thousand to fifteen hundred pound,", 'Perhaps twice the money.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], []]

quoteText: There's no other law?
subQuotationList: ["There's no other law?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Certainly not.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly not.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Why then, sir,
subQuotationList: ['Why then, sir,']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
"_tis_ a
muddle.  'Tis just a muddle a'toogether, an' the sooner I am dead, the
better. 'Tis a' a muddle!
subQuotationList: ['"_tis_ a\nmuddle.  \'Tis just a muddle a\'toogether, an\' the sooner I am dead, the\nbetter.', "'Tis a' a muddle!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Pooh, pooh!  Don't you talk nonsense, my good fellow, about things you don't understand; and don't you call the
Institutions of your country a muddle, or you'll get yourself into a real
muddle one of these fine mornings.  The institutions of your country are
not your piece-work, and the only thing you have got to do, is, to mind
your piece-work.  You didn't take your wife for fast and for loose; but
for better for worse.  If she has turned out worse   why, all we have got
to say is, she might have turned out better.
subQuotationList:
["Pooh, pooh!  Don't you talk nonsense, my good fellow,", "about things you don't understand; and don't you call the
Institutions of your country a muddle, or you'll get yourself into a real
muddle one of these fine mornings.  The institutions of your country are
not your piece-work, and the only thing you have got to do, is, to mind
your piece-work.  You didn't take your wife for fast and for loose; but
for better for worse.  If she has turned out worse   why, all we have got
to say is, she might have turned out better."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool']]]

quoteText: Tis a muddle,
subQuotationList: ['Tis a muddle,']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Now, I'll tell you what! With what I shall call your unhallowed opinions, you have been
quite shocking this lady: who, as I have already told you, is a born
lady, and who, as I have not already told you, has had her own marriage
misfortunes to the tune of tens of thousands of pounds   tens of Thousands
of Pounds! Now, you have always
been a steady Hand hitherto; but my opinion is, and so I tell you
plainly, that you are turning into the wrong road.  You have been
listening to some mischievous stranger or other   they're always about   and
the best thing you can do is, to come out of that.  Now you know;
subQuotationList:
["Now, I'll tell you what!", 'With what I shall call your unhallowed opinions, you have been
quite shocking this lady: who, as I have already told you, is a born
lady, and who, as I have not already told you, has had her own marriage
misfortunes to the tune of tens of thousands of pounds   tens of Thousands
of Pounds!', "Now, you have always
been a steady Hand hitherto; but my opinion is, and so I tell you
plainly, that you are turning into the wrong road.  You have been
listening to some mischievous stranger or other   they're always about   and
the best thing you can do is, to come out of that.  Now you know;"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
I can see as far into a
grindstone as another man; farther than a good many, perhaps, because I
had my nose well kept to it when I was young.  I see traces of the turtle
soup, and venison, and gold spoon in this.  Yes, I do! By the Lord Harry,
I do!
subQuotationList:
['I can see as far into a
grindstone as another man; farther than a good many, perhaps, because I
had my nose well kept to it when I was young.  I see traces of the turtle
soup, and venison, and gold spoon in this.  Yes, I do!', 'By the Lord Harry,
I do!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Yes, missus, it were me.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, missus,', 'it were me.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Yes, missus.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, missus.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: O yes, he were all that.
subQuotationList: ['O yes,', 'he were all that.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Yes, He were ett'n and drinking   as large and as
loud as a Hummobee. Only to see 'em?
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', "He were ett'n and drinking   as large and as\nloud as a Hummobee.", "Only to see 'em?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: 'Deed 'tis.  Don't do't too often, missus.
subQuotationList: ["'Deed 'tis.  Don't do't too often, missus."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Why   there's awmost nobbody but has their troubles, missus.
subQuotationList: ["Why   there's awmost nobbody but has their troubles, missus."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Times.  Just now and then,
subQuotationList: ['Times.  Just now and then,']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: A dozen year,
subQuotationList: ['A dozen year,']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: I am glad you have come at last, Stephen.  You are very late.
subQuotationList: ['I am glad you have come at last, Stephen.  You are very late.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: I ha' been walking up an' down.
subQuotationList: ["I ha' been walking up an' down."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I thought so.  But 'tis too bad a night for that.  The rain falls very
heavy, and the wind has risen.
subQuotationList: ["I thought so.  But 'tis too bad a night for that.  The rain falls very\nheavy, and the wind has risen."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I have been here once before, to-day, Stephen.  Landlady came round for
me at dinner-time.  There was some one here that needed looking to,
subQuotationList: ['I have been here once before, to-day, Stephen.  Landlady came round for\nme at dinner-time.  There was some one here that needed looking to,']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
deed she was right.  All wandering and lost, Stephen.
Wounded too, and bruised.
subQuotationList: ['deed she was right.  All wandering and lost, Stephen.\nWounded too, and bruised.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I came to do what little I could, Stephen; first, for that she worked
with me when we were girls both, and for that you courted her and married
her when I was her friend
subQuotationList: ['I came to do what little I could, Stephen; first, for that she worked\nwith me when we were girls both, and for that you courted her and married\nher when I was her friend']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
And next, for that I know your heart, and am right sure and certain that
'tis far too merciful to let her die, or even so much as suffer, for want
of aid.  Thou knowest who said,
subQuotationList: ["And next, for that I know your heart, and am right sure and certain that\n'tis far too merciful to let her die, or even so much as suffer, for want\nof aid.  Thou knowest who said,"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
There have been plenty to do that.  Thou
art not the man to cast the last stone, Stephen, when she is brought so
low.
subQuotationList: ['There have been plenty to do that.  Thou\nart not the man to cast the last stone, Stephen, when she is brought so\nlow.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: O Rachael, Rachael!
subQuotationList: ['O Rachael, Rachael!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Thou hast been a cruel sufferer, Heaven reward thee! I am thy poor friend, with all my heart and
mind.
subQuotationList: ['Thou hast been a cruel sufferer, Heaven reward thee!', 'I am thy poor friend, with all my heart and\nmind.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I will stay here, Stephen, till the bells go Three.  'Tis to be done again at three, and then she
may be left till morning.
subQuotationList: ['I will stay here, Stephen,', "till the bells go Three.  'Tis to be done again at three, and then she\nmay be left till morning."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: But thy rest agen to-morrow's work, my dear.
subQuotationList: ["But thy rest agen to-morrow's work, my dear."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I slept sound last night.  I can wake many nights, when I am put to it.
'Tis thou who art in need of rest   so white and tired.  Try to sleep in
the chair there, while I watch.  Thou hadst no sleep last night, I can
well believe.  To-morrow's work is far harder for thee than for me.
subQuotationList:
["I slept sound last night.  I can wake many nights, when I am put to it.
'Tis thou who art in need of rest   so white and tired.  Try to sleep in
the chair there, while I watch.  Thou hadst no sleep last night, I can
well believe.  To-morrow's work is far harder for thee than for me."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
She don't know me, Stephen; she just drowsily mutters and stares.  I
have spoken to her times and again, but she don't notice!  'Tis as well
so.  When she comes to her right mind once more, I shall have done what I
can, and she never the wiser.
subQuotationList:
["She don't know me, Stephen; she just drowsily mutters and stares.  I
have spoken to her times and again, but she don't notice!  'Tis as well
so.  When she comes to her right mind once more, I shall have done what I
can, and she never the wiser."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Blackpool']]]

quoteText: How long, Rachael, is 't looked for, that she'll be so?
subQuotationList: ["How long, Rachael, is 't looked for, that she'll be so?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Doctor said she would haply come to her mind to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['Doctor said she would haply come to her mind to-morrow.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: No, it was not that.  He had had a fright.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'it was not that.  He had had a fright.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: A fright?
subQuotationList: ['A fright?']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Ay, ay! coming in.  When I were walking.  When I were thinking.  When
I
subQuotationList: ['Ay, ay! coming in.  When I were walking.  When I were thinking.  When\nI']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Stephen!
subQuotationList: ['Stephen!']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
No!  Don't, please; don't.  Let me see thee setten by the bed.  Let me
see thee, a' so good, and so forgiving.  Let me see thee as I see thee
when I coom in.  I can never see thee better than so.  Never, never,
never!
subQuotationList:
["No!  Don't, please; don't.  Let me see thee setten by the bed.  Let me
see thee, a' so good, and so forgiving.  Let me see thee as I see thee
when I coom in.  I can never see thee better than so.  Never, never,
never!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
When she gets better, Stephen, 'tis to be hoped she'll leave thee to
thyself again, and do thee no more hurt.  Anyways we will hope so now.
And now I shall keep silence, for I want thee to sleep.
subQuotationList: ["When she gets better, Stephen, 'tis to be hoped she'll leave thee to\nthyself again, and do thee no more hurt.  Anyways we will hope so now.\nAnd now I shall keep silence, for I want thee to sleep."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Rachael, am I wakin' or dreamin' this
dreadfo' night?
subQuotationList: ["Rachael, am I wakin' or dreamin' this\ndreadfo' night?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
'Tis all well, Stephen.  I have been asleep, myself.  'Tis near three.
Hush!  I hear the bells.
subQuotationList: ["'Tis all well, Stephen.  I have been asleep, myself.  'Tis near three.\nHush!  I hear the bells."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I thought it must be near three, I am thankful I
stayed!  'Tis done now, when I have put this on.  There!  And now she's
quiet again.  The few drops in the basin I'll pour away, for 'tis bad
stuff to leave about, though ever so little of it.
subQuotationList:
['I thought it must be near three,', "I am thankful I
stayed!  'Tis done now, when I have put this on.  There!  And now she's
quiet again.  The few drops in the basin I'll pour away, for 'tis bad
stuff to leave about, though ever so little of it."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Thou'lt let me walk wi' thee at this hour, Rachael?
subQuotationList: ["Thou'lt let me walk wi' thee at this hour, Rachael?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: No, Stephen.  'Tis but a minute, and I'm home.
subQuotationList: ["No, Stephen.  'Tis but a minute, and I'm home."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Thou'rt not fearfo'; to leave me alone wi' her!
subQuotationList: ["Thou'rt not fearfo';", "to leave me alone wi' her!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Stephen?
subQuotationList: ['Stephen?']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Thou art an Angel.  Bless thee, bless thee!
subQuotationList: ['Thou art an Angel.  Bless thee, bless thee!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I am, as I have told thee, Stephen, thy poor friend.  Angels are not
like me.  Between them, and a working woman fu' of faults, there is a
deep gulf set.  My little sister is among them, but she is changed.
subQuotationList: ["I am, as I have told thee, Stephen, thy poor friend.  Angels are not\nlike me.  Between them, and a working woman fu' of faults, there is a\ndeep gulf set.  My little sister is among them, but she is changed."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Thou changest me from bad to good.  Thou mak'st me humbly wishfo' to be
more like thee, and fearfo' to lose thee when this life is ower, and a'
the muddle cleared awa'.  Thou'rt an Angel; it may be, thou hast saved my
soul alive!
subQuotationList:
["Thou changest me from bad to good.  Thou mak'st me humbly wishfo' to be
more like thee, and fearfo' to lose thee when this life is ower, and a'
the muddle cleared awa'.  Thou'rt an Angel; it may be, thou hast saved my
soul alive!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I coom home desp'rate.  I coom home wi'out a hope, and mad wi' thinking
that when I said a word o' complaint I was reckoned a unreasonable Hand.
I told thee I had had a fright.  It were the Poison-bottle on table.  I
never hurt a livin' creetur; but happenin' so suddenly upon 't, I thowt,
"How can _I_ say what I might ha' done to myseln, or her, or both!"
subQuotationList:
['I coom home desp'rate.  I coom home wi'out a hope, and mad wi' thinking
that when I said a word o' complaint I was reckoned a unreasonable Hand.
I told thee I had had a fright.  It were the Poison-bottle on table.  I
never hurt a livin' creetur; but happenin' so suddenly upon 't, I thowt,
"How can _I_ say what I might ha' done to myseln, or her, or both!"']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
But I see thee, Rachael, setten by the bed.  I ha' seen thee, aw this
night.  In my troublous sleep I ha' known thee still to be there.
Evermore I will see thee there.  I nevermore will see her or think o'
her, but thou shalt be beside her.  I nevermore will see or think o'
anything that angers me, but thou, so much better than me, shalt be by
th' side on't.  And so I will try t' look t' th' time, and so I will try
t' trust t' th' time, when thou and me at last shall walk together far
awa', beyond the deep gulf, in th' country where thy little sister is.
subQuotationList:
["But I see thee, Rachael, setten by the bed.  I ha' seen thee, aw this
night.  In my troublous sleep I ha' known thee still to be there.
Evermore I will see thee there.  I nevermore will see her or think o'
her, but thou shalt be beside her.  I nevermore will see or think o'
anything that angers me, but thou, so much better than me, shalt be by
th' side on't.  And so I will try t' look t' th' time, and so I will try
t' trust t' th' time, when thou and me at last shall walk together far
awa', beyond the deep gulf, in th' country where thy little sister is."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Louisa is becoming, almost a young woman. Thomas is becoming, almost a young man. Really, the period has arrived when Thomas ought
to go to Bounderby.
subQuotationList: ['Louisa is becoming,', 'almost a young woman.', 'Thomas is becoming,', 'almost a young man.', 'Really,', 'the period has arrived when Thomas ought\nto go to Bounderby.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I fear, Jupe, that your continuance at the school
any longer would be useless.
subQuotationList: ['I fear, Jupe,', 'that your continuance at the school\nany longer would be useless.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I am afraid it would, sir,
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid it would, sir,']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
I cannot disguise from you, Jupe, that the result of your probation there has disappointed me; has
greatly disappointed me.  You have not acquired, under Mr. and Mrs.
M'Choakumchild, anything like that amount of exact knowledge which I
looked for.  You are extremely deficient in your facts.  Your
acquaintance with figures is very limited.  You are altogether backward,
and below the mark.
subQuotationList:
['I cannot disguise from you, Jupe,', "that the result of your probation there has disappointed me; has
greatly disappointed me.  You have not acquired, under Mr. and Mrs.
M'Choakumchild, anything like that amount of exact knowledge which I
looked for.  You are extremely deficient in your facts.  Your
acquaintance with figures is very limited.  You are altogether backward,
and below the mark."]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']], [['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText:
I am sorry, sir, but I know it is quite true.  Yet I
have tried hard, sir.
subQuotationList: ['I am sorry, sir,', 'but I know it is quite true.  Yet I\nhave tried hard, sir.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Yes, yes, I believe you have tried hard; I have
observed you, and I can find no fault in that respect.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'yes, I believe you have tried hard; I have\nobserved you, and I can find no fault in that respect.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Thank you, sir.  I have thought sometimes; that
perhaps I tried to learn too much, and that if I had asked to be allowed
to try a little less, I might have
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, sir.  I have thought sometimes;', 'that\nperhaps I tried to learn too much, and that if I had asked to be allowed\nto try a little less, I might have']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
No, Jupe, no, No.  The course you pursued, you
pursued according to the system   the system   and there is no more to be
said about it.  I can only suppose that the circumstances of your early
life were too unfavourable to the development of your reasoning powers,
and that we began too late.  Still, as I have said already, I am
disappointed.
subQuotationList:

quoteText:
I wish I could have made a better acknowledgment, sir, of your kindness
to a poor forlorn girl who had no claim upon you, and of your protection
of her.
subQuotationList: ['I wish I could have made a better acknowledgment, sir, of your kindness\nto a poor forlorn girl who had no claim upon you, and of your protection\nof her.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Don't shed tears, Don't shed tears.  I don't
complain of you.  You are an affectionate, earnest, good young
woman   and   and we must make that do.

quoteText:
You are useful to Mrs. Gradgrind, and (in a generally pervading way) you
are serviceable in the family also; so I understand from Miss Louisa,
and, indeed, so I have observed myself.  I therefore hope, that you can make yourself happy in those relations.

quoteText: I should have nothing to wish, sir, if
subQuotationList: ['I should have nothing to wish, sir, if']

quoteText:
I understand you, you still refer to your father.
I have heard from Miss Louisa that you still preserve that bottle.  Well!
If your training in the science of arriving at exact results had been
more successful, you would have been wiser on these points.  I will say
no more.

quoteText: That's well,

quoteText: Are you there, Loo?

quoteText:
Dear Tom, how long it is since
you have been to see me!
subQuotationList: ['Dear Tom,', 'how long it is since\nyou have been to see me!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Why, I have been otherwise engaged, Loo, in the evenings; and in the
daytime old Bounderby has been keeping me at it rather.  But I touch him
up with you when he comes it too strong, and so we preserve an
understanding.  I say!  Has father said anything particular to you to-day
or yesterday, Loo?
subQuotationList:
