quoteText:
No, Tom.  But he told me to-night that he wished to do so in the
morning.
subQuotationList: ['No, Tom.  But he told me to-night that he wished to do so in the\nmorning.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Ah!  That's what I mean, Do you know where he is
to-night?
subQuotationList: ["Ah!  That's what I mean,", 'Do you know where he is\nto-night?']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: No.
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Then I'll tell you.  He's with old Bounderby.  They are having a regular
confab together up at the Bank.  Why at the Bank, do you think?  Well,
I'll tell you again.  To keep Mrs. Sparsit's ears as far off as possible,
I expect.
subQuotationList:
["Then I'll tell you.  He's with old Bounderby.  They are having a regular

I'll tell you again.  To keep Mrs. Sparsit's ears as far off as possible,
I expect."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: You are very fond of me, an't you, Loo?
subQuotationList: ["You are very fond of me, an't you, Loo?"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Indeed I am, Tom, though you do let such long intervals go by without
coming to see me.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed I am, Tom, though you do let such long intervals go by without\ncoming to see me.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Well, sister of mine, when you say that, you are near my
thoughts.  We might be so much oftener together   mightn't we?  Always
together, almost   mightn't we?  It would do me a great deal of good if you
were to make up your mind to I know what, Loo.  It would be a splendid
thing for me.  It would be uncommonly jolly!
subQuotationList:
['Well, sister of mine,', "when you say that, you are near my
thoughts.  We might be so much oftener together   mightn't we?  Always

quoteText:
I say, Loo!  I thought I'd come, and just hint to you what was going on:
though I supposed you'd most likely guess, even if you didn't know.  I
can't stay, because I'm engaged to some fellows to-night.  You won't
forget how fond you are of me?

quoteText: No, dear Tom, I won't forget.
subQuotationList: ["No, dear Tom, I won't forget."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: That's a capital girl, Good-bye, Loo.
subQuotationList: ["That's a capital girl,", 'Good-bye, Loo.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
My dear Louisa, I prepared you last night to give me
your serious attention in the conversation we are now going to have
together.  You have been so well trained, and you do, I am happy to say,
so much justice to the education you have received, that I have perfect
confidence in your good sense.  You are not impulsive, you are not
romantic, you are accustomed to view everything from the strong
dispassionate ground of reason and calculation.  From that ground alone,
I know you will view and consider what I am going to communicate.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Louisa,', 'I prepared you last night to give me
your serious attention in the conversation we are now going to have
together.  You have been so well trained, and you do, I am happy to say,
so much justice to the education you have received, that I have perfect
confidence in your good sense.  You are not impulsive, you are not
romantic, you are accustomed to view everything from the strong
dispassionate ground of reason and calculation.  From that ground alone,
I know you will view and consider what I am going to communicate.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Louisa, my dear, you are the subject of a proposal of marriage that has
been made to me.
subQuotationList: ['Louisa, my dear, you are the subject of a proposal of marriage that has\nbeen made to me.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
a proposal of
marriage, my dear.
subQuotationList: ['a proposal of\nmarriage, my dear.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I hear you, father.  I am attending, I assure you.
subQuotationList: ['I hear you, father.  I am attending, I assure you.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Well! you are even more dispassionate than I expected,
Louisa.  Or, perhaps, you are not unprepared for the announcement I have
it in charge to make?
subQuotationList: ['Well!', 'you are even more dispassionate than I expected,\nLouisa.  Or, perhaps, you are not unprepared for the announcement I have\nit in charge to make?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I cannot say that, father, until I hear it.  Prepared or unprepared, I
wish to hear it all from you.  I wish to hear you state it to me,
father.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot say that, father, until I hear it.  Prepared or unprepared, I\nwish to hear it all from you.  I wish to hear you state it to me,\nfather.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
What you say, my dear Louisa, is perfectly reasonable.  I have
undertaken then to let you know that   in short, that Mr. Bounderby has
informed me that he has long watched your progress with particular
interest and pleasure, and has long hoped that the time might ultimately
arrive when he should offer you his hand in marriage.  That time, to
which he has so long, and certainly with great constancy, looked forward,
is now come.  Mr. Bounderby has made his proposal of marriage to me, and
has entreated me to make it known to you, and to express his hope that
you will take it into your favourable consideration.
subQuotationList:
['What you say, my dear Louisa, is perfectly reasonable.  I have
undertaken then to let you know that   in short, that Mr. Bounderby has
informed me that he has long watched your progress with particular
interest and pleasure, and has long hoped that the time might ultimately
arrive when he should offer you his hand in marriage.  That time, to
which he has so long, and certainly with great constancy, looked forward,
is now come.  Mr. Bounderby has made his proposal of marriage to me, and
has entreated me to make it known to you, and to express his hope that
you will take it into your favourable consideration.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Father, do you think I love Mr. Bounderby?
subQuotationList: ['Father,', 'do you think I love Mr. Bounderby?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Well, my child, I   really   cannot take upon myself to say.
subQuotationList: ['Well, my child,', 'I   really   cannot take upon myself to say.']

quoteText:
Father, do you ask
me to love Mr. Bounderby?
subQuotationList: ['Father,', 'do you ask\nme to love Mr. Bounderby?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: My dear Louisa, no.  No.  I ask nothing.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Louisa, no.  No.  I ask nothing.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Father, does Mr. Bounderby ask me to love him?
subQuotationList: ['Father,', 'does Mr. Bounderby ask me to love him?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Really, my dear, it is difficult to answer your
question
subQuotationList: ['Really, my dear,', 'it is difficult to answer your\nquestion']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Difficult to answer it, Yes or No, father?
subQuotationList: ['Difficult to answer it, Yes or No, father?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Certainly, my dear.  Because;
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, my dear.  Because;']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
because the reply depends so materially, Louisa, on
the sense in which we use the expression.  Now, Mr. Bounderby does not do
you the injustice, and does not do himself the injustice, of pretending
to anything fanciful, fantastic, or (I am using synonymous terms)
sentimental.  Mr. Bounderby would have seen you grow up under his eyes,
to very little purpose, if he could so far forget what is due to your
good sense, not to say to his, as to address you from any such ground.
Therefore, perhaps the expression itself   I merely suggest this to you, my
dear   may be a little misplaced.
subQuotationList:
['because the reply depends so materially, Louisa, on
the sense in which we use the expression.  Now, Mr. Bounderby does not do
you the injustice, and does not do himself the injustice, of pretending
to anything fanciful, fantastic, or (I am using synonymous terms)

speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: What would you advise me to use in its stead, father?
subQuotationList: ['What would you advise me to use in its stead, father?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Why, my dear Louisa, I would advise you (since you ask me) to consider this question,
as you have been accustomed to consider every other question, simply as
one of tangible Fact.  The ignorant and the giddy may embarrass such
subjects with irrelevant fancies, and other absurdities that have no
existence, properly viewed   really no existence   but it is no compliment to
you to say, that you know better.  Now, what are the Facts of this case?
You are, we will say in round numbers, twenty years of age; Mr. Bounderby
is, we will say in round numbers, fifty.  There is some disparity in your
respective years, but in your means and positions there is none; on the
contrary, there is a great suitability.  Then the question arises, Is
this one disparity sufficient to operate as a bar to such a marriage?  In
considering this question, it is not unimportant to take into account the
statistics of marriage, so far as they have yet been obtained, in England
and Wales.  I find, on reference to the figures, that a large proportion
of these marriages are contracted between parties of very unequal ages,
and that the elder of these contracting parties is, in rather more than
three-fourths of these instances, the bridegroom.  It is remarkable as
showing the wide prevalence of this law, that among the natives of the
British possessions in India, also in a considerable part of China, and
among the Calmucks of Tartary, the best means of computation yet
furnished us by travellers, yield similar results.  The disparity I have
mentioned, therefore, almost ceases to be disparity, and (virtually) all
but disappears.
subQuotationList:
['Why, my dear Louisa,', 'I would advise you (since you ask me) to consider this question,
as you have been accustomed to consider every other question, simply as
one of tangible Fact.  The ignorant and the giddy may embarrass such
subjects with irrelevant fancies, and other absurdities that have no
existence, properly viewed   really no existence   but it is no compliment to

quoteText:
What do you recommend, father, that I should
substitute for the term I used just now?  For the misplaced expression?
subQuotationList: ['What do you recommend, father,', 'that I should\nsubstitute for the term I used just now?  For the misplaced expression?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Louisa, it appears to me that nothing can be
plainer.  Confining yourself rigidly to Fact, the question of Fact you
state to yourself is: Does Mr. Bounderby ask me to marry him?  Yes, he
does.  The sole remaining question then is: Shall I marry him?  I think
nothing can be plainer than that?
subQuotationList:
['Louisa,', 'it appears to me that nothing can be
plainer.  Confining yourself rigidly to Fact, the question of Fact you
state to yourself is: Does Mr. Bounderby ask me to marry him?  Yes, he
does.  The sole remaining question then is: Shall I marry him?  I think
nothing can be plainer than that?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Shall I marry him?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I marry him?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Precisely.  And it is satisfactory to me, as your father, my dear
Louisa, to know that you do not come to the consideration of that
question with the previous habits of mind, and habits of life, that
belong to many young women.
subQuotationList:
['Precisely.  And it is satisfactory to me, as your father, my dear
Louisa, to know that you do not come to the consideration of that
question with the previous habits of mind, and habits of life, that
belong to many young women.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: No, father, I do not.
subQuotationList: ['No, father,', 'I do not.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I now leave you to judge for yourself, I have
stated the case, as such cases are usually stated among practical minds;
I have stated it, as the case of your mother and myself was stated in its
time.  The rest, my dear Louisa, is for you to decide.
subQuotationList:
['I now leave you to judge for yourself,', 'I have
stated the case, as such cases are usually stated among practical minds;
I have stated it, as the case of your mother and myself was stated in its
time.  The rest, my dear Louisa, is for you to decide.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Are you consulting the chimneys of the
Coketown works, Louisa?
subQuotationList: ['Are you consulting the chimneys of the\nCoketown works, Louisa?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
There seems to be nothing there but languid and monotonous smoke.  Yet
when the night comes, Fire bursts out, father!
subQuotationList: ['There seems to be nothing there but languid and monotonous smoke.  Yet\nwhen the night comes, Fire bursts out, father!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Of course I know that, Louisa.  I do not see the application of the
remark.
subQuotationList: ['Of course I know that, Louisa.  I do not see the application of the\nremark.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Father, I have often thought that
life is very short.
subQuotationList: ['Father, I have often thought that\nlife is very short.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
referringExpression: She passed it away with a slight motion of her hand and concentrating her attention upon him again said

quoteText:
It is short, no doubt, my dear.  Still, the average duration of human
life is proved to have increased of late years.  The calculations of
various life assurance and annuity offices, among other figures which
cannot go wrong, have established the fact.
subQuotationList:
['It is short, no doubt, my dear.  Still, the average duration of human
life is proved to have increased of late years.  The calculations of
various life assurance and annuity offices, among other figures which
cannot go wrong, have established the fact.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I speak of my own life, father.
subQuotationList: ['I speak of my own life, father.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
O indeed?  Still, I need not point out to you,
Louisa, that it is governed by the laws which govern lives in the
aggregate.
subQuotationList: ['O indeed?  Still,', 'I need not point out to you,\nLouisa, that it is governed by the laws which govern lives in the\naggregate.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
While it lasts, I would wish to do the little I can, and the little I am
fit for.  What does it matter?
subQuotationList: ['While it lasts, I would wish to do the little I can, and the little I am\nfit for.  What does it matter?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: How, matter?  What matter, my dear?
subQuotationList: ['How, matter?  What matter, my dear?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
referringExpression: Mr Gradgrind seemed rather at a loss to understand the last four words replying

quoteText:
Mr. Bounderby, asks me to marry him.  The question I have to ask myself is, shall
I marry him?  That is so, father, is it not?  You have told me so,
father.  Have you not?
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bounderby,', 'asks me to marry him.  The question I have to ask myself is, shall\nI marry him?  That is so, father, is it not?  You have told me so,\nfather.  Have you not?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: Certainly, my dear.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, my dear.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Let it be so.  Since Mr. Bounderby likes to take me thus, I am satisfied
to accept his proposal.  Tell him, father, as soon as you please, that
this was my answer.  Repeat it, word for word, if you can, because I
should wish him to know what I said.
subQuotationList:
['Let it be so.  Since Mr. Bounderby likes to take me thus, I am satisfied
to accept his proposal.  Tell him, father, as soon as you please, that
this was my answer.  Repeat it, word for word, if you can, because I
should wish him to know what I said.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
It is quite right, my dear, to be
exact.  I will observe your very proper request.  Have you any wish in
reference to the period of your marriage, my child?
subQuotationList: ['It is quite right, my dear,', 'to be\nexact.  I will observe your very proper request.  Have you any wish in\nreference to the period of your marriage, my child?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: None, father.  What does it matter!
subQuotationList: ['None, father.  What does it matter!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Louisa, I have not considered it essential to ask you one question,
because the possibility implied in it appeared to me to be too remote.
But perhaps I ought to do so.  You have never entertained in secret any
other proposal?
subQuotationList:
['Louisa, I have not considered it essential to ask you one question,
because the possibility implied in it appeared to me to be too remote.
But perhaps I ought to do so.  You have never entertained in secret any
other proposal?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
referringExpression: He paused to look at her and still holding her hand said

quoteText:
Father, what other proposal can have
been made to _me_?  Whom have I seen?  Where have I been?  What are my
heart's experiences?
subQuotationList: ['Father,', "what other proposal can have\nbeen made to _me_?  Whom have I seen?  Where have I been?  What are my\nheart's experiences?"]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
My dear Louisa, You
correct me justly.  I merely wished to discharge my duty.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Louisa,', 'You\ncorrect me justly.  I merely wished to discharge my duty.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
What do _I_ know, father, of tastes
and fancies; of aspirations and affections; of all that part of my nature
in which such light things might have been nourished?  What escape have I
had from problems that could be demonstrated, and realities that could be
grasped?
subQuotationList:
['What do _I_ know, father,', 'of tastes
and fancies; of aspirations and affections; of all that part of my nature
in which such light things might have been nourished?  What escape have I
had from problems that could be demonstrated, and realities that could be
grasped?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
My dear, quite true, quite
true.
subQuotationList: ['My dear,', 'quite true, quite\ntrue.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Why, father, what a strange question to ask _me_!  The
baby-preference that even I have heard of as common among children, has
never had its innocent resting-place in my breast.  You have been so
careful of me, that I never had a child's heart.  You have trained me so
well, that I never dreamed a child's dream.  You have dealt so wisely
with me, father, from my cradle to this hour, that I never had a child's
belief or a child's fear.
subQuotationList:
['Why, father,', "what a strange question to ask _me_!  The
baby-preference that even I have heard of as common among children, has
never had its innocent resting-place in my breast.  You have been so
careful of me, that I never had a child's heart.  You have trained me so
well, that I never dreamed a child's dream.  You have dealt so wisely
with me, father, from my cradle to this hour, that I never had a child's
belief or a child's fear."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
My dear Louisa, you abundantly repay my care.  Kiss me,
my dear girl.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Louisa,', 'you abundantly repay my care.  Kiss me,\nmy dear girl.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I
may assure you now, my favourite child, that I am made happy by the sound
decision at which you have arrived.  Mr. Bounderby is a very remarkable
man; and what little disparity can be said to exist between you   if any   is
more than counterbalanced by the tone your mind has acquired.  It has
always been my object so to educate you, as that you might, while still
in your early youth, be (if I may so express myself) almost any age.
Kiss me once more, Louisa.  Now, let us go and find your mother.
subQuotationList:
['I
may assure you now, my favourite child, that I am made happy by the sound
decision at which you have arrived.  Mr. Bounderby is a very remarkable
man; and what little disparity can be said to exist between you   if any   is
more than counterbalanced by the tone your mind has acquired.  It has
always been my object so to educate you, as that you might, while still
in your early youth, be (if I may so express myself) almost any age.
Kiss me once more, Louisa.  Now, let us go and find your mother.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mrs. Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
Mrs. Gradgrind, allow me to present to you Mrs.
Bounderby.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Gradgrind,', 'allow me to present to you Mrs.\nBounderby.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Oh! so you have settled it!  Well, I'm sure I
hope your health may be good, Louisa; for if your head begins to split as
soon as you are married, which was the case with mine, I cannot consider
that you are to be envied, though I have no doubt you think you are, as
all girls do.  However, I give you joy, my dear   and I hope you may now
turn all your ological studies to good account, I am sure I do!  I must
give you a kiss of congratulation, Louisa; but don't touch my right
shoulder, for there's something running down it all day long.  And now
you see, I shall be worrying myself, morning, noon, and
night, to know what I am to call him!
subQuotationList:
['Oh!', "so you have settled it!  Well, I'm sure I
hope your health may be good, Louisa; for if your head begins to split as

speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Mrs. Gradgrind, what do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Gradgrind,', 'what do you mean?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Whatever I am to call him, Mr. Gradgrind, when he is married to Louisa!
I must call him something.  It's impossible, to be constantly addressing him
and never giving him a name.  I cannot call him Josiah, for the name is
insupportable to me.  You yourself wouldn't hear of Joe, you very well
know.  Am I to call my own son-in-law, Mister!  Not, I believe, unless
the time has arrived when, as an invalid, I am to be trampled upon by my
relations.  Then, what am I to call him!
subQuotationList:
["Whatever I am to call him, Mr. Gradgrind, when he is married to Louisa!
I must call him something.  It's impossible,", "to be constantly addressing him
and never giving him a name.  I cannot call him Josiah, for the name is
insupportable to me.  You yourself wouldn't hear of Joe, you very well
know.  Am I to call my own son-in-law, Mister!  Not, I believe, unless
the time has arrived when, as an invalid, I am to be trampled upon by my
relations.  Then, what am I to call him!"]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
As to the wedding, all I ask, Louisa, is,   and I ask it with a fluttering
in my chest, which actually extends to the soles of my feet,   that it may
take place soon.  Otherwise, I know it is one of those subjects I shall
never hear the last of.
subQuotationList:
['As to the wedding, all I ask, Louisa, is,   and I ask it with a fluttering
in my chest, which actually extends to the soles of my feet,   that it may
take place soon.  Otherwise, I know it is one of those subjects I shall
never hear the last of.']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
referringExpression: Mrs Gradgrind departed this life for the time being after delivering the following codicil to her remarks already executed

quoteText:
By George! if she takes it in the fainting way, I'll have the skin off
her nose, at all events!
subQuotationList: ['By George!', "if she takes it in the fainting way, I'll have the skin off\nher nose, at all events!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Good evening, Mr. Bounderby!
subQuotationList: ['Good evening, Mr. Bounderby!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Good evening, ma'am, good evening.
subQuotationList: ["Good evening, ma'am, good evening."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Your fireside, sir.  I freely
admit it.  It is for you to occupy it all, if you think proper.
subQuotationList: ['Your fireside, sir.  I freely\nadmit it.  It is for you to occupy it all, if you think proper.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Don't go to the North Pole, ma'am!
subQuotationList: ["Don't go to the North Pole, ma'am!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Thank you, sir,
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, sir,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am, I have no occasion to say to you, that
you are not only a lady born and bred, but a devilish sensible woman.
subQuotationList: ["Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am,", 'I have no occasion to say to you, that\nyou are not only a lady born and bred, but a devilish sensible woman.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Sir, this is indeed not the first time that you
have honoured me with similar expressions of your good opinion.
subQuotationList: ['Sir,', 'this is indeed not the first time that you\nhave honoured me with similar expressions of your good opinion.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am, I am going to astonish you.
subQuotationList: ["Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am,", 'I am going to astonish you.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Yes, sir?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: I am going, ma'am, to marry Tom Gradgrind's daughter.
subQuotationList: ["I am going, ma'am,", "to marry Tom Gradgrind's daughter."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Yes, sir, I hope you may be happy, Mr.
Bounderby.  Oh, indeed I hope you may be happy, sir!
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir,', 'I hope you may be happy, Mr.\nBounderby.  Oh, indeed I hope you may be happy, sir!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Now confound this
woman, who could have even guessed that she would take it in this way!
subQuotationList: ['Now confound this\nwoman, who could have even guessed that she would take it in this way!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
referringExpression: Bounderby far more disconcerted than if she had thrown her workbox at the mirror or swooned on the hearthrug corked up the smellingsalts tight in his pocket and thought

quoteText: I wish with all my heart, sir, that you may be in all respects very happy.
subQuotationList: ['I wish with all my heart, sir,', 'that you may be in all respects very happy.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Well, ma'am, I am obliged to
you.  I hope I shall be.
subQuotationList: ["Well, ma'am,", 'I am obliged to\nyou.  I hope I shall be.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
_Do_ you, sir! But
naturally you do; of course you do.
subQuotationList: ['_Do_ you, sir!', 'But\nnaturally you do; of course you do.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Well, ma'am, under these circumstances, I imagine
it would not be agreeable to a character like yours to remain here,
though you would be very welcome here.
subQuotationList: ["Well, ma'am,", 'under these circumstances, I imagine\nit would not be agreeable to a character like yours to remain here,\nthough you would be very welcome here.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Oh, dear no, sir, I could on no account think of that!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, dear no, sir, I could on no account think of that!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
However, ma'am, there are apartments at the Bank,
where a born and bred lady, as keeper of the place, would be rather a
catch than otherwise; and if the same terms
subQuotationList: ["However, ma'am,", 'there are apartments at the Bank,\nwhere a born and bred lady, as keeper of the place, would be rather a\ncatch than otherwise; and if the same terms']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I beg your pardon, sir.  You were so good as to promise that you would
always substitute the phrase, annual compliment.
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon, sir.  You were so good as to promise that you would\nalways substitute the phrase, annual compliment.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Well, ma'am, annual compliment.  If the same annual compliment would be
acceptable there, why, I see nothing to part us, unless you do.
subQuotationList: ["Well, ma'am, annual compliment.  If the same annual compliment would be\nacceptable there, why, I see nothing to part us, unless you do."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Sir, The proposal is like yourself, and if the
position I shall assume at the Bank is one that I could occupy without
descending lower in the social scale
subQuotationList: ['Sir,', 'The proposal is like yourself, and if the\nposition I shall assume at the Bank is one that I could occupy without\ndescending lower in the social scale']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Why, of course it is, If it was not, ma'am, you don't
suppose that I should offer it to a lady who has moved in the society you
have moved in.  Not that _I_ care for such society, you know!  But _you_
do.
subQuotationList:
['Why, of course it is,', "If it was not, ma'am, you don't
suppose that I should offer it to a lady who has moved in the society you
have moved in.  Not that _I_ care for such society, you know!  But _you_
do."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Mr. Bounderby, you are very considerate.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bounderby, you are very considerate.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
You'll have your own private apartments, and you'll have your coals and
your candles, and all the rest of it, and you'll have your maid to attend
upon you, and you'll have your light porter to protect you, and you'll be
what I take the liberty of considering precious comfortable,
subQuotationList:
["You'll have your own private apartments, and you'll have your coals and
your candles, and all the rest of it, and you'll have your maid to attend
upon you, and you'll have your light porter to protect you, and you'll be
what I take the liberty of considering precious comfortable,"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
Sir, say no more.  In yielding up my trust
here, I shall not be freed from the necessity of eating the bread of
dependence:
subQuotationList: ['Sir,', 'say no more.  In yielding up my trust\nhere, I shall not be freed from the necessity of eating the bread of\ndependence:']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
and I would
rather receive it from your hand, than from any other.  Therefore, sir, I
accept your offer gratefully, and with many sincere acknowledgments for
past favours.  And I hope, sir, I fondly hope that Miss Gradgrind may
be all you desire, and deserve!
subQuotationList:
['and I would
rather receive it from your hand, than from any other.  Therefore, sir, I
accept your offer gratefully, and with many sincere acknowledgments for
past favours.  And I hope, sir,', 'I fondly hope that Miss Gradgrind may
be all you desire, and deserve!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Ladies and gentlemen, I am Josiah Bounderby of Coketown.  Since you have
done my wife and myself the honour of drinking our healths and happiness,
I suppose I must acknowledge the same; though, as you all know me, and
know what I am, and what my extraction was, you won't expect a speech
from a man who, when he sees a Post, says and when he
sees a Pump, says and is not to be got to call a Post a
Pump, or a Pump a Post, or either of them a Toothpick.  If you want a
speech this morning, my friend and father-in-law, Tom Gradgrind, is a
Member of Parliament, and you know where to get it.  I am not your man.
However, if I feel a little independent when I look around this table
to-day, and reflect how little I thought of marrying Tom Gradgrind's
daughter when I was a ragged street-boy, who never washed his face unless
it was at a pump, and that not oftener than once a fortnight, I hope I
may be excused.  So, I hope you like my feeling independent; if you
don't, I can't help it.  I _do_ feel independent.  Now I have mentioned,
and you have mentioned, that I am this day married to Tom Gradgrind's
daughter.  I am very glad to be so.  It has long been my wish to be so.
I have watched her bringing-up, and I believe she is worthy of me.  At
the same time   not to deceive you   I believe I am worthy of her.  So, I
thank you, on both our parts, for the good-will you have shown towards
us; and the best wish I can give the unmarried part of the present
company, is this: I hope every bachelor may find as good a wife as I have
found.  And I hope every spinster may find as good a husband as my wife
has found.
subQuotationList:

quoteText: What a game girl you are, to be such a first-rate sister, Loo!
subQuotationList: ['What a game girl you are, to be such a first-rate sister, Loo!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Old Bounderby's quite ready, Time's up.  Good-bye!  I shall
be on the look-out for you, when you come back.  I say, my dear Loo!
AN'T it uncommonly jolly now!
subQuotationList: ["Old Bounderby's quite ready,", "Time's up.  Good-bye!  I shall\nbe on the look-out for you, when you come back.  I say, my dear Loo!\nAN'T it uncommonly jolly now!"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Thank you, Bitzer,
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, Bitzer,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Thank _you_, ma'am,
subQuotationList: ["Thank _you_, ma'am,"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: All is shut up, Bitzer?
subQuotationList: ['All is shut up, Bitzer?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: All is shut up, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["All is shut up, ma'am."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
And what, is the news of the
day?  Anything?
subQuotationList: ['And what,', 'is the news of the\nday?  Anything?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Well, ma'am, I can't say that I have heard anything particular.  Our
people are a bad lot, ma'am; but that is no news, unfortunately.
subQuotationList: ["Well, ma'am, I can't say that I have heard anything particular.  Our\npeople are a bad lot, ma'am; but that is no news, unfortunately."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: What are the restless wretches doing now?
subQuotationList: ['What are the restless wretches doing now?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Merely going on in the old way, ma'am.  Uniting, and leaguing, and
engaging to stand by one another.
subQuotationList: ["Merely going on in the old way, ma'am.  Uniting, and leaguing, and\nengaging to stand by one another."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: It is much to be regretted, that the united masters allow of any such class-combinations.
subQuotationList: ['It is much to be regretted,', 'that the united masters allow of any such class-combinations.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Yes, ma'am,
subQuotationList: ["Yes, ma'am,"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Being united themselves, they ought one and all to set their faces
against employing any man who is united with any other man,
subQuotationList: ['Being united themselves, they ought one and all to set their faces\nagainst employing any man who is united with any other man,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
They have done that, ma'am, but it rather fell
through, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["They have done that, ma'am,", "but it rather fell\nthrough, ma'am."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
I do not pretend to understand these things, my lot having been signally cast in a widely different sphere;
and Mr. Sparsit, as a Powler, being also quite out of the pale of any
such dissensions.  I only know that these people must be conquered, and
that it's high time it was done, once for all.
subQuotationList:
['I do not pretend to understand these things,', "my lot having been signally cast in a widely different sphere;
and Mr. Sparsit, as a Powler, being also quite out of the pale of any
such dissensions.  I only know that these people must be conquered, and
that it's high time it was done, once for all."]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Yes, ma'am, You couldn't put it clearer, I am
sure, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, ma'am,", "You couldn't put it clearer, I am\nsure, ma'am."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Has it been a busy day, Bitzer?
subQuotationList: ['Has it been a busy day, Bitzer?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Not a very busy day, my lady.  About an average day.
subQuotationList: ['Not a very busy day, my lady.  About an average day.']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
The clerks, are trustworthy,
punctual, and industrious, of course?
subQuotationList: ['The clerks,', 'are trustworthy,\npunctual, and industrious, of course?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Yes, ma'am, pretty fair, ma'am.  With the usual exception.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, ma'am, pretty fair, ma'am.  With the usual exception."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Pretty fair, ma'am.  With the usual exception, ma'am,
subQuotationList: ["Pretty fair, ma'am.  With the usual exception, ma'am,"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Ah   h!
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Mr. Thomas, ma'am, I doubt Mr. Thomas very much, ma'am, I don't like his
ways at all.
subQuotationList: ["Mr. Thomas, ma'am, I doubt Mr. Thomas very much, ma'am, I don't like his\nways at all."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Bitzer, do you
recollect my having said anything to you respecting names?
subQuotationList: ['Bitzer,', 'do you\nrecollect my having said anything to you respecting names?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I beg your pardon, ma'am.  It's quite true that you did object to names
being used, and they're always best avoided.
subQuotationList: ["I beg your pardon, ma'am.  It's quite true that you did object to names\nbeing used, and they're always best avoided."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Please to remember that I have a charge here, I hold a trust here, Bitzer, under Mr. Bounderby.
However improbable both Mr. Bounderby and myself might have deemed it
years ago, that he would ever become my patron, making me an annual
compliment, I cannot but regard him in that light.  From Mr. Bounderby I
have received every acknowledgment of my social station, and every
recognition of my family descent, that I could possibly expect.  More,
far more.  Therefore, to my patron I will be scrupulously true.  And I do
not consider, I will not consider, I cannot consider, that I
_should_ be scrupulously true, if I allowed names to be mentioned under
this roof, that are unfortunately   most unfortunately   no doubt of
that   connected with his.
subQuotationList:
['Please to remember that I have a charge here,', 'I hold a trust here, Bitzer, under Mr. Bounderby.
However improbable both Mr. Bounderby and myself might have deemed it
years ago, that he would ever become my patron, making me an annual
compliment, I cannot but regard him in that light.  From Mr. Bounderby I
have received every acknowledgment of my social station, and every
recognition of my family descent, that I could possibly expect.  More,
far more.  Therefore, to my patron I will be scrupulously true.  And I do
not consider, I will not consider, I cannot consider,', 'that I
_should_ be scrupulously true, if I allowed names to be mentioned under
this roof, that are unfortunately   most unfortunately   no doubt of
that   connected with his.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Bitzer'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']], [['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
No, Bitzer, say an individual, and I will hear
you; say Mr. Thomas, and you must excuse me.
subQuotationList: ['No, Bitzer,', 'say an individual, and I will hear\nyou; say Mr. Thomas, and you must excuse me.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
With the usual exception, ma'am, of an
individual.
subQuotationList: ["With the usual exception, ma'am,", 'of an\nindividual.']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Ah   h!
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
An individual, ma'am, has never been what he ought to
have been, since he first came into the place.  He is a dissipated,
extravagant idler.  He is not worth his salt, ma'am.  He wouldn't get it
either, if he hadn't a friend and relation at court, ma'am!
subQuotationList:
["An individual, ma'am,", "has never been what he ought to
have been, since he first came into the place.  He is a dissipated,
extravagant idler.  He is not worth his salt, ma'am.  He wouldn't get it
either, if he hadn't a friend and relation at court, ma'am!"]
speaker: Bitzer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: Ah   h!
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I only hope, ma'am, that his friend and relation may
not supply him with the means of carrying on.  Otherwise, ma'am, we know
out of whose pocket _that_ money comes.
subQuotationList: ["I only hope, ma'am,", "that his friend and relation may\nnot supply him with the means of carrying on.  Otherwise, ma'am, we know\nout of whose pocket _that_ money comes."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Ah   h!
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
He is to be pitied, ma'am.  The last party I have alluded to, is to be
pitied, ma'am,
subQuotationList: ["He is to be pitied, ma'am.  The last party I have alluded to, is to be\npitied, ma'am,"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Yes, Bitzer, I have always pitied the delusion,
always.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Bitzer,', 'I have always pitied the delusion,\nalways.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
As to an individual, ma'am, he is as improvident as any of the people in this town.  And you
know what _their_ improvidence is, ma'am.  No one could wish to know it
better than a lady of your eminence does.
subQuotationList: ["As to an individual, ma'am,", "he is as improvident as any of the people in this town.  And you\nknow what _their_ improvidence is, ma'am.  No one could wish to know it\nbetter than a lady of your eminence does."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
They would do well, to take example by you,
Bitzer.
subQuotationList: ['They would do well,', 'to take example by you,\nBitzer.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Thank you, ma'am.  But, since you do refer to me, now look at me, ma'am.
I have put by a little, ma'am, already.  That gratuity which I receive at
Christmas, ma'am: I never touch it.  I don't even go the length of my
wages, though they're not high, ma'am.  Why can't they do as I have done,
ma'am?  What one person can do, another can do.
subQuotationList:
["Thank you, ma'am.  But, since you do refer to me, now look at me, ma'am.
I have put by a little, ma'am, already.  That gratuity which I receive at
Christmas, ma'am: I never touch it.  I don't even go the length of my
wages, though they're not high, ma'am.  Why can't they do as I have done,
ma'am?  What one person can do, another can do."]
speaker: Bitzer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
As to their wanting recreations, ma'am, it's stuff and
nonsense.  _I_ don't want recreations.  I never did, and I never shall; I
don't like 'em.  As to their combining together; there are many of them,
I have no doubt, that by watching and informing upon one another could
earn a trifle now and then, whether in money or good will, and improve
their livelihood.  Then, why don't they improve it, ma'am!  It's the
first consideration of a rational creature, and it's what they pretend to
want.
subQuotationList:
["As to their wanting recreations, ma'am,", "it's stuff and
nonsense.  _I_ don't want recreations.  I never did, and I never shall; I
don't like 'em.  As to their combining together; there are many of them,
I have no doubt, that by watching and informing upon one another could
earn a trifle now and then, whether in money or good will, and improve
their livelihood.  Then, why don't they improve it, ma'am!  It's the
first consideration of a rational creature, and it's what they pretend to
want."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Pretend indeed!
subQuotationList: ['Pretend indeed!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I am sure we are constantly hearing, ma'am, till it becomes quite
nauseous, concerning their wives and families, Why look
at me, ma'am!  I don't want a wife and family.  Why should they?
subQuotationList: ["I am sure we are constantly hearing, ma'am, till it becomes quite\nnauseous, concerning their wives and families,", "Why look\nat me, ma'am!  I don't want a wife and family.  Why should they?"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Because they are improvident,
subQuotationList: ['Because they are improvident,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Yes, ma'am,
subQuotationList: ["Yes, ma'am,"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
that's where it is.  If they were more
provident and less perverse, ma'am, what would they do?  They would say, or as the case might be, ma'am
subQuotationList: ["that's where it is.  If they were more\nprovident and less perverse, ma'am, what would they do?  They would say,", 'or', "as the case might be, ma'am"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: To be sure,
subQuotationList: ['To be sure,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Thank you, ma'am, Would you wish
a little more hot water, ma'am, or is there anything else that I could
fetch you?
subQuotationList: ["Thank you, ma'am,", "Would you wish\na little more hot water, ma'am, or is there anything else that I could\nfetch you?"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Nothing just now, Bitzer.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing just now, Bitzer.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Thank you, ma'am.  I shouldn't wish to disturb you at your meals, ma'am,
particularly tea, knowing your partiality for it, but there's a
gentleman been looking up here for a minute or so, ma'am, and he has come
across as if he was going to knock.  That _is_ his knock, ma'am, no
doubt.
subQuotationList:
["Thank you, ma'am.  I shouldn't wish to disturb you at your meals, ma'am,
particularly tea, knowing your partiality for it,", "but there's a
gentleman been looking up here for a minute or so, ma'am, and he has come
across as if he was going to knock.  That _is_ his knock, ma'am, no
doubt."]
speaker: Bitzer
mentionTextsList: [['you', "ma'am", 'you', 'your', "ma'am", 'your'], [' a\ngentleman been looking up here for a minute or so', "ma'am", 'he', 'he', 'his', "ma'am"]]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
Yes, ma'am.  Would you wish the gentleman to be
shown in, ma'am?
subQuotationList: ["Yes, ma'am.  Would you wish the gentleman to be\nshown in, ma'am?"]
speaker: Bitzer
referringExpression: He stepped to the window and looking out and drawing in his head again confirmed himself with

quoteText: I don't know who it can be,
subQuotationList: ["I don't know who it can be,"]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: A stranger, ma'am, evidently.
subQuotationList: ["A stranger, ma'am, evidently."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
What a stranger can want at the Bank at this time of the evening, unless
he comes upon some business for which he is too late, I don't know, but I hold a charge in this establishment from Mr.
Bounderby, and I will never shrink from it.  If to see him is any part of
the duty I have accepted, I will see him.  Use your own discretion,
Bitzer.
subQuotationList:
["What a stranger can want at the Bank at this time of the evening, unless
he comes upon some business for which he is too late, I don't know,", 'but I hold a charge in this establishment from Mr.
Bounderby, and I will never shrink from it.  If to see him is any part of
the duty I have accepted, I will see him.  Use your own discretion,
Bitzer.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Bitzer'], ['Bitzer']]]

quoteText: If you please, ma'am, the gentleman would wish to see you,
subQuotationList: ["If you please, ma'am, the gentleman would wish to see you,"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: I believe, sir, you wished to see me.
subQuotationList: ['I believe, sir,', 'you wished to see me.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I beg your pardon, pray excuse
me.
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon,', 'pray excuse\nme.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Humph! Five and
thirty, good-looking, good figure, good teeth, good voice, good breeding,
well-dressed, dark hair, bold eyes.
subQuotationList: ['Humph!', 'Five and\nthirty, good-looking, good figure, good teeth, good voice, good breeding,\nwell-dressed, dark hair, bold eyes.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Please to be seated, sir,
subQuotationList: ['Please to be seated, sir,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Thank you.  Allow me.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you.  Allow me.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I left my servant at the railway
looking after the luggage   very heavy train and vast quantity of it in the
van   and strolled on, looking about me.  Exceedingly odd place.  Will you
allow me to ask you if it's _always_ as black as this?
subQuotationList:
["I left my servant at the railway
looking after the luggage   very heavy train and vast quantity of it in the
van   and strolled on, looking about me.  Exceedingly odd place.  Will you
allow me to ask you if it's _always_ as black as this?"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: In general much blacker,
subQuotationList: ['In general much blacker,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Is it possible!  Excuse me: you are not a native, I think?
subQuotationList: ['Is it possible!  Excuse me: you are not a native, I think?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
No, sir, It was once my good or ill fortune,
as it may be   before I became a widow   to move in a very different sphere.
My husband was a Powler.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir,', 'It was once my good or ill fortune,\nas it may be   before I became a widow   to move in a very different sphere.\nMy husband was a Powler.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Beg your pardon, really! Was   ?
subQuotationList: ['Beg your pardon, really!', 'Was   ?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: A Powler.
subQuotationList: ['A Powler.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Powler Family,
subQuotationList: ['Powler Family,']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: You must be very much bored here?
subQuotationList: ['You must be very much bored here?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I am the servant of circumstances, sir, and I have
long adapted myself to the governing power of my life.
subQuotationList: ['I am the servant of circumstances, sir,', 'and I have\nlong adapted myself to the governing power of my life.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Very philosophical, and very exemplary and
laudable, and
subQuotationList: ['Very philosophical,', 'and very exemplary and\nlaudable, and']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
May I be permitted to ask, sir, to what I am
indebted for the favour of
subQuotationList: ['May I be permitted to ask, sir,', 'to what I am\nindebted for the favour of']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Assuredly, Much obliged to you for reminding me.
I am the bearer of a letter of introduction to Mr. Bounderby, the banker.
Walking through this extraordinarily black town, while they were getting
dinner ready at the hotel, I asked a fellow whom I met; one of the
working people; who appeared to have been taking a shower-bath of
something fluffy, which I assume to be the raw material
subQuotationList:
['Assuredly,', 'Much obliged to you for reminding me.
I am the bearer of a letter of introduction to Mr. Bounderby, the banker.
Walking through this extraordinarily black town, while they were getting
dinner ready at the hotel, I asked a fellow whom I met; one of the
working people; who appeared to have been taking a shower-bath of
something fluffy, which I assume to be the raw material']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Raw material   where Mr. Bounderby, the banker, might reside.  Upon
which, misled no doubt by the word Banker, he directed me to the Bank.
Fact being, I presume, that Mr. Bounderby the Banker does _not_ reside in
the edifice in which I have the honour of offering this explanation?
subQuotationList:
['Raw material   where Mr. Bounderby, the banker, might reside.  Upon
which, misled no doubt by the word Banker, he directed me to the Bank.
Fact being, I presume, that Mr. Bounderby the Banker does _not_ reside in
the edifice in which I have the honour of offering this explanation?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: No, sir, he does not.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir,', 'he does not.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Thank you.  I had no intention of delivering my letter at the present
moment, nor have I. But strolling on to the Bank to kill time, and having
the good fortune to observe at the window,
subQuotationList: ['Thank you.  I had no intention of delivering my letter at the present\nmoment, nor have I. But strolling on to the Bank to kill time, and having\nthe good fortune to observe at the window,']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
a lady of a very superior and
agreeable appearance, I considered that I could not do better than take
the liberty of asking that lady where Mr. Bounderby the Banker _does_
live.  Which I accordingly venture, with all suitable apologies, to do.
subQuotationList:
['a lady of a very superior and
agreeable appearance, I considered that I could not do better than take
the liberty of asking that lady where Mr. Bounderby the Banker _does_
live.  Which I accordingly venture, with all suitable apologies, to do.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Banks, I know, are always suspicious, and officially must be, therefore I may
observe that my letter   here it is   is from the member for this
place   Gradgrind   whom I have had the pleasure of knowing in London. Thousand thanks, Of course you know the Banker
well?
subQuotationList:
['Banks, I know, are always suspicious, and officially must be,', 'therefore I may
observe that my letter   here it is   is from the member for this
place   Gradgrind   whom I have had the pleasure of knowing in London.', 'Thousand thanks,', 'Of course you know the Banker
well?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Yes, sir, In my dependent relation towards
him, I have known him ten years.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir,', 'In my dependent relation towards\nhim, I have known him ten years.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Quite an eternity!  I think he married Gradgrind's daughter?
subQuotationList: ["Quite an eternity!  I think he married Gradgrind's daughter?"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Yes, he had
that   honour.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'he had\nthat   honour.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: The lady is quite a philosopher, I am told?
subQuotationList: ['The lady is quite a philosopher, I am told?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Indeed, sir, _Is_ she?
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, sir,', '_Is_ she?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Excuse my impertinent curiosity, but you know the
family, and know the world.  I am about to know the family, and may have
much to do with them.  Is the lady so very alarming?  Her father gives
her such a portentously hard-headed reputation, that I have a burning
desire to know.  Is she absolutely unapproachable?  Repellently and
stunningly clever?  I see, by your meaning smile, you think not.  You
have poured balm into my anxious soul.  As to age, now.  Forty?  Five and
thirty?
subQuotationList:
['Excuse my impertinent curiosity,', 'but you know the
family, and know the world.  I am about to know the family, and may have
much to do with them.  Is the lady so very alarming?  Her father gives
her such a portentously hard-headed reputation, that I have a burning
desire to know.  Is she absolutely unapproachable?  Repellently and
stunningly clever?  I see, by your meaning smile, you think not.  You
have poured balm into my anxious soul.  As to age, now.  Forty?  Five and
thirty?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Louisa Bounderby', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mrs. Gradgrind', 'Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mrs. Gradgrind', 'Young Thomas'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
A chit, Not twenty when she
was married.
subQuotationList: ['A chit,', 'Not twenty when she\nwas married.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: I give you my honour, Mrs. Powler, that I never was so astonished in my life!
subQuotationList: ['I give you my honour, Mrs. Powler,', 'that I never was so astonished in my life!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I
assure you, Mrs. Powler, that the
father's manner prepared me for a grim and stony maturity.  I am obliged
to you, of all things, for correcting so absurd a mistake.  Pray excuse
my intrusion.  Many thanks.  Good day!
subQuotationList:
['I
assure you, Mrs. Powler,', "that the
father's manner prepared me for a grim and stony maturity.  I am obliged
to you, of all things, for correcting so absurd a mistake.  Pray excuse
my intrusion.  Many thanks.  Good day!"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: What do you think of the gentleman, Bitzer?
subQuotationList: ['What do you think of the gentleman, Bitzer?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Spends a deal of money on his dress, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["Spends a deal of money on his dress, ma'am."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: It must be admitted, that it's very tasteful.
subQuotationList: ['It must be admitted,', "that it's very tasteful."]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Yes, ma'am, if that's worth the money.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, ma'am,", "if that's worth the money."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Besides which, ma'am, he looks to me as if he gamed.
subQuotationList: ["Besides which, ma'am,", 'he looks to me as if he gamed.']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: It's immoral to game,
subQuotationList: ["It's immoral to game,"]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
It's ridiculous, ma'am, because the chances are against
the players.
subQuotationList: ["It's ridiculous, ma'am,", 'because the chances are against\nthe players.']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: O, you Fool!
subQuotationList: ['O, you Fool!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Jem, there's a good opening among the hard Fact fellows, and
they want men.  I wonder you don't go in for statistics.
subQuotationList: ["Jem, there's a good opening among the hard Fact fellows, and\nthey want men.  I wonder you don't go in for statistics."]

referringExpression: To whom this honourable and jocular member fraternally said

speaker: _unknowable
referringExpression: his brother put it about among the hard Fact fellows and said

quoteText: My name, sir, is Josiah Bounderby, of Coketown.
subQuotationList: ['My name, sir,', 'is Josiah Bounderby, of Coketown.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Coketown, sir, is not the
kind of place you have been accustomed to.  Therefore, if you will allow
me   or whether you will or not, for I am a plain man   I'll tell you
something about it before we go any further. Don't be too sure of that, I don't promise it.  First
of all, you see our smoke.  That's meat and drink to us.  It's the
healthiest thing in the world in all respects, and particularly for the
lungs.  If you are one of those who want us to consume it, I differ from
you.  We are not going to wear the bottoms of our boilers out any faster
than we wear 'em out now, for all the humbugging sentiment in Great
Britain and Ireland.
subQuotationList:
['Coketown, sir,', "is not the

me   or whether you will or not, for I am a plain man   I'll tell you

of all, you see our smoke.  That's meat and drink to us.  It's the

speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Josiah Bounderby']], [], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
Mr.
Bounderby, I assure you I am entirely and completely of your way of
thinking.  On conviction.
subQuotationList: ['Mr.\nBounderby, I assure you I am entirely and completely of your way of\nthinking.  On conviction.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I am glad to hear it, Now, you have heard a lot of
talk about the work in our mills, no doubt.  You have?  Very good.  I'll
state the fact of it to you.  It's the pleasantest work there is, and
it's the lightest work there is, and it's the best-paid work there is.
More than that, we couldn't improve the mills themselves, unless we laid
down Turkey carpets on the floors.  Which we're not a-going to do.
subQuotationList:
['I am glad to hear it,', "Now, you have heard a lot of
talk about the work in our mills, no doubt.  You have?  Very good.  I'll
state the fact of it to you.  It's the pleasantest work there is, and
it's the lightest work there is, and it's the best-paid work there is.
More than that, we couldn't improve the mills themselves, unless we laid
down Turkey carpets on the floors.  Which we're not a-going to do."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: Mr. Bounderby, perfectly right.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bounderby, perfectly right.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Lastly, as to our Hands.  There's not a Hand in this
town, sir, man, woman, or child, but has one ultimate object in life.
That object is, to be fed on turtle soup and venison with a gold spoon.
Now, they're not a-going   none of 'em   ever to be fed on turtle soup and
venison with a gold spoon.  And now you know the place.
subQuotationList:
['Lastly,', "as to our Hands.  There's not a Hand in this
town, sir, man, woman, or child, but has one ultimate object in life.
That object is, to be fed on turtle soup and venison with a gold spoon.
Now, they're not a-going   none of 'em   ever to be fed on turtle soup and
venison with a gold spoon.  And now you know the place."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Why, you see, it suits my disposition to have a
full understanding with a man, particularly with a public man, when I
make his acquaintance.  I have only one thing more to say to you, Mr.
Harthouse, before assuring you of the pleasure with which I shall
respond, to the utmost of my poor ability, to my friend Tom Gradgrind's
letter of introduction.  You are a man of family.  Don't you deceive
yourself by supposing for a moment that I am a man of family.  I am a bit
of dirty riff-raff, and a genuine scrap of tag, rag, and bobtail.
subQuotationList:
['Why, you see,', "it suits my disposition to have a
full understanding with a man, particularly with a public man, when I
make his acquaintance.  I have only one thing more to say to you, Mr.
Harthouse, before assuring you of the pleasure with which I shall
respond, to the utmost of my poor ability, to my friend Tom Gradgrind's
letter of introduction.  You are a man of family.  Don't you deceive
yourself by supposing for a moment that I am a man of family.  I am a bit
of dirty riff-raff, and a genuine scrap of tag, rag, and bobtail."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
So now, we may shake hands on equal terms.  I say,
equal terms, because although I know what I am, and the exact depth of
the gutter I have lifted myself out of, better than any man does, I am as
proud as you are.  I am just as proud as you are.  Having now asserted my
independence in a proper manner, I may come to how do you find yourself,
and I hope you're pretty well.
subQuotationList:
['So now,', "we may shake hands on equal terms.  I say,
equal terms, because although I know what I am, and the exact depth of
the gutter I have lifted myself out of, better than any man does, I am as
proud as you are.  I am just as proud as you are.  Having now asserted my
independence in a proper manner, I may come to how do you find yourself,
and I hope you're pretty well."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
Perhaps you know, or perhaps you don't know, I married Tom
Gradgrind's daughter.  If you have nothing better to do than to walk up
town with me, I shall be glad to introduce you to Tom Gradgrind's
daughter.
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps you know,', "or perhaps you don't know, I married Tom
Gradgrind's daughter.  If you have nothing better to do than to walk up
town with me, I shall be glad to introduce you to Tom Gradgrind's
daughter."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Mr. Bounderby, you anticipate my dearest wishes.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bounderby,', 'you anticipate my dearest wishes.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
This, sir, is my wife, Mrs. Bounderby: Tom Gradgrind's
eldest daughter.  Loo, Mr. James Harthouse.  Mr. Harthouse has joined
your father's muster-roll.  If he is not Tom Gradgrind's colleague before
long, I believe we shall at least hear of him in connexion with one of
our neighbouring towns.  You observe, Mr. Harthouse, that my wife is my
junior.  I don't know what she saw in me to marry me, but she saw
something in me, I suppose, or she wouldn't have married me.  She has
lots of expensive knowledge, sir, political and otherwise.  If you want
to cram for anything, I should be troubled to recommend you to a better
adviser than Loo Bounderby.
subQuotationList:
['This, sir,', "is my wife, Mrs. Bounderby: Tom Gradgrind's

quoteText:
Come! If you're in the complimentary line, you'll get
on here, for you'll meet with no competition.  I have never been in the
way of learning compliments myself, and I don't profess to understand the
art of paying 'em.  In fact, despise 'em.  But, your bringing-up was
different from mine; mine was a real thing, by George!  You're a
gentleman, and I don't pretend to be one.  I am Josiah Bounderby of
Coketown, and that's enough for me.  However, though I am not influenced
by manners and station, Loo Bounderby may be.  She hadn't my
advantages   disadvantages you would call 'em, but I call 'em advantages   so
you'll not waste your power, I dare say.

advantages   disadvantages you would call 'em, but I call 'em advantages   so
you'll not waste your power, I dare say."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Mr. Bounderby, is a noble
animal in a comparatively natural state, quite free from the harness in
which a conventional hack like myself works.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bounderby,', 'is a noble\nanimal in a comparatively natural state, quite free from the harness in\nwhich a conventional hack like myself works.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
You respect Mr. Bounderby very much, It is
natural that you should.
subQuotationList: ['You respect Mr. Bounderby very much,', 'It is\nnatural that you should.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Now, how am I to take this?
subQuotationList: ['Now, how am I to take this?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
referringExpression: He was disgracefully thrown out for a gentleman who had seen so much of the world and thought

quoteText:
You are going to devote yourself, as I gather from what Mr. Bounderby
has said, to the service of your country.  You have made up your mind, to show the nation the way out of all its
difficulties.
subQuotationList: ['You are going to devote yourself, as I gather from what Mr. Bounderby\nhas said, to the service of your country.  You have made up your mind,', 'to show the nation the way out of all its\ndifficulties.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], []]

quoteText:
Mrs. Bounderby, upon my honour, no.  I will
make no such pretence to you.  I have seen a little, here and there, up
and down; I have found it all to be very worthless, as everybody has, and
as some confess they have, and some do not; and I am going in for your
respected father's opinions   really because I have no choice of opinions,
and may as well back them as anything else.
subQuotationList:
['Mrs. Bounderby,', "upon my honour, no.  I will
make no such pretence to you.  I have seen a little, here and there, up
and down; I have found it all to be very worthless, as everybody has, and
as some confess they have, and some do not; and I am going in for your
respected father's opinions   really because I have no choice of opinions,
and may as well back them as anything else."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Have you none of your own?
subQuotationList: ['Have you none of your own?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I have not so much as the slightest predilection left.  I assure you I
attach not the least importance to any opinions.  The result of the
varieties of boredom I have undergone, is a conviction (unless conviction
is too industrious a word for the lazy sentiment I entertain on the
subject), that any set of ideas will do just as much good as any other
set, and just as much harm as any other set.  There's an English family
with a charming Italian motto.  What will be, will be.  It's the only
truth going!
subQuotationList:
["I have not so much as the slightest predilection left.  I assure you I
attach not the least importance to any opinions.  The result of the

subject), that any set of ideas will do just as much good as any other
set, and just as much harm as any other set.  There's an English family
with a charming Italian motto.  What will be, will be.  It's the only
truth going!"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
The side that can prove anything in a line of units,
tens, hundreds, and thousands, Mrs. Bounderby, seems to me to afford the
most fun, and to give a man the best chance.  I am quite as much attached
to it as if I believed it.  I am quite ready to go in for it, to the same
extent as if I believed it.  And what more could I possibly do, if I did
believe it!
subQuotationList:
['The side that can prove anything in a line of units,
tens, hundreds, and thousands, Mrs. Bounderby, seems to me to afford the
most fun, and to give a man the best chance.  I am quite as much attached

extent as if I believed it.  And what more could I possibly do, if I did
believe it!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
referringExpression: He followed up the advantage by saying

quoteText: You are a singular politician,
subQuotationList: ['You are a singular politician,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Pardon me; I have not even that merit.  We are the largest party in the
state, I assure you, Mrs. Bounderby, if we all fell out of our adopted
ranks and were reviewed together.
subQuotationList: ['Pardon me; I have not even that merit.  We are the largest party in the\nstate, I assure you, Mrs. Bounderby, if we all fell out of our adopted\nranks and were reviewed together.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: charming!
subQuotationList: ['charming!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
referringExpression: Jem in a languid manner received with

quoteText:
Is there nothing, is there nothing that
will move that face?
subQuotationList: ['Is there nothing,', 'is there nothing that\nwill move that face?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Ay, ay? This whelp is the only creature she
cares for.  So, so!
subQuotationList: ['Ay, ay?', 'This whelp is the only creature she\ncares for.  So, so!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
When I was your age, young Tom, I was punctual, or I
got no dinner!
subQuotationList: ['When I was your age, young Tom,', 'I was punctual, or I\ngot no dinner!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
When you were my age, you hadn't a wrong balance to get
right, and hadn't to dress afterwards.
subQuotationList: ['When you were my age,', "you hadn't a wrong balance to get\nright, and hadn't to dress afterwards."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Never mind that now,
subQuotationList: ['Never mind that now,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Well, then, Don't begin with me.
subQuotationList: ['Well, then,', "Don't begin with me."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Mrs. Bounderby, your brother's face is quite familiar to me.  Can I have
seen him abroad?  Or at some public school, perhaps?
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Bounderby,', "your brother's face is quite familiar to me.  Can I have\nseen him abroad?  Or at some public school, perhaps?"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
No, he has never been abroad yet, and
was educated here, at home.  Tom, love, I am telling Mr. Harthouse that
he never saw you abroad.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'he has never been abroad yet, and\nwas educated here, at home.  Tom, love, I am telling Mr. Harthouse that\nhe never saw you abroad.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Young Thomas'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText: No such luck, sir,
subQuotationList: ['No such luck, sir,']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
So much the more is this whelp the only
creature she has ever cared for, So much the more.  So much the more.
subQuotationList: ['So much the more is this whelp the only\ncreature she has ever cared for,', 'So much the more.  So much the more.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Do you smoke?
subQuotationList: ['Do you smoke?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: I believe you!
subQuotationList: ['I believe you!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
He don't seem to care about his
dress, and yet how capitally he does it.  What an easy
swell he is!
subQuotationList: ["He don't seem to care about his\ndress,", 'and yet how capitally he does it.  What an easy\nswell he is!']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
Thank'ee, Thank'ee.  Well, Mr. Harthouse, I hope you have
had about a dose of old Bounderby to-night.
subQuotationList: ["Thank'ee,", "Thank'ee.  Well, Mr. Harthouse, I hope you have\nhad about a dose of old Bounderby to-night."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: A very good fellow indeed!
subQuotationList: ['A very good fellow indeed!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: You think so, don't you?
subQuotationList: ["You think so, don't you?"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: What a comical brother-in-law you are!
subQuotationList: ['What a comical brother-in-law you are!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: What a comical brother-in-law old Bounderby is, I think you mean,
subQuotationList: ['What a comical brother-in-law old Bounderby is, I think you mean,']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: You are a piece of caustic, Tom,
subQuotationList: ['You are a piece of caustic, Tom,']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Oh!  I don't care for old Bounderby, if you mean that.  I
have always called old Bounderby by the same name when I have talked
about him, and I have always thought of him in the same way.  I am not
going to begin to be polite now, about old Bounderby.  It would be rather
late in the day.
subQuotationList:
["Oh!  I don't care for old Bounderby,", 'if you mean that.  I

Don't mind me, but take care when his wife is by, you
know.
subQuotationList: ["Don't mind me,", 'but take care when his wife is by, you\nknow.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: His wife? My sister Loo?  O yes! My sister Loo? _She_ never cared for old Bounderby.
subQuotationList: ['His wife?', 'My sister Loo?  O yes!', 'My sister Loo?', '_She_ never cared for old Bounderby.']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionTextsList: [['His wife'], ['My sister Loo'], ['My sister Loo'], ['She', 'old Bounderby']]

quoteText:
That's the past tense, Tom, We are in the present tense,
now.
subQuotationList: ["That's the past tense, Tom,", 'We are in the present tense,\nnow.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

subQuotationList: ['Verb neuter, not to care.  Indicative mood, present tense.  First person\nsingular, I do not care; second person singular, thou dost not care;\nthird person singular, she does not care,']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Good!  Very quaint! Though you don't mean it.
subQuotationList: ['Good!  Very quaint!', "Though you don't mean it."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
But I _do_ mean it, Upon my honour!  Why, you won't tell
me, Mr. Harthouse, that you really suppose my sister Loo does care for
old Bounderby.
subQuotationList: ['But I _do_ mean it,', "Upon my honour!  Why, you won't tell\nme, Mr. Harthouse, that you really suppose my sister Loo does care for\nold Bounderby."]
