quoteText:
My dear fellow, what am I bound to suppose, when I
find two married people living in harmony and happiness?
subQuotationList: ['My dear fellow,', 'what am I bound to suppose, when I\nfind two married people living in harmony and happiness?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
You know our governor, Mr. Harthouse, and therefore, you
needn't be surprised that Loo married old Bounderby.  She never had a
lover, and the governor proposed old Bounderby, and she took him.
subQuotationList: ['You know our governor, Mr. Harthouse,', "and therefore, you\nneedn't be surprised that Loo married old Bounderby.  She never had a\nlover, and the governor proposed old Bounderby, and she took him."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Very dutiful in your interesting sister,
subQuotationList: ['Very dutiful in your interesting sister,']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Yes, but she wouldn't have been as dutiful, and it would not have come
off as easily, if it hadn't been for me.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, but she wouldn't have been as dutiful, and it would not have come\noff as easily,", "if it hadn't been for me."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
_I_ persuaded her, I
was stuck into old Bounderby's bank (where I never wanted to be), and I
knew I should get into scrapes there, if she put old Bounderby's pipe
out; so I told her my wishes, and she came into them.  She would do
anything for me.  It was very game of her, wasn't it?
subQuotationList:
['_I_ persuaded her,', "I
was stuck into old Bounderby's bank (where I never wanted to be), and I

speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: It was charming, Tom!
subQuotationList: ['It was charming, Tom!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Not that it was altogether so important to her as it was to me, because my liberty and comfort, and perhaps my
getting on, depended on it; and she had no other lover, and staying at
home was like staying in jail   especially when I was gone.  It wasn't as
if she gave up another lover for old Bounderby; but still it was a good
thing in her.
subQuotationList:
['Not that it was altogether so important to her as it was to me,', "because my liberty and comfort, and perhaps my
getting on, depended on it; and she had no other lover, and staying at
home was like staying in jail   especially when I was gone.  It wasn't as
if she gave up another lover for old Bounderby; but still it was a good
thing in her."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Perfectly delightful.  And she gets on so placidly.
subQuotationList: ['Perfectly delightful.  And she gets on so placidly.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Oh, she's a regular girl.
A girl can get on anywhere.  She has settled down to the life, and _she_
don't mind.  It does just as well as another.  Besides, though Loo is a
girl, she's not a common sort of girl.  She can shut herself up within
herself, and think   as I have often known her sit and watch the fire   for
an hour at a stretch.
subQuotationList:
['Oh,', "she's a regular girl.
A girl can get on anywhere.  She has settled down to the life, and _she_
don't mind.  It does just as well as another.  Besides, though Loo is a
girl, she's not a common sort of girl.  She can shut herself up within
herself, and think   as I have often known her sit and watch the fire   for
an hour at a stretch."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Ay, ay?  Has resources of her own,
subQuotationList: ['Ay, ay?  Has resources of her own,']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Not so much of that as you may suppose, for our governor
had her crammed with all sorts of dry bones and sawdust.  It's his
system.
subQuotationList: ['Not so much of that as you may suppose,', "for our governor\nhad her crammed with all sorts of dry bones and sawdust.  It's his\nsystem."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Formed his daughter on his own model?
subQuotationList: ['Formed his daughter on his own model?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: His daughter?  Ah! and everybody else.  Why, he formed Me that way!
subQuotationList: ['His daughter?  Ah! and everybody else.  Why, he formed Me that way!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Impossible!
subQuotationList: ['Impossible!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
He did, though, I mean to say, Mr.
Harthouse, that when I first left home and went to old Bounderby's, I was
as flat as a warming-pan, and knew no more about life, than any oyster
does.
subQuotationList:
['He did, though,', "I mean to say, Mr.
Harthouse, that when I first left home and went to old Bounderby's, I was
as flat as a warming-pan, and knew no more about life, than any oyster
does."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Come, Tom!  I can hardly believe that.  A joke's a joke.
subQuotationList: ["Come, Tom!  I can hardly believe that.  A joke's a joke."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Upon my soul! I am serious; I am indeed!
subQuotationList: ['Upon my soul!', 'I am serious; I am indeed!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Oh!  I have picked up a little since.  I don't
deny that.  But I have done it myself; no thanks to the governor.
subQuotationList: ["Oh!  I have picked up a little since.  I don't\ndeny that.  But I have done it myself; no thanks to the governor."]
speaker: Young Thomas
referringExpression: He smoked with great gravity and dignity for a little while and then added

quoteText: And your intelligent sister?
subQuotationList: ['And your intelligent sister?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
My intelligent sister is about where she was.  She used to complain to
me that she had nothing to fall back upon, that girls usually fall back
upon; and I don't see how she is to have got over that since.  But _she_
don't mind, Girls
can always get on, somehow.
subQuotationList:
["My intelligent sister is about where she was.  She used to complain to
me that she had nothing to fall back upon, that girls usually fall back
upon; and I don't see how she is to have got over that since.  But _she_
don't mind,", 'Girls
can always get on, somehow.']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']], []]

quoteText:
Calling at the Bank yesterday evening, for Mr. Bounderby's address, I
found an ancient lady there, who seems to entertain great admiration for
your sister,
subQuotationList: ["Calling at the Bank yesterday evening, for Mr. Bounderby's address, I\nfound an ancient lady there, who seems to entertain great admiration for\nyour sister,"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Mother Sparsit! What! you have seen her already, have you? Mother Sparsit's feeling for Loo is more than admiration, I should
think, Say affection and devotion.  Mother Sparsit never set
her cap at Bounderby when he was a bachelor.  Oh no!
subQuotationList: ['Mother Sparsit!', 'What! you have seen her already, have you?', "Mother Sparsit's feeling for Loo is more than admiration, I should\nthink,", 'Say affection and devotion.  Mother Sparsit never set\nher cap at Bounderby when he was a bachelor.  Oh no!']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Come, it's late.  Be off!
subQuotationList: ["Come, it's late.  Be off!"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Well! I must take my leave of you
though.  I say.  Yours is very good tobacco.  But it's too mild.
subQuotationList: ['Well!', "I must take my leave of you\nthough.  I say.  Yours is very good tobacco.  But it's too mild."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Yes, it's too mild,
subQuotationList: ["Yes, it's too mild,"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
It's   it's ridiculously mild, Where's the door!  Good
night!
subQuotationList: ["It's   it's ridiculously mild,", "Where's the door!  Good\nnight!"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
OH, my friends, the down-trodden operatives of Coketown!  Oh, my friends
and fellow-countrymen, the slaves of an iron-handed and a grinding
despotism!  Oh, my friends and fellow-sufferers, and fellow-workmen, and
fellow-men!  I tell you that the hour is come, when we must rally round
one another as One united power, and crumble into dust the oppressors
that too long have battened upon the plunder of our families, upon the
sweat of our brows, upon the labour of our hands, upon the strength of
our sinews, upon the God-created glorious rights of Humanity, and upon
the holy and eternal privileges of Brotherhood!
subQuotationList:
['OH, my friends, the down-trodden operatives of Coketown!  Oh, my friends
and fellow-countrymen, the slaves of an iron-handed and a grinding
despotism!  Oh, my friends and fellow-sufferers, and fellow-workmen, and
fellow-men!  I tell you that the hour is come, when we must rally round
one another as One united power, and crumble into dust the oppressors
that too long have battened upon the plunder of our families, upon the
sweat of our brows, upon the labour of our hands, upon the strength of
our sinews, upon the God-created glorious rights of Humanity, and upon
the holy and eternal privileges of Brotherhood!']
speaker: Slackbridge

quoteText: Good! Hear, hear, hear! Hurrah!
subQuotationList: ['Good!', 'Hear, hear, hear!', 'Hurrah!']
speaker: _unknowable
referringExpression: arose in many voices from various parts of the densely crowded

quoteText:
But oh, my friends and brothers!  Oh, men and Englishmen, the
down-trodden operatives of Coketown!  What shall we say of that man   that
working-man, that I should find it necessary so to libel the glorious
name   who, being practically and well acquainted with the grievances and
wrongs of you, the injured pith and marrow of this land, and having heard
you, with a noble and majestic unanimity that will make Tyrants tremble,
resolve for to subscribe to the funds of the United Aggregate Tribunal,
and to abide by the injunctions issued by that body for your benefit,
whatever they may be   what, I ask you, will you say of that working-man,
since such I must acknowledge him to be, who, at such a time, deserts his
post, and sells his flag; who, at such a time, turns a traitor and a
craven and a recreant, who, at such a time, is not ashamed to make to you
the dastardly and humiliating avowal that he will hold himself aloof, and
will _not_ be one of those associated in the gallant stand for Freedom
and for Right?
subQuotationList:
['But oh, my friends and brothers!  Oh, men and Englishmen, the
down-trodden operatives of Coketown!  What shall we say of that man   that
working-man, that I should find it necessary so to libel the glorious
name   who, being practically and well acquainted with the grievances and
wrongs of you, the injured pith and marrow of this land, and having heard
you, with a noble and majestic unanimity that will make Tyrants tremble,
resolve for to subscribe to the funds of the United Aggregate Tribunal,
and to abide by the injunctions issued by that body for your benefit,
whatever they may be   what, I ask you, will you say of that working-man,
since such I must acknowledge him to be, who, at such a time, deserts his
post, and sells his flag; who, at such a time, turns a traitor and a
craven and a recreant, who, at such a time, is not ashamed to make to you
the dastardly and humiliating avowal that he will hold himself aloof, and
will _not_ be one of those associated in the gallant stand for Freedom
and for Right?']
speaker: Slackbridge

quoteText: Be sure you're right, Slackbridge! Put him up! Let's hear him!
subQuotationList: ["Be sure you're right, Slackbridge!", 'Put him up!', "Let's hear him!"]
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText:
Is the man heer?  If the man's
heer, Slackbridge, let's hear the man himseln, 'stead o' yo.
subQuotationList: ["Is the man heer?  If the man's\nheer, Slackbridge, let's hear the man himseln, 'stead o' yo."]
speaker: The Chairman

quoteText:
Oh, my friends and fellow-men! I do not wonder that you, the prostrate sons of
labour, are incredulous of the existence of such a man.  But he who sold
his birthright for a mess of pottage existed, and Judas Iscariot existed,
and Castlereagh existed, and this man exists!
subQuotationList:
['Oh, my friends and fellow-men!', 'I do not wonder that you, the prostrate sons of
labour, are incredulous of the existence of such a man.  But he who sold
his birthright for a mess of pottage existed, and Judas Iscariot existed,
and Castlereagh existed, and this man exists!']
speaker: Slackbridge

quoteText:
My friends, by virtue o' my office as your president, I askes
o' our friend Slackbridge, who may be a little over hetter in this
business, to take his seat, whiles this man Stephen Blackpool is heern.
You all know this man Stephen Blackpool.  You know him awlung o' his
misfort'ns, and his good name.
subQuotationList:
['My friends,', "by virtue o' my office as your president, I askes
o' our friend Slackbridge, who may be a little over hetter in this
business, to take his seat, whiles this man Stephen Blackpool is heern.
You all know this man Stephen Blackpool.  You know him awlung o' his
misfort'ns, and his good name."]
speaker: Slackbridge
mentionTextsList: [[], ['your president', 'Slackbridge', 'his', 'this man Stephen Blackpool', 'this man Stephen Blackpool', 'him', 'his', 'his']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The Chairman'], ['Slackbridge'], ['Slackbridge'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
My friends, I ha' hed
what's been spok'n o' me, and 'tis lickly that I shan't mend it.  But I'd
liefer you'd hearn the truth concernin myseln, fro my lips than fro onny
other man's, though I never cud'n speak afore so monny, wi'out bein
moydert and muddled.
subQuotationList:
['My friends,', "I ha' hed
what's been spok'n o' me, and 'tis lickly that I shan't mend it.  But I'd
liefer you'd hearn the truth concernin myseln, fro my lips than fro onny
other man's, though I never cud'n speak afore so monny, wi'out bein
moydert and muddled."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I'm th' one single Hand in Bounderby's mill, o' a' the men theer, as
don't coom in wi' th' proposed reg'lations.  I canna coom in wi' 'em.  My
friends, I doubt their doin' yo onny good.  Licker they'll do yo hurt.
subQuotationList: ["I'm th' one single Hand in Bounderby's mill, o' a' the men theer, as\ndon't coom in wi' th' proposed reg'lations.  I canna coom in wi' 'em.  My\nfriends, I doubt their doin' yo onny good.  Licker they'll do yo hurt."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

subQuotationList: ["But 't an't sommuch for that as I stands out.  If that were aw, I'd coom\nin wi' th' rest.  But I ha' my reasons   mine, yo see   for being hindered;\nnot on'y now, but awlus   awlus   life long!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Oh,
my friends, what but this did I tell you?  Oh, my fellow-countrymen, what
warning but this did I give you?  And how shows this recreant conduct in
a man on whom unequal laws are known to have fallen heavy?  Oh, you
Englishmen, I ask you how does this subornation show in one of
yourselves, who is thus consenting to his own undoing and to yours, and
to your children's and your children's children's?
subQuotationList:
["Oh,
my friends, what but this did I tell you?  Oh, my fellow-countrymen, what
warning but this did I give you?  And how shows this recreant conduct in
a man on whom unequal laws are known to have fallen heavy?  Oh, you
Englishmen, I ask you how does this subornation show in one of
yourselves, who is thus consenting to his own undoing and to yours, and
to your children's and your children's children's?"]
speaker: Slackbridge

quoteText:
'Tis this Delegate's trade for t' speak, an' he's paid
for 't, an' he knows his work.  Let him keep to 't.  Let him give no heed
to what I ha had'n to bear.  That's not for him.  That's not for nobbody
but me.
subQuotationList:
["'Tis this Delegate's trade for t' speak,", "an' he's paid
for 't, an' he knows his work.  Let him keep to 't.  Let him give no heed
to what I ha had'n to bear.  That's not for him.  That's not for nobbody
but me."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Slackbridge, let the man be heern, and howd thee tongue!
subQuotationList: ['Slackbridge, let the man be heern, and howd thee tongue!']
speaker: The Chairman
referringExpression: The same strong voice called out

quoteText:
My brothers, and
my fellow-workmen   for that yo are to me, though not, as I knows on, to
this delegate here   I ha but a word to sen, and I could sen nommore if I
was to speak till Strike o' day.  I know weel, aw what's afore me.  I
know weel that yo aw resolve to ha nommore ado wi' a man who is not wi'
yo in this matther.  I know weel that if I was a lyin parisht i' th'
road, yo'd feel it right to pass me by, as a forrenner and stranger.
What I ha getn, I mun mak th' best on.
subQuotationList:
['My brothers,', "and
my fellow-workmen   for that yo are to me, though not, as I knows on, to
this delegate here   I ha but a word to sen, and I could sen nommore if I
was to speak till Strike o' day.  I know weel, aw what's afore me.  I
know weel that yo aw resolve to ha nommore ado wi' a man who is not wi'
yo in this matther.  I know weel that if I was a lyin parisht i' th'
road, yo'd feel it right to pass me by, as a forrenner and stranger.
What I ha getn, I mun mak th' best on."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Stephen Blackpool, think on 't agen.  Think
on 't once agen, lad, afore thou'rt shunned by aw owd friends.
subQuotationList: ['Stephen Blackpool,', "think on 't agen.  Think\non 't once agen, lad, afore thou'rt shunned by aw owd friends."]
speaker: The Chairman

quoteText:
I ha thowt on 't, above a bit, sir.  I simply canna coom in.  I mun go
th' way as lays afore me.  I mun tak my leave o' aw heer.
subQuotationList: ["I ha thowt on 't, above a bit, sir.  I simply canna coom in.  I mun go\nth' way as lays afore me.  I mun tak my leave o' aw heer."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Monny's the pleasant word as soom heer has spok'n wi' me; monny's the
face I see heer, as I first seen when I were yoong and lighter heart'n
than now.  I ha' never had no fratch afore, sin ever I were born, wi' any
o' my like; Gonnows I ha' none now that's o' my makin'.  Yo'll ca' me
traitor and that   yo I mean t' say, but 'tis
easier to ca' than mak' out.  So let be.
subQuotationList:
["Monny's the pleasant word as soom heer has spok'n wi' me; monny's the
face I see heer, as I first seen when I were yoong and lighter heart'n
than now.  I ha' never had no fratch afore, sin ever I were born, wi' any
o' my like; Gonnows I ha' none now that's o' my makin'.  Yo'll ca' me
traitor and that   yo I mean t' say,", "but 'tis
easier to ca' than mak' out.  So let be."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Haply, haply, when this question has been tak'n up and discoosed,
there'll be a threat to turn out if I'm let to work among yo.  I hope I
shall die ere ever such a time cooms, and I shall work solitary among yo
unless it cooms   truly, I mun do 't, my friends; not to brave yo, but to
live.  I ha nobbut work to live by; and wheerever can I go, I who ha
worked sin I were no heighth at aw, in Coketown heer?  I mak' no
complaints o' bein turned to the wa', o' bein outcasten and overlooken
fro this time forrard, but hope I shall be let to work.  If there is any
right for me at aw, my friends, I think 'tis that.
subQuotationList:
['Haply,', "haply, when this question has been tak'n up and discoosed,
there'll be a threat to turn out if I'm let to work among yo.  I hope I
shall die ere ever such a time cooms, and I shall work solitary among yo
unless it cooms   truly, I mun do 't, my friends; not to brave yo, but to
live.  I ha nobbut work to live by; and wheerever can I go, I who ha
worked sin I were no heighth at aw, in Coketown heer?  I mak' no
complaints o' bein turned to the wa', o' bein outcasten and overlooken
fro this time forrard, but hope I shall be let to work.  If there is any
right for me at aw, my friends, I think 'tis that."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Your name's Blackpool, ain't it?
subQuotationList: ["Your name's Blackpool, ain't it?"]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Stephen Blackpool
referringExpression: He made a feint of adjusting the lining and said

quoteText: You are the Hand they have sent to Coventry, I mean?
subQuotationList: ['You are the Hand they have sent to Coventry, I mean?']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: Yes,
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I supposed so, from their all appearing to keep away from you.  Mr.
Bounderby wants to speak to you.  You know his house, don't you?
subQuotationList: ["I supposed so, from their all appearing to keep away from you.  Mr.\nBounderby wants to speak to you.  You know his house, don't you?"]
speaker: Bitzer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: Yes,
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Then go straight up there, will you? You're expected,
and have only to tell the servant it's you.  I belong to the Bank; so, if
you go straight up without me (I was sent to fetch you), you'll save me a
walk.
subQuotationList:
['Then go straight up there, will you?', "You're expected,
and have only to tell the servant it's you.  I belong to the Bank; so, if
you go straight up without me (I was sent to fetch you), you'll save me a
walk."]
speaker: Bitzer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
WELL, Stephen, what's this I
hear?  What have these pests of the earth been doing to _you_?  Come in,
and speak up.
subQuotationList: ['WELL, Stephen,', "what's this I\nhear?  What have these pests of the earth been doing to _you_?  Come in,\nand speak up."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: This is the man I was telling you about, Harthouse,
subQuotationList: ['This is the man I was telling you about, Harthouse,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Oh really?
subQuotationList: ['Oh really?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
referringExpression: The gentleman he addressed who was talking to Mrs Bounderby on the sofa got up saying

quoteText: Now, speak up!
subQuotationList: ['Now,', 'speak up!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: What were it, sir, as yo were pleased to want wi' me?
subQuotationList: ['What were it, sir,', "as yo were pleased to want wi' me?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Why, I have told you, Speak up like a man, since
you are a man, and tell us about yourself and this Combination.
subQuotationList: ['Why, I have told you,', 'Speak up like a man, since\nyou are a man, and tell us about yourself and this Combination.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
Wi' yor pardon, sir, I ha' nowt to sen about
it.
subQuotationList: ["Wi' yor pardon, sir,", "I ha' nowt to sen about\nit."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Now, look here, Harthouse, here's a specimen of 'em.  When
this man was here once before, I warned this man against the mischievous
strangers who are always about   and who ought to be hanged wherever they
are found   and I told this man that he was going in the wrong direction.
Now, would you believe it, that although they have put this mark upon
him, he is such a slave to them still, that he's afraid to open his lips
about them?
subQuotationList:
['Now, look here, Harthouse,', "here's a specimen of 'em.  When
this man was here once before, I warned this man against the mischievous
strangers who are always about   and who ought to be hanged wherever they
are found   and I told this man that he was going in the wrong direction.
Now, would you believe it, that although they have put this mark upon
him, he is such a slave to them still, that he's afraid to open his lips
about them?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
I sed as I had nowt to sen, sir; not as I was fearfo' o' openin' my
lips.
subQuotationList: ["I sed as I had nowt to sen, sir; not as I was fearfo' o' openin' my\nlips."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
You said!  Ah!  _I_ know what you said; more than that, I know what you
mean, you see.  Not always the same thing, by the Lord Harry!  Quite
different things.  You had better tell us at once, that that fellow
Slackbridge is not in the town, stirring up the people to mutiny; and
that he is not a regular qualified leader of the people: that is, a most
confounded scoundrel.  You had better tell us so at once; you can't
deceive me.  You want to tell us so.  Why don't you?
subQuotationList:
["You said!  Ah!  _I_ know what you said; more than that, I know what you
mean, you see.  Not always the same thing, by the Lord Harry!  Quite
different things.  You had better tell us at once, that that fellow
Slackbridge is not in the town, stirring up the people to mutiny; and
that he is not a regular qualified leader of the people: that is, a most
confounded scoundrel.  You had better tell us so at once; you can't
deceive me.  You want to tell us so.  Why don't you?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Slackbridge'], ['Slackbridge'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Josiah Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
I'm as sooary as yo, sir, when the people's leaders is bad, They taks such as offers.  Haply 'tis na'
the sma'est o' their misfortuns when they can get no better.
subQuotationList: ["I'm as sooary as yo, sir, when the people's leaders is bad,", "They taks such as offers.  Haply 'tis na'\nthe sma'est o' their misfortuns when they can get no better."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Now, you'll think this pretty well, Harthouse, You'll think this tolerably strong.  You'll say, upon my soul this is a
tidy specimen of what my friends have to deal with; but this is nothing,
sir!  You shall hear me ask this man a question.  Pray, Mr.
Blackpool may I take the liberty of asking
you how it happens that you refused to be in this Combination?
subQuotationList:
["Now, you'll think this pretty well, Harthouse,", "You'll think this tolerably strong.  You'll say, upon my soul this is a
tidy specimen of what my friends have to deal with; but this is nothing,
sir!  You shall hear me ask this man a question.  Pray, Mr.
Blackpool", 'may I take the liberty of asking
you how it happens that you refused to be in this Combination?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], []]

quoteText: How 't happens?
subQuotationList: ["How 't happens?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Ah! how it happens.
subQuotationList: ['Ah!', 'how it happens.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I'd leefer not coom to 't, sir; but sin you put th' question   an' not
want'n t' be ill-manner'n   I'll answer.  I ha passed a promess.
subQuotationList: ["I'd leefer not coom to 't, sir; but sin you put th' question   an' not\nwant'n t' be ill-manner'n   I'll answer.  I ha passed a promess."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Not to me, you know,
subQuotationList: ['Not to me, you know,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: O no, sir.  Not to yo.
subQuotationList: ['O no, sir.  Not to yo.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
As for me, any consideration for me has had just nothing at all to do
with it, If only
Josiah Bounderby of Coketown had been in question, you would have joined
and made no bones about it?
subQuotationList:
['As for me, any consideration for me has had just nothing at all to do
with it,', 'If only
Josiah Bounderby of Coketown had been in question, you would have joined
and made no bones about it?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Why yes, sir.  'Tis true.
subQuotationList: ["Why yes, sir.  'Tis true."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Though he knows, that there
are a set of rascals and rebels whom transportation is too good for!
Now, Mr. Harthouse, you have been knocking about in the world some time.
Did you ever meet with anything like that man out of this blessed
country?
subQuotationList:
['Though he knows,', 'that there
are a set of rascals and rebels whom transportation is too good for!
Now, Mr. Harthouse, you have been knocking about in the world some time.
Did you ever meet with anything like that man out of this blessed
country?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Slackbridge']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Slackbridge']]]

quoteText:
Nay, ma'am, Not rebels, nor yet rascals.  Nowt o' th'
kind, ma'am, nowt o' th' kind.  They've not doon me a kindness, ma'am, as
I know and feel.  But there's not a dozen men amoong 'em, ma'am   a dozen?
Not six   but what believes as he has doon his duty by the rest and by
himseln.  God forbid as I, that ha' known, and had'n experience o' these
men aw my life   I, that ha' ett'n an' droonken wi' 'em, an' seet'n wi'
'em, and toil'n wi' 'em, and lov'n 'em, should fail fur to stan by 'em
wi' the truth, let 'em ha' doon to me what they may!
subQuotationList:
["Nay, ma'am,", "Not rebels, nor yet rascals.  Nowt o' th'
kind, ma'am, nowt o' th' kind.  They've not doon me a kindness, ma'am, as
I know and feel.  But there's not a dozen men amoong 'em, ma'am   a dozen?
Not six   but what believes as he has doon his duty by the rest and by
himseln.  God forbid as I, that ha' known, and had'n experience o' these
men aw my life   I, that ha' ett'n an' droonken wi' 'em, an' seet'n wi'
'em, and toil'n wi' 'em, and lov'n 'em, should fail fur to stan by 'em
wi' the truth, let 'em ha' doon to me what they may!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
No, ma'am, no.  They're true to one another, faithfo' to one another,
'fectionate to one another, e'en to death.  Be poor amoong 'em, be sick
amoong 'em, grieve amoong 'em for onny o' th' monny causes that carries
grief to the poor man's door, an' they'll be tender wi' yo, gentle wi'
yo, comfortable wi' yo, Chrisen wi' yo.  Be sure o' that, ma'am.  They'd
be riven to bits, ere ever they'd be different.
subQuotationList:
["No, ma'am, no.  They're true to one another, faithfo' to one another,
'fectionate to one another, e'en to death.  Be poor amoong 'em, be sick
amoong 'em, grieve amoong 'em for onny o' th' monny causes that carries
grief to the poor man's door, an' they'll be tender wi' yo, gentle wi'
yo, comfortable wi' yo, Chrisen wi' yo.  Be sure o' that, ma'am.  They'd
be riven to bits, ere ever they'd be different."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
In short, it's because they are so full of virtues
that they have turned you adrift.  Go through with it while you are about
it.  Out with it.
subQuotationList: ['In short,', "it's because they are so full of virtues\nthat they have turned you adrift.  Go through with it while you are about\nit.  Out with it."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
How 'tis, ma'am, that what is best in us fok, seems to turn us
most to trouble an' misfort'n an' mistake, I dunno.  But 'tis so.  I know
'tis, as I know the heavens is over me ahint the smoke.  We're patient
too, an' wants in general to do right.  An' I canna think the fawt is aw
wi' us.
subQuotationList:
["How 'tis, ma'am,", "that what is best in us fok, seems to turn us
most to trouble an' misfort'n an' mistake, I dunno.  But 'tis so.  I know
'tis, as I know the heavens is over me ahint the smoke.  We're patient
too, an' wants in general to do right.  An' I canna think the fawt is aw
wi' us."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Now, my friend, if you will favour me with your attention for half a
minute, I should like to have a word or two with you.  You said just now,
that you had nothing to tell us about this business.  You are quite sure
of that before we go any further.
subQuotationList:
['Now, my friend,', 'if you will favour me with your attention for half a
minute, I should like to have a word or two with you.  You said just now,
that you had nothing to tell us about this business.  You are quite sure
of that before we go any further.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: Sir, I am sure on 't.
subQuotationList: ["Sir, I am sure on 't."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Here's a gentleman from London present, a Parliament gentleman.  I
should like him to hear a short bit of dialogue between you and me,
instead of taking the substance of it   for I know precious well,
beforehand, what it will be; nobody knows better than I do, take
notice!   instead of receiving it on trust from my mouth.
subQuotationList:
["Here's a gentleman from London present,", 'a Parliament gentleman.  I
should like him to hear a short bit of dialogue between you and me,
instead of taking the substance of it   for I know precious well,
beforehand, what it will be; nobody knows better than I do, take
notice!   instead of receiving it on trust from my mouth.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
referringExpression: Mr Bounderby made a backhanded point at Mr James Harthouse
mentionTextsList: [['a gentleman from London present'], ['a Parliament gentleman', 'him', 'you']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: Now, what do you complain of?
subQuotationList: ['Now, what do you complain of?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I ha' not coom here, sir, to complain.  I coom
for that I were sent for.
subQuotationList: ["I ha' not coom here, sir,", 'to complain.  I coom\nfor that I were sent for.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
What, do you people, in a
general way, complain of?
subQuotationList: ['What,', 'do you people, in a\ngeneral way, complain of?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Sir, I were never good at showin o 't, though I ha had'n my share in
feeling o 't.  'Deed we are in a muddle, sir.  Look round town   so rich as
'tis   and see the numbers o' people as has been broughten into bein heer,
fur to weave, an' to card, an' to piece out a livin', aw the same one
way, somehows, 'twixt their cradles and their graves.  Look how we live,
an' wheer we live, an' in what numbers, an' by what chances, and wi' what
sameness; and look how the mills is awlus a goin, and how they never
works us no nigher to ony dis'ant object   ceptin awlus, Death.  Look how
you considers of us, and writes of us, and talks of us, and goes up wi'
yor deputations to Secretaries o' State 'bout us, and how yo are awlus
right, and how we are awlus wrong, and never had'n no reason in us sin
ever we were born.  Look how this ha growen an' growen, sir, bigger an'
bigger, broader an' broader, harder an' harder, fro year to year, fro
generation unto generation.  Who can look on 't, sir, and fairly tell a
man 'tis not a muddle?
subQuotationList:
["Sir, I were never good at showin o 't, though I ha had'n my share in
feeling o 't.  'Deed we are in a muddle, sir.  Look round town   so rich as
'tis   and see the numbers o' people as has been broughten into bein heer,
fur to weave, an' to card, an' to piece out a livin', aw the same one
way, somehows, 'twixt their cradles and their graves.  Look how we live,
an' wheer we live, an' in what numbers, an' by what chances, and wi' what
sameness; and look how the mills is awlus a goin, and how they never
works us no nigher to ony dis'ant object   ceptin awlus, Death.  Look how
you considers of us, and writes of us, and talks of us, and goes up wi'
yor deputations to Secretaries o' State 'bout us, and how yo are awlus
right, and how we are awlus wrong, and never had'n no reason in us sin
ever we were born.  Look how this ha growen an' growen, sir, bigger an'
bigger, broader an' broader, harder an' harder, fro year to year, fro
generation unto generation.  Who can look on 't, sir, and fairly tell a
man 'tis not a muddle?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Of course, Now perhaps you'll let the gentleman
know, how you would set this muddle (as you're so fond of calling it) to
rights.
subQuotationList: ['Of course,', "Now perhaps you'll let the gentleman\nknow, how you would set this muddle (as you're so fond of calling it) to\nrights."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I donno, sir.  I canna be expecten to 't.  'Tis not me as should be
looken to for that, sir.  'Tis them as is put ower me, and ower aw the
rest of us.  What do they tak upon themseln, sir, if not to do't?
subQuotationList: ["I donno, sir.  I canna be expecten to 't.  'Tis not me as should be\nlooken to for that, sir.  'Tis them as is put ower me, and ower aw the\nrest of us.  What do they tak upon themseln, sir, if not to do't?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I'll tell you something towards it, at any rate, We will make an example of half a dozen Slackbridges.  We'll
indict the blackguards for felony, and get 'em shipped off to penal
settlements.
subQuotationList: ["I'll tell you something towards it, at any rate,", "We will make an example of half a dozen Slackbridges.  We'll\nindict the blackguards for felony, and get 'em shipped off to penal\nsettlements."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Don't tell me we won't, man, because we will, I tell you!
subQuotationList: ["Don't tell me we won't, man,", 'because we will, I tell you!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby', 'Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Josiah Bounderby', 'Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
Sir, if yo was t' tak a hundred Slackbridges   aw as there is, and aw the
number ten times towd   an' was t' sew 'em up in separate sacks, an' sink
'em in the deepest ocean as were made ere ever dry land coom to be, yo'd
leave the muddle just wheer 'tis.  Mischeevous strangers! when ha we not heern, I am sure, sin ever we can
call to mind, o' th' mischeevous strangers!  'Tis not by _them_ the
trouble's made, sir.  'Tis not wi' _them_ 't commences.  I ha no favour
for 'em   I ha no reason to favour 'em   but 'tis hopeless and useless to
dream o' takin them fro their trade, 'stead o' takin their trade fro
them!  Aw that's now about me in this room were heer afore I coom, an'
will be heer when I am gone.  Put that clock aboard a ship an' pack it
off to Norfolk Island, an' the time will go on just the same.  So 'tis
wi' Slackbridge every bit.
subQuotationList:
['Sir,', "if yo was t' tak a hundred Slackbridges   aw as there is, and aw the
number ten times towd   an' was t' sew 'em up in separate sacks, an' sink
'em in the deepest ocean as were made ere ever dry land coom to be, yo'd
leave the muddle just wheer 'tis.  Mischeevous strangers!", "when ha we not heern, I am sure, sin ever we can
call to mind, o' th' mischeevous strangers!  'Tis not by _them_ the
trouble's made, sir.  'Tis not wi' _them_ 't commences.  I ha no favour
for 'em   I ha no reason to favour 'em   but 'tis hopeless and useless to
dream o' takin them fro their trade, 'stead o' takin their trade fro
them!  Aw that's now about me in this room were heer afore I coom, an'
will be heer when I am gone.  Put that clock aboard a ship an' pack it
off to Norfolk Island, an' the time will go on just the same.  So 'tis
wi' Slackbridge every bit."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Sir, I canna, wi' my little learning an' my common way, tell the
genelman what will better aw this   though some working men o' this town
could, above my powers   but I can tell him what I know will never do 't.
The strong hand will never do 't.  Vict'ry and triumph will never do 't.
Agreeing fur to mak one side unnat'rally awlus and for ever right, and
toother side unnat'rally awlus and for ever wrong, will never, never do
't.  Nor yet lettin alone will never do 't.  Let thousands upon thousands
alone, aw leading the like lives and aw faw'en into the like muddle, and
they will be as one, and yo will be as anoother, wi' a black unpassable
world betwixt yo, just as long or short a time as sich-like misery can
last.  Not drawin nigh to fok, wi' kindness and patience an' cheery ways,
that so draws nigh to one another in their monny troubles, and so
cherishes one another in their distresses wi' what they need
themseln   like, I humbly believe, as no people the genelman ha seen in aw
his travels can beat   will never do 't till th' Sun turns t' ice.  Most o'
aw, rating 'em as so much Power, and reg'latin 'em as if they was figures
in a soom, or machines: wi'out loves and likens, wi'out memories and
inclinations, wi'out souls to weary and souls to hope   when aw goes quiet,
draggin on wi' 'em as if they'd nowt o' th' kind, and when aw goes
onquiet, reproachin 'em for their want o' sitch humanly feelins in their
dealins wi' yo   this will never do 't, sir, till God's work is onmade.
subQuotationList:
["Sir, I canna, wi' my little learning an' my common way, tell the
genelman what will better aw this   though some working men o' this town
could, above my powers   but I can tell him what I know will never do 't.
The strong hand will never do 't.  Vict'ry and triumph will never do 't.

cherishes one another in their distresses wi' what they need
themseln   like, I humbly believe, as no people the genelman ha seen in aw
his travels can beat   will never do 't till th' Sun turns t' ice.  Most o'

speaker: Stephen Blackpool
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Just stop a moment, I told you, the last time you were here with a grievance, that you had
better turn about and come out of that.  And I also told you, if you
remember, that I was up to the gold spoon look-out.
subQuotationList: ['Just stop a moment,', 'I told you, the last time you were here with a grievance, that you had\nbetter turn about and come out of that.  And I also told you, if you\nremember, that I was up to the gold spoon look-out.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: I were not up to 't myseln, sir; I do assure yo.
subQuotationList: ["I were not up to 't myseln, sir; I do assure yo."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Now it's clear to me, that you are one of those
chaps who have always got a grievance.  And you go about, sowing it and
raising crops.  That's the business of _your_ life, my friend. You are such a waspish, raspish, ill-conditioned chap, you see, that even your own Union, the men who know you best, will
have nothing to do with you.  I never thought those fellows could be
right in anything; but I tell you what!  I so far go along with them for
a novelty, that _I_'ll have nothing to do with you either. You can finish off what you're at, and then go elsewhere.
subQuotationList:
["Now it's clear to me,", "that you are one of those
chaps who have always got a grievance.  And you go about, sowing it and
raising crops.  That's the business of _your_ life, my friend.", 'You are such a waspish, raspish, ill-conditioned chap, you see,', "that even your own Union, the men who know you best, will
have nothing to do with you.  I never thought those fellows could be
right in anything; but I tell you what!  I so far go along with them for
a novelty, that _I_'ll have nothing to do with you either.", "You can finish off what you're at,", 'and then go elsewhere.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], []]

quoteText:
Sir, yo know weel, that if I canna get work
wi' yo, I canna get it elsewheer.
subQuotationList: ['Sir, yo know weel,', "that if I canna get work\nwi' yo, I canna get it elsewheer."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
What I know, I know; and what you know, you know.  I have
no more to say about it.
subQuotationList: ['What I know, I know; and what you know, you know.  I have\nno more to say about it.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Heaven help
us aw in this world!
subQuotationList: ['Heaven help\nus aw in this world!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool
referringExpression: Stephen glanced at Louisa again but her eyes were raised to his no more therefore with a sigh and saying

quoteText: Ah, Rachael, my dear!  Missus, thou wi' her!
subQuotationList: ["Ah, Rachael, my dear!  Missus, thou wi' her!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Well, and now you are surprised to be sure, and with reason I must say, Here I am again, you see.
subQuotationList: ['Well, and now you are surprised to be sure, and with reason I must say,', 'Here I am again, you see.']
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText: But how wi' Rachael?
subQuotationList: ["But how wi' Rachael?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Why, I come to be with this good lass pretty much as I came to be with
you, My
visiting time is later this year than usual, for I have been rather
troubled with shortness of breath, and so put it off till the weather was
fine and warm.  For the same reason I don't make all my journey in one
day, but divide it into two days, and get a bed to-night at the
Travellers' Coffee House down by the railroad (a nice clean house), and
go back Parliamentary, at six in the morning.  Well, but what has this to
do with this good lass, says you?  I'm going to tell you.  I have heard
of Mr. Bounderby being married.  I read it in the paper, where it looked
grand   oh, it looked fine!
subQuotationList:
['Why, I come to be with this good lass pretty much as I came to be with
you,', "My
visiting time is later this year than usual, for I have been rather
troubled with shortness of breath, and so put it off till the weather was
fine and warm.  For the same reason I don't make all my journey in one
day, but divide it into two days, and get a bed to-night at the
Travellers' Coffee House down by the railroad (a nice clean house), and
go back Parliamentary, at six in the morning.  Well, but what has this to
do with this good lass, says you?  I'm going to tell you.  I have heard
of Mr. Bounderby being married.  I read it in the paper, where it looked
grand   oh, it looked fine!"]
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText:
and I want to see his wife.  I have never seen her yet.
Now, if you'll believe me, she hasn't come out of that house since noon
to-day.  So not to give her up too easily, I was waiting about, a little
last bit more, when I passed close to this good lass two or three times;
and her face being so friendly I spoke to her, and she spoke to me.
There! you can make all the rest out for
yourself now, a deal shorter than I can, I dare say!
subQuotationList:
["and I want to see his wife.  I have never seen her yet.
Now, if you'll believe me, she hasn't come out of that house since noon
to-day.  So not to give her up too easily, I was waiting about, a little
last bit more, when I passed close to this good lass two or three times;
and her face being so friendly I spoke to her, and she spoke to me.
There!", 'you can make all the rest out for
yourself now, a deal shorter than I can, I dare say!']
speaker: The Old Woman
referringExpression: said the old woman to Stephen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
Well, missus, I ha seen the lady, and she were young and
hansom.  Wi' fine dark thinkin eyes, and a still way, Rachael, as I ha
never seen the like on.
subQuotationList: ['Well, missus,', "I ha seen the lady, and she were young and\nhansom.  Wi' fine dark thinkin eyes, and a still way, Rachael, as I ha\nnever seen the like on."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Young and handsome.  Yes! As
bonny as a rose!  And what a happy wife!
subQuotationList: ['Young and handsome.  Yes!', 'As\nbonny as a rose!  And what a happy wife!']
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText: Aye, missus, I suppose she be,
subQuotationList: ['Aye, missus, I suppose she be,']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Suppose she be?  She must be.  She's your master's wife,
subQuotationList: ["Suppose she be?  She must be.  She's your master's wife,"]
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText: Though as to master, not master onny more.  That's aw enden 'twixt him and me.
subQuotationList: ['Though as to master,', "not master onny more.  That's aw enden 'twixt him and me."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Have you left his work, Stephen?
subQuotationList: ['Have you left his work, Stephen?']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Why, Rachael, whether I ha lef'n his work, or whether his
work ha lef'n me, cooms t' th' same.  His work and me are parted.  'Tis
as weel so   better, I were thinkin when yo coom up wi' me.  It would ha
brought'n trouble upon trouble if I had stayed theer.  Haply 'tis a
kindness to monny that I go; haply 'tis a kindness to myseln; anyways it
mun be done.  I mun turn my face fro Coketown fur th' time, and seek a
fort'n, dear, by beginnin fresh.
subQuotationList:
['Why, Rachael,', "whether I ha lef'n his work, or whether his
work ha lef'n me, cooms t' th' same.  His work and me are parted.  'Tis
as weel so   better, I were thinkin when yo coom up wi' me.  It would ha
brought'n trouble upon trouble if I had stayed theer.  Haply 'tis a
kindness to monny that I go; haply 'tis a kindness to myseln; anyways it
mun be done.  I mun turn my face fro Coketown fur th' time, and seek a
fort'n, dear, by beginnin fresh."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Where will you go, Stephen?
subQuotationList: ['Where will you go, Stephen?']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I donno t'night, But I'm not goin t'night, Rachael, nor
yet t'morrow.  'Tan't easy overmuch t' know wheer t' turn, but a good
heart will coom to me.
subQuotationList: ["I donno t'night,", "But I'm not goin t'night, Rachael, nor\nyet t'morrow.  'Tan't easy overmuch t' know wheer t' turn, but a good\nheart will coom to me."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I'm more leetsome, Rachael, under 't, than I
could'n ha believed.
subQuotationList: ["I'm more leetsome, Rachael, under 't, than I\ncould'n ha believed."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Come to my poor place, missus, and tak a coop o' tea.
Rachael will coom then; and arterwards I'll see thee safe t' thy
Travellers' lodgin.  'T may be long, Rachael, ere ever I ha th' chance o'
thy coompany agen. I ha never thowt yet, missus, o' askin thy name.
subQuotationList:
['Come to my poor place, missus,', "and tak a coop o' tea.
Rachael will coom then; and arterwards I'll see thee safe t' thy
Travellers' lodgin.  'T may be long, Rachael, ere ever I ha th' chance o'
thy coompany agen.", 'I ha never thowt yet, missus,', "o' askin thy name."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool
