quoteText: Mrs. Pegler.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Pegler.']
speaker: The Old Woman
referringExpression: The old lady announced herself as

quoteText: A widder, I think?
subQuotationList: ['A widder, I think?']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Oh, many long years!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, many long years!']
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText:
'Twere a bad job, too, to lose so good a one, Onny
children?
subQuotationList: ["'Twere a bad job, too, to lose so good a one,", 'Onny\nchildren?']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: No, Not now, not now.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'Not now, not now.']
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText: Dead, Stephen,
subQuotationList: ['Dead, Stephen,']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I'm sooary I ha spok'n on 't, I ought t' hadn in my mind
as I might touch a sore place.  I   I blame myseln.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sooary I ha spok'n on 't,", "I ought t' hadn in my mind\nas I might touch a sore place.  I   I blame myseln."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I
had a son, and he did well, wonderfully well.  But he is not
to be spoken of if you please.  He is
subQuotationList: ['I\nhad a son,', 'and he did well, wonderfully well.  But he is not\nto be spoken of if you please.  He is']
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText: dead! I have lost him.
subQuotationList: ['dead!', 'I have lost him.']
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText:
Bounderby! Oh hide me!  Don't let me be seen for the world.  Don't let him
come up till I've got away.  Pray, pray!
subQuotationList: ['Bounderby!', "Oh hide me!  Don't let me be seen for the world.  Don't let him\ncome up till I've got away.  Pray, pray!"]
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText:
But hearken, missus, hearken, 'Tisn't Mr.
Bounderby; 'tis his wife.  Yo'r not fearfo' o' her.  Yo was hey-go-mad
about her, but an hour sin.
subQuotationList: ['But hearken, missus, hearken,', "'Tisn't Mr.\nBounderby; 'tis his wife.  Yo'r not fearfo' o' her.  Yo was hey-go-mad\nabout her, but an hour sin."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Old Woman']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['The Old Woman'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['The Old Woman'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: But are you sure it's the lady, and not the gentleman?
subQuotationList: ["But are you sure it's the lady, and not the gentleman?"]
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText: Certain sure!
subQuotationList: ['Certain sure!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Well then, pray don't speak to me, nor yet take any notice of me, Let me be quite to myself in this corner.
subQuotationList: ["Well then, pray don't speak to me, nor yet take any notice of me,", 'Let me be quite to myself in this corner.']
speaker: The Old Woman

quoteText:
I have come to speak to you, in consequence of what passed just now.  I
should like to be serviceable to you, if you will let me.  Is this your
wife?
subQuotationList: ['I have come to speak to you, in consequence of what passed just now.  I\nshould like to be serviceable to you, if you will let me.  Is this your\nwife?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I remember, I recollect, now,
to have heard your domestic misfortunes spoken of, though I was not
attending to the particulars at the time.  It was not my meaning to ask a
question that would give pain to any one here.  If I should ask any other
question that may happen to have that result, give me credit, if you
please, for being in ignorance how to speak to you as I ought.
subQuotationList:
['I remember,', 'I recollect, now,
to have heard your domestic misfortunes spoken of, though I was not
attending to the particulars at the time.  It was not my meaning to ask a
question that would give pain to any one here.  If I should ask any other
question that may happen to have that result, give me credit, if you
please, for being in ignorance how to speak to you as I ought.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
He has told you what has passed between himself and my husband?  You
would be his first resource, I think.
subQuotationList: ['He has told you what has passed between himself and my husband?  You\nwould be his first resource, I think.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: I have heard the end of it, young lady,
subQuotationList: ['I have heard the end of it, young lady,']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Did I understand, that, being rejected by one employer, he would
probably be rejected by all?  I thought he said as much?
subQuotationList: ['Did I understand, that, being rejected by one employer, he would\nprobably be rejected by all?  I thought he said as much?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
The chances are very small, young lady   next to nothing   for a man who
gets a bad name among them.
subQuotationList: ['The chances are very small, young lady   next to nothing   for a man who\ngets a bad name among them.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: What shall I understand that you mean by a bad name?
subQuotationList: ['What shall I understand that you mean by a bad name?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: The name of being troublesome.
subQuotationList: ['The name of being troublesome.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Then, by the prejudices of his own class, and by the prejudices of the
other, he is sacrificed alike?  Are the two so deeply separated in this
town, that there is no place whatever for an honest workman between
them?
subQuotationList:
['Then, by the prejudices of his own class, and by the prejudices of the
other, he is sacrificed alike?  Are the two so deeply separated in this
town, that there is no place whatever for an honest workman between
them?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
He fell into suspicion, with his fellow-weavers,
because   he had made a promise not to be one of them.  I think it must
have been to you that he made that promise.  Might I ask you why he made
it?
subQuotationList:
['He fell into suspicion,', 'with his fellow-weavers,
because   he had made a promise not to be one of them.  I think it must
have been to you that he made that promise.  Might I ask you why he made
it?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
I didn't seek it of him, poor lad.  I prayed
him to avoid trouble for his own good, little thinking he'd come to it
through me.  But I know he'd die a hundred deaths, ere ever he'd break
his word.  I know that of him well.
subQuotationList:
["I didn't seek it of him, poor lad.  I prayed
him to avoid trouble for his own good, little thinking he'd come to it
through me.  But I know he'd die a hundred deaths, ere ever he'd break
his word.  I know that of him well."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
No one, excepting myseln, can ever know what honour, an' what love, an'
respect, I bear to Rachael, or wi' what cause.  When I passed that
promess, I towd her true, she were th' Angel o' my life.  'Twere a solemn
promess.  'Tis gone fro' me, for ever.
subQuotationList:
["No one, excepting myseln, can ever know what honour, an' what love, an'
respect, I bear to Rachael, or wi' what cause.  When I passed that
promess, I towd her true, she were th' Angel o' my life.  'Twere a solemn
promess.  'Tis gone fro' me, for ever."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: What will you do?
subQuotationList: ['What will you do?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Weel, ma'am, when I
ha finished off, I mun quit this part, and try another.  Fortnet or
misfortnet, a man can but try; there's nowt to be done wi'out tryin'   cept
laying down and dying.
subQuotationList:
["Weel, ma'am,", "when I
ha finished off, I mun quit this part, and try another.  Fortnet or
misfortnet, a man can but try; there's nowt to be done wi'out tryin'   cept
laying down and dying."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: How will you travel?
subQuotationList: ['How will you travel?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Afoot, my kind ledy, afoot.
subQuotationList: ['Afoot, my kind ledy, afoot.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Rachael, will you tell him   for you know how, without offence   that this
is freely his, to help him on his way?  Will you entreat him to take it?
subQuotationList: ['Rachael, will you tell him   for you know how, without offence   that this\nis freely his, to help him on his way?  Will you entreat him to take it?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
I canna do that, young lady, Bless you for thinking o' the poor lad wi' such tenderness.  But 'tis
for him to know his heart, and what is right according to it.
subQuotationList: ['I canna do that, young lady,', "Bless you for thinking o' the poor lad wi' such tenderness.  But 'tis\nfor him to know his heart, and what is right according to it."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Not e'en Rachael, could mak sitch a kind offerin, by onny words, kinder.  T'
show that I'm not a man wi'out reason and gratitude, I'll tak two pound.
I'll borrow 't for t' pay 't back.  'Twill be the sweetest work as ever I
ha done, that puts it in my power t' acknowledge once more my lastin
thankfulness for this present action.
subQuotationList:
["Not e'en Rachael,", "could mak sitch a kind offerin, by onny words, kinder.  T'
show that I'm not a man wi'out reason and gratitude, I'll tak two pound.
I'll borrow 't for t' pay 't back.  'Twill be the sweetest work as ever I
ha done, that puts it in my power t' acknowledge once more my lastin
thankfulness for this present action."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Just wait a moment, Loo!  Before we go, I should like to speak to him a
moment.  Something comes into my head.  If you'll step out on the stairs,
Blackpool, I'll mention it.  Never mind a light, man! It
don't want a light.
subQuotationList:
["Just wait a moment, Loo!  Before we go, I should like to speak to him a
moment.  Something comes into my head.  If you'll step out on the stairs,
Blackpool, I'll mention it.  Never mind a light, man!", "It
don't want a light."]
speaker: Young Thomas
referringExpression: he got up rather hurriedly and put in a word

quoteText:
I say! I think I can do you a good turn.  Don't ask me
what it is, because it may not come to anything.  But there's no harm in
my trying.
subQuotationList: ['I say!', "I think I can do you a good turn.  Don't ask me\nwhat it is, because it may not come to anything.  But there's no harm in\nmy trying."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
That was our light porter at the Bank, who brought you the
message to-night.  I call him our light porter, because I belong to the
Bank too.
subQuotationList: ['That was our light porter at the Bank,', 'who brought you the\nmessage to-night.  I call him our light porter, because I belong to the\nBank too.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: What a hurry he is in!
subQuotationList: ['What a hurry he is in!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Well! Now look here!  When are you off?
subQuotationList: ['Well!', 'Now look here!  When are you off?']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
T' day's Monday, Why, sir, Friday or
Saturday, nigh 'bout.
subQuotationList: ["T' day's Monday,", "Why, sir, Friday or\nSaturday, nigh 'bout."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Friday or Saturday, Now look here!  I am not sure that I
can do you the good turn I want to do you   that's my sister, you know, in
your room   but I may be able to, and if I should not be able to, there's
no harm done.  So I tell you what.  You'll know our light porter again?
subQuotationList:
['Friday or Saturday,', "Now look here!  I am not sure that I
can do you the good turn I want to do you   that's my sister, you know, in
your room   but I may be able to, and if I should not be able to, there's
no harm done.  So I tell you what.  You'll know our light porter again?"]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: Yes, sure,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sure,']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Very well, When you leave work of a night, between this
and your going away, just hang about the Bank an hour or so, will you?
Don't take on, as if you meant anything, if he should see you hanging
about there; because I shan't put him up to speak to you, unless I find I
can do you the service I want to do you.  In that case he'll have a note
or a message for you, but not else.  Now look here!  You are sure you
understand.
subQuotationList:
['Very well,', "When you leave work of a night, between this
and your going away, just hang about the Bank an hour or so, will you?
Don't take on, as if you meant anything, if he should see you hanging
about there; because I shan't put him up to speak to you, unless I find I
can do you the service I want to do you.  In that case he'll have a note
or a message for you, but not else.  Now look here!  You are sure you
understand."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: I understand, sir,
subQuotationList: ['I understand, sir,']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Now look here! Be sure you don't make any mistake then,
and don't forget.  I shall tell my sister as we go home, what I have in
view, and she'll approve, I know.  Now look here!  You're all right, are
you?  You understand all about it?  Very well then.  Come along, Loo!
subQuotationList:
['Now look here!', "Be sure you don't make any mistake then,
and don't forget.  I shall tell my sister as we go home, what I have in
view, and she'll approve, I know.  Now look here!  You're all right, are
you?  You understand all about it?  Very well then.  Come along, Loo!"]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: because she was such a pretty dear.
subQuotationList: ['because she was such a pretty dear.']
speaker: The Old Woman
referringExpression: She was in a state of inexpressible admiration of Mrs Bounderby and like an unaccountable old woman wept

quoteText: I shall strive t' see thee agen, Rachael, afore I go, but if not
subQuotationList: ["I shall strive t' see thee agen, Rachael, afore I go, but if not"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Thou wilt not, Stephen, I know.  'Tis better that we make up our minds
to be open wi' one another.
subQuotationList: ["Thou wilt not, Stephen, I know.  'Tis better that we make up our minds\nto be open wi' one another."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Thou'rt awlus right.  'Tis bolder and better.  I ha been thinkin then,
Rachael, that as 'tis but a day or two that remains, 'twere better for
thee, my dear, not t' be seen wi' me.  'T might bring thee into trouble,
fur no good.
subQuotationList:
["Thou'rt awlus right.  'Tis bolder and better.  I ha been thinkin then,
Rachael, that as 'tis but a day or two that remains, 'twere better for
thee, my dear, not t' be seen wi' me.  'T might bring thee into trouble,
fur no good."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
'Tis not for that, Stephen, that I mind.  But thou know'st our old
agreement.  'Tis for that.
subQuotationList: ["'Tis not for that, Stephen, that I mind.  But thou know'st our old\nagreement.  'Tis for that."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Well, well, 'Tis better, onnyways.
subQuotationList: ['Well, well,', "'Tis better, onnyways."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Thou'lt write to me, and tell me all that happens, Stephen?
subQuotationList: ["Thou'lt write to me, and tell me all that happens, Stephen?"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Yes.  What can I say now, but Heaven be wi' thee, Heaven bless thee,
Heaven thank thee and reward thee!
subQuotationList: ["Yes.  What can I say now, but Heaven be wi' thee, Heaven bless thee,\nHeaven thank thee and reward thee!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
May it bless thee, Stephen, too, in all thy wanderings, and send thee
peace and rest at last!
subQuotationList: ['May it bless thee, Stephen, too, in all thy wanderings, and send thee\npeace and rest at last!']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I towd thee, my dear, that night   that I would
never see or think o' onnything that angered me, but thou, so much better
than me, should'st be beside it.  Thou'rt beside it now.  Thou mak'st me
see it wi' a better eye.  Bless thee.  Good night.  Good-bye!
subQuotationList:
['I towd thee, my dear,', "that night   that I would
never see or think o' onnything that angered me, but thou, so much better
than me, should'st be beside it.  Thou'rt beside it now.  Thou mak'st me
see it wi' a better eye.  Bless thee.  Good night.  Good-bye!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Whom none of us believe, my dear Mrs. Bounderby, and who do not believe
themselves.  The only difference between us and the professors of virtue
or benevolence, or philanthropy   never mind the name   is, that we know it
is all meaningless, and say so; while they know it equally and will never
say so.
subQuotationList:
['Whom none of us believe, my dear Mrs. Bounderby, and who do not believe
themselves.  The only difference between us and the professors of virtue
or benevolence, or philanthropy   never mind the name   is, that we know it
is all meaningless, and say so; while they know it equally and will never
say so.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Why, sir, I am told that Nickits, gave seven hundred pound for that Seabeach.  Now, to be plain
with you, if I ever, in the whole course of my life, take seven looks at
it, at a hundred pound a look, it will be as much as I shall do.  No, by
George!  I don't forget that I am Josiah Bounderby of Coketown.  For
years upon years, the only pictures in my possession, or that I could
have got into my possession, by any means, unless I stole 'em, were the
engravings of a man shaving himself in a boot, on the blacking bottles
that I was overjoyed to use in cleaning boots with, and that I sold when
they were empty for a farthing a-piece, and glad to get it!
subQuotationList:
['Why, sir,', 'I am told that Nickits,', "gave seven hundred pound for that Seabeach.  Now, to be plain
with you, if I ever, in the whole course of my life, take seven looks at
it, at a hundred pound a look, it will be as much as I shall do.  No, by
George!  I don't forget that I am Josiah Bounderby of Coketown.  For
years upon years, the only pictures in my possession, or that I could
have got into my possession, by any means, unless I stole 'em, were the
engravings of a man shaving himself in a boot, on the blacking bottles
that I was overjoyed to use in cleaning boots with, and that I sold when
they were empty for a farthing a-piece, and glad to get it!"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
referringExpression: he would say to a visitor

quoteText:
Harthouse, you have a couple of horses down here.  Bring half a dozen
more if you like, and we'll find room for 'em.  There's stabling in this
place for a dozen horses; and unless Nickits is belied, he kept the full
number.  A round dozen of 'em, sir.  When that man was a boy, he went to
Westminster School.  Went to Westminster School as a King's Scholar, when
I was principally living on garbage, and sleeping in market baskets.
Why, if I wanted to keep a dozen horses   which I don't, for one's enough
for me   I couldn't bear to see 'em in their stalls here, and think what my
own lodging used to be.  I couldn't look at 'em, sir, and not order 'em
out.  Yet so things come round.  You see this place; you know what sort
of a place it is; you are aware that there's not a completer place of its
size in this kingdom or elsewhere   I don't care where   and here, got into
the middle of it, like a maggot into a nut, is Josiah Bounderby.  While
Nickits (as a man came into my office, and told me yesterday), Nickits,
who used to act in Latin, in the Westminster School plays, with the
chief-justices and nobility of this country applauding him till they were
black in the face, is drivelling at this minute   drivelling, sir!   in a
fifth floor, up a narrow dark back street in Antwerp.
subQuotationList:
["Harthouse, you have a couple of horses down here.  Bring half a dozen
more if you like, and we'll find room for 'em.  There's stabling in this
place for a dozen horses; and unless Nickits is belied, he kept the full
number.  A round dozen of 'em, sir.  When that man was a boy, he went to
Westminster School.  Went to Westminster School as a King's Scholar, when
I was principally living on garbage, and sleeping in market baskets.
Why, if I wanted to keep a dozen horses   which I don't, for one's enough
for me   I couldn't bear to see 'em in their stalls here, and think what my
own lodging used to be.  I couldn't look at 'em, sir, and not order 'em
out.  Yet so things come round.  You see this place; you know what sort
of a place it is; you are aware that there's not a completer place of its
size in this kingdom or elsewhere   I don't care where   and here, got into
the middle of it, like a maggot into a nut, is Josiah Bounderby.  While
Nickits (as a man came into my office, and told me yesterday), Nickits,
who used to act in Latin, in the Westminster School plays, with the
chief-justices and nobility of this country applauding him till they were
black in the face, is drivelling at this minute   drivelling, sir!   in a
fifth floor, up a narrow dark back street in Antwerp."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
Mrs. Bounderby, I esteem it a most fortunate accident that I find you
alone here.  I have for some time had a particular wish to speak to you.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Bounderby, I esteem it a most fortunate accident that I find you\nalone here.  I have for some time had a particular wish to speak to you.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Your brother.  My young friend Tom
subQuotationList: ['Your brother.  My young friend Tom']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I
never in my life, saw anything so remarkable and so
captivating as the lighting of those features!
subQuotationList: ['I\nnever in my life,', 'saw anything so remarkable and so\ncaptivating as the lighting of those features!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Pardon me.  The expression of your sisterly interest is so beautiful   Tom
should be so proud of it   I know this is inexcusable, but I am so
compelled to admire.
subQuotationList: ['Pardon me.  The expression of your sisterly interest is so beautiful   Tom\nshould be so proud of it   I know this is inexcusable, but I am so\ncompelled to admire.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Being so impulsive,
subQuotationList: ['Being so impulsive,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Mrs. Bounderby, no: you know I make no pretence with you.  You know I am
a sordid piece of human nature, ready to sell myself at any time for any
reasonable sum, and altogether incapable of any Arcadian proceeding
whatever.
subQuotationList:
['Mrs. Bounderby, no: you know I make no pretence with you.  You know I am
a sordid piece of human nature, ready to sell myself at any time for any
reasonable sum, and altogether incapable of any Arcadian proceeding
whatever.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: I am waiting, for your further reference to my brother.
subQuotationList: ['I am waiting,', 'for your further reference to my brother.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
You are rigid with me, and I deserve it.  I am as worthless a dog as you
will find, except that I am not false   not false.  But you surprised and
started me from my subject, which was your brother.  I have an interest
in him.
subQuotationList:
['You are rigid with me, and I deserve it.  I am as worthless a dog as you
will find, except that I am not false   not false.  But you surprised and
started me from my subject, which was your brother.  I have an interest
in him.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Have you an interest in anything, Mr. Harthouse?
subQuotationList: ['Have you an interest in anything, Mr. Harthouse?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
If you had asked me when I first came here, I should have said no.  I
must say now   even at the hazard of appearing to make a pretence, and of
justly awakening your incredulity   yes.
subQuotationList: ['If you had asked me when I first came here, I should have said no.  I\nmust say now   even at the hazard of appearing to make a pretence, and of\njustly awakening your incredulity   yes.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Mr. Harthouse, I give you credit for
being interested in my brother.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Harthouse, I give you credit for\nbeing interested in my brother.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Thank you.  I claim to deserve it.  You know how little I do claim, but
I will go that length.  You have done so much for him, you are so fond of
him; your whole life, Mrs. Bounderby, expresses such charming
self-forgetfulness on his account   pardon me again   I am running wide of
the subject.  I am interested in him for his own sake.
subQuotationList:
['Thank you.  I claim to deserve it.  You know how little I do claim, but
I will go that length.  You have done so much for him, you are so fond of
him; your whole life, Mrs. Bounderby, expresses such charming
self-forgetfulness on his account   pardon me again   I am running wide of
the subject.  I am interested in him for his own sake.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText:
Mrs. Bounderby, it is no irrevocable offence in a young fellow of your
brother's years, if he is heedless, inconsiderate, and expensive   a little
dissipated, in the common phrase.  Is he?
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Bounderby,', "it is no irrevocable offence in a young fellow of your\nbrother's years, if he is heedless, inconsiderate, and expensive   a little\ndissipated, in the common phrase.  Is he?"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Allow me to be frank.  Do you think he games at all?
subQuotationList: ['Allow me to be frank.  Do you think he games at all?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: I think he makes bets.
subQuotationList: ['I think he makes bets.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: I know he does.
subQuotationList: ['I know he does.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Of course he loses?
subQuotationList: ['Of course he loses?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Everybody does lose who bets.  May I hint at the probability of your
sometimes supplying him with money for these purposes?
subQuotationList: ['Everybody does lose who bets.  May I hint at the probability of your\nsometimes supplying him with money for these purposes?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Acquit me of impertinent curiosity, my dear Mrs. Bounderby.  I think Tom
may be gradually falling into trouble, and I wish to stretch out a
helping hand to him from the depths of my wicked experience.   Shall I say
again, for his sake?  Is that necessary?
subQuotationList:
['Acquit me of impertinent curiosity, my dear Mrs. Bounderby.  I think Tom
may be gradually falling into trouble, and I wish to stretch out a
helping hand to him from the depths of my wicked experience.   Shall I say
again, for his sake?  Is that necessary?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Candidly to confess everything that has occurred to me, I will confide to you my doubt whether he has had many
advantages.  Whether   forgive my plainness   whether any great amount of
confidence is likely to have been established between himself and his
most worthy father.
subQuotationList:
['Candidly to confess everything that has occurred to me,', 'I will confide to you my doubt whether he has had many
advantages.  Whether   forgive my plainness   whether any great amount of
confidence is likely to have been established between himself and his
most worthy father.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: I do not, think it likely.
subQuotationList: ['I do not,', 'think it likely.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Or, between himself, and   I may trust to your perfect understanding of my
meaning, I am sure   and his highly esteemed brother-in-law.
subQuotationList: ['Or, between himself, and   I may trust to your perfect understanding of my\nmeaning, I am sure   and his highly esteemed brother-in-law.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: I do not think that likely, either.
subQuotationList: ['I do not think that likely, either.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Mrs. Bounderby, may there be a
better confidence between yourself and me?  Tom has borrowed a
considerable sum of you?
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Bounderby,', 'may there be a\nbetter confidence between yourself and me?  Tom has borrowed a\nconsiderable sum of you?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
You will understand, Mr. Harthouse, you will understand that if I tell you what you press to know,
it is not by way of complaint or regret.  I would never complain of
anything, and what I have done I do not in the least regret.
subQuotationList: ['You will understand, Mr. Harthouse,', 'you will understand that if I tell you what you press to know,\nit is not by way of complaint or regret.  I would never complain of\nanything, and what I have done I do not in the least regret.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: So spirited, too!
subQuotationList: ['So spirited, too!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
When I married, I found that my brother was even at that time heavily in
debt.  Heavily for him, I mean.  Heavily enough to oblige me to sell some
trinkets.  They were no sacrifice.  I sold them very willingly.  I
attached no value to them.  They, were quite worthless to me.
subQuotationList:
['When I married, I found that my brother was even at that time heavily in
debt.  Heavily for him, I mean.  Heavily enough to oblige me to sell some
trinkets.  They were no sacrifice.  I sold them very willingly.  I
attached no value to them.  They, were quite worthless to me.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Since then, I have given my brother, at various times, what money I
could spare: in short, what money I have had.  Confiding in you at all,
on the faith of the interest you profess for him, I will not do so by
halves.  Since you have been in the habit of visiting here, he has wanted
in one sum as much as a hundred pounds.  I have not been able to give it
to him.  I have felt uneasy for the consequences of his being so
involved, but I have kept these secrets until now, when I trust them to
your honour.  I have held no confidence with any one, because   you
anticipated my reason just now.
subQuotationList:
['Since then, I have given my brother, at various times, what money I
could spare: in short, what money I have had.  Confiding in you at all,
on the faith of the interest you profess for him, I will not do so by
halves.  Since you have been in the habit of visiting here, he has wanted
in one sum as much as a hundred pounds.  I have not been able to give it
to him.  I have felt uneasy for the consequences of his being so
involved, but I have kept these secrets until now, when I trust them to
your honour.  I have held no confidence with any one, because   you
anticipated my reason just now.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
Mrs. Bounderby, though a graceless person, of the world worldly, I feel
the utmost interest, I assure you, in what you tell me.  I cannot
possibly be hard upon your brother.  I understand and share the wise
consideration with which you regard his errors.  With all possible
respect both for Mr. Gradgrind and for Mr. Bounderby, I think I perceive
that he has not been fortunate in his training.  Bred at a disadvantage
towards the society in which he has his part to play, he rushes into
these extremes for himself, from opposite extremes that have long been
forced   with the very best intentions we have no doubt   upon him.  Mr.
Bounderby's fine bluff English independence, though a most charming
characteristic, does not   as we have agreed   invite confidence.  If I might
venture to remark that it is the least in the world deficient in that
delicacy to which a youth mistaken, a character misconceived, and
abilities misdirected, would turn for relief and guidance, I should
express what it presents to my own view.
subQuotationList:
["Mrs. Bounderby, though a graceless person, of the world worldly, I feel
the utmost interest, I assure you, in what you tell me.  I cannot
possibly be hard upon your brother.  I understand and share the wise
consideration with which you regard his errors.  With all possible
respect both for Mr. Gradgrind and for Mr. Bounderby, I think I perceive
that he has not been fortunate in his training.  Bred at a disadvantage
towards the society in which he has his part to play, he rushes into
these extremes for himself, from opposite extremes that have long been
forced   with the very best intentions we have no doubt   upon him.  Mr.
Bounderby's fine bluff English independence, though a most charming
characteristic, does not   as we have agreed   invite confidence.  If I might
venture to remark that it is the least in the world deficient in that
delicacy to which a youth mistaken, a character misconceived, and
abilities misdirected, would turn for relief and guidance, I should
express what it presents to my own view."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby', 'Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby', 'Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
All allowance, must be made.  I have one great fault to
find with Tom, however, which I cannot forgive, and for which I take him
heavily to account.
subQuotationList: ['All allowance,', 'must be made.  I have one great fault to\nfind with Tom, however, which I cannot forgive, and for which I take him\nheavily to account.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Perhaps, I have said enough.  Perhaps it would have been
better, on the whole, if no allusion to it had escaped me.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps,', 'I have said enough.  Perhaps it would have been\nbetter, on the whole, if no allusion to it had escaped me.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: You alarm me, Mr. Harthouse.  Pray let me know it.
subQuotationList: ['You alarm me, Mr. Harthouse.  Pray let me know it.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
To relieve you from needless apprehension   and as this confidence
regarding your brother, which I prize I am sure above all possible
things, has been established between us   I obey.  I cannot forgive him for
not being more sensible in every word, look, and act of his life, of the
affection of his best friend; of the devotion of his best friend; of her
unselfishness; of her sacrifice.  The return he makes her, within my
observation, is a very poor one.  What she has done for him demands his
constant love and gratitude, not his ill-humour and caprice.  Careless
fellow as I am, I am not so indifferent, Mrs. Bounderby, as to be
regardless of this vice in your brother, or inclined to consider it a
venial offence.
subQuotationList:
['To relieve you from needless apprehension   and as this confidence
regarding your brother, which I prize I am sure above all possible
things, has been established between us   I obey.  I cannot forgive him for
not being more sensible in every word, look, and act of his life, of the
affection of his best friend; of the devotion of his best friend; of her
unselfishness; of her sacrifice.  The return he makes her, within my
observation, is a very poor one.  What she has done for him demands his
constant love and gratitude, not his ill-humour and caprice.  Careless
fellow as I am, I am not so indifferent, Mrs. Bounderby, as to be
regardless of this vice in your brother, or inclined to consider it a
venial offence.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText:
In a word, it is to correct your brother in this, Mrs. Bounderby, that I
must aspire.  My better knowledge of his circumstances, and my direction
and advice in extricating them   rather valuable, I hope, as coming from a
scapegrace on a much larger scale   will give me some influence over him,
and all I gain I shall certainly use towards this end.  I have said
enough, and more than enough.  I seem to be protesting that I am a sort
of good fellow, when, upon my honour, I have not the least intention to
make any protestation to that effect, and openly announce that I am
nothing of the sort.  Yonder, among the trees, is your brother himself; no doubt, just come down.  As he seems to be
loitering in this direction, it may be as well, perhaps, to walk towards
him, and throw ourselves in his way.  He has been very silent and doleful
of late.  Perhaps, his brotherly conscience is touched   if there are such
things as consciences.  Though, upon my honour, I hear of them much too
often to believe in them.
subQuotationList:
['In a word, it is to correct your brother in this, Mrs. Bounderby, that I
must aspire.  My better knowledge of his circumstances, and my direction
and advice in extricating them   rather valuable, I hope, as coming from a
scapegrace on a much larger scale   will give me some influence over him,
and all I gain I shall certainly use towards this end.  I have said
enough, and more than enough.  I seem to be protesting that I am a sort
of good fellow, when, upon my honour, I have not the least intention to
make any protestation to that effect, and openly announce that I am
nothing of the sort.  Yonder, among the trees,', 'is your brother himself; no doubt, just come down.  As he seems to be
loitering in this direction, it may be as well, perhaps, to walk towards
him, and throw ourselves in his way.  He has been very silent and doleful
of late.  Perhaps, his brotherly conscience is touched   if there are such
things as consciences.  Though, upon my honour, I hear of them much too
often to believe in them.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText: Halloa! I didn't know you were here.
subQuotationList: ['Halloa!', "I didn't know you were here."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Whose name, Tom, have you been carving on the trees?
subQuotationList: ['Whose name, Tom,', 'have you been carving on the trees?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Whose name? Oh!  You mean what girl's name?
subQuotationList: ['Whose name?', "Oh!  You mean what girl's name?"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
You have a suspicious appearance of inscribing some fair creature's on
the bark, Tom.
subQuotationList: ["You have a suspicious appearance of inscribing some fair creature's on\nthe bark, Tom."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Not much of that, Mr. Harthouse, unless some fair creature with a
slashing fortune at her own disposal would take a fancy to me.  Or she
might be as ugly as she was rich, without any fear of losing me.  I'd
carve her name as often as she liked.
subQuotationList:
["Not much of that, Mr. Harthouse, unless some fair creature with a
slashing fortune at her own disposal would take a fancy to me.  Or she
might be as ugly as she was rich, without any fear of losing me.  I'd
carve her name as often as she liked."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: I am afraid you are mercenary, Tom.
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid you are mercenary, Tom.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Mercenary, Who is not mercenary?  Ask my sister.
subQuotationList: ['Mercenary,', 'Who is not mercenary?  Ask my sister.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Have you so proved it to be a failing of mine, Tom?
subQuotationList: ['Have you so proved it to be a failing of mine, Tom?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: You know whether the cap fits you, Loo, If it does, you can wear it.
subQuotationList: ['You know whether the cap fits you, Loo,', 'If it does, you can wear it.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Tom is misanthropical to-day, as all bored people are now and then, Don't believe him, Mrs. Bounderby.  He knows much
better.  I shall disclose some of his opinions of you, privately
expressed to me, unless he relents a little.
subQuotationList: ['Tom is misanthropical to-day, as all bored people are now and then,', "Don't believe him, Mrs. Bounderby.  He knows much\nbetter.  I shall disclose some of his opinions of you, privately\nexpressed to me, unless he relents a little."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas']], [['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText:
At all events, Mr. Harthouse, you can't tell her that I
ever praised her for being mercenary.  I may have praised her for being
the contrary, and I should do it again, if I had as good reason.
However, never mind this now; it's not very interesting to you, and I am
sick of the subject.
subQuotationList:
['At all events, Mr. Harthouse,', "you can't tell her that I
ever praised her for being mercenary.  I may have praised her for being
the contrary, and I should do it again, if I had as good reason.
However, never mind this now; it's not very interesting to you, and I am
sick of the subject."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: Tom, my fine fellow, I want to have a word with you.
subQuotationList: ['Tom, my fine fellow, I want to have a word with you.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Tom, what's the matter?
subQuotationList: ["Tom, what's the matter?"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Oh!  Mr. Harthouse, I am hard up, and bothered
out of my life.
subQuotationList: ['Oh!  Mr. Harthouse,', 'I am hard up, and bothered\nout of my life.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: My good fellow, so am I.
subQuotationList: ['My good fellow, so am I.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
You! You are the picture of independence.  Mr.
Harthouse, I am in a horrible mess.  You have no idea what a state I have
got myself into   what a state my sister might have got me out of, if she
would only have done it.
subQuotationList:
['You!', 'You are the picture of independence.  Mr.
Harthouse, I am in a horrible mess.  You have no idea what a state I have
got myself into   what a state my sister might have got me out of, if she
would only have done it.']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Tom, you are inconsiderate: you expect too much of your sister.  You
have had money of her, you dog, you know you have.
subQuotationList: ['Tom, you are inconsiderate: you expect too much of your sister.  You\nhave had money of her, you dog, you know you have.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText:
Well, Mr. Harthouse, I know I have.  How else was I to get it?  Here's
old Bounderby always boasting that at my age he lived upon twopence a
month, or something of that sort.  Here's my father drawing what he calls
a line, and tying me down to it from a baby, neck and heels.  Here's my
mother who never has anything of her own, except her complaints.  What
_is_ a fellow to do for money, and where _am_ I to look for it, if not to
my sister?
subQuotationList:
["Well, Mr. Harthouse, I know I have.  How else was I to get it?  Here's
old Bounderby always boasting that at my age he lived upon twopence a
month, or something of that sort.  Here's my father drawing what he calls
a line, and tying me down to it from a baby, neck and heels.  Here's my
mother who never has anything of her own, except her complaints.  What
_is_ a fellow to do for money, and where _am_ I to look for it, if not to
my sister?"]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mrs. Gradgrind'], ['Mrs. Gradgrind'], ['Mrs. Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: But, my dear Tom, if your sister has not got it
subQuotationList: ['But, my dear Tom, if your sister has not got it']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Not got it, Mr. Harthouse?  I don't say she has got it.  I may have
wanted more than she was likely to have got.  But then she ought to get
it.  She could get it.  It's of no use pretending to make a secret of
matters now, after what I have told you already; you know she didn't
marry old Bounderby for her own sake, or for his sake, but for my sake.
Then why doesn't she get what I want, out of him, for my sake?  She is
not obliged to say what she is going to do with it; she is sharp enough;
she could manage to coax it out of him, if she chose.  Then why doesn't
she choose, when I tell her of what consequence it is?  But no.  There
she sits in his company like a stone, instead of making herself agreeable
and getting it easily.  I don't know what you may call this, but I call
it unnatural conduct.
subQuotationList:
["Not got it, Mr. Harthouse?  I don't say she has got it.  I may have
wanted more than she was likely to have got.  But then she ought to get
it.  She could get it.  It's of no use pretending to make a secret of
matters now, after what I have told you already; you know she didn't
marry old Bounderby for her own sake, or for his sake, but for my sake.
Then why doesn't she get what I want, out of him, for my sake?  She is
not obliged to say what she is going to do with it; she is sharp enough;

she choose, when I tell her of what consequence it is?  But no.  There
she sits in his company like a stone, instead of making herself agreeable
and getting it easily.  I don't know what you may call this, but I call
it unnatural conduct."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: My dear Tom, let me try to be your banker.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Tom,', 'let me try to be your banker.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: For God's sake, don't talk about bankers!
subQuotationList: ["For God's sake,", "don't talk about bankers!"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
What is the present need, Tom?  Three figures?  Out with them.  Say what
they are.
subQuotationList: ['What is the present need, Tom?  Three figures?  Out with them.  Say what\nthey are.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Mr. Harthouse, it's too
late; the money is of no use to me at present.  I should have had it
before to be of use to me.  But I am very much obliged to you; you're a
true friend.
subQuotationList:
['Mr. Harthouse,', "it's too
late; the money is of no use to me at present.  I should have had it
before to be of use to me.  But I am very much obliged to you; you're a
true friend."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
Whelp, whelp! what an
Ass you are!
subQuotationList: ['Whelp, whelp!', 'what an\nAss you are!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: And I take your offer as a great kindness, As a great kindness, Mr. Harthouse.
subQuotationList: ['And I take your offer as a great kindness,', 'As a great kindness, Mr. Harthouse.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Well, it may be of more use by and by.  And, my
good fellow, if you will open your bedevilments to me when they come
thick upon you, I may show you better ways out of them than you can find
for yourself.
subQuotationList:
['Well,', 'it may be of more use by and by.  And, my
good fellow, if you will open your bedevilments to me when they come
thick upon you, I may show you better ways out of them than you can find
for yourself.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText: Thank you, I wish I had known you sooner, Mr. Harthouse.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you,', 'I wish I had known you sooner, Mr. Harthouse.']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
Now, you see, Tom, every man is selfish in everything he does, and I am exactly like the
rest of my fellow-creatures.  I am desperately intent; on your softening towards your
sister   which you ought to do; and on your being a more loving and
agreeable sort of brother   which you ought to be.
subQuotationList:
['Now, you see, Tom,', 'every man is selfish in everything he does, and I am exactly like the
rest of my fellow-creatures.  I am desperately intent;', 'on your softening towards your
sister   which you ought to do; and on your being a more loving and
agreeable sort of brother   which you ought to be.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']], [], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText: I will be, Mr. Harthouse.
subQuotationList: ['I will be, Mr. Harthouse.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: No time like the present, Tom.  Begin at once.
subQuotationList: ['No time like the present, Tom.  Begin at once.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Certainly I will.  And my sister Loo shall say so.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly I will.  And my sister Loo shall say so.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Having made which bargain, Tom, we will tear ourselves asunder
until dinner-time.
subQuotationList: ['Having made which bargain, Tom,', 'we will tear ourselves asunder\nuntil dinner-time.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I
didn't mean to be cross, Loo, I know you are fond of me, and you know I am fond of you.
subQuotationList: ["I\ndidn't mean to be cross, Loo,", 'I know you are fond of me, and you know I am fond of you.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: So much the less is the whelp the only creature that she cares for, So much the less, so much the less.
subQuotationList: ['So much the less is the whelp the only creature that she cares for,', 'So much the less, so much the less.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionTextsList: [['the whelp the only creature that she cares for', 'she'], []]

quoteText: Harthouse! Have you heard?
subQuotationList: ['Harthouse!', 'Have you heard?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Heard what?
subQuotationList: ['Heard what?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Then you _haven't_ heard!
subQuotationList: ["Then you _haven't_ heard!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: I have heard you, and so has this brute.  I have heard nothing else.
subQuotationList: ['I have heard you, and so has this brute.  I have heard nothing else.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: The Bank's robbed!
subQuotationList: ["The Bank's robbed!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: You don't mean it!
subQuotationList: ["You don't mean it!"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Robbed last night, sir.  Robbed in an extraordinary manner.  Robbed with
a false key.
subQuotationList: ['Robbed last night, sir.  Robbed in an extraordinary manner.  Robbed with\na false key.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Of much?
subQuotationList: ['Of much?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Why, no; not of very much.  But it
might have been.
subQuotationList: ['Why, no; not of very much.  But it\nmight have been.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
referringExpression: Mr Bounderby in his desire to make the most of it really seemed mortified by being obliged to reply

quoteText: Of how much?
subQuotationList: ['Of how much?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Oh! as a sum   if you stick to a sum   of not more than a hundred and fifty
pound, But it's not the sum; it's the
fact.  It's the fact of the Bank being robbed, that's the important
circumstance.  I am surprised you don't see it.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! as a sum   if you stick to a sum   of not more than a hundred and fifty
pound,', "But it's not the sum; it's the
fact.  It's the fact of the Bank being robbed, that's the important
circumstance.  I am surprised you don't see it."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
My dear Bounderby, I _do_ see it; and am as overcome as you can possibly
desire me to be, by the spectacle afforded to my mental view.
Nevertheless, I may be allowed, I hope, to congratulate you   which I do
with all my soul, I assure you   on your not having sustained a greater
loss.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Bounderby,', 'I _do_ see it; and am as overcome as you can possibly
desire me to be, by the spectacle afforded to my mental view.
Nevertheless, I may be allowed, I hope, to congratulate you   which I do
with all my soul, I assure you   on your not having sustained a greater
loss.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Thank'ee, But I
tell you what.  It might have been twenty thousand pound.
subQuotationList: ["Thank'ee,", 'But I\ntell you what.  It might have been twenty thousand pound.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: I suppose it might.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose it might.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Suppose it might!  By the Lord, you _may_ suppose so.  By George! It
might have been twice twenty.  There's no knowing what it would have
been, or wouldn't have been, as it was, but for the fellows' being
disturbed.
subQuotationList:
['Suppose it might!  By the Lord, you _may_ suppose so.  By George!', "It
might have been twice twenty.  There's no knowing what it would have
been, or wouldn't have been, as it was, but for the fellows' being
disturbed."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Here's Tom Gradgrind's daughter knows pretty well what it might have
been, if you don't, Dropped, sir, as if she was
shot when I told her!  Never knew her do such a thing before.  Does her
credit, under the circumstances, in my opinion!
subQuotationList:
["Here's Tom Gradgrind's daughter knows pretty well what it might have
been, if you don't,", 'Dropped, sir, as if she was
shot when I told her!  Never knew her do such a thing before.  Does her
credit, under the circumstances, in my opinion!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Why, I am going to tell you, If you hadn't been so mighty particular about the sum,
I should have begun to tell you before.  You know this lady (for she _is_
a lady), Mrs. Sparsit?
subQuotationList: ['Why, I am going to tell you,', "If you hadn't been so mighty particular about the sum,\nI should have begun to tell you before.  You know this lady (for she _is_\na lady), Mrs. Sparsit?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText: I have already had the honour
subQuotationList: ['I have already had the honour']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Very well.  And this young man, Bitzer, you saw him too on the same
occasion?
subQuotationList: ['Very well.  And this young man, Bitzer, you saw him too on the same\noccasion?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Very well.  They live at the Bank.  You know they live at the Bank,
perhaps?  Very well.  Yesterday afternoon, at the close of business
hours, everything was put away as usual.  In the iron room that this
young fellow sleeps outside of, there was never mind how much.  In the
little safe in young Tom's closet, the safe used for petty purposes,
there was a hundred and fifty odd pound.
subQuotationList:
["Very well.  They live at the Bank.  You know they live at the Bank,
perhaps?  Very well.  Yesterday afternoon, at the close of business
hours, everything was put away as usual.  In the iron room that this
young fellow sleeps outside of, there was never mind how much.  In the
little safe in young Tom's closet, the safe used for petty purposes,
there was a hundred and fifty odd pound."]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: A hundred and fifty-four, seven, one,
subQuotationList: ['A hundred and fifty-four, seven, one,']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Come! let's have
none of _your_ interruptions.  It's enough to be robbed while you're
snoring because you're too comfortable, without being put right with
_your_ four seven ones.  I didn't snore, myself, when I was your age, let
me tell you.  I hadn't victuals enough to snore.  And I didn't four seven
one.  Not if I knew it.
subQuotationList:
['Come!', "let's have
none of _your_ interruptions.  It's enough to be robbed while you're
snoring because you're too comfortable, without being put right with
_your_ four seven ones.  I didn't snore, myself, when I was your age, let
me tell you.  I hadn't victuals enough to snore.  And I didn't four seven
one.  Not if I knew it."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
A hundred and fifty odd pound, That sum of
money, young Tom locked in his safe, not a very strong safe, but that's
no matter now.  Everything was left, all right.  Some time in the night,
while this young fellow snored   Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am, you say you have
heard him snore?
subQuotationList:
['A hundred and fifty odd pound,', "That sum of
money, young Tom locked in his safe, not a very strong safe, but that's
no matter now.  Everything was left, all right.  Some time in the night,
while this young fellow snored   Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am, you say you have
heard him snore?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Bitzer'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Bitzer']]]

quoteText:
Sir, I cannot say that I have heard him
precisely snore, and therefore must not make that statement.  But on
winter evenings, when he has fallen asleep at his table, I have heard
him, what I should prefer to describe as partially choke.  I have heard
him on such occasions produce sounds of a nature similar to what may be
sometimes heard in Dutch clocks.  Not, that I would convey any imputation on
his moral character.  Far from it.  I have always considered Bitzer a
young man of the most upright principle; and to that I beg to bear my
testimony.
subQuotationList:
['Sir,', 'I cannot say that I have heard him
precisely snore, and therefore must not make that statement.  But on
winter evenings, when he has fallen asleep at his table, I have heard
him, what I should prefer to describe as partially choke.  I have heard
him on such occasions produce sounds of a nature similar to what may be
sometimes heard in Dutch clocks.  Not,', 'that I would convey any imputation on
his moral character.  Far from it.  I have always considered Bitzer a
young man of the most upright principle; and to that I beg to bear my
testimony.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Well! while he was snoring, _or_
choking, _or_ Dutch-clocking, _or_ something _or_ other   being asleep   some
fellows, somehow, whether previously concealed in the house or not
remains to be seen, got to young Tom's safe, forced it, and abstracted
the contents.  Being then disturbed, they made off; letting themselves
out at the main door, and double-locking it again (it was double-locked,
and the key under Mrs. Sparsit's pillow) with a false key, which was
picked up in the street near the Bank, about twelve o'clock to-day.  No
alarm takes place, till this chap, Bitzer, turns out this morning, and
begins to open and prepare the offices for business.  Then, looking at
Tom's safe, he sees the door ajar, and finds the lock forced, and the
money gone.
subQuotationList:
['Well!', "while he was snoring, _or_
choking, _or_ Dutch-clocking, _or_ something _or_ other   being asleep   some
fellows, somehow, whether previously concealed in the house or not
remains to be seen, got to young Tom's safe, forced it, and abstracted
the contents.  Being then disturbed, they made off; letting themselves
out at the main door, and double-locking it again (it was double-locked,
and the key under Mrs. Sparsit's pillow) with a false key, which was
picked up in the street near the Bank, about twelve o'clock to-day.  No
alarm takes place, till this chap, Bitzer, turns out this morning, and
begins to open and prepare the offices for business.  Then, looking at
Tom's safe, he sees the door ajar, and finds the lock forced, and the
money gone."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Where is Tom, by the by?
subQuotationList: ['Where is Tom, by the by?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
He has been helping the police, and stays behind at
the Bank.  I wish these fellows had tried to rob me when I was at his
time of life.  They would have been out of pocket if they had invested
eighteenpence in the job; I can tell 'em that.
subQuotationList:
['He has been helping the police,', "and stays behind at
the Bank.  I wish these fellows had tried to rob me when I was at his
time of life.  They would have been out of pocket if they had invested
eighteenpence in the job; I can tell 'em that."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Is anybody suspected?
subQuotationList: ['Is anybody suspected?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Suspected?  I should think there was somebody suspected.  Egod! Josiah Bounderby of Coketown is not to be plundered and nobody
suspected.  No, thank you! Well, I'll tell you.  It's not to be mentioned everywhere; it's not to be
mentioned anywhere: in order that the scoundrels concerned (there's a
gang of 'em) may be thrown off their guard.  So take this in confidence.
Now wait a bit.
subQuotationList:
['Suspected?  I should think there was somebody suspected.  Egod!', 'Josiah Bounderby of Coketown is not to be plundered and nobody
suspected.  No, thank you!', 'Well,', "I'll tell you.  It's not to be mentioned everywhere; it's not to be
mentioned anywhere: in order that the scoundrels concerned (there's a
gang of 'em) may be thrown off their guard.  So take this in confidence.
Now wait a bit."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
What should you
say to; to a Hand being in it?
subQuotationList: ['What should you\nsay to;', 'to a Hand being in it?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: I hope, not our friend Blackpot?
subQuotationList: ['I hope,', 'not our friend Blackpot?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Say Pool instead of Pot, sir, and that's the man.
subQuotationList: ['Say Pool instead of Pot, sir,', "and that's the man."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
O yes!  I know! I
know!  I am used to that.  I know all about it.  They are the finest
people in the world, these fellows are.  They have got the gift of the
gab, they have.  They only want to have their rights explained to them,
they do.  But I tell you what.  Show me a dissatisfied Hand, and I'll
show you a man that's fit for anything bad, I don't care what it is. But I am acquainted with these chaps, I can read 'em
off, like books.  Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am, I appeal to you.  What warning did
I give that fellow, the first time he set foot in the house, when the
express object of his visit was to know how he could knock Religion over,
and floor the Established Church?  Mrs. Sparsit, in point of high
connexions, you are on a level with the aristocracy,   did I say, or did I
not say, to that fellow, ?
subQuotationList:
['O yes!  I know!', "I
know!  I am used to that.  I know all about it.  They are the finest
people in the world, these fellows are.  They have got the gift of the
gab, they have.  They only want to have their rights explained to them,
they do.  But I tell you what.  Show me a dissatisfied Hand, and I'll
show you a man that's fit for anything bad, I don't care what it is.", 'But I am acquainted with these chaps,', "I can read 'em
off, like books.  Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am, I appeal to you.  What warning did
