not say, to that fellow,", '?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [], [], [['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']], []]

quoteText:
Assuredly, sir, you did, in a highly impressive
manner, give him such an admonition.
subQuotationList: ['Assuredly, sir,', 'you did, in a highly impressive\nmanner, give him such an admonition.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
When he shocked you, ma'am, when he shocked your
feelings?
subQuotationList: ["When he shocked you, ma'am,", 'when he shocked your\nfeelings?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Yes, sir, he
certainly did so.  Though I do not mean to say but that my feelings may
be weaker on such points   more foolish if the term is preferred   than they
might have been, if I had always occupied my present position.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, sir,', 'he
certainly did so.  Though I do not mean to say but that my feelings may
be weaker on such points   more foolish if the term is preferred   than they
might have been, if I had always occupied my present position.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
You can recall for yourself, Harthouse, what I said to him when you saw
him.  I didn't mince the matter with him.  I am never mealy with 'em.  I
KNOW 'em.  Very well, sir.  Three days after that, he bolted.  Went off,
nobody knows where: as my mother did in my infancy   only with this
difference, that he is a worse subject than my mother, if possible.  What
did he do before he went?  What do you say; to his being seen   night after
night   watching the Bank?   to his lurking about there   after dark?   To its
striking Mrs. Sparsit   that he could be lurking for no good   To her calling
Bitzer's attention to him, and their both taking notice of him   And to its
appearing on inquiry to-day   that he was also noticed by the neighbours?
subQuotationList:
["You can recall for yourself, Harthouse, what I said to him when you saw
him.  I didn't mince the matter with him.  I am never mealy with 'em.  I
KNOW 'em.  Very well, sir.  Three days after that, he bolted.  Went off,
nobody knows where: as my mother did in my infancy   only with this
difference, that he is a worse subject than my mother, if possible.  What
did he do before he went?  What do you say;", "to his being seen   night after
night   watching the Bank?   to his lurking about there   after dark?   To its
striking Mrs. Sparsit   that he could be lurking for no good   To her calling
Bitzer's attention to him, and their both taking notice of him   And to its
appearing on inquiry to-day   that he was also noticed by the neighbours?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Bitzer'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Bitzer', 'Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: Suspicious, certainly.
subQuotationList: ['Suspicious,', 'certainly.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I think so, sir, I think so.  But
there are more of 'em in it.  There's an old woman.  One never hears of
these things till the mischief's done; all sorts of defects are found out
in the stable door after the horse is stolen; there's an old woman turns
up now.  An old woman who seems to have been flying into town on a
broomstick, every now and then.  _She_ watches the place a whole day
before this fellow begins, and on the night when you saw him, she steals
away with him and holds a council with him   I suppose, to make her report
on going off duty, and be damned to her. This is not all of 'em, even as we already know 'em, But I have said enough for the
present.  You'll have the goodness to keep it quiet, and mention it to no
one.  It may take time, but we shall have 'em.  It's policy to give 'em
line enough, and there's no objection to that.
subQuotationList:
['I think so, sir,', "I think so.  But
there are more of 'em in it.  There's an old woman.  One never hears of
these things till the mischief's done; all sorts of defects are found out
in the stable door after the horse is stolen; there's an old woman turns
up now.  An old woman who seems to have been flying into town on a
broomstick, every now and then.  _She_ watches the place a whole day
before this fellow begins, and on the night when you saw him, she steals
away with him and holds a council with him   I suppose, to make her report
on going off duty, and be damned to her.", "This is not all of 'em, even as we already know 'em,", "But I have said enough for the
present.  You'll have the goodness to keep it quiet, and mention it to no
one.  It may take time, but we shall have 'em.  It's policy to give 'em
line enough, and there's no objection to that."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['The Old Woman'], ['The Old Woman'], ['The Old Woman'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Louisa Bounderby', 'Bitzer', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Louisa Bounderby', 'Bitzer', 'Josiah Bounderby', 'Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
Of course, they will be punished with the utmost rigour of the law, as
notice-boards observe, and serve them right.
Fellows who go in for Banks must take the consequences.  If there were no
consequences, we should all go in for Banks.
subQuotationList:
['Of course, they will be punished with the utmost rigour of the law, as
notice-boards observe,', 'and serve them right.
Fellows who go in for Banks must take the consequences.  If there were no
consequences, we should all go in for Banks.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
For the present, Loo Bounderby, here's Mrs. Sparsit
to look after.  Mrs. Sparsit's nerves have been acted upon by this
business, and she'll stay here a day or two.  So make her comfortable.
subQuotationList: ['For the present, Loo Bounderby,', "here's Mrs. Sparsit\nto look after.  Mrs. Sparsit's nerves have been acted upon by this\nbusiness, and she'll stay here a day or two.  So make her comfortable."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Thank you very much, sir, but pray do not
let My comfort be a consideration.  Anything will do for Me.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you very much, sir,', 'but pray do not\nlet My comfort be a consideration.  Anything will do for Me.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: but it is my duty to remember,
subQuotationList: ['but it is my duty to remember,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
referringExpression: Mrs Sparsit was fond of observing

quoteText:
that what I was, I am no longer.
Indeed, if I could altogether cancel the remembrance that Mr.
Sparsit was a Powler, or that I myself am related to the Scadgers family;
or if I could even revoke the fact, and make myself a person of common
descent and ordinary connexions; I would gladly do so.  I should think
it, under existing circumstances, right to do so.
subQuotationList:
['that what I was, I am no longer.
Indeed,', 'if I could altogether cancel the remembrance that Mr.
Sparsit was a Powler, or that I myself am related to the Scadgers family;
or if I could even revoke the fact, and make myself a person of common
descent and ordinary connexions; I would gladly do so.  I should think
it, under existing circumstances, right to do so.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Indeed you are very good, sir; wait for the
simple mutton.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed you are very good, sir;', 'wait for the\nsimple mutton.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
You have still good spirits, sir, I am thankful
to find;
subQuotationList: ['You have still good spirits, sir, I am thankful\nto find;']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
referringExpression: she would force a lambent brightness and would be fitfully cheerful and would say

quoteText: Miss Gradgrind,
subQuotationList: ['Miss Gradgrind,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
referringExpression: She had a curious propensity to call

quoteText: the differences, being such.
subQuotationList: ['the differences,', 'being such.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Don't be low, sir.
Pray let me see you cheerful, sir, as I used to do.
subQuotationList: ["Don't be low, sir.\nPray let me see you cheerful, sir, as I used to do."]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I cannot bear to see you so, sir, Try
a hand at backgammon, sir, as you used to do when I had the honour of
living under your roof.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot bear to see you so, sir,', 'Try\na hand at backgammon, sir, as you used to do when I had the honour of\nliving under your roof.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: I haven't played backgammon, ma'am, since that time.
subQuotationList: ["I haven't played backgammon, ma'am,", 'since that time.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
No, sir, I am aware that you have not.  I remember that Miss Gradgrind takes no
interest in the game.  But I shall be happy, sir, if you will
condescend.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir,', 'I am aware that you have not.  I remember that Miss Gradgrind takes no\ninterest in the game.  But I shall be happy, sir, if you will\ncondescend.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
What's the matter, ma'am? you
don't see a Fire, do you?
subQuotationList: ["What's the matter, ma'am?", "you\ndon't see a Fire, do you?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh dear no, sir, I
was thinking of the dew.
subQuotationList: ['Oh dear no, sir,', 'I\nwas thinking of the dew.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: What have you got to do with the dew, ma'am?
subQuotationList: ["What have you got to do with the dew, ma'am?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
It's not myself, sir, I am
fearful of Miss Gradgrind's taking cold.
subQuotationList: ["It's not myself, sir,", "I am\nfearful of Miss Gradgrind's taking cold."]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: She never takes cold,
subQuotationList: ['She never takes cold,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Really, sir? Oh, sir? Not your sherry warm, with
lemon-peel and nutmeg?
subQuotationList: ['Really, sir?', 'Oh, sir?', 'Not your sherry warm, with\nlemon-peel and nutmeg?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Why, I have got out of the habit of taking it
now, ma'am,
subQuotationList: ["Why, I have got out of the habit of taking it\nnow, ma'am,"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
The more's the pity, sir, you are losing all your good old habits.  Cheer up, sir!
If Miss Gradgrind will permit me, I will offer to make it for you, as I
have often done.
subQuotationList: ["The more's the pity, sir,", 'you are losing all your good old habits.  Cheer up, sir!\nIf Miss Gradgrind will permit me, I will offer to make it for you, as I\nhave often done.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
It will do you good, sir.  It will warm your heart.  It is
the sort of thing you want, and ought to take, sir.
subQuotationList: ['It will do you good, sir.  It will warm your heart.  It is\nthe sort of thing you want, and ought to take, sir.']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText: Your health, ma'am!
subQuotationList: ["Your health, ma'am!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Thank you, sir.  The same to you, and happiness also.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, sir.  The same to you, and happiness also.']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText:
Tom, have you anything to tell me?  If ever you loved me in your life,
and have anything concealed from every one besides, tell it to me.
subQuotationList: ['Tom, have you anything to tell me?  If ever you loved me in your life,\nand have anything concealed from every one besides, tell it to me.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: I don't know what you mean, Loo.  You have been dreaming.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know what you mean, Loo.  You have been dreaming."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: My dear brother:
subQuotationList: ['My dear brother:']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
is
there nothing that you have to tell me?  Is there nothing you can tell me
if you will?  You can tell me nothing that will change me.  O Tom, tell
me the truth!
subQuotationList:
['is
there nothing that you have to tell me?  Is there nothing you can tell me
if you will?  You can tell me nothing that will change me.  O Tom, tell
me the truth!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: I don't know what you mean, Loo!
subQuotationList: ["I don't know what you mean, Loo!"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
As you lie here alone, my dear, in the melancholy night, so you must lie
somewhere one night, when even I, if I am living then, shall have left
you.  As I am here beside you, barefoot, unclothed, undistinguishable in
darkness, so must I lie through all the night of my decay, until I am
dust.  In the name of that time, Tom, tell me the truth now!
subQuotationList:
['As you lie here alone, my dear, in the melancholy night, so you must lie
somewhere one night, when even I, if I am living then, shall have left
you.  As I am here beside you, barefoot, unclothed, undistinguishable in
darkness, so must I lie through all the night of my decay, until I am
dust.  In the name of that time, Tom, tell me the truth now!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: What is it you want to know?
subQuotationList: ['What is it you want to know?']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: You may be certain;
subQuotationList: ['You may be certain;']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
that I will not reproach you.  You may be certain
that I will be compassionate and true to you.  You may be certain that I
will save you at whatever cost.  O Tom, have you nothing to tell me?
Whisper very softly.  Say only
subQuotationList:
['that I will not reproach you.  You may be certain
that I will be compassionate and true to you.  You may be certain that I
will save you at whatever cost.  O Tom, have you nothing to tell me?
Whisper very softly.  Say only']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText: and I shall understand you!
subQuotationList: ['and I shall understand you!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Not a word, Tom?
subQuotationList: ['Not a word, Tom?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
How can I say Yes, or how can I say No, when I don't know what you mean?
Loo, you are a brave, kind girl, worthy I begin to think of a better
brother than I am.  But I have nothing more to say.  Go to bed, go to
bed.
subQuotationList:
["How can I say Yes, or how can I say No, when I don't know what you mean?
Loo, you are a brave, kind girl, worthy I begin to think of a better
brother than I am.  But I have nothing more to say.  Go to bed, go to
bed."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: You are tired,
subQuotationList: ['You are tired,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Yes, I am quite tired out.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I am quite tired out.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
You have been so hurried and disturbed to-day.  Have any fresh
discoveries been made?
subQuotationList: ['You have been so hurried and disturbed to-day.  Have any fresh\ndiscoveries been made?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Only those you have heard of, from   him.
subQuotationList: ['Only those you have heard of, from   him.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Tom, have you said to any one that we made a visit to those people, and
that we saw those three together?
subQuotationList: ['Tom, have you said to any one that we made a visit to those people, and\nthat we saw those three together?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['The Old Woman', 'Stephen Blackpool', 'Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Young Thomas', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['The Old Woman', 'Stephen Blackpool', 'Rachel Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
No.  Didn't you yourself particularly ask me to keep it quiet when you
asked me to go there with you?
subQuotationList: ["No.  Didn't you yourself particularly ask me to keep it quiet when you\nasked me to go there with you?"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Yes.  But I did not know then what was going to happen.
subQuotationList: ['Yes.  But I did not know then what was going to happen.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Nor I neither.  How could I?
subQuotationList: ['Nor I neither.  How could I?']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Ought I to say, after what has happened, that I made that
visit?  Should I say so?  Must I say so?
subQuotationList: ['Ought I to say, after what has happened,', 'that I made that\nvisit?  Should I say so?  Must I say so?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Good Heavens, Loo, you are not in the habit of
asking my advice.  Say what you like.  If you keep it to yourself, I
shall keep it to _my_self.  If you disclose it, there's an end of it.
subQuotationList: ['Good Heavens, Loo,', "you are not in the habit of\nasking my advice.  Say what you like.  If you keep it to yourself, I\nshall keep it to _my_self.  If you disclose it, there's an end of it."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Tom, do you believe the man I gave the money to, is really implicated in
this crime?
subQuotationList: ['Tom, do you believe the man I gave the money to, is really implicated in\nthis crime?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: I don't know.  I don't see why he shouldn't be.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know.  I don't see why he shouldn't be."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: He seemed to me an honest man.
subQuotationList: ['He seemed to me an honest man.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Another person may seem to you dishonest, and yet not be so.
subQuotationList: ['Another person may seem to you dishonest, and yet not be so.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
In short, if you come to
that, perhaps I was so far from being altogether in his favour, that I
took him outside the door to tell him quietly, that I thought he might
consider himself very well off to get such a windfall as he had got from
my sister, and that I hoped he would make good use of it.  You remember
whether I took him out or not.  I say nothing against the man; he may be
a very good fellow, for anything I know; I hope he is.
subQuotationList:
['In short,', 'if you come to
that, perhaps I was so far from being altogether in his favour, that I
took him outside the door to tell him quietly, that I thought he might
consider himself very well off to get such a windfall as he had got from
my sister, and that I hoped he would make good use of it.  You remember
whether I took him out or not.  I say nothing against the man; he may be
a very good fellow, for anything I know; I hope he is.']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: Was he offended by what you said?
subQuotationList: ['Was he offended by what you said?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: No, he took it pretty well; he was civil enough.  Where are you, Loo?
subQuotationList: ['No, he took it pretty well; he was civil enough.  Where are you, Loo?']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Good night, my dear, good night.
subQuotationList: ['Good night, my dear, good night.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: You have nothing more to tell me?
subQuotationList: ['You have nothing more to tell me?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: No.  What should I have?  You wouldn't have me tell you a lie!
subQuotationList: ["No.  What should I have?  You wouldn't have me tell you a lie!"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
I wouldn't have you do that to-night, Tom, of all the nights in your
life; many and much happier as I hope they will be.
subQuotationList: ["I wouldn't have you do that to-night, Tom, of all the nights in your\nlife; many and much happier as I hope they will be."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Thank you, my dear Loo.  I am so tired, that I am sure I wonder I don't
say anything to get to sleep.  Go to bed, go to bed.
subQuotationList: ["Thank you, my dear Loo.  I am so tired, that I am sure I wonder I don't\nsay anything to get to sleep.  Go to bed, go to bed."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
It appears but yesterday, sir, that I had the
honour of receiving you at the Bank, when you were so good as to wish to
be made acquainted with Mr. Bounderby's address.
subQuotationList: ['It appears but yesterday, sir,', "that I had the\nhonour of receiving you at the Bank, when you were so good as to wish to\nbe made acquainted with Mr. Bounderby's address."]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
An occasion, I am sure, not to be forgotten by myself in the course of
Ages,
subQuotationList: ['An occasion, I am sure, not to be forgotten by myself in the course of\nAges,']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: We live in a singular world, sir,
subQuotationList: ['We live in a singular world, sir,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I have had the honour, by a coincidence of which I am proud, to have
made a remark, similar in effect, though not so epigrammatically
expressed.
subQuotationList: ['I have had the honour, by a coincidence of which I am proud, to have\nmade a remark, similar in effect, though not so epigrammatically\nexpressed.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
A singular world, I would say, sir, as regards the intimacies we form at one time, with individuals
we were quite ignorant of, at another.  I recall, sir, that on that
occasion you went so far as to say you were actually apprehensive of Miss
Gradgrind.
subQuotationList:
['A singular world, I would say, sir,', 'as regards the intimacies we form at one time, with individuals
we were quite ignorant of, at another.  I recall, sir, that on that
occasion you went so far as to say you were actually apprehensive of Miss
Gradgrind.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Your memory does me more honour than my insignificance deserves.  I
availed myself of your obliging hints to correct my timidity, and it is
unnecessary to add that they were perfectly accurate.  Mrs. Sparsit's
talent for   in fact for anything requiring accuracy   with a combination of
strength of mind   and Family   is too habitually developed to admit of any
question.
subQuotationList:
["Your memory does me more honour than my insignificance deserves.  I
availed myself of your obliging hints to correct my timidity, and it is
unnecessary to add that they were perfectly accurate.  Mrs. Sparsit's
talent for   in fact for anything requiring accuracy   with a combination of
strength of mind   and Family   is too habitually developed to admit of any
question."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit', 'Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mrs. Sparsit', 'Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
You found Miss Gradgrind   I really cannot call her Mrs. Bounderby; it's
very absurd of me   as youthful as I described her?
subQuotationList: ["You found Miss Gradgrind   I really cannot call her Mrs. Bounderby; it's\nvery absurd of me   as youthful as I described her?"]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
You drew her portrait perfectly, Presented her
dead image.
subQuotationList: ['You drew her portrait perfectly,', 'Presented her\ndead image.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Very engaging, sir,
subQuotationList: ['Very engaging, sir,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Highly so.
subQuotationList: ['Highly so.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
It used to be considered, that Miss Gradgrind was
wanting in animation, but I confess she appears to me considerably and
strikingly improved in that respect.  Ay, and indeed here _is_ Mr.
Bounderby! How do you find
yourself this morning, sir?  Pray let us see you cheerful, sir.
subQuotationList:
['It used to be considered,', 'that Miss Gradgrind was
wanting in animation, but I confess she appears to me considerably and
strikingly improved in that respect.  Ay, and indeed here _is_ Mr.
Bounderby!', 'How do you find
yourself this morning, sir?  Pray let us see you cheerful, sir.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
You want your breakfast, sir, but I dare say
Miss Gradgrind will soon be here to preside at the table,
subQuotationList: ['You want your breakfast, sir, but I dare say\nMiss Gradgrind will soon be here to preside at the table,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
If I waited to be taken care of by my wife, ma'am, I believe
you know pretty well I should wait till Doomsday, so I'll trouble _you_
to take charge of the teapot.
subQuotationList: ["If I waited to be taken care of by my wife, ma'am, I believe\nyou know pretty well I should wait till Doomsday, so I'll trouble _you_\nto take charge of the teapot."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
There!  Stop where you are, ma'am, stop where you
are!  Mrs. Bounderby will be very glad to be relieved of the trouble, I
believe.
subQuotationList: ["There!  Stop where you are, ma'am,", 'stop where you\nare!  Mrs. Bounderby will be very glad to be relieved of the trouble, I\nbelieve.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Don't say that, sir, because that is very unkind to Mrs. Bounderby.  And to be unkind is not
to be you, sir.
subQuotationList: ["Don't say that, sir,", 'because that is very unkind to Mrs. Bounderby.  And to be unkind is not\nto be you, sir.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
You may set your mind at rest, ma'am.   You can take it very quietly,
can't you, Loo?
subQuotationList: ["You may set your mind at rest, ma'am.   You can take it very quietly,\ncan't you, Loo?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Of course.  It is of no moment.  Why should it be of any importance to
me?
subQuotationList: ['Of course.  It is of no moment.  Why should it be of any importance to\nme?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Why should it be of any importance to any one, Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am? You attach too
much importance to these things, ma'am.  By George, you'll be corrupted
in some of your notions here.  You are old-fashioned, ma'am.  You are
behind Tom Gradgrind's children's time.
subQuotationList:
["Why should it be of any importance to any one, Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am?", "You attach too
much importance to these things, ma'am.  By George, you'll be corrupted
in some of your notions here.  You are old-fashioned, ma'am.  You are
behind Tom Gradgrind's children's time."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
What is the matter with you? What has
given you offence?
subQuotationList: ['What is the matter with you?', 'What has\ngiven you offence?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Offence! Do you suppose if there was any offence
given me, I shouldn't name it, and request to have it corrected?  I am a
straightforward man, I believe.  I don't go beating about for
side-winds.
subQuotationList:
['Offence!', "Do you suppose if there was any offence
given me, I shouldn't name it, and request to have it corrected?  I am a
straightforward man, I believe.  I don't go beating about for
side-winds."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I suppose no one ever had occasion to think you too diffident, or too
delicate, I have never made that
objection to you, either as a child or as a woman.  I don't understand
what you would have.
subQuotationList:
['I suppose no one ever had occasion to think you too diffident, or too
delicate,', "I have never made that
objection to you, either as a child or as a woman.  I don't understand
what you would have."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Have? Nothing.  Otherwise, don't you, Loo
Bounderby, know thoroughly well that I, Josiah Bounderby of Coketown,
would have it?
subQuotationList: ['Have?', "Nothing.  Otherwise, don't you, Loo\nBounderby, know thoroughly well that I, Josiah Bounderby of Coketown,\nwould have it?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
You are incomprehensible this morning, Pray take no
further trouble to explain yourself.  I am not curious to know your
meaning.  What does it matter?
subQuotationList: ['You are incomprehensible this morning,', 'Pray take no\nfurther trouble to explain yourself.  I am not curious to know your\nmeaning.  What does it matter?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: My benefactor!
subQuotationList: ['My benefactor!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
referringExpression: she imprinted a chaste kiss upon his hand murmured

quoteText:
Serve you right, you Noodle, and I am glad
of it.
subQuotationList: ['Serve you right, you Noodle, and I am glad\nof it.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
referringExpression: the same descendant of the Scadgerses and connexion by matrimony of the Powlers shook her righthand mitten at his portrait made a contemptuous grimace at that work of art and said

quoteText:
Well, my dear, and I hope you are going on
satisfactorily to yourself.  It was all your father's doing.  He set his
heart upon it.  And he ought to know.
subQuotationList: ['Well, my dear,', "and I hope you are going on\nsatisfactorily to yourself.  It was all your father's doing.  He set his\nheart upon it.  And he ought to know."]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: I want to hear of you, mother; not of myself.
subQuotationList: ['I want to hear of you, mother; not of myself.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
You want to hear of me, my dear?  That's something new, I am sure, when
anybody wants to hear of me.  Not at all well, Louisa.  Very faint and
giddy.
subQuotationList: ["You want to hear of me, my dear?  That's something new, I am sure, when\nanybody wants to hear of me.  Not at all well, Louisa.  Very faint and\ngiddy."]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText: Are you in pain, dear mother?
subQuotationList: ['Are you in pain, dear mother?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I think there's a pain somewhere in the room, but
I couldn't positively say that I have got it. You very seldom see your sister, She grows like
you.  I wish you would look at her.  Sissy, bring her here.
subQuotationList: ["I think there's a pain somewhere in the room,", "but\nI couldn't positively say that I have got it.", 'You very seldom see your sister,', 'She grows like\nyou.  I wish you would look at her.  Sissy, bring her here.']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Cecilia Jupe']], [['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText: Do you see the likeness, Louisa?
subQuotationList: ['Do you see the likeness, Louisa?']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText: Yes, mother.  I should think her like me.  But
subQuotationList: ['Yes, mother.  I should think her like me.  But']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Eh!  Yes, I always say so, And that reminds me.  I   I want to speak to you, my dear.
Sissy, my good girl, leave us alone a minute.
subQuotationList: ['Eh!  Yes, I always say so,', 'And that reminds me.  I   I want to speak to you, my dear.\nSissy, my good girl, leave us alone a minute.']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText: You were going to speak to me, mother.
subQuotationList: ['You were going to speak to me, mother.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Eh?  Yes, to be sure, my dear.  You know your father is almost always
away now, and therefore I must write to him about it.
subQuotationList: ['Eh?  Yes, to be sure, my dear.  You know your father is almost always\naway now, and therefore I must write to him about it.']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText: About what, mother?  Don't be troubled.  About what?
subQuotationList: ["About what, mother?  Don't be troubled.  About what?"]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
You must remember, my dear, that whenever I have said anything, on any
subject, I have never heard the last of it: and consequently, that I have
long left off saying anything.
subQuotationList: ['You must remember, my dear, that whenever I have said anything, on any\nsubject, I have never heard the last of it: and consequently, that I have\nlong left off saying anything.']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText: I can hear you, mother.
subQuotationList: ['I can hear you, mother.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
You learnt a great deal, Louisa, and so did your brother.  Ologies of
all kinds from morning to night.  If there is any Ology left, of any
description, that has not been worn to rags in this house, all I can say
is, I hope I shall never hear its name.
subQuotationList:
['You learnt a great deal, Louisa, and so did your brother.  Ologies of
all kinds from morning to night.  If there is any Ology left, of any
description, that has not been worn to rags in this house, all I can say
is, I hope I shall never hear its name.']
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText: I can hear you, mother, when you have strength to go on.
subQuotationList: ['I can hear you, mother, when you have strength to go on.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
But there is something   not an Ology at all   that your father has missed,
or forgotten, Louisa.  I don't know what it is.  I have often sat with
Sissy near me, and thought about it.  I shall never get its name now.
But your father may.  It makes me restless.  I want to write to him, to
find out for God's sake, what it is.  Give me a pen, give me a pen.
subQuotationList:
["But there is something   not an Ology at all   that your father has missed,
or forgotten, Louisa.  I don't know what it is.  I have often sat with
Sissy near me, and thought about it.  I shall never get its name now.
But your father may.  It makes me restless.  I want to write to him, to
find out for God's sake, what it is.  Give me a pen, give me a pen."]
speaker: Mrs. Gradgrind

quoteText:
I tell you what, ma'am; you shall come down here
of a Saturday, while the fine weather lasts, and stay till Monday.
subQuotationList: ["I tell you what, ma'am; you shall come down here\nof a Saturday, while the fine weather lasts, and stay till Monday."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: To hear is to obey.
subQuotationList: ['To hear is to obey.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
And pray, sir, if I may venture to ask a question
appertaining to any subject on which you show reserve   which is indeed
hardy in me, for I well know you have a reason for everything you do   have
you received intelligence respecting the robbery?
subQuotationList:
['And pray, sir,', 'if I may venture to ask a question
appertaining to any subject on which you show reserve   which is indeed
hardy in me, for I well know you have a reason for everything you do   have
you received intelligence respecting the robbery?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Why, ma'am, no; not yet.  Under the circumstances, I didn't expect it
yet.  Rome wasn't built in a day, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["Why, ma'am, no; not yet.  Under the circumstances, I didn't expect it\nyet.  Rome wasn't built in a day, ma'am."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Very true, sir,
subQuotationList: ['Very true, sir,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Nor yet in a week, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["Nor yet in a week, ma'am."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: No, indeed, sir,
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed, sir,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
In a similar manner, ma'am, I can wait, you know.  If
Romulus and Remus could wait, Josiah Bounderby can wait.  They were
better off in their youth than I was, however.  They had a she-wolf for a
nurse; I had only a she-wolf for a grandmother.  She didn't give any
milk, ma'am; she gave bruises.  She was a regular Alderney at that.
subQuotationList:
["In a similar manner, ma'am,", "I can wait, you know.  If
Romulus and Remus could wait, Josiah Bounderby can wait.  They were
better off in their youth than I was, however.  They had a she-wolf for a
nurse; I had only a she-wolf for a grandmother.  She didn't give any
milk, ma'am; she gave bruises.  She was a regular Alderney at that."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Ah!
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
No, ma'am, I have not heard anything more about
it.  It's in hand, though; and young Tom, who rather sticks to business
at present   something new for him; he hadn't the schooling _I_ had   is
helping.  My injunction is, Keep it quiet, and let it seem to blow over.
Do what you like under the rose, but don't give a sign of what you're
about; or half a hundred of 'em will combine together and get this fellow
who has bolted, out of reach for good.  Keep it quiet, and the thieves
will grow in confidence by little and little, and we shall have 'em.
subQuotationList:
["No, ma'am,", "I have not heard anything more about
it.  It's in hand, though; and young Tom, who rather sticks to business
at present   something new for him; he hadn't the schooling _I_ had   is
helping.  My injunction is, Keep it quiet, and let it seem to blow over.
Do what you like under the rose, but don't give a sign of what you're
about; or half a hundred of 'em will combine together and get this fellow
who has bolted, out of reach for good.  Keep it quiet, and the thieves
will grow in confidence by little and little, and we shall have 'em."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
Very sagacious indeed, sir, Very interesting.  The
old woman you mentioned, sir
subQuotationList: ['Very sagacious indeed, sir,', 'Very interesting.  The\nold woman you mentioned, sir']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
The old woman I mentioned, ma'am, is not laid hold of; but, she
may take her oath she will be, if that is any satisfaction to her
villainous old mind.  In the mean time, ma'am, I am of opinion, if you
ask me my opinion, that the less she is talked about, the better.
subQuotationList:
["The old woman I mentioned, ma'am,", "is not laid hold of; but, she
may take her oath she will be, if that is any satisfaction to her
villainous old mind.  In the mean time, ma'am, I am of opinion, if you
ask me my opinion, that the less she is talked about, the better."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: If not quite!
subQuotationList: ['If not quite!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: You recollect the man, Mr. Harthouse?
subQuotationList: ['You recollect the man, Mr. Harthouse?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Oh, perfectly!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, perfectly!']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: His face, and his manner, and what he said?
subQuotationList: ['His face, and his manner, and what he said?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Perfectly.  And an infinitely dreary person he appeared to me to be.
Lengthy and prosy in the extreme.  It was knowing to hold forth, in the
humble-virtue school of eloquence; but, I assure you I thought at the
time,
subQuotationList:
['Perfectly.  And an infinitely dreary person he appeared to me to be.
Lengthy and prosy in the extreme.  It was knowing to hold forth, in the
humble-virtue school of eloquence; but, I assure you I thought at the
time,']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: It has been very difficult to me to think ill of that man.
subQuotationList: ['It has been very difficult to me to think ill of that man.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: My dear Louisa   as Tom says.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Louisa   as Tom says.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
You know no good
of the fellow?
subQuotationList: ['You know no good\nof the fellow?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: No, certainly.
subQuotationList: ['No, certainly.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Nor of any other such person?
subQuotationList: ['Nor of any other such person?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: How can I, when I know nothing of them, men or women?
subQuotationList: ['How can I,', 'when I know nothing of them, men or women?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
My dear Louisa, then consent to receive the submissive representation of
your devoted friend, who knows something of several varieties of his
excellent fellow-creatures   for excellent they are, I am quite ready to
believe, in spite of such little foibles as always helping themselves to
what they can get hold of.  This fellow talks.  Well; every fellow talks.
He professes morality.  Well; all sorts of humbugs profess morality.
From the House of Commons to the House of Correction, there is a general
profession of morality, except among our people; it really is that
exception which makes our people quite reviving.  You saw and heard the
case.  Here was one of the fluffy classes pulled up extremely short by my
esteemed friend Mr. Bounderby   who, as we know, is not possessed of that
delicacy which would soften so tight a hand.  The member of the fluffy
classes was injured, exasperated, left the house grumbling, met somebody
who proposed to him to go in for some share in this Bank business, went
in, put something in his pocket which had nothing in it before, and
relieved his mind extremely.  Really he would have been an uncommon,
instead of a common, fellow, if he had not availed himself of such an
opportunity.  Or he may have originated it altogether, if he had the
cleverness.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Louisa, then consent to receive the submissive representation of
your devoted friend, who knows something of several varieties of his
excellent fellow-creatures   for excellent they are, I am quite ready to
believe, in spite of such little foibles as always helping themselves to

From the House of Commons to the House of Correction, there is a general
profession of morality, except among our people; it really is that
exception which makes our people quite reviving.  You saw and heard the

instead of a common, fellow, if he had not availed himself of such an
opportunity.  Or he may have originated it altogether, if he had the
cleverness.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
I almost feel as though it must be bad in me, to be so ready to agree with you, and to be
so lightened in my heart by what you say.
subQuotationList: ['I almost feel as though it must be bad in me,', 'to be so ready to agree with you, and to be\nso lightened in my heart by what you say.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I only say what is reasonable; nothing worse.  I have talked it over
with my friend Tom more than once   of course I remain on terms of perfect
confidence with Tom   and he is quite of my opinion, and I am quite of his.
Will you walk?
subQuotationList:
['I only say what is reasonable; nothing worse.  I have talked it over
with my friend Tom more than once   of course I remain on terms of perfect
confidence with Tom   and he is quite of my opinion, and I am quite of his.
Will you walk?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Your foot on the last step, my lady, and all
your art shall never blind me.
subQuotationList: ['Your foot on the last step, my lady,', 'and all\nyour art shall never blind me.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
But you'll go down to-morrow, ma'am, all the same.
You'll go down just as if I was there.  It will make no difference to
you.
subQuotationList: ["But you'll go down to-morrow, ma'am, all the same.\nYou'll go down just as if I was there.  It will make no difference to\nyou."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
referringExpression: he intimated this to Mrs Sparsit at the Bank adding

quoteText:
Pray, sir, let me beg you not to
say that.  Your absence will make a vast difference to me, sir, as I
think you very well know.
subQuotationList: ['Pray, sir,', 'let me beg you not to\nsay that.  Your absence will make a vast difference to me, sir, as I\nthink you very well know.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Well, ma'am, then you must get on in my absence as well as you can,
subQuotationList: ["Well, ma'am, then you must get on in my absence as well as you can,"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Mr. Bounderby, your will is to me a law, sir;
otherwise, it might be my inclination to dispute your kind commands, not
feeling sure that it will be quite so agreeable to Miss Gradgrind to
receive me, as it ever is to your own munificent hospitality.  But you
shall say no more, sir.  I will go, upon your invitation.
subQuotationList:
['Mr. Bounderby,', 'your will is to me a law, sir;
otherwise, it might be my inclination to dispute your kind commands, not
feeling sure that it will be quite so agreeable to Miss Gradgrind to
receive me, as it ever is to your own munificent hospitality.  But you
shall say no more, sir.  I will go, upon your invitation.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Why, when I invite you to my house, ma'am, I should hope you want no other invitation.
subQuotationList: ["Why, when I invite you to my house, ma'am,", 'I should hope you want no other invitation.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
No, indeed, sir, I should hope not.  Say no
more, sir.  I would, sir, I could see you gay again.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed, sir,', 'I should hope not.  Say no\nmore, sir.  I would, sir, I could see you gay again.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: What do you mean, ma'am?
subQuotationList: ["What do you mean, ma'am?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Sir, there was wont to be an elasticity in you
which I sadly miss.  Be buoyant, sir!
subQuotationList: ['Sir,', 'there was wont to be an elasticity in you\nwhich I sadly miss.  Be buoyant, sir!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Bitzer, present my compliments to young
Mr. Thomas, and ask him if he would step up and partake of a lamb chop
and walnut ketchup, with a glass of India ale? Mr. Thomas, these plain
viands being on table, I thought you might be tempted.
subQuotationList:
['Bitzer,', 'present my compliments to young
Mr. Thomas, and ask him if he would step up and partake of a lamb chop
and walnut ketchup, with a glass of India ale?', 'Mr. Thomas,', 'these plain
viands being on table, I thought you might be tempted.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Thank'ee, Mrs. Sparsit,
subQuotationList: ["Thank'ee, Mrs. Sparsit,"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: How is Mr. Harthouse, Mr. Tom?
subQuotationList: ['How is Mr. Harthouse, Mr. Tom?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Oh, he's all right,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, he's all right,"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Where may he be at present?
subQuotationList: ['Where may he be at present?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
He is shooting in Yorkshire, Sent Loo a basket half as big
as a church, yesterday.
subQuotationList: ['He is shooting in Yorkshire,', 'Sent Loo a basket half as big\nas a church, yesterday.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
The kind of gentleman, now, whom one might
wager to be a good shot!
subQuotationList: ['The kind of gentleman, now,', 'whom one might\nwager to be a good shot!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Crack,
subQuotationList: ['Crack,']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Mr. Harthouse is a great favourite of mine, as
indeed he is of most people.  May we expect to see him again shortly, Mr.
Tom?
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Harthouse is a great favourite of mine,', 'as\nindeed he is of most people.  May we expect to see him again shortly, Mr.\nTom?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mrs. Sparsit', 'Bitzer'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText: Why, _I_ expect to see him to-morrow,
subQuotationList: ['Why, _I_ expect to see him to-morrow,']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Good news!
subQuotationList: ['Good news!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
I have got an appointment with him to meet him in the evening at the
station here, and I am going to dine with him afterwards, I
believe.  He is not coming down to the country house for a week or so,
being due somewhere else.  At least, he says so; but I shouldn't wonder
if he was to stop here over Sunday, and stray that way.
subQuotationList:
['I have got an appointment with him to meet him in the evening at the
station here,', "and I am going to dine with him afterwards, I
believe.  He is not coming down to the country house for a week or so,
being due somewhere else.  At least, he says so; but I shouldn't wonder
if he was to stop here over Sunday, and stray that way."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
Which reminds me! Would you remember a message to
your sister, Mr. Tom, if I was to charge you with one?
subQuotationList: ['Which reminds me!', 'Would you remember a message to\nyour sister, Mr. Tom, if I was to charge you with one?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Well?  I'll try, if it isn't a long un.
subQuotationList: ["Well?  I'll try,", "if it isn't a long un."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
It is merely my respectful compliments, and I fear
I may not trouble her with my society this week; being still a little
nervous, and better perhaps by my poor self.
subQuotationList: ['It is merely my respectful compliments,', 'and I fear\nI may not trouble her with my society this week; being still a little\nnervous, and better perhaps by my poor self.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Oh!  If that's all, it wouldn't much matter, even if I
was to forget it, for Loo's not likely to think of you unless she sees
you.
subQuotationList: ["Oh!  If that's all,", "it wouldn't much matter, even if I\nwas to forget it, for Loo's not likely to think of you unless she sees\nyou."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Well, Mrs. Sparsit, I must be off!
subQuotationList: ['Well, Mrs. Sparsit, I must be off!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: This is a device to keep him out of the way, Harthouse is with his sister now!
subQuotationList: ['This is a device to keep him out of the way,', 'Harthouse is with his sister now!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
My dearest love, what could I do?  Knowing you were alone,
was it possible that I could stay away?
subQuotationList: ['My dearest love,', 'what could I do?  Knowing you were alone,\nwas it possible that I could stay away?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
You may hang your head, to make yourself the more attractive; _I_ don't
know what they see in you when you hold it up, but you little think, my dearest love, whose eyes are on you!
subQuotationList: ["You may hang your head, to make yourself the more attractive; _I_ don't\nknow what they see in you when you hold it up,", 'but you little think, my dearest love, whose eyes are on you!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: My dear child, will you not bear with my society for a little while?
subQuotationList: ['My dear child,', 'will you not bear with my society for a little while?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Not here.
subQuotationList: ['Not here.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Where, Louisa?
subQuotationList: ['Where, Louisa?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Not here.
subQuotationList: ['Not here.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
But we have so little time to make so much of, and I have come so far,
and am altogether so devoted, and distracted.  There never was a slave at
once so devoted and ill-used by his mistress.  To look for your sunny
welcome that has warmed me into life, and to be received in your frozen
manner, is heart-rending.
subQuotationList:
['But we have so little time to make so much of, and I have come so far,
and am altogether so devoted, and distracted.  There never was a slave at
once so devoted and ill-used by his mistress.  To look for your sunny
welcome that has warmed me into life, and to be received in your frozen
manner, is heart-rending.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Am I to say again, that I must be left to myself here?
subQuotationList: ['Am I to say again, that I must be left to myself here?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: But we must meet, my dear Louisa.  Where shall we meet?
subQuotationList: ['But we must meet, my dear Louisa.  Where shall we meet?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Shall I ride up to the house a few minutes hence, innocently supposing
that its master is at home and will be charmed to receive me?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I ride up to the house a few minutes hence, innocently supposing\nthat its master is at home and will be charmed to receive me?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: No!
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Your cruel commands are implicitly to be obeyed; though I am the most
unfortunate fellow in the world, I believe, to have been insensible to
all other women, and to have fallen prostrate at last under the foot of
the most beautiful, and the most engaging, and the most imperious.  My
dearest Louisa, I cannot go myself, or let you go, in this hard abuse of
your power.
subQuotationList:
['Your cruel commands are implicitly to be obeyed; though I am the most
unfortunate fellow in the world, I believe, to have been insensible to
all other women, and to have fallen prostrate at last under the foot of
the most beautiful, and the most engaging, and the most imperious.  My
dearest Louisa, I cannot go myself, or let you go, in this hard abuse of
your power.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Oh, my dearest love, you little think how well attended you are! She will be at Coketown long before him, though
his horse is never so good.  Where will she wait for him?  And where will
they go together?  Patience.  We shall see.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my dearest love,', 'you little think how well attended you are!', 'She will be at Coketown long before him,', 'though\nhis horse is never so good.  Where will she wait for him?  And where will\nthey go together?  Patience.  We shall see.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
She will get into one, and
will be away before I can follow in another.  At all risks of being run
over, I must see the number, and hear the order given to the coachman.
subQuotationList: ['She will get into one,', 'and\nwill be away before I can follow in another.  At all risks of being run\nover, I must see the number, and hear the order given to the coachman.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: I have lost her!
subQuotationList: ['I have lost her!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
referringExpression: Mrs Sparsit had no resource but to burst into tears of bitterness and say

quoteText: Louisa!
subQuotationList: ['Louisa!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Father, I want to speak to you.
subQuotationList: ['Father, I want to speak to you.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
What is the matter?  How strange you look!  And good Heaven, have you come here exposed to this
storm?
subQuotationList: ['What is the matter?  How strange you look!  And good Heaven,', 'have you come here exposed to this\nstorm?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: What is it?  I conjure you, Louisa, tell me what is the matter.
subQuotationList: ['What is it?  I conjure you, Louisa, tell me what is the matter.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Father, you have trained me from my cradle?
subQuotationList: ['Father, you have trained me from my cradle?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Yes, Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Louisa.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I curse the hour in which I was born to such a destiny.
subQuotationList: ['I curse the hour in which I was born to such a destiny.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Curse the hour?
Curse the hour?
subQuotationList: ['Curse the hour?\nCurse the hour?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
referringExpression: He looked at her in doubt and dread vacantly repeating

quoteText:
How could you give me life, and take from me all the inappreciable
things that raise it from the state of conscious death?  Where are the
graces of my soul?  Where are the sentiments of my heart?  What have you
done, O father, what have you done, with the garden that should have
bloomed once, in this great wilderness here!
subQuotationList:
['How could you give me life, and take from me all the inappreciable
things that raise it from the state of conscious death?  Where are the
graces of my soul?  Where are the sentiments of my heart?  What have you
done, O father, what have you done, with the garden that should have
bloomed once, in this great wilderness here!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
If it had ever been here, its ashes alone would save me from the void in
which my whole life sinks.  I did not mean to say this; but, father, you
remember the last time we conversed in this room?
subQuotationList: ['If it had ever been here, its ashes alone would save me from the void in\nwhich my whole life sinks.  I did not mean to say this; but, father, you\nremember the last time we conversed in this room?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Yes, Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Louisa.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
What has risen to my lips now, would have risen to my lips then, if you
had given me a moment's help.  I don't reproach you, father.  What you
have never nurtured in me, you have never nurtured in yourself; but O! if
you had only done so long ago, or if you had only neglected me, what a
much better and much happier creature I should have been this day!
subQuotationList:
["What has risen to my lips now, would have risen to my lips then, if you
had given me a moment's help.  I don't reproach you, father.  What you
have never nurtured in me, you have never nurtured in yourself; but O! if
you had only done so long ago, or if you had only neglected me, what a
much better and much happier creature I should have been this day!"]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
Father, if you had known, when we were last together here, what even I
feared while I strove against it   as it has been my task from infancy to
strive against every natural prompting that has arisen in my heart; if
you had known that there lingered in my breast, sensibilities,
affections, weaknesses capable of being cherished into strength, defying
all the calculations ever made by man, and no more known to his
arithmetic than his Creator is,   would you have given me to the husband
whom I am now sure that I hate?
subQuotationList:
['Father, if you had known, when we were last together here, what even I
feared while I strove against it   as it has been my task from infancy to
strive against every natural prompting that has arisen in my heart; if
you had known that there lingered in my breast, sensibilities,
affections, weaknesses capable of being cherished into strength, defying
all the calculations ever made by man, and no more known to his
arithmetic than his Creator is,   would you have given me to the husband
whom I am now sure that I hate?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: No.  No, my poor child.
subQuotationList: ['No.  No, my poor child.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Would you have doomed me, at any time, to the frost and blight that have
hardened and spoiled me?  Would you have robbed me   for no one's
enrichment   only for the greater desolation of this world   of the
immaterial part of my life, the spring and summer of my belief, my refuge
from what is sordid and bad in the real things around me, my school in
which I should have learned to be more humble and more trusting with
them, and to hope in my little sphere to make them better?
subQuotationList:
["Would you have doomed me, at any time, to the frost and blight that have
hardened and spoiled me?  Would you have robbed me   for no one's
enrichment   only for the greater desolation of this world   of the
immaterial part of my life, the spring and summer of my belief, my refuge
from what is sordid and bad in the real things around me, my school in
which I should have learned to be more humble and more trusting with
them, and to hope in my little sphere to make them better?"]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: O no, no.  No, Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['O no, no.  No, Louisa.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Yet, father, if I had been stone blind; if I had groped my way by my
sense of touch, and had been free, while I knew the shapes and surfaces
of things, to exercise my fancy somewhat, in regard to them; I should
have been a million times wiser, happier, more loving, more contented,
more innocent and human in all good respects, than I am with the eyes I
have.  Now, hear what I have come to say.
subQuotationList:
['Yet, father, if I had been stone blind; if I had groped my way by my
sense of touch, and had been free, while I knew the shapes and surfaces
of things, to exercise my fancy somewhat, in regard to them; I should
have been a million times wiser, happier, more loving, more contented,
more innocent and human in all good respects, than I am with the eyes I
have.  Now, hear what I have come to say.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
With a hunger and thirst upon me, father, which have never been for a
moment appeased; with an ardent impulse towards some region where rules,
and figures, and definitions were not quite absolute; I have grown up,
battling every inch of my way.
subQuotationList:
['With a hunger and thirst upon me, father, which have never been for a
moment appeased; with an ardent impulse towards some region where rules,
and figures, and definitions were not quite absolute; I have grown up,
battling every inch of my way.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: I never knew you were unhappy, my child.
subQuotationList: ['I never knew you were unhappy, my child.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Father, I always knew it.  In this strife I have almost repulsed and
crushed my better angel into a demon.  What I have learned has left me
doubting, misbelieving, despising, regretting, what I have not learned;
and my dismal resource has been to think that life would soon go by, and
that nothing in it could be worth the pain and trouble of a contest.
subQuotationList:
['Father, I always knew it.  In this strife I have almost repulsed and
crushed my better angel into a demon.  What I have learned has left me
doubting, misbelieving, despising, regretting, what I have not learned;
and my dismal resource has been to think that life would soon go by, and
that nothing in it could be worth the pain and trouble of a contest.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: And you so young, Louisa!
subQuotationList: ['And you so young, Louisa!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
And I so young.  In this condition, father   for I show you now, without
fear or favour, the ordinary deadened state of my mind as I know it   you
proposed my husband to me.  I took him.  I never made a pretence to him
or you that I loved him.  I knew, and, father, you knew, and he knew,
that I never did.  I was not wholly indifferent, for I had a hope of
being pleasant and useful to Tom.  I made that wild escape into something
visionary, and have slowly found out how wild it was.  But Tom had been
the subject of all the little tenderness of my life; perhaps he became so
because I knew so well how to pity him.  It matters little now, except as
it may dispose you to think more leniently of his errors.
subQuotationList:
['And I so young.  In this condition, father   for I show you now, without

speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText:
When I was irrevocably married, there rose up into rebellion against the
tie, the old strife, made fiercer by all those causes of disparity which
arise out of our two individual natures, and which no general laws shall
ever rule or state for me, father, until they shall be able to direct the
anatomist where to strike his knife into the secrets of my soul.
subQuotationList:
['When I was irrevocably married, there rose up into rebellion against the
tie, the old strife, made fiercer by all those causes of disparity which
arise out of our two individual natures, and which no general laws shall
ever rule or state for me, father, until they shall be able to direct the
anatomist where to strike his knife into the secrets of my soul.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
referringExpression: she put her other hand upon his other shoulder and still looking fixedly in his face went on

quoteText: Louisa!
subQuotationList: ['Louisa!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I do not reproach you, father, I make no complaint.  I am here with
another object.
subQuotationList: ['I do not reproach you, father, I make no complaint.  I am here with\nanother object.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: What can I do, child?  Ask me what you will.
subQuotationList: ['What can I do, child?  Ask me what you will.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I am coming to it.  Father, chance then threw into my way a new
acquaintance; a man such as I had had no experience of; used to the
world; light, polished, easy; making no pretences; avowing the low
estimate of everything, that I was half afraid to form in secret;
conveying to me almost immediately, though I don't know how or by what
degrees, that he understood me, and read my thoughts.  I could not find
that he was worse than I.  There seemed to be a near affinity between us.
I only wondered it should be worth his while, who cared for nothing else,
to care so much for me.
subQuotationList:
["I am coming to it.  Father, chance then threw into my way a new
acquaintance; a man such as I had had no experience of; used to the

to care so much for me."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: For you, Louisa!
subQuotationList: ['For you, Louisa!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I say nothing of his plea for claiming my confidence.  It matters very
little how he gained it.  Father, he did gain it.  What you know of the
story of my marriage, he soon knew, just as well.
subQuotationList: ['I say nothing of his plea for claiming my confidence.  It matters very\nlittle how he gained it.  Father, he did gain it.  What you know of the\nstory of my marriage, he soon knew, just as well.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
I have done no worse, I have not disgraced you.  But if you ask me
whether I have loved him, or do love him, I tell you plainly, father,
that it may be so.  I don't know.
subQuotationList: ["I have done no worse, I have not disgraced you.  But if you ask me\nwhether I have loved him, or do love him, I tell you plainly, father,\nthat it may be so.  I don't know."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
This night, my husband being away, he has been with me, declaring
himself my lover.  This minute he expects me, for I could release myself
of his presence by no other means.  I do not know that I am sorry, I do
not know that I am ashamed, I do not know that I am degraded in my own
esteem.  All that I know is, your philosophy and your teaching will not
save me.  Now, father, you have brought me to this.  Save me by some
other means!
subQuotationList:
['This night, my husband being away, he has been with me, declaring

speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I shall die if you hold me!  Let me
fall upon the ground!
subQuotationList: ['I shall die if you hold me!  Let me\nfall upon the ground!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: When was I brought to this room?
subQuotationList: ['When was I brought to this room?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Last night, Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['Last night, Louisa.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText: Who brought me here?
subQuotationList: ['Who brought me here?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Sissy, I believe.
subQuotationList: ['Sissy, I believe.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText: Why do you believe so?
subQuotationList: ['Why do you believe so?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Because I found her here this morning.  She didn't come to my bedside to
wake me, as she always does; and I went to look for her.  She was not in
her own room either; and I went looking for her all over the house, until
I found her here taking care of you and cooling your head.  Will you see
father? Sissy said I was to tell him when you woke.
subQuotationList:
["Because I found her here this morning.  She didn't come to my bedside to
wake me, as she always does; and I went to look for her.  She was not in
her own room either; and I went looking for her all over the house, until
