speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: What a beaming face you have, Jane!
subQuotationList: ['What a beaming face you have, Jane!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Have I?  I am very glad you think so.  I am sure it must be Sissy's
doing.
subQuotationList: ["Have I?  I am very glad you think so.  I am sure it must be Sissy's\ndoing."]
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
You
can tell father if you will. It was you who made my room so cheerful, and gave it this look of
welcome?
subQuotationList: ['You\ncan tell father if you will.', 'It was you who made my room so cheerful, and gave it this look of\nwelcome?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Oh no, Louisa, it was done before I came.  It was
subQuotationList: ['Oh no, Louisa, it was done before I came.  It was']
speaker: Jane

quoteText: My dear Louisa.  My poor daughter.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Louisa.  My poor daughter.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
My unfortunate child. It would be hopeless for me, Louisa, to endeavour to tell you how
overwhelmed I have been, and still am, by what broke upon me last night.
The ground on which I stand has ceased to be solid under my feet.  The
only support on which I leaned, and the strength of which it seemed, and
still does seem, impossible to question, has given way in an instant.  I
am stunned by these discoveries.  I have no selfish meaning in what I
say; but I find the shock of what broke upon me last night, to be very
heavy indeed.
subQuotationList:
['My unfortunate child.', 'It would be hopeless for me, Louisa, to endeavour to tell you how
overwhelmed I have been, and still am, by what broke upon me last night.
The ground on which I stand has ceased to be solid under my feet.  The
only support on which I leaned, and the strength of which it seemed, and
still does seem, impossible to question, has given way in an instant.  I
am stunned by these discoveries.  I have no selfish meaning in what I
say; but I find the shock of what broke upon me last night, to be very
heavy indeed.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I will not say, Louisa, that if you had by any happy chance undeceived
me some time ago, it would have been better for us both; better for your
peace, and better for mine.  For I am sensible that it may not have been
a part of my system to invite any confidence of that kind.  I had proved
my   my system to myself, and I have rigidly administered it; and I must
bear the responsibility of its failures.  I only entreat you to believe,
my favourite child, that I have meant to do right.
subQuotationList:
['I will not say, Louisa, that if you had by any happy chance undeceived
me some time ago, it would have been better for us both; better for your
peace, and better for mine.  For I am sensible that it may not have been
a part of my system to invite any confidence of that kind.  I had proved
my   my system to myself, and I have rigidly administered it; and I must
bear the responsibility of its failures.  I only entreat you to believe,
my favourite child, that I have meant to do right.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby', 'Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
I am well assured of what you say, father.  I know I have been your
favourite child.  I know you have intended to make me happy.  I have
never blamed you, and I never shall.
subQuotationList: ['I am well assured of what you say, father.  I know I have been your\nfavourite child.  I know you have intended to make me happy.  I have\nnever blamed you, and I never shall.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
My dear, I have remained all night at my table, pondering again and
again on what has so painfully passed between us.  When I consider your
character; when I consider that what has been known to me for hours, has
been concealed by you for years; when I consider under what immediate
pressure it has been forced from you at last; I come to the conclusion
that I cannot but mistrust myself.
subQuotationList:
['My dear, I have remained all night at my table, pondering again and
again on what has so painfully passed between us.  When I consider your
character; when I consider that what has been known to me for hours, has
been concealed by you for years; when I consider under what immediate
pressure it has been forced from you at last; I come to the conclusion
that I cannot but mistrust myself.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby', 'Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
But, if I see reason to mistrust myself for the
past, Louisa, I should also mistrust myself for the present and the
future.  To speak unreservedly to you, I do.  I am far from feeling
convinced now, however differently I might have felt only this time
yesterday, that I am fit for the trust you repose in me; that I know how
to respond to the appeal you have come home to make to me; that I have
the right instinct   supposing it for the moment to be some quality of that
nature   how to help you, and to set you right, my child.
subQuotationList:
['But,', 'if I see reason to mistrust myself for the
past, Louisa, I should also mistrust myself for the present and the
future.  To speak unreservedly to you, I do.  I am far from feeling
convinced now, however differently I might have felt only this time
yesterday, that I am fit for the trust you repose in me; that I know how
to respond to the appeal you have come home to make to me; that I have
the right instinct   supposing it for the moment to be some quality of that
nature   how to help you, and to set you right, my child.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Some persons hold, that there is a
wisdom of the Head, and that there is a wisdom of the Heart.  I have not
supposed so; but, as I have said, I mistrust myself now.  I have supposed
the head to be all-sufficient.  It may not be all-sufficient; how can I
venture this morning to say it is!  If that other kind of wisdom should
be what I have neglected, and should be the instinct that is wanted,
Louisa
subQuotationList:
['Some persons hold,', 'that there is a
wisdom of the Head, and that there is a wisdom of the Heart.  I have not
supposed so; but, as I have said, I mistrust myself now.  I have supposed
the head to be all-sufficient.  It may not be all-sufficient; how can I
venture this morning to say it is!  If that other kind of wisdom should
be what I have neglected, and should be the instinct that is wanted,
Louisa']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Louisa,
subQuotationList: ['Louisa,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I have been absent from
here, my dear, a good deal of late; and though your sister's training has
been pursued according to   the system,
subQuotationList: ["I have been absent from\nhere, my dear, a good deal of late; and though your sister's training has\nbeen pursued according to   the system,"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
it has necessarily been modified by daily
associations begun, in her case, at an early age.  I ask you   ignorantly
and humbly, my daughter   for the better, do you think?
subQuotationList: ['it has necessarily been modified by daily\nassociations begun, in her case, at an early age.  I ask you   ignorantly\nand humbly, my daughter   for the better, do you think?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Father, if any harmony has been
awakened in her young breast that was mute in mine until it turned to
discord, let her thank Heaven for it, and go upon her happier way, taking
it as her greatest blessing that she has avoided my way.
subQuotationList:
['Father,', 'if any harmony has been
awakened in her young breast that was mute in mine until it turned to
discord, let her thank Heaven for it, and go upon her happier way, taking
it as her greatest blessing that she has avoided my way.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
O my child, my child! I am an unhappy
man to see you thus!  What avails it to me that you do not reproach me,
if I so bitterly reproach myself!
subQuotationList: ['O my child, my child!', 'I am an unhappy\nman to see you thus!  What avails it to me that you do not reproach me,\nif I so bitterly reproach myself!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Louisa, I have a misgiving that some change may have been slowly
working about me in this house, by mere love and gratitude: that what the
Head had left undone and could not do, the Heart may have been doing
silently.  Can it be so?
subQuotationList:
['Louisa, I have a misgiving that some change may have been slowly
working about me in this house, by mere love and gratitude: that what the
Head had left undone and could not do, the Heart may have been doing
silently.  Can it be so?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
referringExpression: He bent his head and spoke low to her

quoteText:
I am not too proud to believe it, Louisa.  How could I be arrogant, and
you before me!  Can it be so?  Is it so, my dear?
subQuotationList: ['I am not too proud to believe it, Louisa.  How could I be arrogant, and\nyou before me!  Can it be so?  Is it so, my dear?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I hope I have not disturbed you.  I have come to ask if you would let me
stay with you?
subQuotationList: ['I hope I have not disturbed you.  I have come to ask if you would let me\nstay with you?']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Why should you stay with me?  My sister will miss you.  You are
everything to her.
subQuotationList: ['Why should you stay with me?  My sister will miss you.  You are\neverything to her.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Am I? I would be something to you,
if I might.
subQuotationList: ['Am I?', 'I would be something to you,\nif I might.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: What?
subQuotationList: ['What?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Whatever you want most, if I could be that.  At all events, I would like
to try to be as near it as I can.  And however far off that may be, I
will never tire of trying.  Will you let me?
subQuotationList: ['Whatever you want most, if I could be that.  At all events, I would like\nto try to be as near it as I can.  And however far off that may be, I\nwill never tire of trying.  Will you let me?']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: My father sent you to ask me.
subQuotationList: ['My father sent you to ask me.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
No indeed, He told me that I might come in now, but he
sent me away from the room this morning   or at least
subQuotationList: ['No indeed,', 'He told me that I might come in now, but he\nsent me away from the room this morning   or at least']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: At least, what?
subQuotationList: ['At least, what?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I thought it best myself that I should be sent away, for I felt very
uncertain whether you would like to find me here.
subQuotationList: ['I thought it best myself that I should be sent away, for I felt very\nuncertain whether you would like to find me here.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Have I always hated you so much?
subQuotationList: ['Have I always hated you so much?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
I hope not, for I have always loved you, and have always wished that you
should know it.  But you changed to me a little, shortly before you left
home.  Not that I wondered at it.  You knew so much, and I knew so
little, and it was so natural in many ways, going as you were among other
friends, that I had nothing to complain of, and was not at all hurt.
subQuotationList:
['I hope not, for I have always loved you, and have always wished that you
should know it.  But you changed to me a little, shortly before you left
home.  Not that I wondered at it.  You knew so much, and I knew so
little, and it was so natural in many ways, going as you were among other
friends, that I had nothing to complain of, and was not at all hurt.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: May I try?
subQuotationList: ['May I try?']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
First, Sissy, do you know what I am?  I am so proud and so hardened, so
confused and troubled, so resentful and unjust to every one and to
myself, that everything is stormy, dark, and wicked to me.  Does not that
repel you?
subQuotationList:
['First, Sissy, do you know what I am?  I am so proud and so hardened, so
confused and troubled, so resentful and unjust to every one and to
myself, that everything is stormy, dark, and wicked to me.  Does not that
repel you?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
referringExpression: Louisa taking down the hand that would have embraced her in another moment held it in one of hers and answered

quoteText: No!
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
I am so unhappy, and all that should have made me otherwise is so laid
waste, that if I had been bereft of sense to this hour, and instead of
being as learned as you think me, had to begin to acquire the simplest
truths, I could not want a guide to peace, contentment, honour, all the
good of which I am quite devoid, more abjectly than I do.  Does not that
repel you?
subQuotationList:
['I am so unhappy, and all that should have made me otherwise is so laid
waste, that if I had been bereft of sense to this hour, and instead of
being as learned as you think me, had to begin to acquire the simplest
truths, I could not want a guide to peace, contentment, honour, all the
good of which I am quite devoid, more abjectly than I do.  Does not that
repel you?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: No!
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Forgive me, pity me, help me!  Have compassion on my great need, and let
me lay this head of mine upon a loving heart!
subQuotationList: ['Forgive me, pity me, help me!  Have compassion on my great need, and let\nme lay this head of mine upon a loving heart!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: O lay it here! Lay it here, my dear.
subQuotationList: ['O lay it here!', 'Lay it here, my dear.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Well!  I don't know, She was off somewhere at daybreak this morning.  She's always
full of mystery; I hate her.  So I do that white chap; he's always got
his blinking eyes upon a fellow.
subQuotationList: ["Well!  I don't know,", "She was off somewhere at daybreak this morning.  She's always\nfull of mystery; I hate her.  So I do that white chap; he's always got\nhis blinking eyes upon a fellow."]
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Where were you last night, Tom?
subQuotationList: ['Where were you last night, Tom?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Where was I last night! Come!  I like that.  I was waiting
for you, Mr. Harthouse, till it came down as _I_ never saw it come down
before.  Where was I too!  Where were you, you mean.
subQuotationList: ['Where was I last night!', 'Come!  I like that.  I was waiting\nfor you, Mr. Harthouse, till it came down as _I_ never saw it come down\nbefore.  Where was I too!  Where were you, you mean.']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: I was prevented from coming   detained.
subQuotationList: ['I was prevented from coming   detained.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Detained! Two of us were detained.  I was detained
looking for you, till I lost every train but the mail.  It would have
been a pleasant job to go down by that on such a night, and have to walk
home through a pond.  I was obliged to sleep in town after all.
subQuotationList:
['Detained!', 'Two of us were detained.  I was detained
looking for you, till I lost every train but the mail.  It would have
been a pleasant job to go down by that on such a night, and have to walk
home through a pond.  I was obliged to sleep in town after all.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Where?
subQuotationList: ['Where?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Where?  Why, in my own bed at Bounderby's.
subQuotationList: ["Where?  Why, in my own bed at Bounderby's."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Did you see your sister?
subQuotationList: ['Did you see your sister?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
How the deuce, could I see my sister when she
was fifteen miles off?
subQuotationList: ['How the deuce,', 'could I see my sister when she\nwas fifteen miles off?']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
So, whether I am waiting for a hostile message, or an assignation, or a
penitent remonstrance, or an impromptu wrestle with my friend Bounderby
in the Lancashire manner   which would seem as likely as anything else in
the present state of affairs   I'll dine, Bounderby has the advantage in point of weight; and if anything of a
British nature is to come off between us, it may be as well to be in
training.
subQuotationList:
["So, whether I am waiting for a hostile message, or an assignation, or a
penitent remonstrance, or an impromptu wrestle with my friend Bounderby
in the Lancashire manner   which would seem as likely as anything else in
the present state of affairs   I'll dine,", 'Bounderby has the advantage in point of weight; and if anything of a
British nature is to come off between us, it may be as well to be in
training.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Some dinner at six   with a beefsteak in it,
subQuotationList: ['Some dinner at six   with a beefsteak in it,']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
referringExpression: he rang the bell and tossing himself negligently on a sofa ordered

quoteText:
It wouldn't be bad, to give the waiter
five shillings, and throw him. Or
a fellow of about thirteen or fourteen stone might be hired by the hour.
subQuotationList: ["It wouldn't be bad,", 'to give the waiter\nfive shillings, and throw him.', 'Or\na fellow of about thirteen or fourteen stone might be hired by the hour.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
like the Holy Office
and slow torture.
subQuotationList: ['like the Holy Office\nand slow torture.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Beg your pardon, sir.  You're wanted, sir, if you please.
subQuotationList: ["Beg your pardon, sir.  You're wanted, sir, if you please."]
speaker: The Waiter
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: Beg your pardon, sir.  Young lady outside, sir, wishes to see you.
subQuotationList: ['Beg your pardon, sir.  Young lady outside, sir, wishes to see you.']
speaker: The Waiter
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: Outside?  Where?
subQuotationList: ['Outside?  Where?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Outside this door, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Outside this door, sir.']
speaker: The Waiter

quoteText: I speak to Mr. Harthouse?
subQuotationList: ['I speak to Mr. Harthouse?']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
To Mr. Harthouse. And you speak to him with the
most confiding eyes I ever saw, and the most earnest voice (though so
quiet) I ever heard.
subQuotationList: ['To Mr. Harthouse.', 'And you speak to him with the\nmost confiding eyes I ever saw, and the most earnest voice (though so\nquiet) I ever heard.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: If I do not understand   and I do not, sir'
subQuotationList: ["If I do not understand   and I do not, sir'"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
what your honour
as a gentleman binds you to, in other matters:
subQuotationList: ['what your honour\nas a gentleman binds you to, in other matters:']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
I am sure I may rely upon it to
keep my visit secret, and to keep secret what I am going to say.  I will
rely upon it, if you will tell me I may so far trust
subQuotationList: ['I am sure I may rely upon it to\nkeep my visit secret, and to keep secret what I am going to say.  I will\nrely upon it, if you will tell me I may so far trust']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: You may, I assure you.
subQuotationList: ['You may, I assure you.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I am young, as you see; I am alone, as you see.  In coming to you, sir,
I have no advice or encouragement beyond my own hope. But
that is very strong, This is a very odd beginning.  I don't see
where we are going.
subQuotationList:
['I am young, as you see; I am alone, as you see.  In coming to you, sir,
I have no advice or encouragement beyond my own hope.', 'But
that is very strong,', "This is a very odd beginning.  I don't see
where we are going."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [], [['Mr. James Harthouse', 'Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText: I think, you have already guessed whom I left just now!
subQuotationList: ['I think,', 'you have already guessed whom I left just now!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
I have been in the greatest concern and uneasiness during the last
four-and-twenty hours (which have appeared as many years), on a lady's account.  The hopes I have been encouraged to form that you
come from that lady, do not deceive me, I trust.
subQuotationList: ['I have been in the greatest concern and uneasiness during the last\nfour-and-twenty hours (which have appeared as many years),', "on a lady's account.  The hopes I have been encouraged to form that you\ncome from that lady, do not deceive me, I trust."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: I left her within an hour.
subQuotationList: ['I left her within an hour.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: At   !
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: At her father's.
subQuotationList: ["At her father's."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Then I certainly, do _not_ see
where we are going.
subQuotationList: ['Then I certainly,', 'do _not_ see\nwhere we are going.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
She hurried there last night.  She arrived there in great agitation, and
was insensible all through the night.  I live at her father's, and was
with her.  You may be sure, sir, you will never see her again as long as
you live.
subQuotationList:
["She hurried there last night.  She arrived there in great agitation, and
was insensible all through the night.  I live at her father's, and was
with her.  You may be sure, sir, you will never see her again as long as
you live."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
So startling an announcement, so confidently made, and by such lips, is
really disconcerting in the last degree.  May I be permitted to inquire,
if you are charged to convey that information to me in those hopeless
words, by the lady of whom we speak?
subQuotationList:
['So startling an announcement, so confidently made, and by such lips, is
really disconcerting in the last degree.  May I be permitted to inquire,
if you are charged to convey that information to me in those hopeless
words, by the lady of whom we speak?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: I have no charge from her.
subQuotationList: ['I have no charge from her.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
The drowning man catches at the straw.  With no disrespect for your
judgment, and with no doubt of your sincerity, excuse my saying that I
cling to the belief that there is yet hope that I am not condemned to
perpetual exile from that lady's presence.
subQuotationList:
["The drowning man catches at the straw.  With no disrespect for your
judgment, and with no doubt of your sincerity, excuse my saying that I
cling to the belief that there is yet hope that I am not condemned to
perpetual exile from that lady's presence."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
There is not the least hope.  The first object of my coming here, sir,
is to assure you that you must believe that there is no more hope of your
ever speaking with her again, than there would be if she had died when
she came home last night.
subQuotationList:
['There is not the least hope.  The first object of my coming here, sir,
is to assure you that you must believe that there is no more hope of your
ever speaking with her again, than there would be if she had died when
she came home last night.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Must believe?  But if I can't   or if I should, by infirmity of nature, be
obstinate   and won't
subQuotationList: ["Must believe?  But if I can't   or if I should, by infirmity of nature, be\nobstinate   and won't"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: It is still true.  There is no hope.
subQuotationList: ['It is still true.  There is no hope.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Well!  If it should unhappily appear, after due pains and
duty on my part, that I am brought to a position so desolate as this
banishment, I shall not become the lady's persecutor.  But you said you
had no commission from her?
subQuotationList:
['Well!  If it should unhappily appear,', "after due pains and
duty on my part, that I am brought to a position so desolate as this
banishment, I shall not become the lady's persecutor.  But you said you
had no commission from her?"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I have only the commission of my love for her, and her love for me.  I
have no other trust, than that I have been with her since she came home,
and that she has given me her confidence.  I have no further trust, than
that I know something of her character and her marriage.  O Mr.
Harthouse, I think you had that trust too!
subQuotationList:
['I have only the commission of my love for her, and her love for me.  I
have no other trust, than that I have been with her since she came home,
and that she has given me her confidence.  I have no further trust, than
that I know something of her character and her marriage.  O Mr.
Harthouse, I think you had that trust too!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
I am not a moral sort of fellow, and I never make any
pretensions to the character of a moral sort of fellow.  I am as immoral
as need be.  At the same time, in bringing any distress upon the lady who
is the subject of the present conversation, or in unfortunately
compromising her in any way, or in committing myself by any expression of
sentiments towards her, not perfectly reconcilable with   in fact with   the
domestic hearth; or in taking any advantage of her father's being a
machine, or of her brother's being a whelp, or of her husband's being a
bear; I beg to be allowed to assure you that I have had no particularly
evil intentions, but have glided on from one step to another with a
smoothness so perfectly diabolical, that I had not the slightest idea the
catalogue was half so long until I began to turn it over.  Whereas I
find, that it is really in
several volumes.
subQuotationList:
['I am not a moral sort of fellow,', "and I never make any
pretensions to the character of a moral sort of fellow.  I am as immoral
as need be.  At the same time, in bringing any distress upon the lady who
is the subject of the present conversation, or in unfortunately
compromising her in any way, or in committing myself by any expression of
sentiments towards her, not perfectly reconcilable with   in fact with   the
domestic hearth; or in taking any advantage of her father's being a
machine, or of her brother's being a whelp, or of her husband's being a
bear; I beg to be allowed to assure you that I have had no particularly
evil intentions, but have glided on from one step to another with a
smoothness so perfectly diabolical, that I had not the slightest idea the
catalogue was half so long until I began to turn it over.  Whereas I
find,", 'that it is really in
several volumes.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
After what has been just now represented to me, in a manner I find it
impossible to doubt   I know of hardly any other source from which I could
have accepted it so readily   I feel bound to say to you, in whom the
confidence you have mentioned has been reposed, that I cannot refuse to
contemplate the possibility (however unexpected) of my seeing the lady no
more.  I am solely to blame for the thing having come to this   and   and, I
cannot say, that I
have any sanguine expectation of ever becoming a moral sort of fellow, or
that I have any belief in any moral sort of fellow whatever.
subQuotationList:
['After what has been just now represented to me, in a manner I find it
impossible to doubt   I know of hardly any other source from which I could
have accepted it so readily   I feel bound to say to you, in whom the
confidence you have mentioned has been reposed, that I cannot refuse to
contemplate the possibility (however unexpected) of my seeing the lady no
more.  I am solely to blame for the thing having come to this   and   and, I
cannot say,', 'that I
have any sanguine expectation of ever becoming a moral sort of fellow, or
that I have any belief in any moral sort of fellow whatever.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
You spoke, of your
first object.  I may assume that there is a second to be mentioned?
subQuotationList: ['You spoke,', 'of your\nfirst object.  I may assume that there is a second to be mentioned?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Will you oblige me by confiding it?
subQuotationList: ['Will you oblige me by confiding it?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Mr. Harthouse, the only reparation that remains with you, is to leave
here immediately and finally.  I am quite sure that you can mitigate in
no other way the wrong and harm you have done.  I am quite sure that it
is the only compensation you have left it in your power to make.  I do
not say that it is much, or that it is enough; but it is something, and
it is necessary.  Therefore, though without any other authority than I
have given you, and even without the knowledge of any other person than
yourself and myself, I ask you to depart from this place to-night, under
an obligation never to return to it.
subQuotationList:
['Mr. Harthouse,', 'the only reparation that remains with you, is to leave
here immediately and finally.  I am quite sure that you can mitigate in
no other way the wrong and harm you have done.  I am quite sure that it
is the only compensation you have left it in your power to make.  I do
not say that it is much, or that it is enough; but it is something, and
it is necessary.  Therefore, though without any other authority than I
have given you, and even without the knowledge of any other person than
yourself and myself, I ask you to depart from this place to-night, under
an obligation never to return to it.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
But do you know, the extent of what you
ask?  You probably are not aware that I am here on a public kind of
business, preposterous enough in itself, but which I have gone in for,
and sworn by, and am supposed to be devoted to in quite a desperate
manner?  You probably are not aware of that, but I assure you it's the
fact.
subQuotationList:
['But do you know,', "the extent of what you
ask?  You probably are not aware that I am here on a public kind of
business, preposterous enough in itself, but which I have gone in for,
and sworn by, and am supposed to be devoted to in quite a desperate
manner?  You probably are not aware of that, but I assure you it's the
fact."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Besides which, it's so alarmingly absurd.  It would make a man so
ridiculous, after going in for these fellows, to back out in such an
incomprehensible way.
subQuotationList: ['Besides which,', "it's so alarmingly absurd.  It would make a man so\nridiculous, after going in for these fellows, to back out in such an\nincomprehensible way."]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I am quite sure, that it is the only reparation in
your power, sir.  I am quite sure, or I would not have come here.
subQuotationList: ['I am quite sure,', 'that it is the only reparation in\nyour power, sir.  I am quite sure, or I would not have come here.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Upon my soul, I don't
know what to say.  So immensely absurd!
subQuotationList: ["Upon my soul, I don't\nknow what to say.  So immensely absurd!"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
If I were to do such a very ridiculous thing, it could only be in
the most inviolable confidence.
subQuotationList: ['If I were to do such a very ridiculous thing,', 'it could only be in\nthe most inviolable confidence.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: I will trust to you, sir, and you will trust to me.
subQuotationList: ['I will trust to you, sir,', 'and you will trust to me.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']], [['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText:
I suppose a man never was placed in a more ridiculous position, But I see no way out of it.  What
will be, will be.  _This_ will be, I suppose.  I must take off myself, I
imagine   in short, I engage to do it.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose a man never was placed in a more ridiculous position,', 'But I see no way out of it.  What\nwill be, will be.  _This_ will be, I suppose.  I must take off myself, I\nimagine   in short, I engage to do it.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
You will permit me to say, that I doubt
if any other ambassador, or ambassadress, could have addressed me with
the same success.  I must not only regard myself as being in a very
ridiculous position, but as being vanquished at all points.  Will you
allow me the privilege of remembering my enemy's name?
subQuotationList:
['You will permit me to say,', "that I doubt
if any other ambassador, or ambassadress, could have addressed me with
the same success.  I must not only regard myself as being in a very
ridiculous position, but as being vanquished at all points.  Will you
allow me the privilege of remembering my enemy's name?"]
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: _My_ name?
subQuotationList: ['_My_ name?']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: The only name I could possibly care to know, to-night.
subQuotationList: ['The only name I could possibly care to know, to-night.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Sissy Jupe.
subQuotationList: ['Sissy Jupe.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: Pardon my curiosity at parting.  Related to the family?
subQuotationList: ['Pardon my curiosity at parting.  Related to the family?']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
I am only a poor girl, I was separated from my
father   he was only a stroller   and taken pity on by Mr. Gradgrind.  I have
lived in the house ever since.
subQuotationList: ['I am only a poor girl,', 'I was separated from my\nfather   he was only a stroller   and taken pity on by Mr. Gradgrind.  I have\nlived in the house ever since.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
It wanted this to complete the defeat, The defeat may now be considered perfectly accomplished.
Only a poor girl   only a stroller   only James Harthouse made nothing
of   only James Harthouse a Great Pyramid of failure.
subQuotationList: ['It wanted this to complete the defeat,', 'The defeat may now be considered perfectly accomplished.\nOnly a poor girl   only a stroller   only James Harthouse made nothing\nof   only James Harthouse a Great Pyramid of failure.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Send my fellow here.
subQuotationList: ['Send my fellow here.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText: Gone to bed, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Gone to bed, sir.']
speaker: The Waiter

quoteText: Tell him to get up, and pack up.
subQuotationList: ['Tell him to get up, and pack up.']
speaker: Mr. James Harthouse

quoteText:
Now, Tom Gradgrind, here's a lady here   Mrs. Sparsit   you know Mrs.
Sparsit   who has something to say to you that will strike you dumb.
subQuotationList: ['Now, Tom Gradgrind,', "here's a lady here   Mrs. Sparsit   you know Mrs.\nSparsit   who has something to say to you that will strike you dumb."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind']], [['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: You have missed my letter!
subQuotationList: ['You have missed my letter!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Missed your letter, sir! The present time is no
time for letters.  No man shall talk to Josiah Bounderby of Coketown
about letters, with his mind in the state it's in now.
subQuotationList: ['Missed your letter, sir!', "The present time is no\ntime for letters.  No man shall talk to Josiah Bounderby of Coketown\nabout letters, with his mind in the state it's in now."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Bounderby, I
speak of a very special letter I have written to you, in reference to
Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['Bounderby,', 'I\nspeak of a very special letter I have written to you, in reference to\nLouisa.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Tom Gradgrind, I speak of a very special
messenger that has come to me, in reference to Louisa.  Mrs. Sparsit,
ma'am, stand forward!
subQuotationList: ['Tom Gradgrind,', "I speak of a very special\nmessenger that has come to me, in reference to Louisa.  Mrs. Sparsit,\nma'am, stand forward!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
If you can't get it out, ma'am, leave _me_ to get it
out.  This is not a time for a lady, however highly connected, to be
totally inaudible, and seemingly swallowing marbles.  Tom Gradgrind, Mrs.
Sparsit latterly found herself, by accident, in a situation to overhear a
conversation out of doors between your daughter and your precious
gentleman-friend, Mr. James Harthouse.
subQuotationList:
["If you can't get it out, ma'am,", 'leave _me_ to get it
out.  This is not a time for a lady, however highly connected, to be
totally inaudible, and seemingly swallowing marbles.  Tom Gradgrind, Mrs.
Sparsit latterly found herself, by accident, in a situation to overhear a
conversation out of doors between your daughter and your precious
gentleman-friend, Mr. James Harthouse.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mr. James Harthouse']]]

quoteText: Indeed!
subQuotationList: ['Indeed!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Ah!  Indeed! And in that conversation
subQuotationList: ['Ah!  Indeed!', 'And in that conversation']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
It is not necessary to repeat its tenor, Bounderby.  I know what
passed.
subQuotationList: ['It is not necessary to repeat its tenor, Bounderby.  I know what\npassed.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
You do?  Perhaps, you know where your daughter is at
the present time!
subQuotationList: ['You do?  Perhaps,', 'you know where your daughter is at\nthe present time!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Undoubtedly.  She is here.
subQuotationList: ['Undoubtedly.  She is here.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Here?
subQuotationList: ['Here?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
My dear Bounderby, let me beg you to restrain these loud out-breaks, on
all accounts.  Louisa is here.  The moment she could detach herself from
that interview with the person of whom you speak, and whom I deeply
regret to have been the means of introducing to you, Louisa hurried here,
for protection.  I myself had not been at home many hours, when I
received her   here, in this room.  She hurried by the train to town, she
ran from town to this house, through a raging storm, and presented
herself before me in a state of distraction.  Of course, she has remained
here ever since.  Let me entreat you, for your own sake and for hers, to
be more quiet.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Bounderby, let me beg you to restrain these loud out-breaks, on
all accounts.  Louisa is here.  The moment she could detach herself from
that interview with the person of whom you speak, and whom I deeply
regret to have been the means of introducing to you, Louisa hurried here,
for protection.  I myself had not been at home many hours, when I
received her   here, in this room.  She hurried by the train to town, she
ran from town to this house, through a raging storm, and presented
herself before me in a state of distraction.  Of course, she has remained
here ever since.  Let me entreat you, for your own sake and for hers, to
be more quiet.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Now, ma'am!  We shall be happy to hear any little apology you may think
proper to offer, for going about the country at express pace, with no
other luggage than a Cock-and-a-Bull, ma'am!
subQuotationList: ["Now, ma'am!  We shall be happy to hear any little apology you may think\nproper to offer, for going about the country at express pace, with no\nother luggage than a Cock-and-a-Bull, ma'am!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
referringExpression: Mr Bounderby silently gazed about him for some moments in every direction except Mrs Sparsits direction and then abruptly turning upon the niece of Lady Scadgers said

quoteText:
Sir, my nerves are at present too much shaken,
and my health is at present too much impaired, in your service, to admit
of my doing more than taking refuge in tears.
subQuotationList: ['Sir,', 'my nerves are at present too much shaken,\nand my health is at present too much impaired, in your service, to admit\nof my doing more than taking refuge in tears.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Well, ma'am, without making any observation to you
that may not be made with propriety to a woman of good family, what I
have got to add to that, is that there is something else in which it
appears to me you may take refuge, namely, a coach.  And the coach in
which we came here being at the door, you'll allow me to hand you down to
it, and pack you home to the Bank: where the best course for you to
pursue, will be to put your feet into the hottest water you can bear, and
take a glass of scalding rum and butter after you get into bed.
subQuotationList:
["Well, ma'am,", "without making any observation to you
that may not be made with propriety to a woman of good family, what I
have got to add to that, is that there is something else in which it
appears to me you may take refuge, namely, a coach.  And the coach in

speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Now, as you showed me in your face, Tom Gradgrind, that you wanted to
speak to me, here I am.  But, I am not in a very agreeable
state, I tell you plainly: not relishing this business, even as it is,
and not considering that I am at any time as dutifully and submissively
treated by your daughter, as Josiah Bounderby of Coketown ought to be
treated by his wife.  You have your opinion, I dare say; and I have mine,
I know.  If you mean to say anything to me to-night, that goes against
this candid remark, you had better let it alone.
subQuotationList:
['Now, as you showed me in your face, Tom Gradgrind, that you wanted to

quoteText: My dear Bounderby,
subQuotationList: ['My dear Bounderby,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Now, you'll excuse me, but I don't want to be too
dear.  That, to start with.  When I begin to be dear to a man, I
generally find that his intention is to come over me.  I am not speaking
to you politely; but, as you are aware, I am _not_ polite.  If you like
politeness, you know where to get it.  You have your gentleman-friends,
you know, and they'll serve you with as much of the article as you want.
I don't keep it myself.
subQuotationList:
["Now, you'll excuse me,", "but I don't want to be too

generally find that his intention is to come over me.  I am not speaking

politeness, you know where to get it.  You have your gentleman-friends,
you know, and they'll serve you with as much of the article as you want.
I don't keep it myself."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Bounderby, we are all liable to mistakes
subQuotationList: ['Bounderby,', 'we are all liable to mistakes']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I thought you couldn't make 'em,
subQuotationList: ["I thought you couldn't make 'em,"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Perhaps I thought so.  But, I say we are all liable to mistakes and I
should feel sensible of your delicacy, and grateful for it, if you would
spare me these references to Harthouse.  I shall not associate him in our
conversation with your intimacy and encouragement; pray do not persist in
connecting him with mine.
subQuotationList:

quoteText: I never mentioned his name!
subQuotationList: ['I never mentioned his name!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Well, well! Bounderby, I see reason
to doubt whether we have ever quite understood Louisa.
subQuotationList: ['Well, well!', 'Bounderby, I see reason\nto doubt whether we have ever quite understood Louisa.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Who do you mean by We?
subQuotationList: ['Who do you mean by We?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Let me say I, then, I doubt whether I have understood Louisa.  I doubt whether I
have been quite right in the manner of her education.
subQuotationList: ['Let me say I, then,', 'I doubt whether I have understood Louisa.  I doubt whether I\nhave been quite right in the manner of her education.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
There you hit it, There I agree with you.  You
have found it out at last, have you?  Education!  I'll tell you what
education is   To be tumbled out of doors, neck and crop, and put upon the
shortest allowance of everything except blows.  That's what _I_ call
education.
subQuotationList:
['There you hit it,', "There I agree with you.  You
have found it out at last, have you?  Education!  I'll tell you what
education is   To be tumbled out of doors, neck and crop, and put upon the
shortest allowance of everything except blows.  That's what _I_ call
education."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I think your good sense will perceive, that whatever the merits of such a system may be, it would
be difficult of general application to girls.
subQuotationList: ['I think your good sense will perceive,', 'that whatever the merits of such a system may be, it would\nbe difficult of general application to girls.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I don't see it at all, sir,
subQuotationList: ["I don't see it at all, sir,"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Well, we will not enter into the question.  I
assure you I have no desire to be controversial.  I seek to repair what
is amiss, if I possibly can; and I hope you will assist me in a good
spirit, Bounderby, for I have been very much distressed.
subQuotationList:
['Well,', 'we will not enter into the question.  I
assure you I have no desire to be controversial.  I seek to repair what
is amiss, if I possibly can; and I hope you will assist me in a good
spirit, Bounderby, for I have been very much distressed.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: I don't understand you, yet, and therefore I won't make any promises.
subQuotationList: ["I don't understand you, yet,", "and therefore I won't make any promises."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
In the course of a few hours, my dear Bounderby, I appear to
myself to have become better informed as to Louisa's character, than in
previous years.  The enlightenment has been painfully forced upon me, and
the discovery is not mine.  I think there are   Bounderby, you will be
surprised to hear me say this   I think there are qualities in Louisa,
which   which have been harshly neglected, and   and a little perverted.
And   and I would suggest to you, that   that if you would kindly meet me in
a timely endeavour to leave her to her better nature for a while   and to
encourage it to develop itself by tenderness and consideration   it   it
would be the better for the happiness of all of us.  Louisa, has always been my favourite
child.

quoteText: You'd like to keep her here for a time?
subQuotationList: ["You'd like to keep her here for a time?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
referringExpression: he pent up his indignation however and said

quoteText:
I   I had intended to recommend, my dear Bounderby, that you should allow
Louisa to remain here on a visit, and be attended by Sissy (I mean of
course Cecilia Jupe), who understands her, and in whom she trusts.
subQuotationList: ['I   I had intended to recommend, my dear Bounderby, that you should allow\nLouisa to remain here on a visit, and be attended by Sissy (I mean of\ncourse Cecilia Jupe), who understands her, and in whom she trusts.']

quoteText:
I gather from all this, Tom Gradgrind, that you are of opinion that there's what
people call some incompatibility between Loo Bounderby and myself.
subQuotationList: ['I gather from all this, Tom Gradgrind,', "that you are of opinion that there's what\npeople call some incompatibility between Loo Bounderby and myself."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I fear there is at present a general incompatibility between Louisa,
and   and   and almost all the relations in which I have placed her,
subQuotationList: ['I fear there is at present a general incompatibility between Louisa,\nand   and   and almost all the relations in which I have placed her,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Now, look you here, Tom Gradgrind, You have said your say; I am going to say mine.  I am a
Coketown man.  I am Josiah Bounderby of Coketown.  I know the bricks of
this town, and I know the works of this town, and I know the chimneys of
this town, and I know the smoke of this town, and I know the Hands of
this town.  I know 'em all pretty well.  They're real.  When a man tells
me anything about imaginative qualities, I always tell that man, whoever
he is, that I know what he means.  He means turtle soup and venison, with
a gold spoon, and that he wants to be set up with a coach and six.
That's what your daughter wants.  Since you are of opinion that she ought
to have what she wants, I recommend you to provide it for her.  Because,
Tom Gradgrind, she will never have it from me.
subQuotationList:

this town, and I know the smoke of this town, and I know the Hands of

me anything about imaginative qualities, I always tell that man, whoever

That's what your daughter wants.  Since you are of opinion that she ought
to have what she wants, I recommend you to provide it for her.  Because,
Tom Gradgrind, she will never have it from me."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Bounderby, I hoped, after my entreaty, you would
have taken a different tone.
subQuotationList: ['Bounderby,', 'I hoped, after my entreaty, you would\nhave taken a different tone.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Just wait a bit, you have said your say, I
believe.  I heard you out; hear me out, if you please.  Don't make
yourself a spectacle of unfairness as well as inconsistency, because,
although I am sorry to see Tom Gradgrind reduced to his present position,
I should be doubly sorry to see him brought so low as that.  Now, there's
an incompatibility of some sort or another, I am given to understand by
you, between your daughter and me.  I'll give _you_ to understand, in
reply to that, that there unquestionably is an incompatibility of the
first magnitude   to be summed up in this   that your daughter don't properly
know her husband's merits, and is not impressed with such a sense as
would become her, by George! of the honour of his alliance.  That's plain
speaking, I hope.
subQuotationList:

quoteText: Bounderby, this is unreasonable.
subQuotationList: ['Bounderby,', 'this is unreasonable.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Is it? I am glad to hear you say so.  Because when
Tom Gradgrind, with his new lights, tells me that what I say is
unreasonable, I am convinced at once it must be devilish sensible.  With
your permission I am going on.  You know my origin; and you know that for
a good many years of my life I didn't want a shoeing-horn, in consequence
of not having a shoe.  Yet you may believe or not, as you think proper,
that there are ladies   born ladies   belonging to families   Families!   who
next to worship the ground I walk on.
subQuotationList:
['Is it?', "I am glad to hear you say so.  Because when
Tom Gradgrind, with his new lights, tells me that what I say is
unreasonable, I am convinced at once it must be devilish sensible.  With

a good many years of my life I didn't want a shoeing-horn, in consequence
of not having a shoe.  Yet you may believe or not, as you think proper,
that there are ladies   born ladies   belonging to families   Families!   who
next to worship the ground I walk on."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
Whereas your daughter, is far from being a born
lady.  That you know, yourself.  Not that I care a pinch of candle-snuff
about such things, for you are very well aware I don't; but that such is
the fact, and you, Tom Gradgrind, can't change it.  Why do I say this?
subQuotationList:
['Whereas your daughter,', "is far from being a born
lady.  That you know, yourself.  Not that I care a pinch of candle-snuff

quoteText: Not, I fear, to spare me.
subQuotationList: ['Not, I fear,', 'to spare me.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Hear me out, and refrain from cutting in till your
turn comes round.  I say this, because highly connected females have been
astonished to see the way in which your daughter has conducted herself,
and to witness her insensibility.  They have wondered how I have suffered
it.  And I wonder myself now, and I won't suffer it.
subQuotationList:

turn comes round.  I say this, because highly connected females have been

and to witness her insensibility.  They have wondered how I have suffered
it.  And I wonder myself now, and I won't suffer it."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Bounderby, the less we say to-night
the better, I think.
subQuotationList: ['Bounderby,', 'the less we say to-night\nthe better, I think.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
On the contrary, Tom Gradgrind, the more we say to-night, the better, I
think.  That is,
subQuotationList: ['On the contrary, Tom Gradgrind, the more we say to-night, the better, I\nthink.  That is,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
till I have said all I
mean to say, and then I don't care how soon we stop.  I come to a
question that may shorten the business.  What do you mean by the proposal
you made just now?
subQuotationList:
["till I have said all I

quoteText: What do I mean, Bounderby?
subQuotationList: ['What do I mean, Bounderby?']

quoteText: By your visiting proposition,
subQuotationList: ['By your visiting proposition,']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I mean that I hope you may be induced to arrange in a friendly manner,
for allowing Louisa a period of repose and reflection here, which may
tend to a gradual alteration for the better in many respects.
subQuotationList: ['I mean that I hope you may be induced to arrange in a friendly manner,\nfor allowing Louisa a period of repose and reflection here, which may\ntend to a gradual alteration for the better in many respects.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: To a softening down of your ideas of the incompatibility?
subQuotationList: ['To a softening down of your ideas of the incompatibility?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: If you put it in those terms.
subQuotationList: ['If you put it in those terms.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: What made you think of this?
subQuotationList: ['What made you think of this?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I have already said, I fear Louisa has not been understood.  Is it
asking too much, Bounderby, that you, so far her elder, should aid in
trying to set her right?  You have accepted a great charge of her; for
better for worse, for
subQuotationList:
['I have already said, I fear Louisa has not been understood.  Is it
asking too much, Bounderby, that you, so far her elder, should aid in
trying to set her right?  You have accepted a great charge of her; for
better for worse, for']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Come! I don't want to be told about that.  I know what I took
her for, as well as you do.  Never you mind what I took her for; that's
my look out.
subQuotationList: ['Come!', "I don't want to be told about that.  I know what I took\nher for, as well as you do.  Never you mind what I took her for; that's\nmy look out."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I was merely going on to remark, Bounderby, that we may all be more or
less in the wrong, not even excepting you; and that some yielding on your
part, remembering the trust you have accepted, may not only be an act of
true kindness, but perhaps a debt incurred towards Louisa.
subQuotationList:
['I was merely going on to remark, Bounderby, that we may all be more or
less in the wrong, not even excepting you; and that some yielding on your
part, remembering the trust you have accepted, may not only be an act of
true kindness, but perhaps a debt incurred towards Louisa.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
I think differently, I am going to finish this
business according to my own opinions.  Now, I don't want to make a
quarrel of it with you, Tom Gradgrind.  To tell you the truth, I don't
think it would be worthy of my reputation to quarrel on such a subject.
As to your gentleman-friend, he may take himself off, wherever he likes
best.  If he falls in my way, I shall tell him my mind; if he don't fall
in my way, I shan't, for it won't be worth my while to do it.  As to your
daughter, whom I made Loo Bounderby, and might have done better by
leaving Loo Gradgrind, if she don't come home to-morrow, by twelve
o'clock at noon, I shall understand that she prefers to stay away, and I
shall send her wearing apparel and so forth over here, and you'll take
charge of her for the future.  What I shall say to people in general, of
the incompatibility that led to my so laying down the law, will be this.
I am Josiah Bounderby, and I had my bringing-up; she's the daughter of
Tom Gradgrind, and she had her bringing-up; and the two horses wouldn't
pull together.  I am pretty well known to be rather an uncommon man, I
believe; and most people will understand fast enough that it must be a
woman rather out of the common, also, who, in the long run, would come up
to my mark.

to my mark."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Let me seriously entreat you to reconsider this, Bounderby, before you commit yourself to such a decision.
subQuotationList: ['Let me seriously entreat you to reconsider this, Bounderby,', 'before you commit yourself to such a decision.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I always come to a decision, and
whatever I do, I do at once.  I should be surprised at Tom Gradgrind's
addressing such a remark to Josiah Bounderby of Coketown, knowing what he
knows of him, if I could be surprised by anything Tom Gradgrind did,
after his making himself a party to sentimental humbug.  I have given you
my decision, and I have got no more to say.  Good night!
subQuotationList:
['I always come to a decision,', "and
whatever I do, I do at once.  I should be surprised at Tom Gradgrind's
addressing such a remark to Josiah Bounderby of Coketown, knowing what he
knows of him, if I could be surprised by anything Tom Gradgrind did,
after his making himself a party to sentimental humbug.  I have given you
my decision, and I have got no more to say.  Good night!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh, my fellow-men, behold of what a traitor in the camp of
those great spirits who are enrolled upon the holy scroll of Justice and
of Union, is appropriately capable!  Oh, my prostrate friends, with the
galling yoke of tyrants on your necks and the iron foot of despotism
treading down your fallen forms into the dust of the earth, upon which
right glad would your oppressors be to see you creeping on your bellies
all the days of your lives, like the serpent in the garden   oh, my
brothers, and shall I as a man not add, my sisters too, what do you say,
_now_, of Stephen Blackpool, with a slight stoop in his shoulders and
about five foot seven in height, as set forth in this degrading and
disgusting document, this blighting bill, this pernicious placard, this
abominable advertisement; and with what majesty of denouncement will you
crush the viper, who would bring this stain and shame upon the God-like
race that happily has cast him out for ever!  Yes, my compatriots,
happily cast him out and sent him forth!  For you remember how he stood
here before you on this platform; you remember how, face to face and foot
to foot, I pursued him through all his intricate windings; you remember
how he sneaked and slunk, and sidled, and splitted of straws, until, with
not an inch of ground to which to cling, I hurled him out from amongst
us: an object for the undying finger of scorn to point at, and for the
avenging fire of every free and thinking mind to scorch and scar!  And
now, my friends   my labouring friends, for I rejoice and triumph in that
stigma   my friends whose hard but honest beds are made in toil, and whose
scanty but independent pots are boiled in hardship; and now, I say, my
friends, what appellation has that dastard craven taken to himself, when,
with the mask torn from his features, he stands before us in all his
native deformity, a What?  A thief!  A plunderer!  A proscribed fugitive,
with a price upon his head; a fester and a wound upon the noble character
of the Coketown operative!  Therefore, my band of brothers in a sacred
bond, to which your children and your children's children yet unborn have
set their infant hands and seals, I propose to you on the part of the
United Aggregate Tribunal, ever watchful for your welfare, ever zealous
for your benefit, that this meeting does Resolve: That Stephen Blackpool,
weaver, referred to in this placard, having been already solemnly
disowned by the community of Coketown Hands, the same are free from the
shame of his misdeeds, and cannot as a class be reproached with his
dishonest actions!
subQuotationList:
["Oh, my fellow-men, behold of what a traitor in the camp of
those great spirits who are enrolled upon the holy scroll of Justice and
of Union, is appropriately capable!  Oh, my prostrate friends, with the
galling yoke of tyrants on your necks and the iron foot of despotism
treading down your fallen forms into the dust of the earth, upon which
right glad would your oppressors be to see you creeping on your bellies
all the days of your lives, like the serpent in the garden   oh, my
brothers, and shall I as a man not add, my sisters too, what do you say,
_now_, of Stephen Blackpool, with a slight stoop in his shoulders and
