speaker: Slackbridge
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: No!
speaker: _unknowable
referringExpression: A few stern voices called out

quoteText:
Slackbridge, y'or over
hetter in't; y'or a goen too fast!
subQuotationList: ["Slackbridge, y'or over\nhetter in't; y'or a goen too fast!"]
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText: Who is it?
subQuotationList: ['Who is it?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
It is Mr. Bounderby, and your brother
Mr. Tom, and a young woman who says her name is Rachael, and that you
know her.
subQuotationList: ['It is Mr. Bounderby,', 'and your brother\nMr. Tom, and a young woman who says her name is Rachael, and that you\nknow her.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: What do they want, Sissy dear?
subQuotationList: ['What do they want, Sissy dear?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: They want to see you.  Rachael has been crying, and seems angry.
subQuotationList: ['They want to see you.  Rachael has been crying, and seems angry.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Father, I cannot refuse to see them,
for a reason that will explain itself.  Shall they come in here?
subQuotationList: ['Father,', 'I cannot refuse to see them,\nfor a reason that will explain itself.  Shall they come in here?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind']], [['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Rachel Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
Mrs. Bounderby, I don't
disturb you, I hope.  This is an unseasonable hour, but here is a young
woman who has been making statements which render my visit necessary.
Tom Gradgrind, as your son, young Tom, refuses for some obstinate reason
or other to say anything at all about those statements, good or bad, I am
obliged to confront her with your daughter.
subQuotationList:
['Mrs. Bounderby,', "I don't
disturb you, I hope.  This is an unseasonable hour, but here is a young
woman who has been making statements which render my visit necessary.
Tom Gradgrind, as your son, young Tom, refuses for some obstinate reason
or other to say anything at all about those statements, good or bad, I am
obliged to confront her with your daughter."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionTextsList: [['Mrs. Bounderby'], ['you', ' a young\nwoman ', 'Tom Gradgrind', 'your son', 'young Tom', 'her', 'your daughter']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: You have seen me once before, young lady,
subQuotationList: ['You have seen me once before, young lady,']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: You have seen me, young lady, once before.
subQuotationList: ['You have seen me, young lady,', 'once before.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: I have.
subQuotationList: ['I have.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Will you
make it known, young lady, where, and who was there?
subQuotationList: ['Will you\nmake it known, young lady, where, and who was there?']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind
referringExpression: Rachael cast her eyes proudly towards Mr Bounderby and said

quoteText:
I went to the house where Stephen Blackpool lodged, on the night of his
discharge from his work, and I saw you there.  He was there too; and an
old woman who did not speak, and whom I could scarcely see, stood in a
dark corner.  My brother was with me.
subQuotationList:
['I went to the house where Stephen Blackpool lodged, on the night of his
discharge from his work, and I saw you there.  He was there too; and an
old woman who did not speak, and whom I could scarcely see, stood in a
dark corner.  My brother was with me.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionTextsList: [['Stephen Blackpool', 'his', 'his', 'He', 'an\nold woman who did not speak', 'My brother']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['The Old Woman'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText: Why couldn't you say so, young Tom?
subQuotationList: ["Why couldn't you say so, young Tom?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: I promised my sister I wouldn't.
subQuotationList: ["I promised my sister I wouldn't."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
And
besides, she tells her own story so precious
well   and so full   that what business had I to take it out of her mouth!
subQuotationList: ['And\nbesides,', 'she tells her own story so precious\nwell   and so full   that what business had I to take it out of her mouth!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Say, young lady, if you please, why, in an evil hour,
you ever came to Stephen's that night.
subQuotationList: ['Say, young lady, if you please,', "why, in an evil hour,\nyou ever came to Stephen's that night."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I felt compassion for him, and I
wished to know what he was going to do, and wished to offer him
assistance.
subQuotationList: ['I felt compassion for him,', 'and I\nwished to know what he was going to do, and wished to offer him\nassistance.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Thank you, ma'am, Much flattered and obliged.
subQuotationList: ["Thank you, ma'am,", 'Much flattered and obliged.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Did you offer him, a bank-note?
subQuotationList: ['Did you offer him,', 'a bank-note?']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Yes; but he refused it, and would only take two pounds in gold.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; but he refused it, and would only take two pounds in gold.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh, certainly! If you put the question whether your
ridiculous and improbable account was true or not, I am bound to say it's
confirmed.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, certainly!', "If you put the question whether your\nridiculous and improbable account was true or not, I am bound to say it's\nconfirmed."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Young lady, Stephen Blackpool is now named as a thief in
public print all over this town, and where else!  There have been a
meeting to-night where he have been spoken of in the same shameful way.
Stephen!  The honestest lad, the truest lad, the best!
subQuotationList:
['Young lady,', 'Stephen Blackpool is now named as a thief in
public print all over this town, and where else!  There have been a
meeting to-night where he have been spoken of in the same shameful way.
Stephen!  The honestest lad, the truest lad, the best!']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: I am very, very sorry,
subQuotationList: ['I am very, very sorry,']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh, young lady, young lady, I hope you may be, but I
don't know!  I can't say what you may ha' done!  The like of you don't
know us, don't care for us, don't belong to us.  I am not sure why you
may ha' come that night.  I can't tell but what you may ha' come wi' some
aim of your own, not mindin to what trouble you brought such as the poor
lad.  I said then, Bless you for coming; and I said it of my heart, you
seemed to take so pitifully to him; but I don't know now, I don't know!
subQuotationList:
['Oh, young lady, young lady,', "I hope you may be, but I
don't know!  I can't say what you may ha' done!  The like of you don't
know us, don't care for us, don't belong to us.  I am not sure why you
may ha' come that night.  I can't tell but what you may ha' come wi' some
aim of your own, not mindin to what trouble you brought such as the poor
lad.  I said then, Bless you for coming; and I said it of my heart, you
seemed to take so pitifully to him; but I don't know now, I don't know!"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Rachel Gradgrind', 'Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind', 'Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind', 'Stephen Blackpool'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
And when I think, that the poor lad was
so grateful, thinkin you so good to him   when I mind that he put his hand
over his hard-worken face to hide the tears that you brought up there   Oh,
I hope you may be sorry, and ha' no bad cause to be it; but I don't know,
I don't know!
subQuotationList:
['And when I think,', "that the poor lad was
so grateful, thinkin you so good to him   when I mind that he put his hand
over his hard-worken face to hide the tears that you brought up there   Oh,
I hope you may be sorry, and ha' no bad cause to be it; but I don't know,
I don't know!"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
You're a pretty article, to come here with these precious imputations!  You ought to be
bundled out for not knowing how to behave yourself, and you would be by
rights.
subQuotationList: ["You're a pretty article,", 'to come here with these precious imputations!  You ought to be\nbundled out for not knowing how to behave yourself, and you would be by\nrights.']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Come! you know what you have engaged to do.  You had better
give your mind to that; not this.
subQuotationList: ['Come!', 'you know what you have engaged to do.  You had better\ngive your mind to that; not this.']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
'Deed, I am loath, that any here
should see me like this; but I won't be seen so again.  Young lady, when
I had read what's put in print of Stephen   and what has just as much truth
in it as if it had been put in print of you   I went straight to the Bank
to say I knew where Stephen was, and to give a sure and certain promise
that he should be here in two days.  I couldn't meet wi' Mr. Bounderby
then, and your brother sent me away, and I tried to find you, but you was
not to be found, and I went back to work.  Soon as I come out of the Mill
to-night, I hastened to hear what was said of Stephen   for I know wi'
pride he will come back to shame it!   and then I went again to seek Mr.
Bounderby, and I found him, and I told him every word I knew; and he
believed no word I said, and brought me here.
subQuotationList:
["'Deed, I am loath,", "that any here
should see me like this; but I won't be seen so again.  Young lady, when
I had read what's put in print of Stephen   and what has just as much truth
in it as if it had been put in print of you   I went straight to the Bank
to say I knew where Stephen was, and to give a sure and certain promise
that he should be here in two days.  I couldn't meet wi' Mr. Bounderby
then, and your brother sent me away, and I tried to find you, but you was
not to be found, and I went back to work.  Soon as I come out of the Mill
to-night, I hastened to hear what was said of Stephen   for I know wi'
pride he will come back to shame it!   and then I went again to seek Mr.
Bounderby, and I found him, and I told him every word I knew; and he
believed no word I said, and brought me here."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
So far, that's true enough, But I have known you people before to-day,
you'll observe, and I know you never die for want of talking.  Now, I
recommend you not so much to mind talking just now, as doing.  You have
undertaken to do something; all I remark upon that at present is, do it!
subQuotationList:
["So far, that's true enough,", "But I have known you people before to-day,
you'll observe, and I know you never die for want of talking.  Now, I
recommend you not so much to mind talking just now, as doing.  You have
undertaken to do something; all I remark upon that at present is, do it!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
I have written to Stephen by the post that went out this afternoon, as I
have written to him once before sin' he went away, and he
will be here, at furthest, in two days.
subQuotationList: ["I have written to Stephen by the post that went out this afternoon, as I\nhave written to him once before sin' he went away,", 'and he\nwill be here, at furthest, in two days.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Then, I'll tell you something.  You are not aware perhaps, that you yourself have been looked after now and then, not
being considered quite free from suspicion in this business, on account
of most people being judged according to the company they keep.  The
post-office hasn't been forgotten either.  What I'll tell you is, that no
letter to Stephen Blackpool has ever got into it.  Therefore, what has
become of yours, I leave you to guess.  Perhaps you're mistaken, and
never wrote any.
subQuotationList:
["Then, I'll tell you something.  You are not aware perhaps,", "that you yourself have been looked after now and then, not
being considered quite free from suspicion in this business, on account
of most people being judged according to the company they keep.  The
post-office hasn't been forgotten either.  What I'll tell you is, that no
letter to Stephen Blackpool has ever got into it.  Therefore, what has
become of yours, I leave you to guess.  Perhaps you're mistaken, and
never wrote any."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind']], [['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
He hadn't been gone from here, young lady, as much as a week, when he sent me the only
letter I have had from him, saying that he was forced to seek work in
another name.
subQuotationList: ["He hadn't been gone from here, young lady,", 'as much as a week, when he sent me the only\nletter I have had from him, saying that he was forced to seek work in\nanother name.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Oh, by George! he
changes his name, does he!  That's rather unlucky, too, for such an
immaculate chap.  It's considered a little suspicious in Courts of
Justice, I believe, when an Innocent happens to have many names.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, by George!', "he
changes his name, does he!  That's rather unlucky, too, for such an
immaculate chap.  It's considered a little suspicious in Courts of
Justice, I believe, when an Innocent happens to have many names."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
What, what, young
lady, in the name of Mercy, was left the poor lad to do!  The masters
against him on one hand, the men against him on the other, he only wantin
to work hard in peace, and do what he felt right.  Can a man have no soul
of his own, no mind of his own?  Must he go wrong all through wi' this
side, or must he go wrong all through wi' that, or else be hunted like a
hare?
subQuotationList:
['What,', "what, young
lady, in the name of Mercy, was left the poor lad to do!  The masters
against him on one hand, the men against him on the other, he only wantin
to work hard in peace, and do what he felt right.  Can a man have no soul
of his own, no mind of his own?  Must he go wrong all through wi' this
side, or must he go wrong all through wi' that, or else be hunted like a
hare?"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
Indeed, indeed, I pity him from my heart, and I hope
that he will clear himself.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, indeed, I pity him from my heart,', 'and I hope\nthat he will clear himself.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: You need have no fear of that, young lady.  He is sure!
subQuotationList: ['You need have no fear of that, young lady.  He is sure!']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
All the surer, I suppose, for your refusing to
tell where he is?  Eh?
subQuotationList: ['All the surer, I suppose,', 'for your refusing to\ntell where he is?  Eh?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
He shall not, through any act of mine, come back wi' the unmerited
reproach of being brought back.  He shall come back of his own accord to
clear himself, and put all those that have injured his good character,
and he not here for its defence, to shame.  I have told him what has been
done against him, and he will be here, at furthest, in two days.
subQuotationList:
["He shall not, through any act of mine, come back wi' the unmerited
reproach of being brought back.  He shall come back of his own accord to
clear himself, and put all those that have injured his good character,
and he not here for its defence, to shame.  I have told him what has been
done against him,", 'and he will be here, at furthest, in two days.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']], [['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
Notwithstanding which, if he can be laid hold of
any sooner, he shall have an earlier opportunity of clearing himself.  As
to you, I have nothing against you; what you came and told me turns out
to be true, and I have given you the means of proving it to be true, and
there's an end of it.  I wish you good night all!  I must be off to look
a little further into this.
subQuotationList:
['Notwithstanding which,', "if he can be laid hold of
any sooner, he shall have an earlier opportunity of clearing himself.  As
to you, I have nothing against you; what you came and told me turns out
to be true, and I have given you the means of proving it to be true, and
there's an end of it.  I wish you good night all!  I must be off to look
a little further into this."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Good night, father!
subQuotationList: ['Good night, father!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: Rachael, you will not distrust me one day, when you know me better.
subQuotationList: ['Rachael, you will not distrust me one day, when you know me better.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
It goes against me, to mistrust
any one; but when I am so mistrusted   when we all are   I cannot keep such
things quite out of my mind.  I ask your pardon for having done you an
injury.  I don't think what I said now.  Yet I might come to think it
again, wi' the poor lad so wronged.
subQuotationList:
['It goes against me,', "to mistrust
any one; but when I am so mistrusted   when we all are   I cannot keep such
things quite out of my mind.  I ask your pardon for having done you an
injury.  I don't think what I said now.  Yet I might come to think it
again, wi' the poor lad so wronged."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Did you tell him in your letter, that suspicion seemed
to have fallen upon him, because he had been seen about the Bank at
night?  He would then know what he would have to explain on coming back,
and would be ready.
subQuotationList:
['Did you tell him in your letter,', 'that suspicion seemed
to have fallen upon him, because he had been seen about the Bank at
night?  He would then know what he would have to explain on coming back,
and would be ready.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Yes, dear, but I can't guess what can have ever taken
him there.  He never used to go there.  It was never in his way.  His way
was the same as mine, and not near it.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, dear,', "but I can't guess what can have ever taken\nhim there.  He never used to go there.  It was never in his way.  His way\nwas the same as mine, and not near it."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: I doubt, if he can be here till next day.
subQuotationList: ['I doubt,', 'if he can be here till next day.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Then I will come next night too,
subQuotationList: ['Then I will come next night too,']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Louisa, my dear, I have never, that I know of, seen this man.  Do you
believe him to be implicated?
subQuotationList: ['Louisa, my dear, I have never, that I know of, seen this man.  Do you\nbelieve him to be implicated?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
referringExpression: Mr Gradgrind lifted up his head and said to his daughter

quoteText:
I think I have believed it, father, though with great difficulty.  I do
not believe it now.
subQuotationList: ['I think I have believed it, father, though with great difficulty.  I do\nnot believe it now.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
That is to say, you once persuaded yourself to believe it, from knowing
him to be suspected.  His appearance and manner; are they so honest?
subQuotationList: ['That is to say, you once persuaded yourself to believe it, from knowing\nhim to be suspected.  His appearance and manner; are they so honest?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: Very honest.
subQuotationList: ['Very honest.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
And her confidence not to be shaken!  I ask myself, does the real culprit know of these accusations?  Where is he?
Who is he?
subQuotationList: ['And her confidence not to be shaken!  I ask myself,', 'does the real culprit know of these accusations?  Where is he?\nWho is he?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
_Was_ the
suspected fellow the thief?  A pretty question!  If not, where was the
man, and why did he not come back?
subQuotationList: ['_Was_ the\nsuspected fellow the thief?  A pretty question!  If not, where was the\nman, and why did he not come back?']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
I misdoubt, if there is as many as twenty left in all
this place, who have any trust in the poor dear lad now.
subQuotationList: ['I misdoubt,', 'if there is as many as twenty left in all\nthis place, who have any trust in the poor dear lad now.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
If it hadn't been mercifully brought about, that I was to have you to
speak to, times are, when I think my mind would not
have kept right.  But I get hope and strength through you; and you
believe that though appearances may rise against him, he will be proved
clear?
subQuotationList:
["If it hadn't been mercifully brought about, that I was to have you to
speak to,", 'times are, when I think my mind would not
have kept right.  But I get hope and strength through you; and you
believe that though appearances may rise against him, he will be proved
clear?']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I do believe so, with my whole heart.  I feel so
certain, Rachael, that the confidence you hold in yours against all
discouragement, is not like to be wrong, that I have no more doubt of him
than if I had known him through as many years of trial as you have.
subQuotationList:
['I do believe so,', 'with my whole heart.  I feel so
certain, Rachael, that the confidence you hold in yours against all
discouragement, is not like to be wrong, that I have no more doubt of him
than if I had known him through as many years of trial as you have.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
And I, my dear, have known
him through them all, to be, according to his quiet ways, so faithful to
everything honest and good, that if he was never to be heard of more, and
I was to live to be a hundred years old, I could say with my last breath,
God knows my heart.  I have never once left trusting Stephen Blackpool!
subQuotationList:
['And I, my dear,', 'have known
him through them all, to be, according to his quiet ways, so faithful to
everything honest and good, that if he was never to be heard of more, and
I was to live to be a hundred years old, I could say with my last breath,
God knows my heart.  I have never once left trusting Stephen Blackpool!']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
We all believe, up at the Lodge, Rachael, that he will be freed from
suspicion, sooner or later.
subQuotationList: ['We all believe, up at the Lodge, Rachael, that he will be freed from\nsuspicion, sooner or later.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
The better I know it to be so believed there, my dear, and the kinder I feel it that you come away from there, purposely to
comfort me, and keep me company, and be seen wi' me when I am not yet
free from all suspicion myself, the more grieved I am that I should ever
have spoken those mistrusting words to the young lady.  And yet I
subQuotationList:
['The better I know it to be so believed there, my dear,', "and the kinder I feel it that you come away from there, purposely to
comfort me, and keep me company, and be seen wi' me when I am not yet
free from all suspicion myself, the more grieved I am that I should ever
have spoken those mistrusting words to the young lady.  And yet I"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: You don't mistrust her now, Rachael?
subQuotationList: ["You don't mistrust her now, Rachael?"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Now that you have brought us more together, no.  But I can't at all
times keep out of my mind
subQuotationList: ["Now that you have brought us more together, no.  But I can't at all\ntimes keep out of my mind"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I can't at all times keep out of my mind, mistrustings of some one.  I
can't think who 'tis, I can't think how or why it may be done, but I
mistrust that some one has put Stephen out of the way.  I mistrust that
by his coming back of his own accord, and showing himself innocent before
them all, some one would be confounded, who   to prevent that   has stopped
him, and put him out of the way.
subQuotationList:
["I can't at all times keep out of my mind, mistrustings of some one.  I
can't think who 'tis, I can't think how or why it may be done, but I
mistrust that some one has put Stephen out of the way.  I mistrust that
by his coming back of his own accord, and showing himself innocent before
them all, some one would be confounded, who   to prevent that   has stopped
him, and put him out of the way."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: That is a dreadful thought,
subQuotationList: ['That is a dreadful thought,']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: It _is_ a dreadful thought to think he may be murdered.
subQuotationList: ['It _is_ a dreadful thought to think he may be murdered.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
When it makes its way into my mind, dear, and it will
come sometimes, though I do all I can to keep it out, wi' counting on to
high numbers as I work, and saying over and over again pieces that I knew
when I were a child   I fall into such a wild, hot hurry, that, however
tired I am, I want to walk fast, miles and miles.  I must get the better
of this before bed-time.  I'll walk home wi' you.
subQuotationList:
['When it makes its way into my mind, dear,', "and it will
come sometimes, though I do all I can to keep it out, wi' counting on to
high numbers as I work, and saying over and over again pieces that I knew
when I were a child   I fall into such a wild, hot hurry, that, however
tired I am, I want to walk fast, miles and miles.  I must get the better
of this before bed-time.  I'll walk home wi' you."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
He might fall ill upon the journey back, and in such a case, there are many places on the
road where he might stop.
subQuotationList: ['He might fall ill upon the journey back,', 'and in such a case, there are many places on the\nroad where he might stop.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
But he is in none of them.  He has been sought for in all, and he's not
there.
subQuotationList: ["But he is in none of them.  He has been sought for in all, and he's not\nthere."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: True,
subQuotationList: ['True,']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
He'd walk the journey in two days.  If he was footsore and couldn't
walk, I sent him, in the letter he got, the money to ride, lest he should
have none of his own to spare.
subQuotationList: ["He'd walk the journey in two days.  If he was footsore and couldn't\nwalk, I sent him, in the letter he got, the money to ride, lest he should\nhave none of his own to spare."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
Let us hope that to-morrow will bring something better, Rachael.  Come
into the air!
subQuotationList: ['Let us hope that to-morrow will bring something better, Rachael.  Come\ninto the air!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: You're not so hurried now, Rachael, and your hand is cooler.
subQuotationList: ["You're not so hurried now, Rachael, and your hand is cooler."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
I get better, dear, if I can only walk, and breathe a little fresh.
'Times when I can't, I turn weak and confused.
subQuotationList: ["I get better, dear, if I can only walk, and breathe a little fresh.\n'Times when I can't, I turn weak and confused."]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
But you must not begin to fail, Rachael, for you may be wanted at any
time to stand by Stephen.  To-morrow is Saturday.  If no news comes
to-morrow, let us walk in the country on Sunday morning, and strengthen
you for another week.  Will you go?
subQuotationList:
['But you must not begin to fail, Rachael, for you may be wanted at any
time to stand by Stephen.  To-morrow is Saturday.  If no news comes
to-morrow, let us walk in the country on Sunday morning, and strengthen
you for another week.  Will you go?']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind']]]

quoteText: Yes, dear.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, dear.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: It's a coincidence,
subQuotationList: ["It's a coincidence,"]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: It's a Providence!  Come out, ma'am! come out, or we'll have you dragged out!
subQuotationList: ["It's a Providence!  Come out, ma'am!", "come out, or we'll have you dragged out!"]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Leave her alone, everybody!
subQuotationList: ['Leave her alone, everybody!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Let nobody touch her.  She belongs to me.  Come in, ma'am! Come in, ma'am, or
we'll have you dragged in!
subQuotationList: ["Let nobody touch her.  She belongs to me.  Come in, ma'am!", "Come in, ma'am, or\nwe'll have you dragged in!"]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Fetch Mr. Bounderby down! Rachael, young woman;
you know who this is?
subQuotationList: ['Fetch Mr. Bounderby down!', 'Rachael, young woman;\nyou know who this is?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['The Old Woman']]]

quoteText: It's Mrs. Pegler,
subQuotationList: ["It's Mrs. Pegler,"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I should think it is! Fetch Mr.
Bounderby.  Stand away, everybody!
subQuotationList: ['I should think it is!', 'Fetch Mr.\nBounderby.  Stand away, everybody!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Don't tell me, I have told you twenty
times, coming along, that I will _not_ leave you till I have handed you
over to him myself.
subQuotationList: ["Don't tell me,", 'I have told you twenty\ntimes, coming along, that I will _not_ leave you till I have handed you\nover to him myself.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Why, what's the matter now! Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am?
subQuotationList: ["Why, what's the matter now!", "Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'The Old Woman', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
Sir, I trust it is my good fortune to
produce a person you have much desired to find.  Stimulated by my wish to
relieve your mind, sir, and connecting together such imperfect clues to
the part of the country in which that person might be supposed to reside,
as have been afforded by the young woman, Rachael, fortunately now
present to identify, I have had the happiness to succeed, and to bring
that person with me   I need not say most unwillingly on her part.  It has
not been, sir, without some trouble that I have effected this; but
trouble in your service is to me a pleasure, and hunger, thirst, and cold
a real gratification.
subQuotationList:
['Sir,', 'I trust it is my good fortune to
produce a person you have much desired to find.  Stimulated by my wish to
relieve your mind, sir, and connecting together such imperfect clues to
the part of the country in which that person might be supposed to reside,

not been, sir, without some trouble that I have effected this; but
trouble in your service is to me a pleasure, and hunger, thirst, and cold
a real gratification.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'The Old Woman', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Why, what do you mean by this? I ask you, what do you mean by this, Mrs. Sparsit,
ma'am?
subQuotationList: ['Why, what do you mean by this?', "I ask you, what do you mean by this, Mrs. Sparsit,\nma'am?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'The Old Woman', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText: Sir!
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Why don't you mind your own business, ma'am? How
dare you go and poke your officious nose into my family affairs?
subQuotationList: ["Why don't you mind your own business, ma'am?", 'How\ndare you go and poke your officious nose into my family affairs?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'The Old Woman', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
My dear Josiah! My darling boy!  I am
not to blame.  It's not my fault, Josiah.  I told this lady over and over
again, that I knew she was doing what would not be agreeable to you, but
she would do it.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Josiah!', "My darling boy!  I am
not to blame.  It's not my fault, Josiah.  I told this lady over and over
again, that I knew she was doing what would not be agreeable to you, but
she would do it."]
speaker: The Old Woman
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
What did you let her bring you for?  Couldn't you knock her cap off, or
her tooth out, or scratch her, or do something or other to her?
subQuotationList: ["What did you let her bring you for?  Couldn't you knock her cap off, or\nher tooth out, or scratch her, or do something or other to her?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'The Old Woman', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Old Woman'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['The Old Woman'], ['The Old Woman'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit'], ['Mrs. Sparsit']]]

quoteText:
My own boy!  She threatened me that if I resisted her, I should be
brought by constables, and it was better to come quietly than make that
stir in such a
subQuotationList: ['My own boy!  She threatened me that if I resisted her, I should be\nbrought by constables, and it was better to come quietly than make that\nstir in such a']
speaker: The Old Woman
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
such a fine house as this.  Indeed, indeed, it is not my fault!
My dear, noble, stately boy!  I have always lived quiet, and secret,
Josiah, my dear.  I have never broken the condition once.  I have never
said I was your mother.  I have admired you at a distance; and if I have
come to town sometimes, with long times between, to take a proud peep at
you, I have done it unbeknown, my love, and gone away again.
subQuotationList:
['such a fine house as this.  Indeed, indeed, it is not my fault!
My dear, noble, stately boy!  I have always lived quiet, and secret,

speaker: The Old Woman
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
I am surprised, madam, that in your old age
you have the face to claim Mr. Bounderby for your son, after your
unnatural and inhuman treatment of him.
subQuotationList: ['I am surprised, madam,', 'that in your old age\nyou have the face to claim Mr. Bounderby for your son, after your\nunnatural and inhuman treatment of him.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'The Old Woman', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
_Me_ unnatural! _Me_ inhuman!  To my dear
boy?
subQuotationList: ['_Me_ unnatural!', '_Me_ inhuman!  To my dear\nboy?']
speaker: The Old Woman
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
Dear! Yes; dear in his self-made prosperity,
madam, I dare say.  Not very dear, however, when you deserted him in his
infancy, and left him to the brutality of a drunken grandmother.
subQuotationList: ['Dear!', 'Yes; dear in his self-made prosperity,\nmadam, I dare say.  Not very dear, however, when you deserted him in his\ninfancy, and left him to the brutality of a drunken grandmother.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'The Old Woman', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['The Old Woman'], ['The Old Woman'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
_I_ deserted my Josiah! Now,
Lord forgive you, sir, for your wicked imaginations, and for your scandal
against the memory of my poor mother, who died in my arms before Josiah
was born.  May you repent of it, sir, and live to know better!
subQuotationList:
['_I_ deserted my Josiah!', 'Now,
Lord forgive you, sir, for your wicked imaginations, and for your scandal
against the memory of my poor mother, who died in my arms before Josiah
was born.  May you repent of it, sir, and live to know better!']
speaker: The Old Woman
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
Do you deny, then, madam, that you left your son to   to be brought up in
the gutter?
subQuotationList: ['Do you deny, then, madam, that you left your son to   to be brought up in\nthe gutter?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'The Old Woman', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
referringExpression: Mr Gradgrind shocked by the possibility which dawned upon him said
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Old Woman'], ['The Old Woman'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Josiah in the gutter!
subQuotationList: ['Josiah in the gutter!']
speaker: The Old Woman
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
No such a thing, sir.
Never!  For shame on you!  My dear boy knows, and will give _you_ to
know, that though he come of humble parents, he come of parents that
loved him as dear as the best could, and never thought it hardship on
themselves to pinch a bit that he might write and cipher beautiful, and
I've his books at home to show it!  Aye, have I!
subQuotationList:
["No such a thing, sir.
Never!  For shame on you!  My dear boy knows, and will give _you_ to
know, that though he come of humble parents, he come of parents that
loved him as dear as the best could, and never thought it hardship on
themselves to pinch a bit that he might write and cipher beautiful, and
I've his books at home to show it!  Aye, have I!"]
speaker: The Old Woman
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
And my dear boy knows, and will give _you_ to know,
sir, that after his beloved father died, when he was eight years old, his
mother, too, could pinch a bit, as it was her duty and her pleasure and
her pride to do it, to help him out in life, and put him 'prentice.  And
a steady lad he was, and a kind master he had to lend him a hand, and
well he worked his own way forward to be rich and thriving.  And _I_'ll
give you to know, sir   for this my dear boy won't   that though his mother
kept but a little village shop, he never forgot her, but pensioned me on
thirty pound a year   more than I want, for I put by out of it   only making
the condition that I was to keep down in my own part, and make no boasts
about him, and not trouble him.  And I never have, except with looking at
him once a year, when he has never knowed it.  And it's right, that I _should_ keep down
in my own part, and I have no doubts that if I was here I should do a
many unbefitting things, and I am well contented, and I can keep my pride
in my Josiah to myself, and I can love for love's own sake!  And I am
ashamed of you, sir, for your slanders and
suspicions.  And I never stood here before, nor never wanted to stand
here when my dear son said no.  And I shouldn't be here now, if it hadn't
been for being brought here.  And for shame upon you, Oh, for shame, to
accuse me of being a bad mother to my son, with my son standing here to
tell you so different!
subQuotationList:
["And my dear boy knows, and will give _you_ to know,
sir, that after his beloved father died, when he was eight years old, his
mother, too, could pinch a bit, as it was her duty and her pleasure and

speaker: The Old Woman
addressees: ['Josiah Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['The Old Woman'], ['The Old Woman'], ['The Old Woman'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
I don't exactly know, how I come to be favoured
with the attendance of the present company, but I don't inquire.  When
they're quite satisfied, perhaps they'll be so good as to disperse;
whether they're satisfied or not, perhaps they'll be so good as to
disperse.  I'm not bound to deliver a lecture on my family affairs, I
have not undertaken to do it, and I'm not a going to do it.  Therefore
those who expect any explanation whatever upon that branch of the
subject, will be disappointed   particularly Tom Gradgrind, and he can't
know it too soon.  In reference to the Bank robbery, there has been a
mistake made, concerning my mother.  If there hadn't been
over-officiousness it wouldn't have been made, and I hate
over-officiousness at all times, whether or no. Good evening!
subQuotationList:
["I don't exactly know,", "how I come to be favoured
with the attendance of the present company, but I don't inquire.  When
they're quite satisfied, perhaps they'll be so good as to disperse;
whether they're satisfied or not, perhaps they'll be so good as to
disperse.  I'm not bound to deliver a lecture on my family affairs, I
have not undertaken to do it, and I'm not a going to do it.  Therefore
those who expect any explanation whatever upon that branch of the
subject, will be disappointed   particularly Tom Gradgrind, and he can't
know it too soon.  In reference to the Bank robbery, there has been a
mistake made, concerning my mother.  If there hadn't been
over-officiousness it wouldn't have been made, and I hate
over-officiousness at all times, whether or no. Good evening!"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
addressees: ['Louisa Bounderby', 'Young Thomas', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'The Old Woman', 'Thomas Gradgrind', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The Old Woman', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe', 'Thomas Gradgrind'], ['The Old Woman', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe', 'Thomas Gradgrind'], ['The Old Woman', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe', 'Thomas Gradgrind'], ['The Old Woman', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe', 'Thomas Gradgrind'], ['The Old Woman', 'Mrs. Sparsit', 'Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe', 'Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
It is
so still here, Rachael, and the way is so untrodden, that I think we must
be the first who have been here all the summer.
subQuotationList: ['It is\nso still here, Rachael, and the way is so untrodden, that I think we must\nbe the first who have been here all the summer.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
And yet
I don't know.  This has not been broken very long.  The wood is quite
fresh where it gave way.  Here are footsteps too.   O Rachael!
subQuotationList: ["And yet\nI don't know.  This has not been broken very long.  The wood is quite\nfresh where it gave way.  Here are footsteps too.   O Rachael!"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: What is the matter?
subQuotationList: ['What is the matter?']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: I don't know.  There is a hat lying in the grass.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know.  There is a hat lying in the grass."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
O the poor lad, the poor lad!  He has been made away with.  He is lying
murdered here!
subQuotationList: ['O the poor lad, the poor lad!  He has been made away with.  He is lying\nmurdered here!']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Is there   has the hat any blood upon it?
subQuotationList: ['Is there   has the hat any blood upon it?']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Rachael, I will go on a little by
myself.
subQuotationList: ['Rachael,', 'I will go on a little by\nmyself.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText: O, my good Lord!  He's down there!  Down there!
subQuotationList: ["O, my good Lord!  He's down there!  Down there!"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
Rachael, dear Rachael, good Rachael, for the love of Heaven, not these
dreadful cries!  Think of Stephen, think of Stephen, think of Stephen!
subQuotationList: ['Rachael, dear Rachael, good Rachael, for the love of Heaven, not these\ndreadful cries!  Think of Stephen, think of Stephen, think of Stephen!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
Rachael, Stephen may be living.  You wouldn't leave him lying maimed at
the bottom of this dreadful place, a moment, if you could bring help to
him?
subQuotationList: ["Rachael, Stephen may be living.  You wouldn't leave him lying maimed at\nthe bottom of this dreadful place, a moment, if you could bring help to\nhim?"]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: No, no, no!
subQuotationList: ['No, no, no!']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Don't stir from here, for his sake!  Let me go and listen.
subQuotationList: ["Don't stir from here, for his sake!  Let me go and listen."]
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
Rachael, we must lose not a moment.  We must
go in different directions, seeking aid.  You shall go by the way we have
come, and I will go forward by the path.  Tell any one you see, and every
one what has happened.  Think of Stephen, think of Stephen!
subQuotationList:
['Rachael, we must lose not a moment.  We must
go in different directions, seeking aid.  You shall go by the way we have
come, and I will go forward by the path.  Tell any one you see, and every
one what has happened.  Think of Stephen, think of Stephen!']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe'], ['Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind', 'Cecilia Jupe'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText: Lower away!
subQuotationList: ['Lower away!']
speaker: _unknowable
referringExpression: the sobered man and another got in with lights giving the word

quoteText:
But he's hurt very bad, Where's doctor?  He's hurt so very bad, sir, that we donno
how to get him up.
subQuotationList: ["But he's hurt very bad,", "Where's doctor?  He's hurt so very bad, sir, that we donno\nhow to get him up."]
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText: Rachael.
subQuotationList: ['Rachael.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Rachael, my dear.
subQuotationList: ['Rachael, my dear.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Don't let 't go.
subQuotationList: ["Don't let 't go."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Thou'rt in great pain, my own dear Stephen?
subQuotationList: ["Thou'rt in great pain, my own dear Stephen?"]
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText:
I ha' been, but not now.  I ha' been   dreadful, and dree, and long, my
dear   but 'tis ower now.  Ah, Rachael, aw a muddle!  Fro' first to last, a
muddle!
subQuotationList: ["I ha' been, but not now.  I ha' been   dreadful, and dree, and long, my\ndear   but 'tis ower now.  Ah, Rachael, aw a muddle!  Fro' first to last, a\nmuddle!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I ha' fell into th' pit, my dear, as have cost wi'in the knowledge o'
old fok now livin, hundreds and hundreds o' men's lives   fathers, sons,
brothers, dear to thousands an' thousands, an' keeping 'em fro' want and
hunger.  I ha' fell into a pit that ha' been wi' th' Firedamp crueller
than battle.  I ha' read on 't in the public petition, as onny one may
read, fro' the men that works in pits, in which they ha' pray'n and
pray'n the lawmakers for Christ's sake not to let their work be murder to
'em, but to spare 'em for th' wives and children that they loves as well
as gentlefok loves theirs.  When it were in work, it killed wi'out need;
when 'tis let alone, it kills wi'out need.  See how we die an' no need,
one way an' another   in a muddle   every day!
subQuotationList:
["I ha' fell into th' pit, my dear, as have cost wi'in the knowledge o'
old fok now livin, hundreds and hundreds o' men's lives   fathers, sons,
brothers, dear to thousands an' thousands, an' keeping 'em fro' want and
hunger.  I ha' fell into a pit that ha' been wi' th' Firedamp crueller
than battle.  I ha' read on 't in the public petition, as onny one may
read, fro' the men that works in pits, in which they ha' pray'n and
pray'n the lawmakers for Christ's sake not to let their work be murder to
'em, but to spare 'em for th' wives and children that they loves as well
as gentlefok loves theirs.  When it were in work, it killed wi'out need;
when 'tis let alone, it kills wi'out need.  See how we die an' no need,
one way an' another   in a muddle   every day!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Thy little sister, Rachael, thou hast not forgot her.  Thou'rt not like
to forget her now, and me so nigh her.  Thou know'st   poor, patient,
suff'rin, dear   how thou didst work for her, seet'n all day long in her
little chair at thy winder, and how she died, young and misshapen, awlung
o' sickly air as had'n no need to be, an' awlung o' working people's
miserable homes.  A muddle!  Aw a muddle!
subQuotationList:
["Thy little sister, Rachael, thou hast not forgot her.  Thou'rt not like
to forget her now, and me so nigh her.  Thou know'st   poor, patient,
suff'rin, dear   how thou didst work for her, seet'n all day long in her
little chair at thy winder, and how she died, young and misshapen, awlung
o' sickly air as had'n no need to be, an' awlung o' working people's
miserable homes.  A muddle!  Aw a muddle!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
If aw th' things that tooches us, my dear, was not so muddled, I
should'n ha' had'n need to coom heer.  If we was not in a muddle among
ourseln, I should'n ha' been, by my own fellow weavers and workin'
brothers, so mistook.  If Mr. Bounderby had ever know'd me right   if he'd
ever know'd me at aw   he would'n ha' took'n offence wi' me.  He would'n
ha' suspect'n me.  But look up yonder, Rachael!  Look aboove!
subQuotationList:
["If aw th' things that tooches us, my dear, was not so muddled, I
should'n ha' had'n need to coom heer.  If we was not in a muddle among
ourseln, I should'n ha' been, by my own fellow weavers and workin'
brothers, so mistook.  If Mr. Bounderby had ever know'd me right   if he'd
ever know'd me at aw   he would'n ha' took'n offence wi' me.  He would'n
ha' suspect'n me.  But look up yonder, Rachael!  Look aboove!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Rachel Gradgrind', 'Stephen Blackpool'], ['Rachel Gradgrind', 'Stephen Blackpool'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Rachel Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
It ha' shined upon me, in my pain and trouble down
below.  It ha' shined into my mind.  I ha' look'n at 't and thowt o'
thee, Rachael, till the muddle in my mind have cleared awa, above a bit,
I hope.  If soom ha' been wantin' in unnerstan'in me better, I, too, ha'
been wantin' in unnerstan'in them better.  When I got thy letter, I
easily believen that what the yoong ledy sen and done to me, and what her
brother sen and done to me, was one, and that there were a wicked plot
betwixt 'em.  When I fell, I were in anger wi' her, an' hurryin on t' be
as onjust t' her as oothers was t' me.  But in our judgments, like as in
our doins, we mun bear and forbear.  In my pain an' trouble, lookin up
yonder,   wi' it shinin on me   I ha' seen more clear, and ha' made it my
dyin prayer that aw th' world may on'y coom toogether more, an' get a
better unnerstan'in o' one another, than when I were in 't my own weak
seln.
subQuotationList:
["It ha' shined upon me,", "in my pain and trouble down
below.  It ha' shined into my mind.  I ha' look'n at 't and thowt o'
thee, Rachael, till the muddle in my mind have cleared awa, above a bit,
I hope.  If soom ha' been wantin' in unnerstan'in me better, I, too, ha'
been wantin' in unnerstan'in them better.  When I got thy letter, I
easily believen that what the yoong ledy sen and done to me, and what her
brother sen and done to me, was one, and that there were a wicked plot
betwixt 'em.  When I fell, I were in anger wi' her, an' hurryin on t' be
as onjust t' her as oothers was t' me.  But in our judgments, like as in
our doins, we mun bear and forbear.  In my pain an' trouble, lookin up
yonder,   wi' it shinin on me   I ha' seen more clear, and ha' made it my
dyin prayer that aw th' world may on'y coom toogether more, an' get a
better unnerstan'in o' one another, than when I were in 't my own weak
seln."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
You ha' heard? I ha' not
forgot you, ledy.
subQuotationList: ["You ha' heard?", "I ha' not\nforgot you, ledy."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: Yes, Stephen, I have heard you.  And your prayer is mine.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Stephen, I have heard you.  And your prayer is mine.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: You ha' a father.  Will yo tak' a message to him?
subQuotationList: ["You ha' a father.  Will yo tak' a message to him?"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: He is here, Shall I bring him to you?
subQuotationList: ['He is here,', 'Shall I bring him to you?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: If yo please.
subQuotationList: ['If yo please.']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Sir, yo will clear me an' mak my name good wi' aw men.  This I leave to
yo.
subQuotationList: ["Sir, yo will clear me an' mak my name good wi' aw men.  This I leave to\nyo."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Sir, yor son will tell yo how.  Ask him.  I mak no
charges: I leave none ahint me: not a single word.  I ha' seen an' spok'n
wi' yor son, one night.  I ask no more o' yo than that yo clear me   an' I
trust to yo to do 't.
subQuotationList:
['Sir,', "yor son will tell yo how.  Ask him.  I mak no
charges: I leave none ahint me: not a single word.  I ha' seen an' spok'n
wi' yor son, one night.  I ask no more o' yo than that yo clear me   an' I
trust to yo to do 't."]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Often as I coom to myseln, and found it shinin' on me down there in my
trouble, I thowt it were the star as guided to Our Saviour's home.  I
awmust think it be the very star!
subQuotationList: ["Often as I coom to myseln, and found it shinin' on me down there in my\ntrouble, I thowt it were the star as guided to Our Saviour's home.  I\nawmust think it be the very star!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
Rachael, beloved lass!  Don't let go my hand.  We may walk toogether
t'night, my dear!
subQuotationList: ["Rachael, beloved lass!  Don't let go my hand.  We may walk toogether\nt'night, my dear!"]
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText: I will hold thy hand, and keep beside thee, Stephen, all the way.
subQuotationList: ['I will hold thy hand, and keep beside thee, Stephen, all the way.']
speaker: Rachel Gradgrind

quoteText: Bless thee!  Will soombody be pleased to coover my face!
subQuotationList: ['Bless thee!  Will soombody be pleased to coover my face!']
speaker: Stephen Blackpool

quoteText:
I believe, father, he will not come back to town
to-night.
subQuotationList: ['I believe, father,', 'he will not come back to town\nto-night.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Not now, my dears; in the evening. I am not able yet   to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['Not now, my dears; in the evening.', 'I am not able yet   to-morrow.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Dear father, you have
three young children left.  They will be different, I will be different
yet, with Heaven's help.
subQuotationList: ['Dear father,', "you have\nthree young children left.  They will be different, I will be different\nyet, with Heaven's help."]
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind']], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Cecilia Jupe', 'Louisa Bounderby', 'Jane'], ['Cecilia Jupe', 'Louisa Bounderby', 'Jane']]]

quoteText:
Your wretched brother, Do you think he had
planned this robbery, when he went with you to the lodging?
subQuotationList: ['Your wretched brother,', 'Do you think he had\nplanned this robbery, when he went with you to the lodging?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I fear so, father.  I know he had wanted money very much, and had spent
a great deal.
subQuotationList: ['I fear so, father.  I know he had wanted money very much, and had spent\na great deal.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
The poor man being about to leave the town, it came into his evil brain
to cast suspicion on him?
subQuotationList: ['The poor man being about to leave the town, it came into his evil brain\nto cast suspicion on him?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I think it must have flashed upon him while he sat there, father.  For I
asked him to go there with me.  The visit did not originate with him.
subQuotationList: ['I think it must have flashed upon him while he sat there, father.  For I\nasked him to go there with me.  The visit did not originate with him.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: He had some conversation with the poor man.  Did he take him aside?
subQuotationList: ['He had some conversation with the poor man.  Did he take him aside?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
He took him out of the room.  I asked him afterwards, why he had done
so, and he made a plausible excuse; but since last night, father, and
when I remember the circumstances by its light, I am afraid I can imagine
too truly what passed between them.
subQuotationList:
['He took him out of the room.  I asked him afterwards, why he had done
so, and he made a plausible excuse; but since last night, father, and
when I remember the circumstances by its light, I am afraid I can imagine
too truly what passed between them.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Young Thomas', 'Stephen Blackpool']]]

quoteText:
Let me know, if your thoughts present your guilty
brother in the same dark view as mine.
subQuotationList: ['Let me know,', 'if your thoughts present your guilty\nbrother in the same dark view as mine.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I fear, father, that he must have made some
representation to Stephen Blackpool   perhaps in my name, perhaps in his
own   which induced him to do in good faith and honesty, what he had never
done before, and to wait about the Bank those two or three nights before
he left the town.
subQuotationList:
['I fear, father,', 'that he must have made some
representation to Stephen Blackpool   perhaps in my name, perhaps in his
own   which induced him to do in good faith and honesty, what he had never
done before, and to wait about the Bank those two or three nights before
he left the town.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText: Too plain! Too plain!
subQuotationList: ['Too plain!', 'Too plain!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
And now, how is he to be found?  How is he to be saved from justice?  In
the few hours that I can possibly allow to elapse before I publish the
truth, how is he to be found by us, and only by us?  Ten thousand pounds
could not effect it.
subQuotationList:
['And now, how is he to be found?  How is he to be saved from justice?  In
the few hours that I can possibly allow to elapse before I publish the
truth, how is he to be found by us, and only by us?  Ten thousand pounds
could not effect it.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Stephen Blackpool'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Sissy has effected it, father.
subQuotationList: ['Sissy has effected it, father.']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
It is
always you, my child!
subQuotationList: ['It is\nalways you, my child!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
referringExpression: He raised his eyes to where she stood like a good fairy in his house and said

quoteText:
We had our fears, before
yesterday; and when I saw you brought to the side of the litter last
night, and heard what passed (being close to Rachael all the time), I
went to him when no one saw, and said to him, He
was in a tremble before I whispered to him, and he started and trembled
more then, and said, I thought of father's old circus.  I have
not forgotten where Mr. Sleary goes at this time of year, and I read of
him in a paper only the other day.  I told him to hurry there, and tell
his name, and ask Mr. Sleary to hide him till I came. he said.  And I saw him shrink away among the
people.
subQuotationList:
['We had our fears,', 'before
yesterday; and when I saw you brought to the side of the litter last
night, and heard what passed (being close to Rachael all the time), I
went to him when no one saw, and said to him,', 'He
was in a tremble before I whispered to him, and he started and trembled
more then, and said,', "I thought of father's old circus.  I have
not forgotten where Mr. Sleary goes at this time of year, and I read of
him in a paper only the other day.  I told him to hurry there, and tell
his name, and ask Mr. Sleary to hide him till I came.", 'he said.  And I saw him shrink away among the
people.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe', 'Louisa Bounderby'], ['Cecilia Jupe', 'Louisa Bounderby']], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Rachel Gradgrind'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']], [['Mr. Sleary'], ['Mr. Sleary']], [['Mr. Sleary']]]

quoteText: Thank Heaven! He may be got abroad yet.
subQuotationList: ['Thank Heaven!', 'He may be got abroad yet.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
If you do it again, I'll throw the horse at
you!
subQuotationList: ["If you do it again, I'll throw the horse at\nyou!"]
speaker: The Clown

quoteText: Now _I_'ll have a turn!
subQuotationList: ["Now _I_'ll have a turn!"]
speaker: The Clown
referringExpression: the Clown left alone in the ring had just warmed himself and said

quoteText:
Thethilia, it doth me good to thee you.  You wath alwayth
a favourite with uth, and you've done uth credith thinth the old timeth
I'm thure.  You mutht thee our people, my dear, afore we thpeak of
bithnith, or they'll break their hearth   ethpethially the women.  Here'th
Jothphine hath been and got married to E. W. B. Childerth, and thee hath
got a boy, and though he'th only three yearth old, he thtickth on to any
pony you can bring againtht him.  He'th named The Little Wonder of
Thcolathtic Equitation; and if you don't hear of that boy at Athley'th,
you'll hear of him at Parith.  And you recollect Kidderminthter, that
wath thought to be rather thweet upon yourthelf?  Well.  He'th married
too.  Married a widder.  Old enough to be hith mother.  Thee wath
Tightrope, thee wath, and now thee'th nothing   on accounth of fat.
They've got two children, tho we're thtrong in the Fairy bithnith and the
Nurthery dodge.  If you wath to thee our Children in the Wood, with their
father and mother both a dyin' on a horthe   their uncle a retheiving of
'em ath hith wardth, upon a horthe   themthelvth both a goin' a
black-berryin' on a horthe   and the Robinth a coming in to cover 'em with
leavth, upon a horthe   you'd thay it wath the completetht thing ath ever
you thet your eyeth on!  And you remember Emma Gordon, my dear, ath wath
a'motht a mother to you?  Of courthe you do; I needn't athk.  Well!
Emma, thee lotht her huthband.  He wath throw'd a heavy back-fall off a
Elephant in a thort of a Pagoda thing ath the Thultan of the Indieth, and
he never got the better of it; and thee married a thecond time   married a
Cheethemonger ath fell in love with her from the front   and he'th a
Overtheer and makin' a fortun.
subQuotationList:
['Thethilia,', "it doth me good to thee you.  You wath alwayth
a favourite with uth, and you've done uth credith thinth the old timeth
I'm thure.  You mutht thee our people, my dear, afore we thpeak of

you thet your eyeth on!  And you remember Emma Gordon, my dear, ath wath
a'motht a mother to you?  Of courthe you do; I needn't athk.  Well!
Emma, thee lotht her huthband.  He wath throw'd a heavy back-fall off a
Elephant in a thort of a Pagoda thing ath the Thultan of the Indieth, and
he never got the better of it; and thee married a thecond time   married a
Cheethemonger ath fell in love with her from the front   and he'th a
Overtheer and makin' a fortun."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText:
There!  Now Thethilia hath kithd all the children, and hugged all the
women, and thaken handth all round with all the men, clear, every one of
you, and ring in the band for the thecond part!
subQuotationList: ['There!  Now Thethilia hath kithd all the children, and hugged all the\nwomen, and thaken handth all round with all the men, clear, every one of\nyou, and ring in the band for the thecond part!']
speaker: Mr. Sleary
addressees: ['Louisa Bounderby', 'Josephine Sleary', 'Mr. E. W. B. Childers', 'Cecilia Jupe']

quoteText:
Now, Thethilia,
I don't athk to know any thecreth, but I thuppothe I may conthider thith
to be Mith Thquire.
subQuotationList: ["Now, Thethilia,\nI don't athk to know any thecreth, but I thuppothe I may conthider thith\nto be Mith Thquire."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: This is his sister.  Yes.
subQuotationList: ['This is his sister.  Yes.']
speaker: Cecilia Jupe

quoteText:
And t'other on'th daughter.  That'h what I mean.  Hope I thee you well,
mith.  And I hope the Thquire'th well?
subQuotationList: ["And t'other on'th daughter.  That'h what I mean.  Hope I thee you well,\nmith.  And I hope the Thquire'th well?"]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: My father will be here soon, Is my brother safe?
subQuotationList: ['My father will be here soon,', 'Is my brother safe?']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
Thafe and thound! I want you jutht to take a peep at the
Ring, mith, through here.  Thethilia, you know the dodgeth; find a
thpy-hole for yourthelf.
subQuotationList: ['Thafe and thound!', 'I want you jutht to take a peep at the\nRing, mith, through here.  Thethilia, you know the dodgeth; find a\nthpy-hole for yourthelf.']

Mr. Sleary
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Louisa Bounderby', 'Cecilia Jupe'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Louisa Bounderby', 'Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText: Yes,
speaker: _group

quoteText:
Look at 'em again, look at 'em well.  You thee em all?
Very good.  Now, mith; I have my
opinionth, and the Thquire your father hath hith.  I don't want to know
what your brother'th been up to; ith better for me not to know.  All I
thay ith, the Thquire hath thtood by Thethilia, and I'll thtand by the
Thquire.  Your brother ith one them black thervanth. Ith a fact, and even knowin' it, you couldn't put your
finger on him.  Let the Thquire come.  I thall keep your brother here
after the performanth.  I thant undreth him, nor yet wath hith paint off.
Let the Thquire come here after the performanth, or come here yourthelf
after the performanth, and you thall find your brother, and have the
whole plathe to talk to him in.  Never mind the lookth of him, ath long
ath he'th well hid.
subQuotationList:

quoteText:
Your thervant, Thquire, If you want me you'll find me here.  You muthn't mind your thon having a
comic livery on.
subQuotationList: ['Your thervant, Thquire,', "If you want me you'll find me here.  You muthn't mind your thon having a\ncomic livery on."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: How was this done?
subQuotationList: ['How was this done?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: How was what done?
subQuotationList: ['How was what done?']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: This robbery,
subQuotationList: ['This robbery,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I forced the safe myself over night, and shut it up ajar before I went
away.  I had had the key that was found, made long before.  I dropped it
that morning, that it might be supposed to have been used.  I didn't take
the money all at once.  I pretended to put my balance away every night,
but I didn't.  Now you know all about it.
subQuotationList:
["I forced the safe myself over night, and shut it up ajar before I went
away.  I had had the key that was found, made long before.  I dropped it
that morning, that it might be supposed to have been used.  I didn't take
the money all at once.  I pretended to put my balance away every night,
but I didn't.  Now you know all about it."]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
If a thunderbolt had fallen on me, it would have
shocked me less than this!
subQuotationList: ['If a thunderbolt had fallen on me,', 'it would have\nshocked me less than this!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I don't see why, So many people are employed in
situations of trust; so many people, out of so many, will be dishonest.
I have heard you talk, a hundred times, of its being a law.  How can _I_
help laws?  You have comforted others with such things, father.  Comfort
yourself!
subQuotationList:
["I don't see why,", 'So many people are employed in
situations of trust; so many people, out of so many, will be dishonest.
I have heard you talk, a hundred times, of its being a law.  How can _I_
help laws?  You have comforted others with such things, father.  Comfort
yourself!']
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: You must be got to Liverpool, and sent abroad.
subQuotationList: ['You must be got to Liverpool, and sent abroad.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I suppose I must.  I can't be more miserable anywhere, than I have been here, ever since I can remember.  That's one
thing.
subQuotationList: ["I suppose I must.  I can't be more miserable anywhere,", "than I have been here, ever since I can remember.  That's one\nthing."]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText:
Why, I've been thinking of it, Thquire.  There'th not muth time to
lothe, tho you muth thay yeth or no.  Ith over twenty mileth to the rail.
There'th a coath in half an hour, that goeth _to_ the rail, 'purpothe to
cath the mail train.  That train will take him right to Liverpool.
subQuotationList:
["Why, I've been thinking of it, Thquire.  There'th not muth time to
lothe, tho you muth thay yeth or no.  Ith over twenty mileth to the rail.
There'th a coath in half an hour, that goeth _to_ the rail, 'purpothe to
cath the mail train.  That train will take him right to Liverpool."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: But look at him, Will any coach
subQuotationList: ['But look at him,', 'Will any coach']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I don't mean that he thould go in the comic livery, Thay
the word, and I'll make a Jothkin of him, out of the wardrobe, in five
minutes.
subQuotationList: ["I don't mean that he thould go in the comic livery,", "Thay\nthe word, and I'll make a Jothkin of him, out of the wardrobe, in five\nminutes."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: I don't understand,
subQuotationList: ["I don't understand,"]
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
A Jothkin   a Carter.  Make up your mind quick, Thquire.  There'll be beer
to feth.  I've never met with nothing but beer ath'll ever clean a comic
blackamoor.
subQuotationList: ["A Jothkin   a Carter.  Make up your mind quick, Thquire.  There'll be beer\nto feth.  I've never met with nothing but beer ath'll ever clean a comic\nblackamoor."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText:
Now, come along to the coath, and jump up behind; I'll go
with you there, and they'll thuppothe you one of my people.  Thay
farewell to your family, and tharp'th the word.
subQuotationList: ['Now,', "come along to the coath, and jump up behind; I'll go\nwith you there, and they'll thuppothe you one of my people.  Thay\nfarewell to your family, and tharp'th the word."]
