quoteText:
Here is your letter, All necessary means will be
provided for you.  Atone, by repentance and better conduct, for the
shocking action you have committed, and the dreadful consequences to
which it has led.  Give me your hand, my poor boy, and may God forgive
you as I do!
subQuotationList:
['Here is your letter,', 'All necessary means will be
provided for you.  Atone, by repentance and better conduct, for the
shocking action you have committed, and the dreadful consequences to
which it has led.  Give me your hand, my poor boy, and may God forgive
you as I do!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Young Thomas']], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText: Not you.  I don't want to have anything to say to you!
subQuotationList: ["Not you.  I don't want to have anything to say to you!"]
speaker: Young Thomas

quoteText: O Tom, Tom, do we end so, after all my love!
subQuotationList: ['O Tom, Tom, do we end so, after all my love!']
speaker: Louisa Bounderby

quoteText:
After all your love! Pretty love!  Leaving
old Bounderby to himself, and packing my best friend Mr. Harthouse off,
and going home just when I was in the greatest danger.  Pretty love that!
Coming out with every word about our having gone to that place, when you
saw the net was gathering round me.  Pretty love that!  You have
regularly given me up.  You never cared for me.
subQuotationList:
['After all your love!', 'Pretty love!  Leaving
old Bounderby to himself, and packing my best friend Mr. Harthouse off,
and going home just when I was in the greatest danger.  Pretty love that!
Coming out with every word about our having gone to that place, when you
saw the net was gathering round me.  Pretty love that!  You have
regularly given me up.  You never cared for me.']
speaker: Young Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Louisa Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Mr. James Harthouse'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Louisa Bounderby']]]

quoteText: Tharp'th the word!
subQuotationList: ["Tharp'th the word!"]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText:
I'm sorry to interfere with your plans, but I can't allow myself to be done by horse-riders.  I must have young
Mr. Tom; he mustn't be got away by horse-riders; here he is in a smock
frock, and I must have him!
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry to interfere with your plans,", "but I can't allow myself to be done by horse-riders.  I must have young\nMr. Tom; he mustn't be got away by horse-riders; here he is in a smock\nfrock, and I must have him!"]
speaker: Bitzer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind', 'Mr. Sleary', 'Louisa Bounderby', 'Cecilia Jupe', 'Young Thomas']], [['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas']]]

quoteText: Bitzer, have you a heart?
subQuotationList: ['Bitzer,', 'have you a heart?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
The circulation, sir, couldn't be carried on without one.  No man, sir, acquainted
with the facts established by Harvey relating to the circulation of the
blood, can doubt that I have a heart.
subQuotationList: ['The circulation, sir,', "couldn't be carried on without one.  No man, sir, acquainted\nwith the facts established by Harvey relating to the circulation of the\nblood, can doubt that I have a heart."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Is it accessible, to any compassionate
influence?
subQuotationList: ['Is it accessible,', 'to any compassionate\ninfluence?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText: It is accessible to Reason, sir, And to nothing else.
subQuotationList: ['It is accessible to Reason, sir,', 'And to nothing else.']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
What motive   even what motive in reason   can you have for preventing the
escape of this wretched youth, and crushing his
miserable father?  See his sister here.  Pity us!
subQuotationList: ['What motive   even what motive in reason   can you have for preventing the\nescape of this wretched youth,', 'and crushing his\nmiserable father?  See his sister here.  Pity us!']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Sir, since you ask me what motive I have in reason, for taking young Mr. Tom
back to Coketown, it is only reasonable to let you know.  I have
suspected young Mr. Tom of this bank-robbery from the first.  I had had
my eye upon him before that time, for I knew his ways.  I have kept my
observations to myself, but I have made them; and I have got ample proofs
against him now, besides his running away, and besides his own
confession, which I was just in time to overhear.  I had the pleasure of
watching your house yesterday morning, and following you here.  I am
going to take young Mr. Tom back to Coketown, in order to deliver him
over to Mr. Bounderby.  Sir, I have no doubt whatever that Mr. Bounderby
will then promote me to young Mr. Tom's situation.  And I wish to have
his situation, sir, for it will be a rise to me, and will do me good.
subQuotationList:
['Sir,', "since you ask me what motive I have in reason, for taking young Mr. Tom
back to Coketown, it is only reasonable to let you know.  I have
suspected young Mr. Tom of this bank-robbery from the first.  I had had
my eye upon him before that time, for I knew his ways.  I have kept my
observations to myself, but I have made them; and I have got ample proofs
against him now, besides his running away, and besides his own
confession, which I was just in time to overhear.  I had the pleasure of
watching your house yesterday morning, and following you here.  I am
going to take young Mr. Tom back to Coketown, in order to deliver him
over to Mr. Bounderby.  Sir, I have no doubt whatever that Mr. Bounderby
will then promote me to young Mr. Tom's situation.  And I wish to have
his situation, sir, for it will be a rise to me, and will do me good."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText: If this is solely a question of self-interest with you
subQuotationList: ['If this is solely a question of self-interest with you']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I beg your pardon for interrupting you, sir, but I am
sure you know that the whole social system is a question of
self-interest.  What you must always appeal to, is a person's
self-interest.  It's your only hold.  We are so constituted.  I was
brought up in that catechism when I was very young, sir, as you are
aware.
subQuotationList:
['I beg your pardon for interrupting you, sir,', "but I am
sure you know that the whole social system is a question of
self-interest.  What you must always appeal to, is a person's
self-interest.  It's your only hold.  We are so constituted.  I was
brought up in that catechism when I was very young, sir, as you are
aware."]
speaker: Bitzer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']], [['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
What sum of money, will you set against your
expected promotion?
subQuotationList: ['What sum of money,', 'will you set against your\nexpected promotion?']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Thank you, sir, for hinting at the proposal; but I
will not set any sum against it.  Knowing that your clear head would
propose that alternative, I have gone over the calculations in my mind;
and I find that to compound a felony, even on very high terms indeed,
would not be as safe and good for me as my improved prospects in the
Bank.
subQuotationList:
['Thank you, sir,', 'for hinting at the proposal; but I
will not set any sum against it.  Knowing that your clear head would
propose that alternative, I have gone over the calculations in my mind;
and I find that to compound a felony, even on very high terms indeed,
would not be as safe and good for me as my improved prospects in the
Bank.']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Bitzer, Bitzer, I have but one chance left
to soften you.  You were many years at my school.  If, in remembrance of
the pains bestowed upon you there, you can persuade yourself in any
degree to disregard your present interest and release my son, I entreat
and pray you to give him the benefit of that remembrance.
subQuotationList:
['Bitzer,', 'Bitzer, I have but one chance left
to soften you.  You were many years at my school.  If, in remembrance of
the pains bestowed upon you there, you can persuade yourself in any
degree to disregard your present interest and release my son, I entreat
and pray you to give him the benefit of that remembrance.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I really wonder, sir, to find you taking a position so untenable.  My schooling was
paid for; it was a bargain; and when I came away, the bargain ended.
subQuotationList: ['I really wonder, sir,', 'to find you taking a position so untenable.  My schooling was\npaid for; it was a bargain; and when I came away, the bargain ended.']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
I don't deny, that my schooling was cheap.  But that
comes right, sir.  I was made in the cheapest market, and have to dispose
of myself in the dearest.
subQuotationList: ["I don't deny,", 'that my schooling was cheap.  But that\ncomes right, sir.  I was made in the cheapest market, and have to dispose\nof myself in the dearest.']
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Pray don't do that, it's of no use doing that: it only
worries.  You seem to think that I have some animosity against young Mr.
Tom; whereas I have none at all.  I am only going, on the reasonable
grounds I have mentioned, to take him back to Coketown.  If he was to
resist, I should set up the cry of Stop thief!  But, he won't resist, you
may depend upon it.
subQuotationList:
["Pray don't do that,", "it's of no use doing that: it only
worries.  You seem to think that I have some animosity against young Mr.
Tom; whereas I have none at all.  I am only going, on the reasonable
grounds I have mentioned, to take him back to Coketown.  If he was to
resist, I should set up the cry of Stop thief!  But, he won't resist, you
may depend upon it."]
speaker: Bitzer

quoteText:
Thquire, you know perfectly well, and your daughter knowth perfectly
well (better than you, becauthe I thed it to her), that I didn't know
what your thon had done, and that I didn't want to know   I thed it wath
better not, though I only thought, then, it wath thome thkylarking.
However, thith young man having made it known to be a robbery of a bank,
why, that'h a theriouth thing; muth too theriouth a thing for me to
compound, ath thith young man hath very properly called it.
Conthequently, Thquire, you muthn't quarrel with me if I take thith young
man'th thide, and thay he'th right and there'th no help for it.  But I
tell you what I'll do, Thquire; I'll drive your thon and thith young man
over to the rail, and prevent expothure here.  I can't conthent to do
more, but I'll do that.
subQuotationList:
["Thquire, you know perfectly well, and your daughter knowth perfectly

speaker: Mr. Sleary
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Young Thomas'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
The Thquire thtood by you, Thethilia, and I'll thtand by the Thquire.
More than that: thith ith a prethiouth rathcal, and belongth to that
bluthtering Cove that my people nearly pitht out o' winder.  It'll be a
dark night; I've got a horthe that'll do anything but thpeak; I've got a
pony that'll go fifteen mile an hour with Childerth driving of him; I've
got a dog that'll keep a man to one plathe four-and-twenty hourth.  Get a
word with the young Thquire.  Tell him, when he theeth our horthe begin
to danthe, not to be afraid of being thpilt, but to look out for a
pony-gig coming up.  Tell him, when he theeth that gig clothe by, to jump
down, and it'll take him off at a rattling pathe.  If my dog leth thith
young man thtir a peg on foot, I give him leave to go.  And if my horthe
ever thtirth from that thpot where he beginth a danthing, till the
morning   I don't know him?   Tharp'th the word!
subQuotationList:
["The Thquire thtood by you, Thethilia, and I'll thtand by the Thquire.
More than that: thith ith a prethiouth rathcal, and belongth to that

speaker: Mr. Sleary
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Mr. E. W. B. quoteText:
All right, Thquire! your thon may be aboard-a-thip by
thith time.  Childerth took him off, an hour and a half after we left
there latht night.  The horthe danthed the polka till he wath dead beat
(he would have walthed if he hadn't been in harneth), and then I gave him
the word and he went to thleep comfortable.  When that prethiouth young
Rathcal thed he'd go for'ard afoot, the dog hung on to hith
neck-hankercher with all four legth in the air and pulled him down and
rolled him over.  Tho he come back into the drag, and there he that,
'till I turned the horthe'th head, at half-patht thixth thith morning.
subQuotationList:
['All right, Thquire!', "your thon may be aboard-a-thip by
thith time.  Childerth took him off, an hour and a half after we left
there latht night.  The horthe danthed the polka till he wath dead beat
(he would have walthed if he hadn't been in harneth), and then I gave him
the word and he went to thleep comfortable.  When that prethiouth young
Rathcal thed he'd go for'ard afoot, the dog hung on to hith
neck-hankercher with all four legth in the air and pulled him down and
rolled him over.  Tho he come back into the drag, and there he that,
'till I turned the horthe'th head, at half-patht thixth thith morning."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers']]]

quoteText:
I don't want money mythelf, Thquire; but Childerth ith a family man, and
if you wath to like to offer him a five-pound note, it mightn't be
unactheptable.  Likewithe if you wath to thtand a collar for the dog, or
a thet of bellth for the horthe, I thould be very glad to take 'em.
Brandy and water I alwayth take.
subQuotationList:
["I don't want money mythelf, Thquire; but Childerth ith a family man, and
if you wath to like to offer him a five-pound note, it mightn't be
unactheptable.  Likewithe if you wath to thtand a collar for the dog, or
a thet of bellth for the horthe, I thould be very glad to take 'em.
Brandy and water I alwayth take."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Thomas Gradgrind'], ['Mr. E. W. B. Childers'], ['Thomas Gradgrind']]]

quoteText:
If you wouldn't think it going too far,
Thquire, to make a little thpread for the company at about three and
thixth ahead, not reckoning Luth, it would make 'em happy.
subQuotationList: ["If you wouldn't think it going too far,\nThquire, to make a little thpread for the company at about three and\nthixth ahead, not reckoning Luth, it would make 'em happy."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText:
Very well, Thquire; then, if you'll only give a Horthe-riding, a
bethpeak, whenever you can, you'll more than balanthe the account.  Now,
Thquire, if your daughter will ethcuthe me, I thould like one parting
word with you.
subQuotationList:
["Very well, Thquire; then, if you'll only give a Horthe-riding, a
bethpeak, whenever you can, you'll more than balanthe the account.  Now,
Thquire, if your daughter will ethcuthe me, I thould like one parting
word with you."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: Thquire,   you don't need to be told that dogth ith wonderful animalth.
subQuotationList: ["Thquire,   you don't need to be told that dogth ith wonderful animalth."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: Their instinct, is surprising.
subQuotationList: ['Their instinct,', 'is surprising.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
Whatever you call it   and I'm bletht if _I_ know what to call it it ith athtonithing.  The way in whith a dog'll find you   the
dithtanthe he'll come!
subQuotationList: ["Whatever you call it   and I'm bletht if _I_ know what to call it", "it ith athtonithing.  The way in whith a dog'll find you   the\ndithtanthe he'll come!"]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: His scent, being so fine.
subQuotationList: ['His scent,', 'being so fine.']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind

quoteText:
I'm bletht if I know what to call it, but I have had dogth find me, Thquire, in a way that made me think
whether that dog hadn't gone to another dog, and thed, And whether that
dog mightn't have thed, And
whether that dog mightn't have thought it over, and thed, In conthequenth of my
being afore the public, and going about tho muth, you thee, there mutht
be a number of dogth acquainted with me, Thquire, that _I_ don't know!
subQuotationList:
["I'm bletht if I know what to call it,", "but I have had dogth find me, Thquire, in a way that made me think
whether that dog hadn't gone to another dog, and thed,", "And whether that
dog mightn't have thed,", "And
whether that dog mightn't have thought it over, and thed,", "In conthequenth of my
being afore the public, and going about tho muth, you thee, there mutht
be a number of dogth acquainted with me, Thquire, that _I_ don't know!"]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText:
Any way, ith fourteen month ago, Thquire, thinthe we wath at Chethter.  We wath
getting up our Children in the Wood one morning, when there cometh into
our Ring, by the thtage door, a dog.  He had travelled a long way, he
wath in a very bad condithon, he wath lame, and pretty well blind.  He
went round to our children, one after another, as if he wath a theeking
for a child he know'd; and then he come to me, and throwd hithelf up
behind, and thtood on hith two forelegth, weak ath he wath, and then he
wagged hith tail and died.  Thquire, that dog wath Merrylegth.
subQuotationList:
['Any way,', "ith fourteen month ago, Thquire, thinthe we wath at Chethter.  We wath
getting up our Children in the Wood one morning, when there cometh into
our Ring, by the thtage door, a dog.  He had travelled a long way, he
wath in a very bad condithon, he wath lame, and pretty well blind.  He
went round to our children, one after another, as if he wath a theeking
for a child he know'd; and then he come to me, and throwd hithelf up
behind, and thtood on hith two forelegth, weak ath he wath, and then he
wagged hith tail and died.  Thquire, that dog wath Merrylegth."]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: Sissy's father's dog!
subQuotationList: ["Sissy's father's dog!"]
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText:
Thethilia'th father'th old dog.  Now, Thquire, I can take my oath, from
my knowledge of that dog, that that man wath dead   and buried   afore that
dog come back to me.  Joth'phine and Childerth and me talked it over a
long time, whether I thould write or not.  But we agreed,
subQuotationList:
["Thethilia'th father'th old dog.  Now, Thquire, I can take my oath, from
my knowledge of that dog, that that man wath dead   and buried   afore that
dog come back to me.  Joth'phine and Childerth and me talked it over a
long time, whether I thould write or not.  But we agreed,"]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText:
Tho, whether her father bathely detherted her; or whether he
broke hith own heart alone, rather than pull her down along with him;
never will be known, now, Thquire, till   no, not till we know how the
dogth findth uth out!
subQuotationList:
['Tho, whether her father bathely detherted her; or whether he
broke hith own heart alone, rather than pull her down along with him;
never will be known, now, Thquire, till   no, not till we know how the

mentionEntitiesList: [[['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Mr. Sleary', 'Signor Jupe']]]

quoteText:
She keeps the bottle that he sent her for, to this hour; and she will
believe in his affection to the last moment of her life,
subQuotationList: ['She keeps the bottle that he sent her for, to this hour; and she will\nbelieve in his affection to the last moment of her life,']
speaker: Thomas Gradgrind
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Signor Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText:
It theemth to prethent two thingth to a perthon, don't it, Thquire? one, that there ith a love in the world, not all
Thelf-interetht after all, but thomething very different; t'other, that
it hath a way of ith own of calculating or not calculating, whith
thomehow or another ith at leatht ath hard to give a name to, ath the
wayth of the dogth ith!
subQuotationList:
["It theemth to prethent two thingth to a perthon, don't it, Thquire?", "one, that there ith a love in the world, not all
Thelf-interetht after all, but thomething very different; t'other, that
it hath a way of ith own of calculating or not calculating, whith
thomehow or another ith at leatht ath hard to give a name to, ath the
wayth of the dogth ith!"]
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText:
Thethilia my dear, kith me and good-bye!  Mith Thquire, to thee you
treating of her like a thithter, and a thithter that you trutht and
honour with all your heart and more, ith a very pretty thight to me.  I
hope your brother may live to be better detherving of you, and a greater
comfort to you.  Thquire, thake handth, firtht and latht!  Don't be croth
with uth poor vagabondth.  People mutht be amuthed.  They can't be
alwayth a learning, nor yet they can't be alwayth a working, they an't
made for it.  You _mutht_ have uth, Thquire.  Do the withe thing and the
kind thing too, and make the betht of uth; not the wurtht!
subQuotationList:
["Thethilia my dear, kith me and good-bye!  Mith Thquire, to thee you
treating of her like a thithter, and a thithter that you trutht and
honour with all your heart and more, ith a very pretty thight to me.  I
hope your brother may live to be better detherving of you, and a greater
comfort to you.  Thquire, thake handth, firtht and latht!  Don't be croth
with uth poor vagabondth.  People mutht be amuthed.  They can't be
alwayth a learning, nor yet they can't be alwayth a working, they an't
made for it.  You _mutht_ have uth, Thquire.  Do the withe thing and the
kind thing too, and make the betht of uth; not the wurtht!"]
speaker: Mr. Sleary
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Louisa Bounderby'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe'], ['Cecilia Jupe']]]

quoteText: And I never thought before, that I wath tho muth of a Cackler!
subQuotationList: ['And I never thought before,', 'that I wath tho muth of a Cackler!']
speaker: Mr. Sleary

quoteText: What's the matter now, ma'am?
subQuotationList: ["What's the matter now, ma'am?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Pray, sir, do not bite my nose off.
subQuotationList: ['Pray, sir,', 'do not bite my nose off.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Bite your nose off, ma'am? _Your_ nose!
subQuotationList: ["Bite your nose off, ma'am?", '_Your_ nose!']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Mr. Bounderby,
sir!
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bounderby,\nsir!']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
referringExpression: Mrs Sparsit took her foot out of her stirrup and said

quoteText: Well, ma'am? What are you staring at?
subQuotationList: ["Well, ma'am?", 'What are you staring at?']
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
May I ask, sir, have you been ruffled this
morning?
subQuotationList: ['May I ask, sir,', 'have you been ruffled this\nmorning?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Yes, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, ma'am."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
May I inquire, sir, whether _I_ am the
unfortunate cause of your having lost your temper?
subQuotationList: ['May I inquire, sir,', 'whether _I_ am the\nunfortunate cause of your having lost your temper?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText:
Now, I'll tell you what, ma'am, I am not come here to
be bullied.  A female may be highly connected, but she can't be permitted
to bother and badger a man in my position, and I am not going to put up
with it.
subQuotationList:
["Now, I'll tell you what, ma'am,", "I am not come here to
be bullied.  A female may be highly connected, but she can't be permitted
to bother and badger a man in my position, and I am not going to put up
with it."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
It is apparent to me that I am in your
way at present.  I will retire to my own apartment. Sir,
subQuotationList: ['It is apparent to me that I am in your\nway at present.  I will retire to my own apartment.', 'Sir,']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Allow me to open the door, ma'am.
subQuotationList: ["Allow me to open the door, ma'am."]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Thank you, sir; I can do it for myself.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, sir; I can do it for myself.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: You had better allow me, ma'am,
subQuotationList: ["You had better allow me, ma'am,"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText: Really, sir?
subQuotationList: ['Really, sir?']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
referringExpression: Mrs Sparsit gave him a look of the darkest scorn and said

quoteText:
I have been thinking it over, you see, since the late affairs have
happened, ma'am,
subQuotationList: ["I have been thinking it over, you see, since the late affairs have\nhappened, ma'am,"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
Oh!  Pray, sir, don't disparage your judgment.  Everybody knows how unerring Mr.
Bounderby's judgment is.  Everybody has had proofs of it.  It must be the
theme of general conversation.  Disparage anything in yourself but your
judgment, sir,
subQuotationList:
['Oh!  Pray, sir,', "don't disparage your judgment.  Everybody knows how unerring Mr.
Bounderby's judgment is.  Everybody has had proofs of it.  It must be the
theme of general conversation.  Disparage anything in yourself but your
judgment, sir,"]
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Josiah Bounderby']], [['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby'], ['Josiah Bounderby']]]

quoteText:
It appears to me, ma'am, I say, that a different sort of establishment
altogether would bring out a lady of _your_ powers.  Such an
establishment as your relation, Lady Scadgers's, now.  Don't you think
you might find some affairs there, ma'am, to interfere with?
subQuotationList:
["It appears to me, ma'am, I say, that a different sort of establishment
altogether would bring out a lady of _your_ powers.  Such an
establishment as your relation, Lady Scadgers's, now.  Don't you think
you might find some affairs there, ma'am, to interfere with?"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby
referringExpression: Mr Bounderby very red and uncomfortable resumed

quoteText:
It never occurred to me before, sir, but now
you mention it, should think it highly probable.
subQuotationList: ['It never occurred to me before, sir,', 'but now\nyou mention it, should think it highly probable.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit

quoteText: Then suppose you try, ma'am,
subQuotationList: ["Then suppose you try, ma'am,"]
speaker: Josiah Bounderby

quoteText:
You can take your own time for
going, ma'am; but perhaps in the meanwhile, it will be more agreeable to
a lady of your powers of mind, to eat her meals by herself, and not to be
intruded upon.  I really ought to apologise to you   being only Josiah
Bounderby of Coketown   for having stood in your light so long. because I can take the opportunity of
saying a word to you, before you go.  Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am, I rather think
you are cramped here, do you know?  It appears to me, that, under my
humble roof, there's hardly opening enough for a lady of your genius in
other people's affairs. and it appears to my poor judgment
subQuotationList:
["You can take your own time for
going, ma'am; but perhaps in the meanwhile, it will be more agreeable to
a lady of your powers of mind, to eat her meals by herself, and not to be
intruded upon.  I really ought to apologise to you   being only Josiah
Bounderby of Coketown   for having stood in your light so long.", "because I can take the opportunity of
saying a word to you, before you go.  Mrs. Sparsit, ma'am, I rather think

quoteText:
Pray don't name it, sir, If that portrait
could speak, sir   but it has the advantage over the original of not
possessing the power of committing itself and disgusting others,   it would
testify, that a long period has elapsed since I first habitually
addressed it as the picture of a Noodle.  Nothing that a Noodle does, can
awaken surprise or indignation; the proceedings of a Noodle can only
inspire contempt.
subQuotationList:
["Pray don't name it, sir,", 'If that portrait
could speak, sir   but it has the advantage over the original of not
possessing the power of committing itself and disgusting others,   it would
testify, that a long period has elapsed since I first habitually
addressed it as the picture of a Noodle.  Nothing that a Noodle does, can
awaken surprise or indignation; the proceedings of a Noodle can only
inspire contempt.']
speaker: Mrs. Sparsit
